questions.text: A 74-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician for evaluation of shortness of breath. Over the past several weeks, the patient has been using three to four pillows to prop herself up to sleep at night. Past medical history includes hypertension, diabetes, hyperlipidemia, and myocardial infarction with stent placement. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 148/82 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 97% on room air. Physical examination demonstrates an additional low frequency heart sound heard just after S2. Which of the following best describes the underlying pathophysiology of this cardiac finding?

choices.text: Age-related calcification of the aortic valve

questions.solution:
This patient presents with cardiac auscultatory findings characteristic of an S3 or ventricular gallop. The finding is most commonly associated with heart failure and increased ventricular filling pressures.   

The third heart sound (S3) is clinically characterized as a low-frequency, brief vibration occurring in early diastole at the end of the rapid diastolic filling period of the right or left ventricle. In other words, this sound is heard immediately after the normal two "lub-dub" heart sounds (S1 and S2). The sound itself occurs as blood oscillates back and forth between the walls of dilated, compliant ventricles and is observed in patients with heart failure. This heart sound is best heard over the cardiac apex with the patient lying in the left lateral decubitus position.  

Option Analysis

✅ Increased ventricular filling pressure:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Ventricular non-compliance :
Incorrect: The S4 gallop, characterized by an extra heart sound heard in late diastole, occurs just after atrial contraction and immediately before the systolic S1 heart sound. This heart sound is reflective of an abnormally stiff or hypertrophic ventricle. In contrast, this patient’s extra heart sound is characteristic of an S3 gallop. 
❌ Untreated Streptococcal throat infection:
Incorrect: Rheumatic heart disease typically results in the development of mitral stenosis. This valvular pathology is characterized by an opening snap followed by a diastolic murmur. In contrast, this patient’s extra heart sound is characteristic of an S3 gallop. 
❌ Age-related calcification of the aortic valve:
Incorrect: Aortic stenosis is most commonly due to age-related calcification of the aortic valve and is characterized by a crescendo-decrescendo systolic ejection murmur and soft S2 heart sound. In contrast, this patient’s extra heart sound is characteristic of an S3 gallop. 
❌ Ventricular septal defect :
Incorrect: Ventricular septal defects are characterized by holosystolic, harsh-sounding murmurs. In contrast, this patient’s extra heart sound is characteristic of an S3 gallop.

questions.text: The process of thyroid hormone synthesis in the thyroid gland yields two types of thyroid hormones, triiodothyronine (T3) and thyroxine (T4). Which of the following is true regarding the differences between these two types?

choices.text: Only T3 bound to thyroxine-binding globulin is the active form of thyroid hormone
T3 binds nuclear receptors with greater affinity than T4
T4 is the highly active form with a half-life of one to two days
Only a tiny amount of T4 will travel unbound in the blood 0.3%
Once inside the cell, T­4 is mainly converted into reverse T3 (rT3) by 5’- deiodinase

questions.solution:
Nearly all of both thyroid hormones (T3 and T4) are carried in blood tightly bound to thyroxine-binding globulin or albumin. T4 is the more abundant compound, constituting 90% of the circulating thyroid hormone. Both molecules bind the same intracellular receptors of target cells, but T3 is 2- to 10-fold more active than T4. The small, unbound (free) fraction (about 0.03% of T4 and 0.3% of T3) is responsible for the biologic activity. Thus, despite the significant difference in total amount, the free fraction of T3 approximates that of T4, and given that T3 is intrinsically more active than T4, most biologic activity is attributed to T3.  The half-life of T3 is one to two days compared to a week for T4. T3 binds nuclear receptors with greater affinity than T4. Both thyroid hormones increase the number and size of mitochondria and stimulate mitochondrial protein synthesis, helping to enhance metabolic activity.  

Option Analysis

❌ Only T3 bound to thyroxine-binding globulin is the active form of thyroid hormone  :
Incorrect: T3 and T4 bound to TBG and other plasma proteins are the biologically inactive form of thyroid hormone.  
✅ T3 binds nuclear receptors with greater affinity than T4  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ T4 is the highly active form with a half-life of one to two days  :
Incorrect: T3 is the highly active form with a half-life of one to two days. T4 is the less active form with a longer half-life of six to eight days.  
❌ Only a tiny amount of T4 will travel unbound in the blood 0.3%  :
Incorrect: Only a small amount of T3 and T4 will travel unbound in the blood–about 0.03% of T4 and 0.3% of T3–and this fraction is biologically active, which means that this is what gets picked up by virtually every cell in the body.  
❌ Once inside the cell, T­4 is mainly converted into reverse T3 (rT3) by 5’- deiodinase  :
Incorrect: Once inside the cell, T­4 is primarily converted into T3 (not reverse T3) by the enzyme 5’- deiodinase. T3 binds to thyroid hormone receptors within the cell’s nucleus, which regulate gene expression. Reverse T3 (rT3) is a metabolically inactive form of thyroid hormone.

questions.text: Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) is a serum biomarker that can be used to determine the presence or absence of pregnancy. Which of the following best describes the main source of hCG during the initial 2 weeks of pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) is a heterodimeric (two different subunits) glycoprotein hormone produced by newly fertilized embryos and subsequently by the placenta. hCG has an α-subunit that is identical to the α-subunit of FSH, LH, and TSH and a unique β-subunit. Syncytiotrophoblasts secrete hCG, which is detectable in blood 1 week after fertilization and on home urine tests 2 weeks after fertilization.

Most of the pregnancy tests utilize a monoclonal antibody to the β-subunit of hCG, thereby avoiding interference from the similar FSH and LH α-subunits. Placental hormone secretion generally increases over the course of pregnancy, but hCG peaks at 8–10 weeks of gestation.  

Option Analysis

✅ Syncytiotrophoblasts:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hypothalamus:
Incorrect: Hypothalamus secretes GnRH which stimulates the release of FSH and LH and acts on the ovaries to produce estrogen and progesterone. It is not the source of hCG.  
❌ Corpus luteum:
Incorrect: Human chorionic gonadotropin is not secreted by the corpus luteum; rather, hCG is required to maintain the function of the corpus luteum and its continued progesterone production.  
❌ Corpus albicans:
Incorrect: The corpus albicans is an ovarian scar composed of connective tissue that forms after the corpus luteum degenerates. It is primarily made of collagen and persists on the ovary for a few months. It does not produce hCG.  
❌ Primordial follicles:
Incorrect: Primordial follicles are inactive follicles and do not produce any hormones.

questions.text: A study on the development of women’s secondary sexual characteristics is done. It was shown that some changes like pubic and axillary hair development is due to a contribution of a hormone that is produced outside the ovaries. This hormone is most likely produced in which of the following locations?

choices.text: Zona reticularis of the adrenal cortex
Zona fasciculata of the adrenal cortex
Zona glomerulosa of the adrenal cortex

questions.solution:
The adrenal glands are a pair of almond-shaped organs that sit on top of the kidneys. They are divided into a cortex and a medulla where each has different functions.  

The adrenal cortex is divided into 3 main parts, and each part produces unique hormones. The outermost layer of the cortex is called the zona glomerulosa and is the site of the production of aldosterone. Aldosterone production is unique because it is not controlled by adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) but by angiotensin II. The middle layer of the cortex is called zona fasciculata and it is the site of the production of cortisol. This is controlled by the pituitary gland under the influence of ACTH.  
Finally, the innermost layer of the cortex is called the zona reticularis and is responsible for the production of androgens and estrogens in males and females. In females, the androgens produced in the zona reticularis are in fact responsible for the development of certain secondary sexual characteristics like axillary and pubic hair. The zona reticularis is also controlled by the pituitary gland through ACTH.  

Option Analysis

✅ Zona reticularis of the adrenal cortex  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Zona fasciculata of the adrenal cortex  :
Incorrect: The zona fasciculata is responsible for the production of cortisol, not androgens.  
❌ Zona glomerulosa of the adrenal cortex  :
Incorrect: The zona glomerulosa of the adrenal cortex is responsible for the production of aldosterone.  
❌ The adrenal medulla  :
Incorrect: The adrenal medulla produces epinephrine and norepinephrine, but does not produce androgens or sex hormones.  
❌ The pituitary gland  :
Incorrect: The pituitary gland is not responsible for the direct production of androgens.

questions.text: A 47-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of shortness of breath. The symptoms developed shortly after he returned from an overseas business trip to Germany. Medical history is notable for hypertension. The patient smokes a pack of cigarettes per day. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 148/89 mmHg, and pulse is 110/min. Physical examination reveals clear, bilateral breath sounds. A D-dimer level returns elevated. Which of the following best characterizes the ventilation, perfusion, and V/Q ratio for the affected regions of this patient’s lungs?
questions.solution:
This patient has chest pain and an elevated D-dimer in the setting of recent long-distance travel, which is suggestive of pulmonary embolism. The blood clot occludes vessels within the lungs, leading to decreased perfusion and a reduced V/Q ratio within affected portions of the lungs.

The V/Q ratio is the ratio of alveolar ventilation (V) to pulmonary blood flow (Q). Ventilation and perfusion matching are essential to achieving optimal gas exchange. Conditions that lead to airway obstruction (e.g., foreign body aspiration, bronchoconstriction) will decrease ventilation of the affected alveoli and lead to an increased V/Q ratio. In contrast, conditions that decrease blood flow (e.g. pulmonary embolism) will decrease perfusion and lead to an increased V/Q ratio.
 

Option Analysis

✅ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ :
Incorrect: This patient most likely has a pulmonary embolism. The condition will reduce blood flow to affected portions of the lung, thereby causing the perfusion to decrease. Since perfusion decreases whereas ventilation remains largely unchanged, the ventilation/perfusion (V/Q) ratio will increase.   
❌ :
Incorrect: This patient most likely has a pulmonary embolism. The condition will reduce blood flow to affected portions of the lung, thereby causing a decrease in perfusion.   
❌ :
Incorrect: Conditions such as foreign body aspiration can lead to decreased ventilation, or gas exchange, within alveoli distal to the obstruction site. As a result, ventilation will decrease, and so will the V/Q ratio. However, this patient’s clinical history is more concerning for pulmonary embolism.   
❌ :
Incorrect: This patient has chest pain and an elevated D-dimer in recent long-distance travel, which is suggestive of pulmonary embolism. The embolus occludes vessels within the lungs, leading to decreased perfusion of affected portions of the lungs.

questions.text: An investigator is studying the transport mechanisms of carbon dioxide (CO<sub>2</sub>) from peripheral tissues to the lungs via the bloodstream. According to his studies, there are multiple ways by which CO<sub>2</sub> is carried to the lungs. Which mechanisms are responsible for transporting most carbon dioxide from the tissues to the lungs via the bloodstream?

choices.text: CO2 In the form of HCO3

questions.solution:
Carbon dioxide (CO2) is the primary waste product produced by tissues and needs to be carried by the bloodstream to the lungs to get expelled from the body. There are three main mechanisms by which CO2 is transported through the blood:

1. Dissolved CO2 in the blood: Dissolved CO2 in the blood is one mechanism by which CO2 is carried to the lungs. However, this mechanism only accounts for around 3-5% of the total CO2 carried by the blood.

2. Bound to hemoglobin: In the peripheral tissues, abundant CO2 diffuses into red blood cells (RBCs) and gets attached to the hemoglobin at N-terminus (a different binding site than oxygen). When the CO2 binds to hemoglobin, it decreases the affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen, thus causing oxygen to be released into the tissues. This phenomenon is termed the Bohr effect and is responsible for increased oxygen release into tissues with high CO2 concentration. This transport mechanism also accounts for a small fraction (3-5%) of the amount of CO2 carried in the blood.

3. In the form of HCO3-: When CO2 is abundant, it diffuses into RBCs. Within RBCs, CO2 reacts with H2O due to the enzyme carbonic anhydrase, which catalyzes this reaction and produces hydrogen bicarbonate (H2CO3). H2CO3 is an unstable molecule that converts to H+ and HCO3-. H+ attaches to hemoglobin, forming H-Hb, while HCO3- is expelled outside the RBC in exchange for chloride (Cl-) ions. This form of transport accounts for most CO2 transported in the bloodstream.  

Option Analysis

✅ CO2 In the form of HCO3:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ CO2 bound to hemoglobin:
Incorrect: Carbaminohemoglobin (CO2 bound to hemoglobin) is one of the ways through which CO2 is transported to the lungs. However, this mechanism is responsible for transporting only a small proportion of CO2 in the blood.  
❌ CO2 dissolved in the blood:
Incorrect: Dissolved CO2 in the blood is one mechanism by which CO2 is carried to the lungs. However, this mechanism only accounts for around 3-5% of the total CO2 carried by the blood.  
❌ CO2 bound to albumin:
Incorrect: CO2 does not bind to albumin. This is not one of the mechanisms of transporting CO2 from the tissues to the lungs via the bloodstream.  
❌ CO2 dissolved in erythrocytes:
Incorrect: CO2 in erythrocytes, CO2 binds to hemoglobin or reacts with H2O to produce H+ and HCO3-.

questions.text: The human body obtains vitamin D either from the diet or from sun exposure. Which of the following changes will enhance the production of an active form of vitamin D?
questions.solution:
Normally, total blood calcium is between 8.5 to 10 mg/dl. If calcium levels drop, more parathyroid hormone (PTH) is released, which increases bone resorption and releases calcium and phosphate ions into the blood. PTH also acts on the kidneys to increase calcium reabsorption in the loop of Henle, the distal convoluted tubule, and collecting ducts, while blocking phosphate reabsorption in the proximal tubule. Furthermore, in renal cells in the proximal tubule, it increases the synthesis of 1-alpha-hydroxylase which converts calcifediol into active vitamin D. Decreased levels of phosphate can also trigger the increased synthesis of 1-alpha-hydroxylase.  

Active vitamin D is then transported through the blood to various tissues. In the bones, vitamin D stimulates the release of cytokines including RANKL and macrophage colony-stimulating factors. These cytokines help form osteoclasts, which breaks down bone and releases calcium and phosphate into the blood.  

In enterocytes, active vitamin D increases calcium and phosphate absorption by stimulating the synthesis of calbindin D-28K, a calcium-binding protein that helps stimulate calcium absorption. It also increases the synthesis of sodium-phosphate cotransporters in enterocytes.  

In the kidneys, active vitamin D in the principal cells of the distal convoluted tubules stimulates the synthesis of calbindin D-28K, allowing more calcium to be reabsorbed from the urine. Whereas in tubular cells of the proximal convoluted tubules, it causes increased synthesis of sodium-phosphate cotransporters on the apical surface, which increases phosphate reabsorption.  

Option Analysis

❌ Increased 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol   :
Incorrect: Increased 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol feedback inhibits its own production.  
✅ Increased parathyroid hormone  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hypercalcemia:
Incorrect: Hypocalcemia (rather than hypercalcemia) enhances the production of 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol by stimulating the release of PTH.
❌ Hyperphosphatemia:
Incorrect: Hypophosphatemia (rather than hypercalcemia) enhances the production of 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol by increasing the synthesis of 1-alpha-hydroxylase.  
❌ Hypernatremia:
Incorrect: Hypernatremia does not regulate active vitamin D production.

questions.text: A patient is hospitalized for recurrent bacterial pneumonia. Several blood samples are taken from the patient, centrifuged, and subsequently analyzed. Which components will only be found in the buffy coat of this patient’s blood sample?
questions.solution:
When blood samples are taken from patients, they are frequently centrifuged to separate them into their major components. Centrifuging blood to divide it into its major components is also used after blood donation. Blood products such as packed red blood cells, platelets, fresh frozen plasma, and others are prepared via this process.  

The red blood cells (erythrocytes) make up about 45% of the blood volume. Hematocrit is used as a surrogate marker for this percentage.  

The buffy coat (typically looks white after centrifugation) makes up less than 1% of the blood volume. It contains platelets (fragments of megakaryocytes) which help form plugs to seal up damaged blood vessels and white blood cells (e.g. granulocytes).  

The plasma makes up about 55% of the blood volume and does not contain cells. Essential electrolytes, gases, hormones, nutrients, proteins, and many molecules are found in the plasma and makeup about 10% of the plasma. The other 90% of the plasma is water.  


Option Analysis

❌ Albumin:
Incorrect: Albumin is a protein found in the blood plasma portion. It helps transport many molecules (including many medications) and plays a key role in maintaining vascular oncotic pressure.  
❌ Erythrocytes:
Incorrect: Erythrocytes make up 45% of the blood and form their layer when a blood sample is centrifuged. Hematocrit is an excellent surrogate marker of this percentage.  
❌ Fibrinogen:
Incorrect: Fibrinogen is a protein found in the blood plasma portion. It helps platelets attach and can become deficient in several clotting disorders (e.g. DIC).  
✅ Granulocytes:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Soluble immunoglobulins  :
Incorrect: Immunoglobulins (antibodies) are proteins found in the plasma portion of blood. Although the white blood cells that secrete antibodies (B-lymphocytes) are found in the buffy coat, secreted immunoglobulins are soluble and go into the plasma.

questions.text: An investigation is done on hemostasis to determine the steps involved in preventing blood loss after injury. During the experiment, the team determines that hemostasis typically has two stages: primary and secondary hemostasis. Which of the following is true regarding primary hemostasis?

choices.text: ADP released from activated platelets binds to P2Y12 receptors on adjacent platelets, causing increased expression of Gp2B/3A.
After an endothelial injury, vasodilation mediated by neural reflex occurs immediately
Adhesion of platelets to the site of injury is mediated by binding to von Willebrand factor (vWF) via GpIIB/IIIA receptors
Calcium released from platelets binds to P2Y12 receptors on adjacent platelets, causing increased expression of Gp2b/3A.
Fibrinogen mediates platelets aggregation via GpIB receptors

questions.solution:
After an injury to a blood vessel, hemostasis occurs to prevent blood loss. Hemostasis is divided into two stages, primary and secondary hemostasis. Primary hemostasis occurs first and results in a platelet plug formation at the site of endothelial injury.  

Primary hemostasis starts immediately after an endothelial injury and is divided into five main stages: endothelial injury, exposure, adhesion, activation, and aggregation. 

Endothelial injury: Primary hemostasis starts when a blood vessel's endothelium is injured. The first thing that happens is vasoconstriction to prevent further blood loss, which is mediated by both neural reflex and endothelin released from damaged endothelial cells.  

Exposure: The injured endothelial cells allow for the exposure of subendothelial collagen,  which binds to the von Willebrand factor (vWF) released from damaged endothelial cells.  

Adhesion: Platelets then bind to the vWF (which is bound to the subendothelial collagen at the site of injury) via GpIB receptors on the platelets, which results in the activation of platelets.  

Activation: Once the platelets bind to VWF and get activated, they undergo a conformational change and release calcium, ADP, and thromboxane A2. Calcium is involved in the secondary hemostasis. ADP binds to the P2Y12 receptors on adjacent platelets and induces the expression of GpIIB/IIIA receptors on the platelets, which mediates the final step of primary hemostasis.  


Aggregation: Finally, after GpIIB/IIIA are expressed on the platelets, fibrinogen binds these receptors and helps aggregate platelets together, forming a platelet plug and marking an end for the primary hemostasis.


Option Analysis

✅ ADP released from activated platelets binds to P2Y12 receptors on adjacent platelets, causing increased expression of Gp2B/3A.   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ After an endothelial injury, vasodilation mediated by neural reflex occurs immediately  :
Incorrect: Immediately after endothelial injury, vasoconstriction is mediated by neural reflex and endothelin. This is the first step in primary hemostasis.  
❌ Adhesion of platelets to the site of injury is mediated by binding to von Willebrand factor (vWF) via GpIIB/IIIA receptors:
Incorrect: vWF binds to the subendothelial collagen exposed after endothelial injury. Then platelets bind to the VWF using GpIB receptors. This is called adhesion.  
❌ Calcium released from platelets binds to P2Y12 receptors on adjacent platelets, causing increased expression of Gp2b/3A.  :
Incorrect: Calcium released from activated platelets aids in secondary hemostasis. In contrast, ADP binds to the P2Y12 receptors on adjacent platelets, resulting in increased expression of Gp2b/3A.  
❌ Fibrinogen mediates platelets aggregation via GpIB receptors  :
Incorrect: Fibrinogen mediates platelet aggregation via GpIIB/3A receptors.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to the physician complaining of joint pain. She tells the physician that she has had pain in the joints of her hands and wrists for the last eight months, in addition to morning stiffness lasting more than an hour. Physical examination reveals swelling, warmth, and deformities in the proximal interphalangeal joints and the wrists. Her serum analysis is positive for rheumatoid factor and anti-citrullinated peptide (anti-CCP). In addition, her C-reactive protein levels are elevated. Which of the following is the primary cytokine responsible for producing and releasing C-reactive protein?
questions.solution:
Interleukins are cytokines that modulate the immune response and inflammation. One of the major proinflammatory cytokines is interleukin-6 (IL-6), secreted by immune cells like macrophages and lymphocytes and non-immune cells like endothelial cells in the damaged or infected tissue.  

The effects of interleukin-2 are widespread and include effects on immune cells, the central nervous system, and the liver. IL-6 helps in the growth and differentiation of B-cells. Also, it is one of the main mediators of fever (which is also mediated by interleukin-1). Finally, IL-6 stimulates the liver to increase the production of acute-phase reactants, which can be used as markers of inflammation. Such acute-phase reactants include C-reactive protein, ferritin, hepcidin, serum amyloid A, fibrinogen, and haptoglobin.  

Option Analysis

✅ Interleukin-6  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Interleukin-10  :
Incorrect: IL-10 is an anti-inflammatory cytokine that attenuates the immune system and inhibits activated macrophages and other immune cells. It does not stimulate the release of acute-phase proteins.  
❌ Interleukin-2  :
Incorrect: IL-2 stimulates the growth and differentiation of lymphocytes and natural killer cells, but it is not involved in stimulating the release of acute phase reactants.  
❌ Interleukin-8  :
Incorrect: IL-8 is released by macrophages and acts as a chemotactic factor for neutrophils to attract them to the site of inflammation. However, it does not stimulate the release of acute-phase reactants.  
❌ Interleukin-1  :
Incorrect: IL-1 is a major proinflammatory cytokine that helps in mediating acute inflammation and also is involved in fever. Although it also increases the synthesis and release of acute-phase reactants, it is not the primary cytokine involved in this process.

questions.text: An inflammatory response is observed to determine the different aspects of it. During the inflammation, blood vessels were noted to dilate and increase their permeability to certain cells. Neutrophils were noted to leave the vessels and aim directly at the site of inflammation. Which of the following molecules help direct and attract neutrophils to the site of inflammation?
questions.solution:
During inflammation, blood vessels dilate and increase their permeability to allow the fluids and immune cells to reach the damaged or infected organ in order to clear the organ from infection and debris. One of the major cells that are involved in inflammation are neutrophils.  

Neutrophils are major cells in acute inflammation, and they are responsible for the phagocytosis of bacteria and other pathogens, as well as dead tissue, and this helps clear the tissue and allow for regeneration and repair. In order for neutrophils to reach the site of inflammation, several factors play a role in directing them. These agents are called neutrophil chemotactic agents. The neutrophil chemotactic agents are C5a, interleukin-8, leukotriene B4 (LTB4), kallikrein, platelet-activating factor, and N-formylmethionine, which is found on bacterial surfaces.  

Option Analysis

❌ Interleukin-6  :
Incorrect: IL-6 is an important mediator of fever and of the acute phase response. IL-6 is not, however, a chemotactic agent for neutrophils.  
❌ C3a:
Incorrect: C3a is an effector of the complement system. However, it is not a chemotactic agent for neutrophils.  
❌ Interleukin-10  :
Incorrect: IL-10 is a cytokine involved in immunoregulation and downregulates the expression of Th1 cytokines. It is not a chemotactic agent for neutrophils  
❌ Interleukin-17  :
Incorrect: IL-17 is involved in inducing and mediating proinflammatory responses and is commonly associated with allergic responses. IL-17 is not a chemotactic agent for neutrophils.  
✅ Interleukin-8  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A medical student is studying the physiology and source of aldosterone. Which of the following is true regarding the effects of aldosterone?

choices.text: Increases reabsorption of sodium and bicarbonate in the proximal convoluted tubules
Inhibits the cotransport system (Na+/K+/2Cl−) of the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle
Increases sodium reabsorption and potassium secretion

questions.solution:
In volume-depleted states formation of angiotensin II (ATII) occurs by activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS). ATII has myriad effects, including the release of aldosterone from the zona glomerulosa cells of the adrenal cortex. Aldosterone is a mineralocorticoid that exerts the following effects:
  
  • Binds to intracellular receptors in principal cells of collecting ducts to stimulate expression of genes, including those coding for the sodium-potassium ATPase pumps. These protein pumps found on the basal surface of these cells establish a concentration gradient that pulls sodium (and water) out of the lumen of the tubule (via ENaC channels) and into the blood while excreting potassium.  
  • Aldosterone increases hydrogen ion secretion from alpha intercalated cells in the distal convoluted tubule by upregulating H+ ATPase activity. 

Option Analysis

❌ Increases reabsorption of hydrogen ions:
Incorrect: Aldosterone increases hydrogen ion secretion from alpha intercalated cells in the distal convoluted tubule by upregulating H+ ATPase activity.  
❌ Only causes water reabsorption:
Incorrect: Isolated water reabsorption is a function of antidiuretic hormone (ADH), which acts on the principal cells of the collecting ducts of nephrons.  
❌ Increases reabsorption of sodium and bicarbonate in the proximal convoluted tubules:
Incorrect: The absorption of sodium and bicarbonate in the proximal convoluted tubules is stimulated by angiotensin II, which upregulates the activity of sodium hydrogen (Na+/H+) exchanger.  
❌ Inhibits the cotransport system (Na+/K+/2Cl−) of the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle:
Incorrect: This cotransport system is inhibited by loop diuretics (e.g. furosemide). Aldosterone does not act on this cotransporter.  
✅ Increases sodium reabsorption and potassium secretion:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A group of researchers is studying the immune response against different types of antigens. In the study, the immune response against a polysaccharide antigen of Leuconostoc mesenteroides bacteria is compared with the response when the same antigen is conjugated with a protein. Which of the following regarding the immune responses in the two cases is true?

choices.text: The conjugated antigen results in a more robust immune response that involves T-cells and B-cells
The polysaccharide-only antigen creates a longer-lasting immune response.
The polysaccharide-only antigen activates both humoral and cellular immunity
The conjugated antigen results in a more robust immune response that only involves B-cells
Both conjugated antigens and polysaccharide-only antigens result in similar immune responses.

questions.solution:
Thymus-independent (TI) antigens are polysaccharides that stimulate B-cells to induce an immune response without stimulating T-cells. These antigens cannot stimulate the T-cells because polysaccharides cannot be presented to T-cells on MHC. Therefore, T-cells cannot stimulate the T-cells because polysaccharides cannot be presented to T-cells on MHC, and thus, T-cells cannot activate.  

On the other hand, thymus-dependent antigens contain a protein component and can be presented to T-cells on MHC, therefore involving activation of the T-cells. This results in a more robust and longer-lasting immune response because the T-cells release cytokines that stimulate class-switching, affinity maturation, and memory B- and T-cell formation.  

Subunit vaccines use a highly immunogenic subunit to produce active immunity against certain microorganisms. Some of these subunits can be polysaccharides, such as the capsular polysaccharide used in vaccines against Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae type B and Neissieria meningitides.   

When the polysaccharide antigen is used alone in the vaccines, it will result in a thymus-independent response, a weaker response that will not last long. Therefore, booster doses and adjuvants are usually required to maintain immunity.  

On the other hand, the capsular polysaccharide can be conjugated with a protein. This results in switching the immune response to a thymus-dependent reaction involving T-cells because the antigen can be presented to T-cells and activate them, causing a much more robust and longer-lasting immune response.  

Option Analysis

✅ The conjugated antigen results in a more robust immune response that involves T-cells and B-cells  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ The polysaccharide-only antigen creates a longer-lasting immune response.  :
Incorrect: Polysaccharide-only antigens are thymus-independent antigens that cannot activate T-cells. This results in a weaker immune response and a shorter one.  
❌ The polysaccharide-only antigen activates both humoral and cellular immunity  :
Incorrect: Polysaccharide-only antigens are thymus-independent antigens and cannot activate T-cells; they only activate B-cells.  
❌ The conjugated antigen results in a more robust immune response that only involves B-cells  :
Incorrect: Conjugation of a polysaccharide antigen results in switching the immune response to a thymus-dependent immune response that involves T-cells and B-cells.  
❌ Both conjugated antigens and polysaccharide-only antigens result in similar immune responses.  :
Incorrect: The polysaccharide antigens are thymus-independent antigens that cannot activate T-cells. Conjugated antigens can activate T-cells and result in thymus-dependent responses that are stronger and longer lasting.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents to the clinic with a pruritic rash on his abdomen for one day. It began as a macular rash that progressed to pruritic papules. This inflammatory process is mediated by which of the following cell types?
questions.solution:
This patient’s skin findings of an itchy, red, papular rash are characteristic of contact dermatitis secondary to possible nickel exposure from his belt, which is a type IV (delayed-type) hypersensitivity reaction.   

Type IV hypersensitivity reaction is initiated by CD8+ T cells (also known as killer T cells or cytotoxic T cells) and CD4+ T cells, also known as helper T cells. The former causes direct lysis of the cells with antigen via perforin and granzymes.  

CD4+ T cells, on the other hand, are only activated when the antigen is presented to them via an antigen-presenting cell or APC (e.g. Langerhans cells). Once bound, a series of events causes CD4+ naive T cells to be differentiated into type 1 helper T (TH1) cells. These cells release the interleukin-2, which helps it and other T cells in the area proliferate, and interferon-gamma, which activates phagocytes like macrophages and creates more TH1 cells. Those activated macrophages release pro-inflammatory cytokines like tumor necrosis factor, interleukin-1, and interleukin-6, which enhance endothelial permeability to allow for more immune cells into the area, all leading to local swelling or edema redness, and warmth as well as systemic symptoms like a fever.   

Option Analysis

✅ T-cells  :
Correct: See Main Explanation  
❌ B-cells  :
Incorrect: Type IV hypersensitivity reaction is different from type I-III hypersensitivity because it does not involve B-cells and related antibody release.  
❌ Neutrophils:
Incorrect: Neutrophils are recruited late in type IV hypersensitivity reaction when the cytokines from activated macrophages cause leakiness in the endothelial barriers.  
❌ Macrophages:
Incorrect: Macrophages are recruited and activated late in type IV hypersensitivity reaction when type 1 helper T cell or a TH1 cell releases interferon-gamma.  
❌ Natural killer cells   :
Incorrect: Natural killer cells are not directly involved in type IV hypersensitivity reaction.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents to a clinic for a wellness examination. During the visit, bilateral patellar reflexes are evaluated by tapping the patellar tendons with a reflex hammer. Which of the following best characterizes the neural pathway responsible for regulating the flexor muscles involved in this reflex?

choices.text: Type Ia sensory neuron → Interneuron → α-motor neuron
Type II sensory neuron → Interneuron → α-motor neuron

questions.solution:
The patellar reflex is an example of a myotatic stretch reflex. The reflex is elicited by tapping against the patellar tendon, which leads to stretching of muscle spindles within the extensor muscles of the thigh (quadriceps). To prevent overstretching, the flexor muscles of the thigh (hamstrings) are inhibited, whereas the extensor muscles (quadriceps) are activated.  

Inhibition of the flexor muscles is mediated via a three-neuron pathway. Signals from the peripheral are transmitted to the spinal cord via type II sensory neurons. The type II sensory neurons then synapse in the anterior horn with interneurons, which send inhibitory signals to the flexor muscles via α-motor neurons.   

In contrast, activation of the extensor muscles is mediated via a two-neurons pathway. Signals from the periphery are transmitted via type Ia sensory neurons. These neurons then stimulate α-motor neurons.  

The end result of extensor muscle contraction and flexor muscle relaxation is knee extension, which helps decrease stretching of the patellar tendon and quadriceps muscle.

 

Option Analysis

❌ Type Ia sensory neuron → Interneuron → α-motor neuron  :
Incorrect: The patellar reflex is caused by stretching of the patellar tendon. Type Ia sensory neurons transmit signals from the stretch receptors to the spinal cord. These neurons then synapse with α-motor neurons to trigger activation of the extensor muscles within the thigh, thereby preventing overstretching.  
❌ Type Ia sensory neuron → α-motor neuron  :
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the neuronal pathway responsible for regulating the extensor muscles involved in the patellar reflex.  
❌ Type 1b sensory neuron → Interneuron → α-motor neuron  :
Incorrect: The patellar reflex is an example of a stretch reflex. Afferent signals are transmitted via type Ia and II neurons, but not via type Ib neurons.  
❌ Type II sensory neuron → α-motor neuron  :
Incorrect: Type II sensory neurons synapse with an interneuron, which then synapses with an α-motor neuron, to regulate the flexor muscles in the patellar reflex.  
✅ Type II sensory neuron → Interneuron → α-motor neuron   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A researcher is evaluating dynamic changes of the kidney during pregnancy. He notes that as the glomerular filtration rate (GFR) increases both the filtration rate and excretion of certain molecules are affected. Which of the following changes in glucose clearance would be expected as a result of these changes?

choices.text: Increased filtered glucose and glucosuria occurs at lower plasma glucose concentrations
Increased filtered glucose and decreased glucose reabsorption in the proximal convoluted tubules
Increased filtered glucose, but all filtered glucose will be reabsorbed in the proximal convoluted tubules

questions.solution:
Glucose is normally filtered by the glomerulus. In the proximal convoluted tubule, sodium-glucose linked transporters (SGLT) reabsorb all filtered glucose into plasma.

Glucose filtration is directly proportional to the plasma concentration of glucose, so if plasma glucose increases, the quantity of filtered glucose increases. Similarly, if the glomerular filtration rate (GFR) increases, the amount of filtered glucose will also increase. This occurs in physiologic states that result in dilation of the afferent arterioles (e.g. pregnancy).

SGLT transporters can reabsorb all filtered glucose until the plasma concentration of glucose reaches 200 g/dL. At a plasma glucose concentration of 375 g/dL, all SGLT channels are saturated, and glucose begins appearing in urine (glucosuria).  


Option Analysis

✅ Increased filtered glucose and glucosuria occurs at lower plasma glucose concentrations:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Increased filtered glucose and decreased glucose reabsorption in the proximal convoluted tubules:
Incorrect: Due to increased glucose filtration, there will be increased reabsorption of glucose in the proximal convoluted tubules.  
❌ No change in glucose filtration:
Incorrect: An increased GFR will cause an increase in the filtration of glucose.  
❌ Decreased glucose filtration:
Incorrect: Increased GFR will cause an increased filtration of glucose.  
❌ Increased filtered glucose, but all filtered glucose will be reabsorbed in the proximal convoluted tubules:
Incorrect: Due to increased glucose filtration, there will be increased reabsorption of glucose in the proximal convoluted tubules.

questions.text: A group of researchers are conducting a study on vitamin K. In the study, they find that vitamin K, once absorbed, enters the liver and participates in a series of reactions that lead to the activation of several clotting factors. Which of the following is true regarding vitamin K?

choices.text: y-glutamyl carboxylase uses the reduced form of vitamin K to activate clotting factors.
The reduced form of vitamin K is converted to the oxidized form using epoxide reductase enzyme.
Vitamin K helps activate the clotting factors of the extrinsic pathway only.
Vitamin K helps activate the clotting factors of the intrinsic pathway only.
Epoxide reductase uses the reduced form of vitamin K to activate clotting factors.

questions.solution:
Vitamin K is a fat soluble vitamin that is obtained from the diet or from bacteria in the gut. Once absorbed, vitamin K enters the liver where it is activated and used in the activation of clotting factors.  

The active form of vitamin K is the reduced form. Once in the reduced form, vitamin K acts as a cofactor to the enzyme y-glutamyl carboxylase in activating the clotting factors II, VII, IX, X, and protein C and S. After this reaction, vitamin K is converted into the oxidized form which is inactive.  

In order to recycle and reuse vitamin K, it must be converted back to the reduced form (active form), which is done by the enzyme epoxide reductase. Epoxide reductase converts the oxidized form of vitamin K to the reduced form, which can be then used again by y-glutamyl carboxylase in the activation of clotting factors. Notably, warfarin is an anticoagulant that inhibits vitamin K epoxide reductase, thereby inhibiting this recycling process.  





Option Analysis

✅ y-glutamyl carboxylase uses the reduced form of vitamin K to activate clotting factors.  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ The reduced form of vitamin K is converted to the oxidized form using epoxide reductase enzyme.  :
Incorrect: The active form of vitamin K is the reduced form, and epoxide reductase converts the oxidized form to the reduced form and, therefore, activates vitamin K.  
❌ Vitamin K helps activate the clotting factors of the extrinsic pathway only.  :
Incorrect: Vitamin K helps in activating factors II, VII, IX, X, as well as protein C and S.  
❌ Vitamin K helps activate the clotting factors of the intrinsic pathway only.  :
Incorrect: Vitamin K helps in activating factors II, VII, IX, X, as well as protein C and S.
❌ Epoxide reductase uses the reduced form of vitamin K to activate clotting factors.   :
Incorrect: The function of epoxide reductase is to convert the oxidized form of vitamin K to the reduced form, where it can be used by the enzyme y-glutamyl carboxylase to activate clotting factors.

questions.text: A 6-day-old female is brought to the pediatrician by her parents for evaluation of jaundice. She was born at 36 weeks gestation to a 29-year-old, gravida 1 para 1, woman via an uncomplicated vaginal delivery. According to her parents, the patient has had difficulty latching to her mother’s breast. The patient has passed meconium and produces 3-4 wet diapers per day. In the office, she is fussy but consolable. Physical examination shows depressed anterior and posterior fontanelles. Scleral icterus and jaundice of the head and chest are observed. Cardiac, pulmonary, and abdominal exams are noncontributory. Which of the following best describes the pathophysiology of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Impaired conjugation of bilirubin in the liver
Extrahepatic fibrosis of the bile ducts
Decreased elimination of bilirubin via feces

questions.solution:
This patient has breastfeeding failure jaundice, also termed starvation jaundice. It typically occurs during the first-week of life and is due to poor breast milk intake. As a result, these babies have inadequate stooling and decreased elimination of bilirubin via feces. Therefore, there is increased enterohepatic circulation, ultimately causing unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. 

Preterm babies are at increased risk of breastfeeding failure jaundice, since they may lack the strength and coordination to properly breastfeed. Patients with this condition can have jaundice, scleral icterus, and kernicterus in severe cases. In addition, the condition is associated with clinical features such as mild dehydration and weight loss in the first few days of life. As such, the patient in this vignette had sunken fontanelles and reduced urine output, both of which are signs of dehydration. Of note, a helpful tip in determining the number of wet diapers in the first week of life is that it is usually equivalent to the number of days since birth (e.g. a 6-day-old infant should produce 6 wet diapers/day).  

Treatment involves preventing dehydration and increasing the frequency and duration of feeds. All of these approaches help promote bilirubin excretion.  

Option Analysis

❌ Increased red blood cell turnover:
Incorrect: Newborns have higher rates of erythrocyte turnover when compared to adults. As a result, more hemoglobin is released and subsequently turned into unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, resulting in physiologic jaundice of the newborn. However, this patient has a history of poor breastfeeding and dehydration, which raises suspicion for breastfeeding failure jaundice.  
❌ Impaired conjugation of bilirubin in the liver:
Incorrect: Impaired conjugation of bilirubin by UDP-glucuronyl transferase can cause physiologic jaundice of the newborn. However, this patient has a history of difficulty breastfeeding and dehydration, which makes breastfeeding failure jaundice a more likely explanation for her symptoms.  
❌ Extrahepatic fibrosis of the bile ducts:
Incorrect: This answer describes biliary atresia, a condition wherein fibrosis results in destruction of the extrahepatic biliary tree. Individuals can have jaundice, dark urine, pale stools, and hepatomegaly. Although this patient has jaundice, she has none of the other symptoms associated with biliary atresia.  
❌ Increased intestinal deconjugation of bilirubin:
Incorrect: This describes the pathophysiology of breast milk jaundice. In this condition, the high levels of glucuronidase in breast milk deconjugates intestinal bilirubin, thereby increasing enterohepatic circulation of unconjugated bilirubin. However, the patient’s history of poor feeding and dehydration makes breastfeeding failure jaundice more likely.  
✅ Decreased elimination of bilirubin via feces:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man presents to the cardiologist for a routine visit. During this visit, the patient is diagnosed with arteriosclerosis. Which of the following best describes the systolic blood pressure, diastolic blood pressure, pulse pressure, and arterial compliance of this patient when compared to those of a healthy individual?
questions.solution:
This patient was diagnosed with arteriosclerosis. The condition is characterized by the hardening of the arterial walls. He will likely have elevated systolic blood pressure, unchanged diastolic blood pressure, elevated pulse pressure, and reduced arterial compliance.

Pulse pressure is defined as the difference between systolic blood pressure (SBP) and diastolic blood pressure (DBP). Pulse pressure is directly proportional to stroke volume and inversely proportional to arterial compliance. An increase in stroke volume means more blood is ejected from the heart, which would result in an increased SBP and pulse pressure. Similarly, a decrease in vascular compliance means the ejected blood is pushing against a stiff vascular wall, which would also increase SBP and pulse pressure.

These physiological parameters can be illustrated via some clinical scenarios. One example is arteriosclerosis, which leads to decreased arterial compliance. SBP will increase whereas DBP, which is determined by total peripheral resistance (provided chiefly by the arterioles), will remain largely unchanged. The end result is an increased pulse pressure. Another example is aortic stenosis. In this condition, narrowing of the aortic valve interferes with the ejection of blood from the left ventricle into the aorta and results in a decreased stroke volume. In turn, SBP and ultimately pulse pressure are decreased.
 

Option Analysis

✅ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ :
Incorrect: Arteriosclerosis will lead to stiff blood vessels that have a difficult time expanding in response to changes in pressure. As a result, arterial compliance, which is defined as the change in volume divided by the change in pressure, will be decreased. Furthermore, diastolic blood pressure will be largely unchanged in patients with arteriosclerosis.   
❌ :
Incorrect: This patient was diagnosed with arteriosclerosis. While patients with arteriosclerosis will have elevated systolic blood pressure and reduced arterial compliance, their diastolic blood pressure will remain largely unchanged. Additionally, patients with arteriosclerosis will have an elevated systolic blood pressure since blood ejected by the heart is now pushing against a stiff vascular wall that has difficulty expanding. The combination of elevated systolic blood pressure and unchanged diastolic blood pressure will in turn result in elevated pulse pressure.   
❌ :
Incorrect: This patient was diagnosed with arteriosclerosis or hardening of the arterial walls. Patients with arteriosclerosis will have elevated systolic blood pressure since blood ejected by the heart is now pushing against a stiff vascular wall that has difficulty expanding. The combination of elevated systolic blood pressure and unchanged diastolic blood pressure will in turn result in elevated pulse pressure.   
❌ :
Incorrect: Arteriosclerosis will lead to stiff blood vessels that have a difficult time expanding in response to changes in pressure. As a result, arterial compliance, which is defined as the change in volume divided by the change in pressure, will be decreased. Furthermore, arteriosclerosis will result in an increased, not decreased, systolic blood pressure.

questions.text: A disease of the heart in elderly patients is being studied by a group of researchers. In the study, it was discovered that the sinoatrial (SA) cells in the SA node become fibrosed and are unable to generate action potentials. Which of the following is expected to happen as a result of this disease?

choices.text: Ectopic pacemaker cells generate the action potentials at a lower firing rate than the SA node
Ectopic pacemaker cells generate the action potentials at a higher firing rate than the SA node
Ectopic pacemaker cells generate the action potentials at the same firing rate than the SA node
Myocytes in the atria and ventricles generate their own action potentials separately
Action potentials cannot be generated spontaneously

questions.solution:
The heart is unique because of its ability to generate its own electrical action potential. This is due to the presence of pacemaker cells which generate action potentials spontaneously and send the impulses to the heart myocytes, therefore contracting the heart.

The main pacemaker cells in the heart are found in the sinoatrial (SA) node located in the right atrium near the opening of the superior vena cava. These cells have the highest firing rate and the shortest action potential duration of all pacemaker cells, allowing them to depolarize very fast after each action potential. The rate of depolarization determines the heart rate. Because of their highest firing rate and shortest action potential, these cells usually take over, generating the action potential in the heart.

However, SA nodal cells are not the only pacemaker cells in the heart, and if they fail, other pacemaker cells found in the heart will take over and start generating action potentials.

The first pacemaker cells that will start generating action potentials if the SA node fails are the pacemaker cells in the atria, and if they fail, the pacemaker cells in the atrioventricular (AV) node take over. Finally, if all of these fail, the pacemaker cells in the Bundle of His and Purkinje fibers will take over and start the action potential generation. These pacemaker cells are called ectopic pacemakers and they allow the automaticity of the heart even if the SA node fails.
 
 

Option Analysis

✅ Ectopic pacemaker cells generate the action potentials at a lower firing rate than the SA node:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Ectopic pacemaker cells generate the action potentials at a higher firing rate than the SA node  :
Incorrect: The pacemaker cells in the SA node have the fastest firing rate. Other pacemaker cells have automaticity and are able to generate action potentials, but at a slower rate than that of the SA node.  
❌ Ectopic pacemaker cells generate the action potentials at the same firing rate than the SA node  :
Incorrect: The pacemaker cells in the SA node have the fastest firing rate. Other pacemaker cells have automaticity and are able to generate action potentials, but at a slower rate than that of the SA node.  
❌ Myocytes in the atria and ventricles generate their own action potentials separately:
Incorrect: Although the main pacemaker cells are the SA node, other pacemaker cells are able to generate action potentials if the SA node fails, which ensures that the heart keeps contracting at an appropriate rate and in synchronization between the right and left atria and ventricles.  
❌ Action potentials cannot be generated spontaneously:
Incorrect: The SA node is the main pacemaker of the heart but is not the only group of pacemaker cells. Other pacemaker cells in the heart are able to take over and generate action potentials should the SA node fail.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man is involved in a motor vehicle accident and sustains massive blood loss. His initial blood pressure is steady at 100/70 mm Hg, but the trauma team is concerned about developing shock. Which of the following pathways is involved in the afferent limb of the physiologic response maintaining this patient's blood pressure?

choices.text: The aortic arch transmits via the vagus nerve to the midbrain
The aortic body transmits via the vagus nerve to the medulla
The carotid body transmits via the glossopharyngeal nerve to the medulla
Carotid sinus transmits via the glossopharyngeal nerve to the medulla
Carotid sinus transmits via the vagus nerve to the medulla

questions.solution:
The primary means by which the body deals with volume loss in the short term is via the arterial baroreflex. The body responds to short-term changes in blood pressure via the arterial baroreflex to maintain mean arterial pressure between 85 and 100 mm Hg. The decreased pressure causes the walls of the aortic arch and carotid sinus to become less stretched, and the baroreceptors start firing less frequently. The glossopharyngeal and vagus nerve carries that decreased signal to the cardiovascular centers of the brainstem (nucleus tractus solitarius in the medulla). These centers stimulate the sympathetic and inhibit the parasympathetic nervous systems from bringing the pressure back up to normal. Specifically, the vasomotor center increases the vasoconstrictive effect of the sympathetic nervous system, causing the arterioles to narrow, increasing the total peripheral arterial resistance and constriction of veins. This increases more blood return to the heart. Increased venous return means more preload, which also increases cardiac output.  Meanwhile, the cardiac accelerator center in the medulla is also stimulated, increasing the heart rate and contractility. In contrast, the cardiac decelerator center is deactivated, reducing the parasympathetic effects on the heart, which speeds up the heart rate. Combined, these effects result in an increased cardiac output (CO) and an increase in total peripheral resistance (TPR) which raises the blood pressure (BP) back to normal. In this case, these changes are essential in responding to severe hemorrhage.  


Option Analysis

❌ The aortic arch transmits via the vagus nerve to the midbrain:
Incorrect: There are minor contributors to the arterial baroreflex in the aortic arch that transmit via the vagus nerve, but they synapse at the nucleus tractus solitarius in the medulla, not the midbrain. Thus, this answer is incorrect.  
❌ The aortic body transmits via the vagus nerve to the medulla:
Incorrect: This answer is wrong because the aortic body is a chemoreceptor, not a baroreceptor. It will respond to a decreased PO2 (less than 60 mm Hg), increased PCO2, or decreased blood pH. These conditions may develop in this patient, but the dominant physiological stressor in this patient is hypovolemia.  
❌ The carotid body transmits via the glossopharyngeal nerve to the medulla:
Incorrect: Carotid bodies are chemoreceptors, not baroreceptors, and respond to hypoxemia, hypercapnia, and academia. The baroreflex maintains blood pressure in the acute situation described in the stem.  
✅ Carotid sinus transmits via the glossopharyngeal nerve to the medulla:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Carotid sinus transmits via the vagus nerve to the medulla:
Incorrect: The baroreflex afferent limb consists of transmission from the carotid sinus  baroreceptors to the medulla via the glossopharyngeal nerve, not the vagus. The vagus is involved in the afferent limb from the aortic arch baroreceptors, not the carotid sinus baroreceptors. Thus, this answer is incorrect.

questions.text: An experiment is carried out on the adrenal cortex of mice to determine the enzymes involved in the synthesis of adrenocortical hormones. In the experiment, an enzyme called 11-B hydroxylase was inhibited in the zona glomerulosa of the adrenal cortex. Which of the following steps is most likely to be disrupted as a result of this?
questions.solution:
The adrenal cortex is responsible for the production of adrenocortical hormones, which include aldosterone, cortisol, androgens, and estrogens. Although the synthesis of these hormones take different paths in different areas in the adrenal cortex, they all start with a common precursor, which is cholesterol.  

Under the influence of adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) produced by the pituitary gland, the adrenal cortex takes cholesterol from the blood. The same hormone mediates the conversion of cholesterol to pregnenolone by the enzyme cholesterol desmolase. Pregnenolone is then taken by the different zones in the adrenal cortex and used to synthesize adrenocortical hormones.  

Zona glomerulosa  
In the zona glomerulosa, pregnenolone is taken and converted into progesterone by the enzyme 3-β hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase (3β-HSD). Progesterone is then converted to 11- deoxycorticosterone by the enzyme 21-hydroxylase. This is followed by the conversion of 11- deoxycorticosterone to corticosterone by 11β-hydroxylase enzyme. Finally, corticosterone is converted into aldosterone by the enzyme aldosterone synthase, which is controlled by angiotensin II.  


Zona Fasciculata  
The zona fasciculata takes pregnenolone and progesterone and they are converted into 17-hydroxypregnenolone and 17-hydroxyprogesterone respectively, by the enzyme 17-α hydroxylase. Then the 17-hydroxypregnenolone is converted into 17-hydroxyprogesterone by the enzyme 3β-HSD. 17-hydroxyprogesterone is converted to 11-deoxycortisol by 21-hydroxylase enzyme, which is then converted to cortisol by 11-β hydroxylase enzyme.  


Zona reticularis  
In the zona reticularis, 17-hydroxypregnenolone and 17-hydroxyprogesterone are taken from the zona fasciculata and converted by the enzyme 17,20-lyase into dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA) and androstenedione respectively. Androstenedione is converted to testosterone by the enzyme 11-β HSD. On the other hand, DHEA can be converted to androstenedione by the enzyme 3β-HSD which is then converted to testosterone, or alternatively can be converted to androstenediol by 11-β HSD and then to testosterone by 3β-HSD.  Finally, testosterone is converted by the enzyme aromatase to estradiol or estrogen.  



Option Analysis

✅ Conversion of 11-deoxycorticosterone to corticosterone.  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Conversion of corticosterone to aldosterone  :
Incorrect: The Conversion of corticosterone to aldosterone is metabolized by the enzyme aldosterone synthase, which is stimulated by angiotensin II.  
❌ Conversion of progesterone to 11-deoxycorticosterone  :
Incorrect: The conversion of progesterone to 11-deoxycorticosterone is done by the enzyme 21-β hydroxylase, not 11β-hydroxylase.  
❌ Conversion of 11-deoxycortisol to cortisol   :
Incorrect: Although 11β-hydroxylase is responsible for the conversion of 11-deoxycortisol to cortisol, this step is part of the production of cortisol which takes place in the zona fasciculata, not zona glomerulosa.  
❌ Conversion of progesterone to 17-hydroxyprogesterone  :
Incorrect: The conversion of progesterone to 17-hydroxyprogesterone is mediated by the enzyme 17-a hydroxylase, not 11β-hydroxylase.

questions.text: A group of researchers are studying the functions and regulation of the parathyroid hormone (PTH). Which of the following metabolic changes will have a stimulatory effect on the release of PTH?
questions.solution:
In addition to hypocalcemia, parathyroid hormone (PTH) secretion from the parathyroid chief cells is also stimulated by hyperphosphatemia. The increased serum phosphate binds the serum calcium, leading to reduced stimulation of calcium-sensing receptors in the parathyroid gland. This stimulates the release of PTH.  

PTH increases bone resorption and releases calcium and phosphate ions into the blood. It also acts on the kidneys to increase calcium reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubule, while blocking phosphate reabsorption in the proximal tubule, thereby leading to increased phosphate excretion via the kidneys. Moreover, it increases the synthesis of 1-alpha-hydroxylase which converts calcifediol into calcitriol (active vitamin D), which increases blood calcium (Ca2+) mainly by increasing the uptake of calcium from the intestines.  

Option Analysis

❌ Hyperkalemia:
Incorrect: Hyperkalemia has no direct effect on PTH secretion.  
✅ Hyperphosphatemia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hypernatremia:
Incorrect: Hypernatremia has no direct effect on PTH secretion.  
❌ Hypercalcemia:
Incorrect: An increase in serum calcium would inhibit the release of PTH from parathyroid glands.  
❌ Hypermagnesemia:
Incorrect: Hypomagnesemia, rather than hypermagnesemia, regulates the release of PTH levels depending on the reduction in serum magnesium levels. Moderate hypomagnesemia promotes the action of PTH on kidneys to improve magnesium reabsorption, whereas severe hypomagnesemia leads to the inhibition of PTH release.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman comes to the physician to evaluate chest and abdominal pain, typically after eating large meals. Biochemical testing reveals markedly elevated gastrin levels. In addition to increased gastric acid secretion, which of the following is also expected to happen in this patient due to increased gastrin levels?

choices.text: Decreased bicarbonate secretion in the small intestine

questions.solution:
Gastrin is a polypeptide hormone secreted by the G-cells, which are mainly in the pyloric antrum of the stomach but can also be found in the small intestines and pancreas. Gastrin’s primary functions are in the gastrointestinal tract.  

Gastrin is responsible for increasing gastric acid secretions, both directly and indirectly. It does this directly by binding to cholecystokinin B (CCKB) receptors on parietal cells, enhancing the activity of the H+/K+ ATPase pumps and ultimately increasing acid secretion into the gastric lumen. It also does this indirectly by stimulating enterochromaffin-like cells (ECL) to produce histamine, which then promotes acid secretion.  

In addition, gastrin also has other functions, such as increasing gastric motility and stimulating the growth and proliferation of gastric mucosa.  

Gastrin secretion is increased by vagal stimulation (through gastrin-releasing peptide (GRP)), stomach distention, increased pH of the stomach, and the presence of amino acids in the stomach. In contrast, the secretion of gastrin is inhibited by low stomach pH via negative feedback.  

Option Analysis

✅ Proliferation of gastric mucosa  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Decreased gastric motility:
Incorrect: Gastrin increases gastric motility.
❌ Decreased bicarbonate secretion in the small intestine  :
Incorrect: Gastrin increases gastric acid secretion, which is expected to cause increases in the bicarbonate secretion in the small intestine to help neutralize the incoming gastric acid.  
❌ Increased appetite  :
Incorrect: Gastrin does not affect appetite.  
❌ Decreased histamine secretion  :
Incorrect: Gastrin directly stimulates enterochromaffin-like cells in the stomach to secrete histamine to maximize gastric acid secretion.

questions.text: Research is done to study the origins of hematological cells. It was found that all these cells are produced in the bone marrow. A cell known as CD34+ stem cell is responsible for the production of hematopoiesis and the production of all blood cells including erythrocytes and leukocytes. Which of the following is correct about myeloid and lymphoid cells?

choices.text: All immune cells differentiate from myeloid stem cells
Myeloid cells are produced in the bone marrow, while lymphoid cells are produced in peripheral tissues
Macrophages are granulocytes that originate from myeloblasts
All innate immune cells are myeloid cells
Natural killer cells differentiate from lymphoid stem cells

questions.solution:
Hematological cells (erythrocytes, leukocytes, platelets) are all produced in the bone marrow and they all originate from the same stem cell called multipotent CD34+ stem cell. The multipotent stem cell then differentiates into either myeloid stem cell or lymphoid stem cell, and each then produces different types of hematological cells.  

Myeloid stem cells differentiate into 4 types of other stem cells which each produce different cells. The first type of stem cell is the erythroblasts, which produce erythrocytes. The second is the megakaryoblasts, which produce platelets. The third type is the myeloblasts. The myeloblasts are responsible for producing granulocytes, which are eosinophils, basophils, mast cells, and neutrophils. These cells are called granulocytes due to the fact that they contain granules in their cytoplasm. Finally, the fourth type is the monoblasts, which produce monocytes that can stay in the blood or go into tissues and become macrophages and dendritic cells.  

On the other hand, the lymphoblasts or lymphoid progenitor cells produce 3 types of cells. These are the T-cells, B-cells, and natural killer cells.  


Option Analysis

❌ All immune cells differentiate from myeloid stem cells  :
Incorrect: Granulocytes, as well as monocytes, mast cells, and dendritic cells, all originate from the myeloid stem cells. However, natural killer cells and lymphocytes differentiate from the lymphoid progenitor cells.  
❌ Myeloid cells are produced in the bone marrow, while lymphoid cells are produced in peripheral tissues:
Incorrect: Both myeloid and lymphoid cells are produced in the bone marrow.  
❌ Macrophages are granulocytes that originate from myeloblasts  :
Incorrect: Macrophages originate from myeloid stem cells which differentiate into monoblasts. Monoblasts then give rise to macrophages in the peripheral tissues or monocytes in the blood.  
❌ All innate immune cells are myeloid cells  :
Incorrect: Although most innate immune cells are myeloid cells, natural killer cells are part of the innate immune system but are lymphoid cells.  
✅ Natural killer cells differentiate from lymphoid stem cells  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A CD4+ and CD8+ double-positive T-cell are present within the thymic cortex. It binds successfully with MHC I molecules expressed by cortical epithelial cells and travels to the thymic medulla. Which of the following stages in T-cell development did this cell just complete?
questions.solution:
T-cells undergo positive and negative selection in the thymus as part of the maturation process.  

After arriving in the thymus, T-cells will begin expressing CD4 and CD8 surface receptors. They also undergo VDJ recombination to produce a T-cell receptor. Afterward, each T-cell undergoes positive selection in the thymic cortex, which involves testing the ability of the T-cell to bind with MHC I and II receptors on the surface of thymic cortex cells. T-cells that have an MHC affinity and can serve useful functions in the body are allowed to survive and undergo negative selection. In contrast, T-cells that fail to bind with MHC receptors will undergo apoptosis.  

The next step involves negative selection, which helps ensure the thymus is not producing self-reactive T-cells. This stage occurs in the thymic medulla, which expresses the AIRE gene and enables the cells to express antigens generally found in other body organs (e.g., bones, ovaries, pancreas). It essentially allows the thymus to serve as a microcosm of the entire body. T-cells that bind self-antigens undergo apoptosis. Those who do not bind will survive, mature, and downregulate CD4 or CD8 receptors to become a single positive T-cell.  

Option Analysis

❌ VDJ rearrangement  :
Incorrect: VDJ rearrangement is a process of somatic recombination that occurs during the early stages of T and B-cell development. This process enables the body to generate various antibodies and T-cell receptors. However, the process of VDJ recombination would not entail T-cells binding with MHC molecules in the thymus.  
❌ Self-tolerance  :
Incorrect: Self-tolerance is when the body’s immune system does not attack antigens expressed by its organs. The negative selection process, when T-cells that bind to self-antigens presented by MHC molecules on thymic medullary cells, will undergo apoptosis, help preserve self-tolerance. In contrast, the process described in this question stem is more consistent with positive selection.  
❌ Autocrine stimulation  :
Incorrect: Autocrine stimulation is when a cell secretes a chemical messenger (e.g., cytokine, hormone) that binds to receptors on the same cell. For instance, during T-cell activation, T-cells release IL-2, which subsequently binds to IL-2 receptors on the same cell. In contrast, the process described in this question stem is more consistent with positive selection.
✅ Positive selection  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Negative selection  :
Incorrect: Negative selection is when T-cells that bind to self-antigens presented by MHC molecules on thymic medullary cells will undergo apoptosis. This process ensures the self-tolerance of the immune system. In contrast, the developing T-cell in this vignette underwent further maturation after successfully binding with an MHC I molecule,  which is more consistent with positive selection.

questions.text: A researcher is investigating the effects of angiotensin II on the human body. Which of the following is true regarding the effects of angiotensin II?

choices.text: Stimulates the secretion of oxytocin from the posterior pituitary gland
Stimulates the activity of sodium/hydrogen ATPase in the proximal convoluted tubule

questions.solution:
The renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) is one of the mechanisms by which the cardiovascular system and kidneys attempt to maintain normal arterial blood pressure by controlling blood volume. Angiotensin II (ATII) has the following effects:

  • Vasoconstriction: ATII stimulates ATII receptors to type I on arteriolar smooth muscle to cause vasoconstriction. 
  • Constriction of efferent arterioles: ATII preferentially constricts efferent arterioles more than afferent arterioles to preserve glomerular filtration rate (GFR) in volume-depleted states. However, chronically high levels of ATII can cause constriction of both, leading to a decline in GFR.
  • Increased Na+/H+ exchanger activity in proximal convoluted tubule (PCT): ATII stimulates the reabsorption of sodium ions and water by stimulating PCT cells. 
  • Stimulation of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) secretion from the posterior pituitary gland: ADH acts on the principal cells of the collecting ducts in nephrons to reabsorb water via increased expression of aquaporins on the luminal surface of these cells. 
  • Stimulation of thirst: ATII acts directly on the hypothalamus to stimulate thirst to improve volume status. 
  • Stimulation of aldosterone secretion: ATII stimulates aldosterone from zona glomerulosa of the adrenal cortex, which increases hydrogen ion secretion from alpha intercalated cells in the distal convoluted tubule. Aldosterone also acts on the principal cells of the collecting ducts, where it causes increased sodium reabsorption and potassium secretion. 

Option Analysis

❌ Stimulates the secretion of oxytocin from the posterior pituitary gland:
Incorrect: Angiotensin II stimulates the secretion of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) from the posterior pituitary gland, which then acts on the principal cells of the collecting ducts of nephrons to reabsorb water.  
❌ Inhibits the secretion of aldosterone:
Incorrect: Angiotensin II stimulates (not inhibits) the secretion of aldosterone from the zona glomerulosa of the adrenal cortex, which increases hydrogen ion secretion from alpha intercalated cells in the distal convoluted tubule. Aldosterone also acts on the principal cells of the collecting ducts, where it causes increased sodium reabsorption and potassium secretion.  
✅ Stimulates the activity of sodium/hydrogen ATPase in the proximal convoluted tubule:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Inhibits arteriolar smooth muscle contraction:
Incorrect: Angiotensin II stimulates, not inhibits, arteriolar smooth muscle contraction.  
❌ Constricts peritubular capillaries:
Incorrect: Angiotensin II  improves the glomerular filtration rate in volume-depleted states by preferentially constricting efferent arterioles more than afferent arterioles. It does not affect peritubular capillaries.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man is working in a warehouse and lifts a heavy carton of apples. There is shortening of the biceps brachii, which activates the golgi tendon organs within the muscle. Which of the following best describes the neuronal pathway via which signals from the golgi tendon organs help prevent biceps over-contraction?

choices.text: Type Ib sensory neuron → Inhibitory interneuron → α-motor neuron
Type II sensory neuron → Inhibitory interneuron → α-motor neuron
Type Ia sensory neuron → Inhibitory interneuron → α-motor neuron

questions.solution:
The golgi tendon reflex prevents damage to muscles secondary to over-contraction.  

The reflex is facilitated by golgi tendon organs, which are proprioceptors found in the tendons. When the golgi tendon organs of a muscle are compressed, they fire more action potentials. These action potentials travel through type Ib afferent fibers to the spinal cord.    

Within the posterior horn of the spinal cord, they synapse with inhibitory interneurons, which in turn, synapse with α-motor neurons of the contracting muscle.    

At the same time, type Ib afferent neurons also synapse with stimulatory interneurons that synapse with α-motor neurons innervating the antagonist muscles.    

The net result is relaxation of the flexed muscle and contraction of the antagonist muscles, thereby preventing the flexed muscles from being damaged through over-contraction  

Option Analysis

✅ Type Ib sensory neuron → Inhibitory interneuron → α-motor neuron   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Type Ib sensory neuron → α-motor neuron  :
Incorrect: The golgi tendon reflex prevents muscle over-contraction and damage. In this reflex arc, signals from the golgi tendon organs are transmitted via type Ib sensory neurons to the spinal cord. In the spinal cord, the sensory neurons synapse with an inhibitory interneuron, which then relays signals back to the muscles via α-motor neurons.  
❌ Type II sensory neuron → Inhibitory interneuron → α-motor neuron  :
Incorrect: The golgi tendon reflex prevents muscle over-contraction and damage. In this reflex arc, signals from the golgi tendon organs are transmitted via type Ib sensory neurons, not type II sensory neurons.  
❌ Type II sensory neuron → α-motor neuron  :
Incorrect: The golgi tendon reflex prevents muscle over-contraction and damage. In this reflex arc, signals from the golgi tendon organs are transmitted via type Ib sensory neurons, not type II sensory neurons. Moreover, this reflex arc involves an inhibitory interneuron.  
❌ Type Ia sensory neuron → Inhibitory interneuron → α-motor neuron  :
Incorrect: The golgi tendon reflex prevents muscle over-contraction and damage. In this reflex arc, signals from the golgi tendon organs are transmitted via type Ib sensory neurons, not type Ia sensory neurons.

questions.text: A pathologist examines a segment of the testes to determine the cells' functions. One cell was identified lining the seminiferous tubules near the basolateral membrane. These cells secrete a hormone called inhibin that decreases the production of follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) from the anterior pituitary. Which of the following is an additional function?
questions.solution:
Sertoli cells are essential cells in the testes and have many functions. Sertoli cells are non-germ cells found in the testes' seminiferous tubules. These cells are mainly located on the basolateral side of the tubules.

First, during the intrauterine period, Sertoli cells secrete Mullerian inhibitory factor (MIF), which prevents the development of the female reproductive organs. Sertoli cells are also crucial in developing sperms by providing nutrients and regulating the environment in the seminiferous tubules. Additionally, Sertoli cells maintain a high amount of testosterone in the seminiferous tubules, which is needed to develop sperms. This is done by secreting androgen binding peptide (ABP), which captures the testosterone secreted by Leydig cells and allows more testosterone to enter the seminiferous tubules.

Follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) stimulates the sertoli cells to secrete ABP. Sertoli cells regulate the secretion of FSH from the anterior pituitary by secreting a hormone called inhibin, which acts as a feedback inhibitor on FSH secretion. Finally, Sertoli cells protect the spermatozoa from autoimmune attacks. This is done by forming tight junctions between the Sertoli cells, creating the blood-testis barrier, which prevents the immune cells from attacking and surveilling the developing spermatozoa.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Formation of the blood-testis-barrier:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Production of testosterone:
