Incorrect: Testosterone is produced by the Leydig cells, not Sertoli cells. Leydig cells are found in the interstitial space outside the seminiferous tubules.  
❌ Feedback inhibition of luteinizing hormone (LH)  :
Incorrect: Testosterone produced by Leydig cells is responsible for the feedback inhibition of LH, whereas Sertoli cells produce inhibin that is responsible for the feedback inhibition of FSH.  
❌ Production of primary spermatocyte:
Incorrect: Spermatogonia are the germ cells that produce primary spermatocytes, which then continue to develop into sperm. Sertoli cells are non-germ cells.  
❌ Maintenance of germ cell pool:
Incorrect: Spermatogonia are the germ cells that maintain the germ cell pool. Sertoli cells are non-germ cells.

questions.text: A study is conducted on a peripheral neuromuscular disease. In the study, the disease was found to occur secondary to autoimmune destruction of neuromuscular junction motor end-plate receptors. Which of the following is true regarding the type of these receptors and their associated signaling molecule?
questions.solution:
Contractions of skeletal muscle fibers are controlled by the motor nerves, and the lower motor nerves supply muscle fibers at the neuromuscular junction (NMJ). Three structures are found in the NMJ: the axon nerve terminals of the lower motor neurons, the synaptic cleft, and the postsynaptic membrane of the skeletal muscle fiber (i.e. the motor end plate).

When action potentials reach the axon terminal, depolarization results in the release of acetylcholine into the synaptic cleft, which then acts on the nicotinic receptors in the motor end plate, resulting in the propagation of action potentials to the muscle fibers, resulting in muscle contraction.  
 

Option Analysis

✅ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ :
Incorrect: The motor end plate receptors are nicotinic receptors, not cholinergic receptors.   
❌ :
Incorrect: Acetylcholine is the signaling molecule for the nicotinic receptor in the motor end plate, not epinephrine.   
❌ :
Incorrect: The motor end plate receptors are nicotinic receptors, and the signaling molecule for these receptors is acetylcholine.   
❌ :
Incorrect: The receptors in the motor end plate are nicotinic receptors.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman requires a blood transfusion before elective surgery. Her blood type is found to be O negative. This patient can receive blood from which of the following type(s) of blood donors?

choices.text: Type A, B, AB, and O negative

questions.solution:
Every person has a unique blood group based on two classification systems: the ABO system and the Rh system. An individual is either Rh-positive, meaning they have the antigen on their red blood cells (and therefore, do not produce antibodies against it), or Rh-negative (and therefore, produces antibodies against it), meaning it is absent. The most significant Rh antigen is the D antigen.  

Rh-positive people can receive both Rh-negative and Rh-positive blood since they do not have antibodies against the Rh glycoprotein. But if an Rh-negative person receives Rh-positive blood, they could develop a hemolytic transfusion reaction. That's why hospitals do not typically give Rh-positive blood to Rh-negative patients. It can be done in an emergency because these individuals don't have naturally occurring Rh antibodies since they require exposure to Rh-positive RBCs (prior blood transfusion recipient or pregnant women carrying a fetus with Rh-positive blood). So, for someone who doesn’t have Rh antibodies, Rh-positive blood might be okay the first time, but then they'll develop antibodies and won't be able to receive Rh-positive blood in the future.  


Option Analysis

❌ Type AB positive  :
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. Type O negative blood group has A, AB, and Rh antibodies and can cause a hemolytic transfusion reaction, and type AB positive blood is transfused.  
❌ Type A, B, AB, and O negative   :
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect.  Type O negative blood group has A, AB, and Rh antibodies and can cause a hemolytic transfusion reaction after reacting with A and B antigens in type A, B AB blood.  
✅ Type O negative  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Type A and B positive  :
Incorrect:  This answer choice is incorrect. Type O negative blood group has A, AB, and Rh antibodies and can cause a hemolytic transfusion reaction after reacting with A and B antigens in type A and B blood.  
❌ Type O positive  :
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. Type O negative blood group has A, AB, and Rh antibodies and can cause a hemolytic transfusion reaction after reacting with Rh antigen in O-positive blood.

questions.text: A graduate student is conducting an experiment on a mouse. Using an echocardiogram, he is able to determine the percentage of the blood the left ventricle is pumping out with each contraction. This is the definition of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ejection fraction (EF) is a measurement, expressed as a percentage, of how much blood the left ventricle pumps out with each contraction. Mathematically, it is expressed as stroke volume over end-diastolic volume.

        EF = SV/EDV = EDV - ESV/EDV

A normal EF is usually between 50-70 percent. When examined using an echocardiogram, a significant number of patients with heart failure are found to have normal ventricular ejection fractions. This condition, which was previously called diastolic heart failure, is now referred to as heart failure with preserved ejection fractions. Patients with an EF of <40% are considered to have heart failure with reduced ejection fraction.  

Option Analysis

❌ Stroke volume  :
Incorrect: Stroke volume is the amount of blood pumped by the left ventricle of the heart in one contraction. Mathematically, it is the difference between the end-diastolic volume and the end-systolic volume. It can not be expressed as a percentage.  
✅ Ejection fraction:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ ​Cardiac output  :
Incorrect: Cardiac output is the amount of blood the heart pumps through the circulatory system in a minute. Mathematically, it is a product of stroke volume and heart rate.  
❌ Pulse pressure  :
Incorrect: Pulse pressure is the difference between systolic and diastolic blood pressures. A change in pulse pressure is proportional to a change in stroke volume but inversely proportional to arterial compliance.  
❌ Mean arterial pressure  :
Incorrect: Mean arterial pressure (MAP) is the average arterial pressure throughout one cardiac cycle, systole, and diastole. Mathematically, it is a product of cardiac output and total peripheral resistance.

questions.text: A scientist is studying the effect of different pathologic processes on cardiac preload. An increase in preload will be observed in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Cardiac preload is defined as the ventricular wall stress at the end of diastole. Mathematically, it can be expressed by the Law of Laplace, which states that:

                        Wall stress = pressure (P) x radius (R) / 2 x wall thickness (W)

Since it is cumbersome to measure these values in vivo, a surrogate for cardiac preload used clinically is a left-ventricular end-diastolic volume (LVEDV), which can be easily measured using an echocardiogram. LVEDV is affected by five factors, which are as follows:
 
  1.  Venous pressure and rate of venous return (VR): Decreased VR (e.g. hypovolemic states like dehydration or hemorrhage) decreases preload, whereas increased VR (e.g. hypervolemic conditions like early pregnancy) increases VR. 
  2.  Atrial contraction: Loss of atrial contraction (e.g. in atrial arrhythmias such as atrial fibrillation and atrial flutter) decreases LVEDV, resulting in reduced preload. 
  3.  Resistance from valves: Valvular abnormalities that cause decreased LVEDV (e.g. mitral stenosis) result in reduced preload, whereas those that increase LVEDV (e.g. aortic or pulmonary stenosis) increase preload. 
  4.  Ventricular compliance: Compliant, stretchy ventricles, such as that seen in dilated cardiomyopathy, increases preload, while non-compliant, stiff ventricles, such as that seen in ventricular hypertrophy, decrease preload. 
  5.  Heart rate: Normal heart rate allows adequate time for ventricles to fill, while tachycardia reduces the filling time, ultimately decreasing preload. 
Of note, cardiac preload is one of the main factors influencing how much blood the heart pumps out with each heartbeat (stroke volume). An increase in preload causes an increase in stroke volume.  

Option Analysis

❌ Mitral stenosis  :
Incorrect: Inflow resistance created by the narrowing of the atrioventricular valve, such as mitral stenosis and tricuspid stenosis, results in decreased filling of the ventricles and, therefore, reduced preload.  
❌ Dehydration:
Incorrect: Decrease in circulating blood volume (hypovolemia) in the context of dehydration leads to decreased end-diastolic volume and, therefore, reduced preload.  
❌ Loss of atrial contraction:
Incorrect: Loss of atrial contraction, common in atrial arrhythmias (e.g., atrial fibrillation, atrial flutter), decreases the volume of blood that enters the ventricle, ultimately causing a decrease in end-diastolic volume and preload.  
✅ Dilated cardiomyopathy  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Sinus tachycardia:
Incorrect: Sinus tachycardia reduces the ventricular filling time, ultimately decreasing preload.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man comes to the clinic for a routine visit. The patient currently has no complaints and came for medication refills. He has a past medical history of hypertension diagnosed 30 years ago. He has not been using his medications in the past several years but recently started taking them as prescribed after a family member died of a heart attack. The patient’s medications include amlodipine and losartan. Cardiac auscultation reveals an abnormal heart sound just before S1. Which of the following electrocardiographic findings are most likely to be seen in this patient?

choices.text: P-wave in lead V1 and V2 over 1.5 mm
Bifid P-wave in lead II with a gap of over 40 ms separating the two peaks
Dominant R wave in V1 with R/S ratio > 1
Right axis deviation with an axis of 115 degrees
Deep S wave in lead V1 and tall R wave in lead V6

questions.solution:
This patient with chronic hypertension and medication noncompliance, together with auscultation revealing an S4 (abnormal heart sound just before S1), has most likely developed left ventricular hypertrophy. Electrocardiogram (ECG) of such patients reveals a deep S-wave in lead V1 and a tall R-wave in lead V6.

The most commonly used voltage criteria to identify left ventricular hypertrophy is that adding up the S-wave in V1 and the tallest R-wave in V5 or V6 has to be over 35 millimeters or 35 little boxes. Additional criteria include things like having an R-wave that goes on for longer than usual - typically over 50ms, ST-segment depression, and T-wave inversion in V5 or V6. These are signs that the left ventricle is straining during muscle contraction.

Left ventricular hypertrophy commonly develops due to chronic systemic hypertension, or elevated systemic blood pressure, since the left ventricle needs more muscle so that it can eject blood against higher pressures.
 

Option Analysis

❌ P-wave in lead V1 and V2 over 1.5 mm:
Incorrect: In right atrial enlargement, the extra right atrial muscle tissue results in a large P wave in leads V1 and V2, often over 1.5 mm. One of the common causes of right atrial enlargement includes tricuspid stenosis, as well as severe pulmonary hypertension.  
❌ Bifid P-wave in lead II with a gap of over 40 ms separating the two peaks:
Incorrect: Bifid P-wave in lead II with a gap of over 40 ms separating the two peaks is seen in patients with left atrial enlargement. One of the common causes of left atrial enlargement includes mitral stenosis.  
❌ Dominant R wave in V1 with R/S ratio > 1:
Incorrect: A dominant R wave in V1 is a classic sign of right ventricular hypertrophy and it’s defined as one that is over 7mm tall or 7 little boxes and is larger than the S wave, making the R/S ratio >1.  
❌ Right axis deviation with an axis of 115 degrees:
Incorrect: Right axis deviation resulting in an axis of 110 degrees or more is seen in patients with right ventricular hypertrophy.  
✅ Deep S wave in lead V1 and tall R wave in lead V6:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: The menstrual cycle refers to the regular changes in the activity of the ovaries and endometrium that make reproduction possible. Which of the following days in an average 28-day cycle usually represents the day of ovulation?
questions.solution:
The menstrual cycle refers to the regular changes in the activity of the ovaries and endometrium that make reproduction possible.

The menstrual cycle actually consists of two interconnected and synchronized processes: the ovarian cycle, which centers on the development of the ovarian follicles and ovulation; and the endometrial cycle, which centers on endometrial thickening and thinning in response to ovarian activity.

The monthly menstrual cycle can vary in duration from 20 to 35 days, with an average duration of 28 days. Each menstrual cycle begins on the first day of menstruation, which is referred to as day 1 of the cycle.

Ovulation usually occurs 14 days after the first day of menstruation (i.e., 14 days before the next cycle begins). For an average 28-day menstrual cycle, there are usually 14 days leading up to ovulation (preovulatory phase) and 14 days following ovulation (postovulatory phase).  


Option Analysis

❌ Day 1:
Incorrect: Each menstrual cycle begins on the first day of menstruation and this is referred to as day one of the cycle.  
❌ Day 5:
Incorrect: On average, menstruation stops around day 5 of the menstrual cycle and the follicular (proliferative phase) begins around this time.  
✅ Day 14  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Day 20:
Incorrect: Ovulation typically occurs around day 14 of the menstrual cycle, as opposed to day 20.  
❌ Day 25:
Incorrect: Around day 25, if fertilization does not occur, the corpus luteum degenerates into a nonfunctional corpus albicans that does not synthesize hormones. Eventually, estrogen and progesterone levels decrease and lead to the beginning of a new menstrual cycle at around day 28.

questions.text: A researcher is studying the structure and function of hemoglobin. He discovers that certain conditions decrease oxygen unloading to tissues, as demonstrated in the graph below. Which of the following conditions favors this effect?

choices.text: Decreasing the partial pressure of CO2
Increasing the partial pressure of CO2

questions.solution:
The oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve reflects the saturation of hemoglobin at different partial pressures of oxygen. Several conditions may result in either a left or right curve shift. A rightward shift indicates increasing oxygen unloading to tissues, where certain conditions decrease hemoglobin’s affinity for oxygen. In contrast, a leftward shift means decreasing oxygen unloading to tissues and a relative increase in affinity for oxygen. Conditions associated with either shift are reflected in the tables above.  


Option Analysis

✅ Decreasing the partial pressure of CO2:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Increasing the partial pressure of CO2:
Incorrect: Increasing the partial pressure of CO2 will result in a rightward shift of the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve.  
❌ Increasing the temperature:
Incorrect:  Increasing the temperature will result in a rightward shift of the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve.  
❌ Decreasing the pH:
Incorrect: Decreasing the pH will result in a rightward shift of the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve.  
❌ High altitude:
Incorrect: High altitude will result in a rightward shift of the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve.

questions.text: A synthetic analog of a hormone produced by the body is being studied for use in weight loss. In the study, the synthetic hormone is shown to decrease fat absorption in the gastrointestinal tract. During a 6-month evaluation after initiating treatment, it was noted that there was an increased incidence of diabetes mellitus and gallstone formation in subjects receiving the hormone. The analog used in this trial is most similar to which of the following physiological hormones?
questions.solution:
Somatostatin is a primary regulatory hormone that is produced throughout the body. In the gastrointestinal tract, somatostatin is produced by the D-cells found at several locations in the digestive system, namely the pyloric antrum, duodenum, and pancreatic islets.  

Somatostatin is an inhibitory hormone, and in the gastrointestinal tract, it inhibits various secretions, including exocrine secretions such as bile, gastric acid, pancreatic secretions, colonic fluid, cholecystokinin, and vasoactive intestinal polypeptide (VIP). Due to its inhibition of cholecystokinin, a hormone that causes gallbladder contractions, somatostatin causes bile stasis. Therefore, octreotide can increase the risk of gallstone formation. Additionally, somatostatin inhibits endocrine secretions of insulin and glucagon from the pancreas.  

The inhibitory effects of somatostatin, specifically via its analogs like octreotide, make its use beneficial in various pathological conditions, such as gastrinoma, VIPoma, and carcinoid syndrome. However, somatostatin has a very short half-life, so synthetic analogs with longer half-lives are used (e.g. octreotide).  

Option Analysis

✅ Somatostatin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Gastrin:
Incorrect: Gastrin increases gastric acid production, which may damage the villi of the intestines and decrease fat absorption. However, it is not associated with an increased risk of diabetes mellitus or gallstones.  
❌ Cholecystokinin:
Incorrect: Cholecystokinin increases fat absorption by stimulating gallbladder contraction and bile secretion into the intestines. Additionally, it decreases the risk of gallstone formation.
❌ Secretin:
Incorrect: Secretin increases fat absorption by stimulating bile and pancreatic secretions.  
❌ Vasoactive intestinal polypeptide (VIP)  :
Incorrect: VIP does not inhibit the absorption of fat.

questions.text: A male newborn is delivered at term to a 32-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 2. Examination of the newborn shows a swollen face and abdomen. There is palpable hepatosplenomegaly. His hemoglobin concentration is 6.9 g/dL and serum bilirubin concentration is 8.1 mg/dL. A direct antiglobulin test shows immediate agglutination of red blood cells. Her previous pregnancy was uncomplicated with the birth of a healthy boy. The mother’s blood group is AB negative, and the father's blood group is AB positive. Which of the following is the underlying cause of the newborn's current condition?

choices.text: Presence of anti-D IgG in the maternal serum
Previous pregnancy with blood group A fetus
Previous pregnancy with blood group B fetus

questions.solution:
This combination of findings is associated with Rhesus incompatibility, which can result in hemolytic disease of the fetus and newborn (HDFN). HDFN is characterized by the destruction of fetal red blood cells and subsequent anemia. It is commonly caused by a Rhesus (Rh) or ABO incompatibility between the mother and fetus.  

In Rh incompatibility with an Rh-negative mother with an Rh-positive fetus, maternal exposure to fetal blood (most often during birth) leads to maternal IgM antibodies against the Rh antigen. Over time, seroconversion to anti-Rh IgG occurs. IgG antibodies can cross the placenta. In a subsequent pregnancy with another Rh-positive child, these antibodies bind to the Rh antigen of fetal RBCs, marking them for destruction. Hydrops fetalis and severe anemia are often seen in cases of HDFN due to Rh incompatibility, but these features are usually absent in cases of HDFN due to ABO incompatibility.  

Prevention is by administering anti-D IgG to Rh-negative pregnant patients during the third trimester and early postpartum period in the first and subsequent pregnancies with an Rh-positive fetus. This prevents maternal anti-D IgG production.

Option Analysis

❌ Mother with blood group AB  :
Incorrect: Since both mother and father’s blood group is AB, no antibodies will cross the placenta to the fetus to cause hemolysis. The fetus is unlikely to develop ABO incompatibility.  
✅ Presence of anti-D IgG in the maternal serum  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Previous pregnancy with blood group A fetus  :
Incorrect: Previous pregnancy with blood group A fetus will not result in hydrops fetalis in this newborn since the mother would not have anti-A antibodies due to her AB blood type.  
❌ Previous pregnancy with Rh-negative fetus  :
Incorrect: Previous pregnancy with an Rh-negative fetus is impossible as the father is Rh-positive. Moreover, if the previous pregnancy were with an Rh-negative fetus, no anti-D IgG would be formed in the mother, and Rh hemolytic disease of the newborn would not be seen in this pregnancy.  
❌ Previous pregnancy with blood group B fetus  :
Incorrect: Previous pregnancy with blood group B fetus will not result in hydrops fetalis in this newborn since the mother would not have anti-B antibodies due to her AB blood type.

questions.text: A researcher is investigating the pathway that results in the generation of angiotensin II and, in particular, is studying the angiotensin-converting enzyme. Endothelial cells of which of the following organs contain the greatest concentration of angiotensin-converting enzyme?
questions.solution:
The renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) is one of the main physiologic mechanisms by which the cardiovascular system and kidneys attempt to maintain normal arterial blood pressure by controlling blood volume. When blood gets supplied to the renal artery, it reaches the afferent arterioles, and in the walls of the afferent arterioles are specialized smooth muscle cells called juxtaglomerular (JG) cells that secrete renin when stimulated.

Renin cleaves a large protein synthesized by the liver, angiotensinogen, to produce angiotensin I. Angiotensin I then travels in circulation to reach endothelial cells of the lungs and kidneys, which have an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) on their surface. ACE cleaves angiotensin I into an 8-amino acid peptide called angiotensin II (AT II).

Option Analysis

✅ Lungs:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Liver:
Incorrect: The liver synthesizes angiotensinogen, cleaved by renin into angiotensin I. The liver does not house endothelial cells with angiotensin-converting enzymes.  
❌ Spleen:
Incorrect: Endothelial cells of the splenic vessels do not have a significant amount of angiotensin-converting enzyme.  
❌ Pancreas:
Incorrect: Endothelial cells of the pancreatic vessels do not have a significant amount of angiotensin-converting enzyme.  
❌ Heart:
Incorrect: Endothelial cells of the coronary vessels do not contain a significant amount of angiotensin-converting enzyme.

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant is brought to the pediatrician to receive his scheduled vaccination. The infant is scheduled for hepatitis B vaccination. Which of the following is true regarding this vaccine?

choices.text: It is a live attenuated vaccine.
It is contraindicated in patients with immunodeficiencies.

questions.solution:
The Hepatitis B vaccine is a subunit vaccine. Subunit vaccines contain only a fragment of the pathogen that contains the parts of the pathogen which stimulate the immune system the most.  

The fragment in subunit vaccines can be a polysaccharide or a protein. For example, the Streptococcus pneumoniae vaccine contains a capsular polysaccharide that can produce immunity against the pathogen. In polysaccharide-only vaccines, B-cells stimulate an immune response without stimulating T-cells (also known as a thymus-independent antigen). Therefore, the polysaccharide can be conjugated in with a protein to switch the response to a thymus-dependent reaction which is more robust. The vaccines against Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae type B, and Neissieria meningitidis are all subunit vaccines that contain the capsular polysaccharide and are conjugated with a protein. Other subunit vaccines include the hepatitis B vaccine, HPV vaccine, and pertussis vaccine.  

Subunit vaccines are safe and have fewer side effects. However, they do not produce a robust immune response compared to live-attenuated vaccines. And therefore, it may require booster doses or adjuvants to stimulate the immune response.  

Option Analysis

✅ It is a subunit vaccine.  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ It is a whole-cell vaccine.  :
Incorrect: Hepatitis B vaccine is a subunit vaccine, not a whole-cell vaccine. Whole-cell vaccines are live attenuated vaccines and inactivated vaccines.  
❌ It is a polysaccharide vaccine.  :
Incorrect: Hepatitis B vaccine is a subunit vaccine that contains hepatitis B surface antigen (HbsAg), which is a protein, not a polysaccharide.  
❌ It is a live attenuated vaccine.  :
Incorrect: Hepatitis B vaccine is a subunit vaccine.  
❌ It is contraindicated in patients with immunodeficiencies.  :
Incorrect: The hepatitis B vaccine is not contraindicated in patients with immunodeficiencies. Also, it is not contraindicated in patients with autoimmune disorders or pregnant or lactating women.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman comes to the physician to evaluate chest and abdominal pain, typically after eating large meals. Biochemical testing reveals markedly elevated gastrin levels. In addition to increased gastric acid secretion, which of the following is also expected to happen in this patient due to increased gastrin levels?

choices.text: Decreased bicarbonate secretion in the small intestine

questions.solution:
Gastrin is a polypeptide hormone secreted by the G-cells, which are mainly in the pyloric antrum of the stomach but can also be found in the small intestines and pancreas. Gastrin’s primary functions are in the gastrointestinal tract.  

Gastrin is responsible for increasing gastric acid secretions, both directly and indirectly. It does this directly by binding to cholecystokinin B (CCKB) receptors on parietal cells, enhancing the activity of the H+/K+ ATPase pumps and ultimately increasing acid secretion into the gastric lumen. It also does this indirectly by stimulating enterochromaffin-like cells (ECL) to produce histamine, which then promotes acid secretion.  

In addition, gastrin also has other functions, such as increasing gastric motility and stimulating the growth and proliferation of gastric mucosa.   

Gastrin secretion is increased by vagal stimulation (through gastrin-releasing peptide (GRP)), stomach distention, increased pH of the stomach, and the presence of amino acids in the stomach. In contrast, the secretion of gastrin is inhibited by low stomach pH via negative feedback.  

Option Analysis

✅ Proliferation of gastric mucosa  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Decreased gastric motility  :
Incorrect: Gastrin increases gastric motility.  
❌ Decreased bicarbonate secretion in the small intestine  :
Incorrect: Gastrin increases gastric acid secretion, which is expected to cause increases in the bicarbonate secretion in the small intestine to help neutralize the incoming gastric acid.  
❌ Increased appetite  :
Incorrect: Gastrin does not affect appetite.  
❌ Decreased histamine secretion  :
Incorrect: Gastrin directly stimulates enterochromaffin-like cells in the stomach to secrete histamine to maximize gastric acid secretion.

questions.text: Researchers are studying the neuronal action potential. The study finds that the first step involves opening ligand-gated ion channels, which allows calcium ions into the muscle cell, thus increasing membrane potential positivity. This step triggers the opening of voltage-gated ion channels and depolarization due to the influx of ion X. After a few milliseconds, another voltage-gated ion channel opens and allows molecule Y to efflux outside the cell, causing repolarization of the cell membrane. Which of the following is most likely ion X and Y?
questions.solution:
The neuronal action potential allows an electrochemical signal to be transmitted through the neuron. It usually starts when a neurotransmitter binds to dendrites and triggers the opening of ligand-gated ion channels. When open, these channels allow for the entrance of a positively charged ion into the cell, causing slight depolarization of the membrane and bringing it closer to the action potential threshold. When these interactions occur, they are referred to as  excitatory postsynaptic potentials (EPSP).  
 

Once the cell reaches a voltage-gated threshold, voltage-gated sodium channels open, allowing sodium ions to influx into cells and induce depolarization. The influx of sodium brings the membrane potential up to around 40 mV, and the action potential propagates through the axon.  


The voltage-gated sodium channels become inactivated once the membrane potential reaches around 40 mV. Although these channels remain open, no sodium enters the cell. At this point, voltage-gated potassium channels are available, causing an efflux of potassium outside the cell, bringing the membrane potential towards repolarization and membrane resting potential (~ -65mV).  The cell during this period is in the effective refractory period, meaning that no matter the strength of the signal, no additional action potentials can be initiated.  


After the cell membrane reaches the resting potential, potassium channels remain open, allowing membrane potential to become more negative, a setting called hyperpolarization. At this stage, sodium channels remain closed, and the neuron remains in the relative refractory period.  


The voltage of the neuronal action potential phases is summarized in the chart below:  


Option Analysis

✅ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ :
Incorrect: Sodium influx into the cell causes depolarization, while potassium efflux causes repolarization.   
❌ :
Incorrect: Chloride is not responsible for the repolarizing neuronal action potential. Potassium ions efflux through the voltage-gated ion channels causing repolarization.   
❌ :
Incorrect: Calcium and Chloride channels may play a role in stimulating or inhibiting action potential in neurons, but they are not responsible for the action potential itself.   
❌ :
Incorrect: Calcium ions are not responsible for depolarizing the membrane in neuronal action potential, which is completed by the influx of sodium ions through voltage-gated ion channels.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man requires a blood transfusion following significant bleeding after a motor vehicle accident. His blood type is found to be AB positive. This patient can receive blood from which of the following type(s) of blood donors?

choices.text: Type A and type B only
Type A, type B, and type AB
Type A, type B, type AB, and type O

questions.solution:
Every person has a unique blood group based on two classification systems: the ABO system and the Rh system.  

The immune system produces antibodies against the glycoproteins that a patient doesn’t have. The ABO system refers to the type of glycoproteins found on a person’s red blood cells. It can be either type A, type B, type A and B glycoproteins, or neither, called type O blood. People with type A blood have antibodies to type B blood, and people with type B blood have antibodies to type A blood. People with blood type AB don’t have antibodies to type A or type B blood, so they can receive blood from any blood type. Thus, people with blood type AB are universal recipients. However, since their red blood cells have both type A and type B antigens, they can’t donate blood to anyone except other AB blood type individuals.  



On the other hand, people with type O blood have antibodies to both A and B glycoproteins, so they cannot receive type A, type B, or type AB blood. But since their red blood cells don’t have type A or type B antigens, they can donate blood to anyone. That is, they’re universal donors.  




Option Analysis

❌ Type AB only  :
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. People with blood type AB don’t have antibodies to type A or type B blood so they can receive blood from any of the blood types.  
❌ Type O only  :
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. People with blood type AB don’t have antibodies to type A or type B blood so they can receive blood from any of the blood types.  
❌ Type A and type B only  :
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. People with blood type AB don’t have antibodies to type A or type B blood so they can receive blood from any of the blood types.  
❌ Type A, type B, and type AB  :
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. People with blood type AB don’t have antibodies to type A or type B so they can receive blood from any blood type.  
✅ Type A, type B, type AB, and type O  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents for evaluation of chest pain and dyspnea that worsens with exertion. Medical history is notable for untreated Streptococcal pharyngitis as a child. An echocardiogram is performed and reveals aortic stenosis. The patient is found to have a left ventricular wall thickness of T and a radius of R. The intraventricular pressure during systole is P. The patient is lost to follow-up and, upon returning a year later, is found to have a wall thickness of 1.2T and radius of 0.6R. Intraventricular pressure remains unchanged. Which of the following best characterizes decreased left ventricular wall stress over the past year?
questions.solution:
This patient was diagnosed with aortic stenosis, which led to an increase in cardiac afterload. Over time, the heart muscle will hypertrophy to reduce ventricular wall stress during systole. The change in ventricular wall stress can be calculated using the law of Laplace.

The law of Laplace states that the wall tension of a hollow cylinder or sphere is proportional to its pressure and radius. A modified version of this equation can be used to calculate ventricular wall stress and is as follows:
 

The first step to finding the change in ventricular wall stress is calculating the initial wall stress after one year. Next, the difference between these two values should be calculated, representing the change in wall stress:

                                          Initial ventricular wall stress = (P*R) / (2*T)

                     One-year ventricular wall stress = (P*0.6R) / (2*1.2T) = (P*R) / (4*T)

           Change in ventricular wall stress = (P*R) / (4*T) – (P*R) / (2*T) = - (P*R) / (4*T)

These equations demonstrate that ventricular hypertrophy, which increases wall thickness and decreases the inner radius of the ventricle, helps reduce wall stress.   

Option Analysis

❌ (PR)/(2T):
Incorrect: Ventricular wall stress can be calculated using the law of Laplace. Based on this law of physics, the patient’s initial left ventricular wall stress is (PR)/(2T), whereas a year later is (PR)/(4T). The decrease in left ventricular wall stress is the difference between these two values: (PR)/(4T).  
❌ (PR)/(T):
Incorrect: Ventricular wall stress can be calculated using the law of Laplace. Based on this law of physics, the patient’s initial left ventricular wall stress is (PR)/(2T), whereas a year later, it is (PR)/(4T). The decrease in left ventricular wall stress is the difference between these two values: (PR)/(4T).  
❌ PRT:
Incorrect: According to the law of Laplace, ventricular wall stress is inversely proportional to the wall thickness. Therefore, the variable T should appear in the denominator of the expression.  
✅ (PR)/(4T)  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ (PR)/6  :
Incorrect: Wall tension of a hollow structure is determined by its radius and the pressure of its contents. However, this question asks for the change in wall stress, which considers pressure, radius, and wall thickness. As a result, the variable T (ventricular wall thickness) should be present in the correct answer.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents for evaluation of amenorrhea that has been ongoing for the past 12 months. She has also experienced dyspareunia, recurrent headaches, and infrequent episodes of night sweats. The patient is subsequently diagnosed with menopause. Which of the following laboratory findings is most specific to this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Menopause is the permanent cessation of menstruation due to loss of ovarian follicular function. It is diagnosed retrospectively after 12 months of amenorrhea. Menopause usually sets in around age 50 and is preceded by a couple of years of hormonal and physical changes, which is termed perimenopause.

During menopause, there is a decrease in serum estrogen production due to an age-linked decline in the number of ovarian follicles. The pituitary gland responds by producing greater amounts of both FSH and LH in an attempt to drive ovarian function. The increase in FSH is specific for menopause and results from loss of negative feedback on FSH due to decreased estrogen levels. Similar to estrogen, progesterone and testosterone levels also fall during menopause.

Common symptoms of menopause include hot flashes, night sweats, mood swings, headaches, and atrophic vaginitis (pruritis or dyspareunia). Menopause also increases the risk of developing coronary artery disease and osteoporosis.  

Option Analysis

❌ Increase in serum estrogen levels:
Incorrect: Menopause is associated with a decrease in serum estrogen production due to an age-linked decline in the number of ovarian follicles.  
❌ Decrease in serum LH levels:
Incorrect: Serum LH increases during menopause due to the loss of negative feedback. However, this finding is not specific to menopause.  
✅ Increase in serum FSH levels:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Decrease in GnRH levels:
Incorrect: Serum GnRH increases in menopause due to the loss of negative feedback from estrogen.
❌ Increase in testosterone levels:
Incorrect: Testosterone levels decrease with menopause. Estrogen levels drop by a greater amount in comparison, leading to an increased androgen-to-estrogen ratio that manifests with androgen-associated symptoms such as facial hair and deeper voice.

questions.text: A group of investigators are studying the effect of exogenous steroid intake on the hypothalamus-pituitary-adrenal axis in mice. Which of the following changes will be observed in mice who are receiving exogenous cortisol administration?
questions.solution:
Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) is a peptide hormone that helps regulate the release of hormones by the adrenal glands. Secretion of ACTH is dependent on the hypothalamic-pituitary axis.The hypothalamus secretes corticotropin releasing hormone, or CRH, into the hypophyseal portal system, which is a network of capillaries linking the hypothalamus to the anterior part of the pituitary gland. In the anterior pituitary the CRH binds to a surface protein of corticotroph cells, and stimulates them to release ACTH. The main action of ACTH involves stimulating adrenocortical cells of the zona fasciculata of the adrenal cortex to secrete glucocorticoids which has anti-inflammatory effects, increases blood glucose and stimulates fat and protein breakdown. Increased cortisol levels negatively feedback on the hypothalamus and inhibit hypothalamic release of CRH with a subsequent decrease in ACTH secretion. A similar feedback is seen in patients using exogenous steroids.  


Option Analysis

✅  CRH  ACTH  Cortisol  Decrease  Decrease  Increase :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌  CRH  ACTH  Cortisol  No change  Decrease  Decrease :
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. Exogenous administration of cortisol inhibits the secretion of CRH via negative feedback inhibition, which in turn decreases ACTH secretion from the pituitary. Serum cortisol levels would be elevated.   
❌  CRH  ACTH  Cortisol  No change  No change  Increase :
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. Exogenous administration of cortisol inhibits the secretion of CRH via negative feedback inhibition, which in turn decreases ACTH secretion from the pituitary.   
❌  CRH  ACTH  Cortisol  Increase  No change  Increase :
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. Exogenous administration of cortisol inhibits the secretion of CRH via negative feedback inhibition, which in turn decreases ACTH secretion from the pituitary.   
❌  CRH  ACTH  Cortisol  Decrease  Increase  Increase :
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. Exogenous administration of cortisol inhibits the secretion of CRH via negative feedback inhibition, which in turn decreases ACTH secretion from the pituitary.

questions.text: A lab study is simulating secondary hemostasis. In the study, both the intrinsic and extrinsic pathways of coagulation lead to the formation of the active form of factor X (Xa). Which of the following is the correct order of events to occur afterward?

choices.text: Factor Xa activates factor V, then factors Xa and Va activates factor II, which cleaves fibrinogen into fibrin
Factor Xa alone activates factor II, which then cleaves fibrinogen into fibrin.
Factor Xa cleaves fibrinogen into fibrin
Factor Xa uses factor VIIIa as a cofactor to activate factor II, which then cleaves fibrinogen into fibrin.
Factor Xa activates factor V, then factor Va alone activates factor II, which cleaves fibrinogen into fibrin.

questions.solution:
Secondary hemostasis (also known as coagulation) involves the stabilization of the platelet plug formed in primary hemostasis using a fibrin meshwork. Fibrin is formed by the cleavage of fibrinogen and this involves many clotting factors that get activated to reach this end result.  

Both the intrinsic and extrinsic pathways of coagulation yields the activated form of factor X (Xa) and marks the beginning of the common pathway. Factor Xa then cleaves factor V into the active form (Va), and both these factors with calcium form the prothrombinase complex, which cleaves factor II (prothrombin) into the active form IIa (thrombin). 

Thrombin then has 4 main functions: activation of additional factors V, VIII, and IX; activation of platelets; and most importantly, conversion of fibrinogen to fibrin. Fibrin is insoluble (unlike fibrinogen) and this fibrin meshwork then stabilizes the platelet plug. The final function of thrombin is the activation of factor XIII, which further helps in stabilizing the platelet plug by forming cross-links between the fibrin molecules in the plug.  



Option Analysis

✅ Factor Xa activates factor V, then factors Xa and Va activates factor II, which cleaves fibrinogen into fibrin  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Factor Xa alone activates factor II, which then cleaves fibrinogen into fibrin.  :
Incorrect: Factor Xa activates factor V which then acts as a cofactor with factor Xa to convert factor II to the active form (IIa).  
❌ Factor Xa cleaves fibrinogen into fibrin  :
Incorrect: Factor Xa, using activated factor V as a cofactor, cleaves factor II (prothrombin) into the active form IIa (thrombin). Factor IIa then cleaves fibrinogen into fibrin.  
❌ Factor Xa uses factor VIIIa as a cofactor to activate factor II, which then cleaves fibrinogen into fibrin.:
Incorrect: Factor Xa, using activated factor V, as a cofactor cleaves factor II (prothrombin) into the active form IIa (thrombin). Factor IIa then cleaves fibrinogen into fibrin.
❌ Factor Xa activates factor V, then factor Va alone activates factor II, which cleaves fibrinogen into fibrin.:
Incorrect: Factor Xa activates factor V which then acts as a cofactor with factor Xa to convert factor II to the active form (IIa).

questions.text: A researcher identified that an enzyme from phagocytes is responsible for the greenish color of sputum. This enzyme is called myeloperoxidase and is part of the oxidative burst that takes place in the phagolysosome. This enzyme catalyzes which of the following reactions?

choices.text: Creating hypochlorite from chloride ions and hydrogen peroxide.

questions.solution:
Phagocytosis is a process that involves engulfing and destroying pathogens by immune cells called phagocytes (e.g., neutrophils, and macrophages). These pathogens are engulfed in a phagosome, which is part of the cell membrane of the phagocyte. Once inside the cell, the phagosome is joined by the lysosome to create a phagolysosome where the pathogen is destroyed.  

One of the effective mechanisms for pathogen destruction in the phagolysosome is called oxidative burst, which involves the creation of reactive oxygen species (ROS) that damages the cell membrane of the pathogen and thereby resulting in death of the pathogen.  

The oxidative burst starts with an enzyme called NADPH oxidase which oxidizes NADPH to NADP+ and results in the formation of superoxide (O2-) from oxygen. Superoxide is then converted to hydrogen peroxide by superoxide dismutase. Finally, hydrogen peroxide joins with chloride ions to form bleach (hydrochlorite, HOCl) by a reaction catalyzed by myeloperoxidase. All the formed ROS (e.g., superoxide, hydrogen peroxide, bleach) causes damage to the pathogen’s cell membrane, although bleach is the most effective.  


Option Analysis

✅ Creating hypochlorite from chloride ions and hydrogen peroxide.  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Converting NADPH to NADP+  :
Incorrect: The first step in the oxidative burst is done by NADPH oxidase, which catalyzes the oxidation of NADPH to NADP, thus creating superoxide (O2-) from oxygen (O2).
❌ Converting oxygen to superoxide  :
Incorrect: The first step in the oxidative burst is done by NADPH oxidase, which catalyzes the oxidation of NADPH to NADP, thus creating superoxide (O2-) from oxygen (O2).  
❌ Converting superoxide to hydrogen peroxide  :
Incorrect: The conversion of superoxide to hydrogen peroxide is catalyzed by the enzyme superoxide dismutase.  
❌ Converting hydrogen peroxide to water  :
Incorrect: Catalase enzyme converts hydrogen peroxide to water. This step is not a part of the oxidative burst.

questions.text: An activated B cell located in the spleen binds an antigen and is activated via cytokines from a nearby T cell. An enzyme is then expressed in the B cell, which causes random nucleotides to be changed in the B cell receptor variable region. Subsequent generations of daughter cells of this B cell develop progressively stronger binding to this antigen. Which of the following correctly describes this process?
questions.solution:
B cells have a myriad of ways to improve their diversity and strength (affinity) of antigen recognition. During the maturation process, B cells (and T cells) undergo VDJ rearrangement, randomly altering the variable (antibody-binding) region of the B cell and T cell receptors. Activated B cells within the spleen and lymph nodes also undergo somatic hypermutation and subsequent affinity maturation. When these activated B cells bind to an antigen, they express CD40, which binds to the CD40 ligand from nearby T cells. This binding causes the T cells to secrete cytokines which induce an enzyme in B cells called AID (activation-induced cytidine deaminase). AID then replaces many cytidine nucleotides with uridine in single strands of DNA within the B cell receptor (BCR) variable region. These uridine nucleotides are then “repaired” via base excision or mismatch repair, eventually leading to a strand of DNA different from the original. As replication of this activated B cell progresses, this somatic hypermutation occurs many times in many different ways, presenting a slightly different antigen-binding site (variable region) in each daughter cell.    

The daughter B cells with a stronger affinity to the original antigen will bind to it more strongly than other daughter B cells. These daughter B cells will then go on to replicate, allowing more and more B cells with a strong affinity to develop. The B cells that developed BCR with less affinity during this random process will eventually die out as they cannot compete with the affinity of the other daughter B cells. This entire process is referred to as affinity maturation, as over time, the affinity of the BCR to the antigen matures and becomes stronger.  

Option Analysis

❌ Isotype switching  :
Incorrect: Isotype switching refers to a change within the constant region (Fc) of a B cell receptor or antibody, causing B cell receptors or antibodies to convert between IgA, IgD, IgE, IgG, and IgM. This process does not involve random nucleotide changes or changes in antigen affinity.    
❌ VDJ rearrangement  :
Incorrect: While this process also has the purpose of improving antigen-receptor diversity and affinity, it occurs while B cells are maturing and occurs without the involvement of T cells.    
❌ Peripheral tolerance  :
Incorrect: Peripheral tolerance refers to the process of regulatory T cells (Treg cells)  inhibiting other immune cells that are not functioning properly.    
✅ Affinity maturation  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.    
❌ MHC binding  :
Incorrect: Major histocompatibility complex (MHC) is the receptor on which antigens can be presented to other immune cells. The process in the question above is not referring to the process of MHC binding.

questions.text: A blood sample containing a large number of dendritic cells and natural killer cells is isolated from a patient with severe autoimmune disease. When the blood is exposed to T cells expressing high levels of PD-1 receptors, the T cells remain active. When the blood is exposed to T cells expressing high levels of CTLA-4, or high levels of Fas receptors, the T cells undergo inactivation or apoptosis, respectively. Which of the following processes is dysfunctional in this patient?
questions.solution:
The immune system has many different ways to modulate, limit, or kill different immune cells. Regulatory T cells (Treg cells), clonal anergy, clonal deletion, and clonal exhaustion are the main components of this process. Treg cells develop in the thymus and modulate the immune system in three major ways:  

1) increased expression of IL-2 and adenosine receptors on their surface  
2) secretion of cytokines which limit antigen-presenting cells’ ability to present ligands  
3) secretion of cytokines which cause antigen-presenting cells to express more PD-1 ligands  

As the immune response is winding down, clonal anergy and clonal deletion take place.  

In clonal anergy, Treg cells secrete cytokines which cause antigen-presenting cells (APC) to downregulate B7 expression and cause T cells to upregulate CTLA-4 expression. CTLA-4 is a protein receptor constitutively expressed in Treg cells that function to downregulate the immune response. CTLA-4 binds much more strongly to B7 than does CD28, and causes inactivation of the T cell.  

In clonal deletion, T cells express more Fas receptors on their surface. This allows the Fas ligand on CD8+ T cells and natural killer cells to bind to Fas receptors and secretes caspase enzymes, which cause apoptosis of the T cells.  

In clonal exhaustion, T cells that have been around for a long time will express more PD-1 (programed death) receptors on their surface. APCs expressing PD-1 ligands can then bind to this T cell via PD-1 and inactivate it.   

Option Analysis

❌ Affinity maturation  :
Incorrect: This refers to the process whereby cells that underwent somatic hypermutation lead to daughter cells with a progressively stronger affinity for a specific antigen. This question involves cell-to-cell interactions rather than cell-to-antigen interactions.  
❌ Clonal anergy  :
Incorrect: This is an immune-modulating mechanism by which regulatory T cells secrete cytokines causing increased expression of CTLA-4 (a protein receptor that downregulates immune responses) on T cells and decreased expression of B7 on antigen-presenting (e.g., dendritic) cells. Since the T cells expressing CTLA-4 that were added to this blood sample were inactivated, we can assume clonal anergy is working.    
❌ Clonal deletion  :
Incorrect: This is an immune-modulating mechanism by which Fas ligands on CD8+ T cells or natural killer cells bind to Fas receptors on T cells, inactivating (or destroying) them. Since the T cells expressing Fas receptors that were added to this blood sample were destroyed, we can assume clonal deletion is working.
✅ Clonal exhaustion  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Somatic hypermutation  :
Incorrect: Somatic hypermutation involves altering certain nucleotides within the DNA of the B cell receptor variable region. The subsequent replacement of the DNA strand with other nucleotides causes slightly different variable regions, with the goal of developing both higher affinity and diversity of antigen-binding.

questions.text: A study is underway to understand the effects of parathyroid hormone on controlling bone formation and resorption. Scientists agree that the hormone contributes to bone remodeling and is affected by serum calcium levels. Calcium ions act on the calcium-sensing receptors on the parathyroid glands and subsequent serum levels of parathyroid hormone. Which of the following is true regarding parathyroid hormone?

choices.text: Chronic serum elevation in parathyroid hormone has catabolic effects on bone
Low intermittent elevation of serum parathyroid hormone has catabolic effects on bone
Parathyroid hormone directly stimulates osteoclasts to increase bone resorption
Parathyroid hormone stimulates apoptosis of osteoclasts while inhibiting the apoptosis of osteoblasts.
Serum elevations in parathyroid hormone increase bone resorption, regardless of the duration of elevation.

questions.solution:
Parathyroid hormone (PTH) is a significant hormone in controlling calcium homeostasis and bone resorption and formation. PTH stimulates osteoblasts to increase the production of RANK ligand (RANKL), which then activates osteoclasts and thus bone resorption. In addition, PTH enhances bone formation by increasing osteoblast proliferation and differentiation and decreasing osteoblast apoptosis. Therefore, the effects of parathyroid hormone on the bones can be anabolic or catabolic, depending on the periodicity and duration of PTH secretion.  

When there are continuous PTH serum elevations, there will be primarily catabolic effects on the bones. On the other hand, low intermittent exposure to PTH leads to anabolic effects on the bone, increasing bone formation. Due to this effect, low intermittent administration of PTH is often used in the management of osteoporosis.  

Option Analysis

✅ Chronic serum elevation in parathyroid hormone has catabolic effects on bone  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Low intermittent elevation of serum parathyroid hormone has catabolic effects on bone  :
Incorrect: Low intermittent secretion of parathyroid hormone has been shown to have anabolic effects on the bone. It stimulates bone formation without resorption.  
❌ Parathyroid hormone directly stimulates osteoclasts to increase bone resorption  :
Incorrect: Parathyroid hormone stimulates osteoclasts indirectly by stimulating the osteoblasts to increase the secretion of RANK ligand, which then activates osteoclasts.  
❌ Parathyroid hormone stimulates apoptosis of osteoclasts while inhibiting the apoptosis of osteoblasts.  :
Incorrect: This stem describes the effects of estrogen, not a parathyroid hormone.  
❌ Serum elevations in parathyroid hormone increase bone resorption, regardless of the duration of elevation.   :
Incorrect: Low intermittent secretion of parathyroid hormone has been shown to have anabolic effects on bone, while the chronic elevation of parathyroid hormone has catabolic effects on bone.

questions.text: A patient with bilateral renal artery stenosis presents to the physician for management. Further workup reveals that this patient has increased levels of a hormone that acts on intracellular receptors and causes increased reabsorption of sodium in the kidneys back into the blood. Which of the following is also a function of this hormone?

choices.text: Increased reabsorption of H+ by α-intercalated cells of the collecting ducts back into the blood
Increased excretion of H+ into the urine by principal cells of the collecting ducts
Decreased excretion of potassium into the urine by principal cells of the collecting ducts
Increased excretion of potassium into the urine by α-intercalated cells of the collecting ducts
Increased excretion of potassium into the urine by principal cells of the collecting ducts

questions.solution:
This patient has bilateral renal artery stenosis, which results in the activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS). Aldosterone is a steroid hormone that acts on its intracellular receptors in the collecting tubules and ducts. It stimulates the reabsorption of sodium by inserting more channels into the apical surface of principal cells, resulting in more influx of sodium into the cells. In addition, aldosterone increases the amount of sodium-potassium ATPase pumps (Na+/K+ ATPase channel) on the surface of these cells, which pumps sodium into the interstitial fluid and back into the blood while also pumping potassium into the cells.
 

Aldosterone plays a very important role in potassium homeostasis. Since aldosterone increases the activity of Na+/K+ ATPase pumps in the basolateral membrane of principal cells, the number of intracellular potassium increases. The intracellular potassium is subsequently pushed out of the cells into the tubules and urine.

The movement of potassium into the urine is further augmented by the insertion of more potassium channels in the apical membranes of these cells, allowing greater amounts of potassium to move out of the cells into the urine.

Finally, aldosterone indirectly increases the secretion of potassium into urine by augmenting the urine’s electrical gradient. Since sodium ions are reabsorbed from the urine, there is a negative environment in the urine that pulls in more potassium ions.

Through a combination of these three effects, aldosterone increases the excretion of potassium into the urine.  


Option Analysis

❌ Increased reabsorption of H+ by α-intercalated cells of the collecting ducts back into the blood:
Incorrect: Aldosterone increases the excretion of H+ ions from the blood into the urine through α-intercalated cells.  
❌ Increased excretion of H+ into the urine by principal cells of the collecting ducts  :
Incorrect: Aldosterone increases the secretion of H+ ions into the urine. However, this effect is due to aldosterone’s effects on α-intercalated cells (not principal cells).  
❌ Decreased excretion of potassium into the urine by principal cells of the collecting ducts:
Incorrect: Aldosterone increases the excretion of potassium into the urine.  
❌ Increased excretion of potassium into the urine by α-intercalated cells of the collecting ducts:
Incorrect: Aldosterone increases the secretion of potassium into the urine. This effect is due to aldosterone’s effect on principal cells, not the α-intercalated cells.  
✅ Increased excretion of potassium into the urine by principal cells of the collecting ducts:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A newborn is found to have jaundice that resolved in 48 hours. The mother’s blood group is O positive, and the fetus is A positive. The previous two pregnancies were also complicated by jaundice in the newborn, requiring phototherapy. Which of the following is the most likely cause of jaundice in this newborn?

choices.text: Pre-existing anti-B and anti-A IgG antibodies in the mother
Previous pregnancy with blood group B fetus
Formation of anti-D IgG in the maternal serum from a previous pregnancy

questions.solution:
This combination of findings is associated with ABO incompatibility, resulting in hemolytic disease of the fetus and newborn (HDFN). HDFN is characterized by the destruction of fetal red blood cells and subsequent anemia. It is commonly caused by a Rhesus (Rh) or ABO incompatibility between the mother and fetus.  

ABO HDFN occurs almost exclusively in infants with blood group A or B who are born to group O mothers, given that group O mothers have naturally occurring antibodies against the A and B antigens that are of the IgG class and are thus capable of crossing the placenta and causing hemolysis in fetal and newborn RBCs. Unlike Rh, ABO HDFN may affect the first-born ABO-incompatible infant because anti-A and anti-B IgG antibodies are generally present in group O adults. Infants with ABO HDFN typically have the less severe disease than those with Rh incompatibility. Although infants affected by ABO incompatibility may require phototherapy to treat their jaundice, fewer than 0.1% require exchange transfusion. Hydrops fetalis caused by ABO alloimmune HDFN is extremely rare.  

Option Analysis

✅ Pre-existing anti-B and anti-A IgG antibodies in the mother  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Previous pregnancy with blood group B fetus  :
Incorrect: The newborn most likely has jaundice secondary to ABO incompatibility. Although the recurrence rate of ABO compatibility is high, previous ABO incompatibility is not the cause of jaundice in this patient.  
❌ Previous pregnancy with Rh-negative fetus  :
Incorrect: An Rh-negative fetus with at least one Rh-positive parent is unlikely. Moreover, it would not contribute to ABO incompatibility.  
❌ Formation of anti-D IgG in the maternal serum from a previous pregnancy   :
Incorrect: Anti-D IgG is usually formed in the maternal serum in response to exposure to the Rh antigen of the fetus if the mother is Rh-negative.  
❌ Rh-positive mother  :
Incorrect: The presence of Rhesus antigen on maternal RBCs would not cause hemolytic anemia since the mother would not produce anti-D IgG antibodies.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman, gravida 1 para 0, comes to the obstetrician to discuss the possibility of home birth. The patient insists on giving birth to her child at home as an approach to an “all-natural delivery.” The physician reviews her case; he states that while home delivery is possible for the patient to do, he recommends that the baby is brought in following birth to be given vitamin K to prevent fatal bleeding. Which of the following explains the need of vitamin K administration in neonates?

choices.text: Insufficient colonization of the colon by bacteria that produce vitamin K
Inability of neonates to absorb the abundant vitamin K found in breast milk
Inability to store vitamin K in neonates due to lack of fat
Neonates are unable to recycle vitamin K once used
Vitamin K requirements in neonates are much higher than in adults.

questions.solution:
Vitamin K is a fat soluble vitamin that helps in activating clotting factors involved in secondary hemostasis, and thereby contributes to coagulation. Without vitamin K, the clotting factors II, VII, IX, and X cannot be activated, and can cause massive bleeding.  

The main resources of vitamin K are from the diet. Additionally, bacteria colonizing the gut produces vitamin K and helps maintain adequate levels of vitamin K. Therefore, deficiency in vitamin K is quite rare in adults except in certain disorders (e.g. malabsorption). However, neonates are prone to vitamin K deficiency, and this is attributed to the decreased endogenous and exogenous supply of vitamin K.   

First of all, the endogenous vitamin K is through the gut bacteria. In neonates, the gut is still sterile, and therefore few bacteria that produce vitamin K are present. Insufficient colonization of bacteria in the colon that produces vitamin K in neonates plays an important role in the deficiency of vitamin K.  

Additionally, the exogenous supply of vitamin K in neonates is very low. Vitamin K is not transported across the placenta, so the neonates are born without sufficient storage. In addition, breast milk contains low amounts of vitamin K which are insufficient to meet the required levels for neonates.  

Due to these reasons, neonates must be given vitamin K soon after birth to prevent catastrophic complications which include bleeding, intracranial hemorrhage, and death.   

Option Analysis

✅ Insufficient colonization of the colon by bacteria that produce vitamin K  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Inability of neonates to absorb the abundant vitamin K found in breast milk  :
Incorrect: Breast milk contains low amounts of vitamin K, which predisposes to vitamin K deficiency in neonates.  
❌ Inability to store vitamin K in neonates due to lack of fat   :
Incorrect: Vitamin K can be stored in infants, and the reason for vitamin K deficiency in neonates is deficiency in the endogenous and exogenous supply of the vitamin.
❌ Neonates are unable to recycle vitamin K once used  :
Incorrect: The enzyme epoxide reductase is responsible for converting vitamin K to the reduced form after it is used, thereby recycling it and making it available for use again. Although the enzyme function in neonates is not at the same level as in adults, it is still functional and can recycle vitamin K to the reduced form.  
❌ Vitamin K requirements in neonates are much higher than in adults.  :
Incorrect: The reason for vitamin K supplementation in neonates is due to decreased supply, not increased demand.

questions.text: A researcher is studying the effect that different pathologies have on cardiac physiology. Which of the following conditions will most likely result in a decreased cardiac afterload?
questions.solution:
Cardiac afterload is the amount of resistance that the ventricles must overcome during systole. The three factors contributing to afterload are systemic vascular resistance, aortic pressure, and valvular diseases. Conditions that increase afterload will lead to a decrease in stroke volume.
 
  •  Systemic vascular resistance measures how readily vessels allow blood to flow through them. Systemic vascular resistance can be affected by changes in the vessel lumen or blood viscosity. 
  •  Aortic pressure is the blood pressure at the root of the aorta. An increase in aortic pressure means the heart must contract harder and generate more pressure within the left ventricle to pump blood out. Therefore, an increase in aortic pressure will lead to an increase in afterload. 
  •  There is valvular disease. In aortic stenosis, the aortic valve does not fully open, and the heart must generate more pressure to eject blood during systole. In mitral regurgitation, the mitral valves do not fully close, and blood flows back from the left ventricle into the left atrium. As a result, less blood must be ejected into the systemic circulation. 

Option Analysis

❌ Aortic stenosis:
Incorrect: Afterload is affected by systemic vascular resistance, aortic pressure, and valvular disease. In aortic stenosis, the aortic valve does not fully open, and the heart must generate more pressure to eject blood during systole. As a result, the condition will lead to increased afterload.  
❌ Systemic vasoconstriction:
Incorrect: Afterload is affected by systemic vascular resistance, aortic pressure, and valvular disease. Systemic vasoconstriction will increase vascular resistance and, in turn, increase afterload.  
❌ Polycythemia vera:
Incorrect: Polycythemia vera is a myeloproliferative disorder characterized primarily by the overproduction of red blood cells. The condition leads to increased blood viscosity, which can, in turn, increase systemic vascular resistance and afterload.  
❌ Adrenal aldosteronoma:
Incorrect: Afterload is affected by systemic vascular resistance, aortic pressure, and valvular disease. An aldosteronoma will lead to unregulated aldosterone secretion, which will cause hypertension refractory to medical treatment and increased afterload.  
✅ Acute mitral regurgitation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A study is done to record the action potentials of the different cells in the heart. During the study, a myocyte action potential is recorded and is shown below. During which of the following phases do calcium ions influx into the myocyte causing contraction?
questions.solution:
The action potential is electrical activity across the cell membrane. In the heart, two distinct types of action potentials occur in 2 different types of cells, the pacemaker cells, and the cardiac myocytes.

The myocytes are the contractile units of the heart and make up the myocardium. Their action potential is characterized by 5 different phases:

Phase 4: Also known as the resting phase. It is the initial phase where the ion channels are mainly closed and the membrane potential is resting at -90 mV. Because of the presence of gap junctions between the myocytes, some positive ions leak from neighboring cells that are depolarized (mainly calcium ions) bringing the membrane potential up to -70 mV, which is the threshold potential for depolarization.
 
 
Phase 0: This is known as the depolarization phase. When the membrane potential reaches the threshold (-70 mV), the voltage-gated sodium channels open and the rapid influx of sodium into the cells brings the membrane potential up to +20 mV.
 
 
Phase 1: the initial repolarization phase. After the membrane potential of myocytes reaches +20 mV, depolarization ends and the sodium channels close. This is followed by the opening of the voltage-gated potassium channels. The efflux of potassium towards the outside of the cell causes the membrane potential to drop until phase 2 starts. The initial repolarization is responsible for the notch seen in the myocytes action potential.
 

Phase 2: the plateau phase. Shortly after the opening of the voltage-gated potassium channels in phase 1, voltage-gated calcium channels open and allow calcium ions to influx into the cells. In this phase, the inward current by calcium ions balances the outward current of potassium channels, and the membrane potential stabilizes, thus called the plateau phase. This phase is important in the myocyte action potential because it is responsible for the length of the action potential and the calcium influx is what actually causes the myocytes to contract.
 

Phase 3: the repolarization phase. Here the voltage-gated calcium channels close while the voltage-gated potassium channels remain open, and the potassium continues to efflux outside the cell bringing the membrane potential back to the resting potential (-90 mV), thus, marking the end of the action potential.  


Finally, few notable differences can be made between the action potentials of myocytes and skeletal muscles. First of all, myocytes are electrically coupled with gap junctions, while skeletal muscle cells are not. Additionally, the plateau phase in myocytes action potentials is absent in skeletal muscle action potentials. And finally, the influx of calcium ions in the plateau phase is required to induce the release of calcium ions from the sarcoplasmic reticulum and, therefore, required for muscle contraction.  

Option Analysis

❌ Phase 0  :
Incorrect: Phase 0 is the depolarization phase of the myocytes and is characterized by an influx of sodium into the cells. However, calcium channels are closed in phase 0.  
❌ Phase 1  :
Incorrect: Phase 1 is also known as the initial repolarization phase and is characterized by an influx of potassium ions, not calcium ions.  
✅ Phase 2:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Phase 3:
Incorrect: Phase 3 is the repolarization phase and the calcium channels close while the potassium channels are open, resulting in an efflux of potassium towards the outside of the cell, causing the membrane to drop back to -90 mV.  
❌ Phase 4  :
Incorrect: Phase 0 is the resting phase of the myocyte where all channels are expected to be closed.

questions.text: An experiment is done to determine the physiology of maintaining normal plasma osmolarity. In the experiment, the plasma osmolarity of a subject is raised to 320 mOsm/L. This triggers the release of a hormone from the posterior pituitary that increases the reabsorption of water from urine in the collecting ducts. Which of the following is an additional function of this hormone?

choices.text: Decreased excretion of urea in urine
Increased excretion of urea in urine
Increased excretion of potassium in urine

questions.solution:
Antidiuretic hormone (ADH) is one of the major hormones that regulate blood osmolarity and volume. ADH is produced in the hypothalamus, specifically in the neurons found in the supraoptic nuclei and the paraventricular nuclei of the hypothalamus, and is then stored in vesicles in the neurons. Once stimulated, these neurons release ADH in the posterior pituitary, where it is then secreted into the blood.  

The major stimulus for the release of ADH has increased plasma osmolarity; but, also other signals can stimulate the release of ADH including decreased blood volume and increased circulating angiotensin II. In contrast, decreased plasma osmolarity, increased blood volume and elevated blood pressures all inhibit the release of ADH.  

Once released, ADH acts on two receptors: V1 and V2 receptors. The major effects of ADH are on V2 receptors, which are found in the distal convoluted tubules and the principal cells of the collecting ducts. V2 receptors are G-protein coupled receptors that, when stimulated, cause increased synthesis of aquaporin-2 channels and increased insertion of these channels on the basolateral membrane of the distal convoluted tubules and collecting ducts. These channels permit water reabsorption from the urine, thereby increasing water reabsorption from urine. Additionally, ADH also increases the reabsorption of urea in the collecting ducts in order to maximize the corticomedullary gradient, and hence increase the water reabsorption.  

On the other hand, ADH actions on the V1 receptors cause vasoconstriction, which helps bring up the blood pressure, and can be seen in hypovolemic states (e.g., dehydration, blood loss).  

Option Analysis

✅ Decreased excretion of urea in urine  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Increased excretion of urea in urine  :
Incorrect: Antidiuretic hormone increases the reabsorption of urea from the urine, thereby decreasing its excretion in the urine.  
❌ Increased sodium reabsorption  :
Incorrect: Antidiuretic hormone has no effect on sodium reabsorption in the renal tubules.  
❌ Increased excretion of potassium in urine  :
Incorrect: Antidiuretic hormone has no effect on potassium excretion in the renal tubules.  
❌ Increased secretion of renin  :
Incorrect: Antidiuretic hormone does not stimulate the secretion of renin.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman is diagnosed with primary hypothyroidism. Administering liothyronine (T3) in this patient would result in which of the following hormonal changes?
questions.solution:
The hypothalamus-pituitary-thyroid axis is regulated by negative feedback by the thyroid hormone on the thyrotropin-releasing (TRH) hormone-secreting neurons in the hypothalamus and thyrotrophs of the anterior pituitary. For example, a slight reduction of thyroid hormone triggers a rapid increase of TRH and thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) secretion, resulting in thyroid gland stimulation and increased thyroid hormone production. When thyroid hormone reaches a normal level, it feeds back to suppress TRH and TSH, and a new steady state is attained.  

In patients with primary hypothyroidism, TSH should be elevated when T4 and T3 concentrations are low, reflecting reduced feedback inhibition. Treatment with liothyronine (T3) would increase T3 levels and decrease T4 secondary to the suppression of TSH via negative feedback to the hypothalamus and anterior pituitary. Reverse T3 would also be decreased because it is derived from the peripheral conversion of T4.  


Option Analysis

✅ Thyroid-stimulating hormone  T3  T4  Reverse T3   Decrease  Increase  Decrease   Decrease :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌  Thyroid-stimulating hormone  T3  T4  Reverse T3   No Change Increase  Decrease   Increase:
Incorrect: Although treatment with liothyronine (T3) would increase T3 levels, it would suppress TSH via negative feedback to the hypothalamus and anterior pituitary. Reverse T3 would also be decreased because it is derived from the peripheral conversion of T4.   
❌  Thyroid-stimulating hormone  T3  T4  Reverse T3   No Change Increase  Decrease   Decrease :
Incorrect: Although treatment with liothyronine (T3) would increase T3 levels, it would lead to the suppression of TSH via negative feedback to the hypothalamus and anterior pituitary.   
❌  Thyroid-stimulating hormone  T3  T4  Reverse T3   Decrease  Increase  Decrease   Increase :
Incorrect: Although treatment with liothyronine (T3) would increase T3 levels and suppression of TSH via negative feedback to the hypothalamus and anterior pituitary. Reverse T3 would also be decreased because it is derived from the peripheral conversion of T4.   
❌  Thyroid-stimulating hormone  T3  T4  Reverse T3   Decrease  Increase  Increase Decrease :
Incorrect: Treatment with liothyronine (T3) would result in an increased T3 but decreased T4 levels due to negative feedback inhibition of TSH.

questions.text: Gestational diabetes develops when the body is not able to produce enough of the hormone insulin during pregnancy. Which of the following hormones released during pregnancy is related to gestational diabetes?
questions.solution:
The placenta makes human placental lactogen (hPL) which counters the effect of maternal insulin to help ensure that there is adequate glucose available in the blood for the fetus. Human placental lactogen is thought to be responsible for the marked rise in maternal plasma insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1) concentrations as the pregnancy approaches term.  It exerts metabolic effects during pregnancy via IGF-I. It is associated with insulin resistance, enhanced insulin secretion which stimulates lipolysis, increased circulating free fatty acids, and inhibition of gluconeogenesis. In effect, it antagonizes insulin action, induces glucose intolerance, and results in lipolysis and proteolysis in the maternal system. The elevated blood glucose level in gestational diabetes is caused by this hPL.  

Option Analysis

❌ Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG)  :
Incorrect: Human chorionic gonadotropin is secreted by the syncytiotrophoblasts and is important for the maintenance of the pregnancy. It, however, has no role in the development of gestational diabetes.  
❌ Estrogen:
Incorrect: Estrogen is important for the maintenance of the pregnancy. It also prevents other follicles from maturing during the pregnancy.  
❌ Progesterone:
Incorrect: During pregnancy, progesterone is important for the prevention of preterm labor. It also prepares and maintains the endometrium to allow implantation earlier.  
❌ Prolactin:
Incorrect: Prolactin production during pregnancy prepares the mammary glands for lactation once the progesterone levels fall at the end of pregnancy. It has no role in the development of gestational diabetes.  
✅ Human placental lactogen:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother after swallowing a small toy. Imaging is performed, revealing the toy is lodged within the right middle lobe bronchus. The patient’s partial pressure of arterial oxygen (PaO<sub>2</sub>) is 75 mmHg. Which of the following best characterizes the V/Q ratio in the affected portions of the lung and the effect that 100% supplemental oxygen administration would have on the patient’s PaO<sub>2</sub>?
questions.solution:
