This patient was brought to the emergency department after aspirating a foreign object. The object has obstructed a bronchus, which will lead to decreased ventilation within the alveoli distal to the obstruction site. As a result, the V/Q ratio will decrease.

Furthermore, administering supplemental oxygen will not improve this patient’s partial pressure of arterial oxygen (PaO2). This is a case of decreased ventilation that manifests with a decreased V/Q ratio. Supplemental oxygen cannot reach the obstructed alveoli to participate in gas exchange. Hence, the PaO2 will not increase.

In contrast, in perfusion defect (e.g. pulmonary embolism), which manifests with an increased V/Q ratio, supplemental oxygen will increase the PaO2. This is because oxygen can diffuse into the bloodstream via alveoli perfused by vessels not obstructed by the embolus.  

Option Analysis

❌ :
Incorrect: This patient has aspirated a foreign object obstructing the right middle lobe bronchus. As a result, affected portions of the right lung will have decreased ventilation and a decreased V/Q ratio, as opposed to an increased V/Q ratio.   
❌ :
Incorrect: This patient has aspirated a foreign object obstructing the right middle lobe bronchus. As a result, affected portions of the right lung will have decreased ventilation and a decreased V/Q ratio, as opposed to an increased V/Q ratio.   
❌ :
Incorrect: This patient has aspirated a foreign object obstructing the right middle lobe bronchus. As a result, affected portions of the right lung will have decreased ventilation and a decreased V/Q ratio, as opposed to an unchanged V/Q ratio.   
❌ :
Incorrect: This patient has aspirated a foreign object that is obstructing the right middle lobe bronchus, which will lead to a decreased V/Q ratio within affected portions of the lung. However, administering supplemental oxygen will not improve the patient’s PaO2. This phenomenon exists since the supplemental oxygen will not be able to reach the obstructed alveoli to participate in gas exchange.   
✅ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A study is done to determine how carbon dioxide is transported through the bloodstream to the lungs. Two blood samples are examined, one in the peripheral tissues and one in the lungs. Which of the following findings is expected to be seen?

choices.text: Hemoglobin has a lower affinity for CO2 in the lungs
Hemoglobin has a higher affinity for CO2 in the lungs
Red blood cells (RBCs) in the lungs have higher chloride content
Hemoglobin has the same affinity for CO2 in both tissues
Hemoglobin has a higher affinity for H+ in the lungs

questions.solution:
Carbon dioxide (CO2) is transported in the blood in three main forms: dissolved in the blood, bound to hemoglobin, and in the form of HCO3-.

When blood reaches the lungs, these mechanisms reverse to facilitate the expulsion of CO2.

When blood reaches the lungs, oxygen diffuses into the red blood cells and attaches to hemoglobin. This binding causes a change in the structure of hemoglobin and decreases its affinity for CO2 and H+, causing the release of both molecules. This effect is termed the Haldane effect and helps in the reformation of free CO2. The CO2 released from the hemoglobin diffuses into the blood and the alveoli.

In addition, the release of H+ from hemoglobin causes HCO3- (the main form in which CO2 is carried in the bloodstream) to diffuse back into the RBC (in exchange for chloride). H+ and HCO3- are then joined together in the RBC cytoplasm by the enzyme carbonic anhydrase to make H2CO3, which quickly transforms into CO2 and H2O. CO2 then diffuses into the alveoli and gets exhaled.  

Option Analysis

✅ Hemoglobin has a lower affinity for CO2 in the lungs:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hemoglobin has a higher affinity for CO2 in the lungs:
Incorrect: The high oxygen concentration in the lungs causes oxygen to bind to hemoglobin. This binding causes a change in the structure of hemoglobin and decreases its affinity for CO2 and H+, causing the release of both molecules.  
❌ Red blood cells (RBCs) in the lungs have higher chloride content:
Incorrect: Since H+ is released from hemoglobin in the lungs, HCO3- diffuses into the RBC in exchange for chloride (Cl-). Therefore, the Cl- concentration in the RBCs is lower in the lungs than in peripheral tissues.  
❌ Hemoglobin has the same affinity for CO2 in both tissues  :
Incorrect: The high oxygen concentration in the lungs causes oxygen to bind to hemoglobin. This binding causes a change in the structure of hemoglobin and decreases its affinity for CO2 and H+, causing the release of both molecules.  
❌ Hemoglobin has a higher affinity for H+ in the lungs:
Incorrect: The high oxygen concentration in the lungs causes oxygen to bind to hemoglobin. This binding causes a change in the structure of hemoglobin and decreases its affinity for CO2 and H+, causing the release of both molecules.

questions.text: A researcher is studying the physiology of vision. She identifies a cell responsible for processing light stimuli in bright environments and facilitating high-acuity vision. Which of the following cells was most likely identified?
questions.solution:
Photoreception is the process that describes how photoreceptors (e.g., rods, and cones) absorb light waves that enter the eye and convert them into electrical signals. These signals are then sent to the brain for visual processing.  

Rods are located in the periphery of the retina. They have a high concentration of rhodopsin, which makes rods sensitive to light. As a result, they allow for vision in dark conditions. In contrast, cones are located in the fovea, have a low sensitivity to light, and work best in bright conditions.   

Both rods and cones synapse with bipolar cells, which then synapse with the ganglion cells. Multiple rods can synapse with a single ganglion cell. In contrast, each cone synapses with its own distinct ganglion cells. As a result, cones provide high-acuity vision whereas rods provide low-acuity vision.   

Finally, the axons of the ganglion cells form the optic nerve and relay signals to the brain for processing and interpretation.   

Option Analysis

✅ Cone:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Rod:
Incorrect: Rods are photoreceptors responsible for low-acuity vision in dimly lit environments. In contrast, cones are the cell type responsible for high-acuity vision in bright environments.  
❌ Ganglion cell  :
Incorrect: Retinal ganglion cells are bridging neurons that connect photoreceptors, such as rods and cones, to the central nervous system. They are not directly responsible for processing light stimuli that reach the retina.  
❌ Bipolar cell  :
Incorrect: Bipolar cells are interneurons that connect photoreceptors (e.g., rods, cones) with the retinal ganglion cells. Bipolar cells are not directly responsible for processing light stimuli that reach the retina.  
❌ Vestibular hair cell  :
Incorrect: Vestibular hair cells are located in the inner ear and can detect changes in motor and position. They are not responsible for facilitating vision.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman requires a blood transfusion before elective surgery. Her blood type is found to be O negative. This patient can receive blood from which of the following type(s) of blood donors?

choices.text: Type A, B, AB, and O negative

questions.solution:
Every person has a unique blood group based on two classification systems: the ABO system and the Rh system. An individual is either Rh-positive, meaning they have the antigen on their red blood cells (and therefore, do not produce antibodies against it), or Rh-negative (and therefore, produces antibodies against it), meaning it is absent. The most significant Rh antigen is the D antigen.   

Rh-positive people can receive both Rh-negative and Rh-positive blood since they do not have antibodies against the Rh glycoprotein. But if an Rh-negative person receives Rh-positive blood, they could develop a hemolytic transfusion reaction. That's why hospitals do not typically give Rh-positive blood to Rh-negative patients. It can be done in an emergency because these individuals don't have naturally occurring Rh antibodies since they require exposure to Rh-positive RBCs (prior blood transfusion recipient or pregnant women carrying a fetus with Rh-positive blood). So, for someone who doesn’t have Rh antibodies, Rh-positive blood might be okay the first time, but then they'll develop antibodies and won't be able to receive Rh-positive blood in the future.  


Option Analysis

❌ Type AB positive  :
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. Type O negative blood group has A, AB, and Rh antibodies and can cause a hemolytic transfusion reaction, and type AB positive blood is transfused.  
❌ Type A, B, AB, and O negative  :
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect.  Type O negative blood group has A, AB, and Rh antibodies and can cause a hemolytic transfusion reaction after reacting with A and B antigens in type A, B AB blood.  
✅ Type O negative  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Type A and B positive  :
Incorrect:  This answer choice is incorrect. Type O negative blood group has A, AB, and Rh antibodies and can cause a hemolytic transfusion reaction after reacting with A and B antigens in type A and B blood.  
❌ Type O positive  :
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. Type O negative blood group has A, AB, and Rh antibodies and can cause a hemolytic transfusion reaction after reacting with Rh antigen in O-positive blood.

questions.text: Secondary hemostasis involves the activation of clotting factors that lead to the formation of a stable fibrin mesh. This can be done using the intrinsic pathway or the extrinsic pathway. Which of the following is true regarding the intrinsic pathway and extrinsic pathway?

choices.text: Tissue factor activates factor VII leading to the activation of the extrinsic pathway.
Both pathways are activated by same signals
Tissue factor activates factor XII leading to activation of the intrinsic pathway
Subendothelial collagen activates factor VII and leads to the activation of the intrinsic pathway.
The activation of the intrinsic pathway and the extrinsic pathway is dependent on each other

questions.solution:
Hemostasis is a process that controls bleeding and prevents blood loss. It is divided into two stages: the primary hemostasis, which involves the formation of a platelet plug; and, the secondary hemostasis, which involves the strengthening of the platelet plug by the fibrin mesh.  

Secondary hemostasis is also known as coagulation and is mediated by proteins called clotting factors, which become activated by proteolysis and induce coagulation and fibrin mesh formation.  

Activation of the coagulation can be done via two pathways, the intrinsic pathway, and the extrinsic pathway. Both pathways use different clotting factors, are activated independently, and reach a pathway in common called the common pathway which eventually leads to the formation of fibrin.  

The intrinsic pathway starts with the activation of factor XII by subendothelial collagen or activated platelets. Then activated factor XII (XIIa) activates factor XI, which then activates factor IX. Finally activated factor IX with activated factor VIII activates factor X which then continues in the common pathway.  

On the other hand, tissue factor (also known as factor III) activates factor VII in the extrinsic pathway, which then joins with calcium and activates factor X and continues the activation of the rest of the coagulation factors in the common pathway.  



Option Analysis

✅ Tissue factor activates factor VII leading to the activation of the extrinsic pathway.:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Both pathways are activated by same signals  :
Incorrect: While the intrinsic pathway is activated by subendothelial collagen and activated platelets, the extrinsic pathway is activated by tissue factors.  
❌ Tissue factor activates factor XII leading to activation of the intrinsic pathway:
Incorrect: Tissue factor activates factor VII and leads to activation of the extrinsic pathway, not the intrinsic pathway.
❌ Subendothelial collagen activates factor VII and leads to the activation of the intrinsic pathway.:
Incorrect: Subendothelial collagen activates factor XII leading to the activation of the intrinsic pathway. Factor VII is activated by tissue factors and is part of the extrinsic pathway.  
❌ The activation of the intrinsic pathway and the extrinsic pathway is dependent on each other  :
Incorrect: The activation of the intrinsic pathway and the extrinsic pathway is independent of each other.

questions.text: A study is done on the inflammatory response in the body. The study found that many immune cells and cytokines play a role in coordinating the immune response. One of the primary cells involved was macrophages. Which of the following is true about the roles of macrophages and the cytokines it produces?

choices.text: Macrophages secrete interleukin-8, which mediates fever
Macrophages secrete Interleukin-2 (IL-2) which stimulates other immune cells.
Macrophages secrete Interleukin-4 (IL-4) which mediates the differentiation of T-helper cells into Th2 cells.
Macrophages secrete IL-12 which activates natural killer cells and induce T-helper cells differentiation into Th2 cells.
Macrophages secrete IL-12 which activates natural killer cells and induce T-helper cells differentiation into Th1 cells.

questions.solution:
Macrophages are phagocytes that are part of innate immunity. They are one of the most important cells involved in inflammation. These cells are normally inactive, but once activated by various immune signals, they not only perform their functions of phagocytosis but also release many cytokines that modulate the immune response. The most notable cytokines produced by macrophages are Interleukin-1 (IL-1), interleukin-6 (IL-6), interleukin-12 (IL-12), and tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-a). These cytokines help in the defense against bacterial and viral infections, as well as in destroying tumor cells.  

  • IL-1, IL-6, and TNF-a are major proinflammatory cytokines. They target various immune cells but also act on the liver to produce acute phase reactants and on the brain to induce fever. Although their effects are important to the function of the immune system, these cytokines are also implicated in certain diseases, like the excessive secretion of IL-1 and TNF, leading to septic shock and multiorgan failure due to excessive generalized inflammation.  
  • TNF is one of the most potent cytokines.  As discussed earlier, it induces fever and increased acute phase reactants production and is also involved in the pathogenesis of sepsis. TNF also suppresses the appetite and is responsible for cachexia in cancer patients. Additionally, TNF causes vasodilation and increased vascular permeability, which allows immune cells to reach the inflammatory site.   

  • IL-1 (especially IL-1B) is mainly produced by macrophages but also by lymphocytes, natural killer cells, and fibroblasts. IL-1 actions include inducing fever, increased acute phase reactants production, and increased expression of adhesion molecules on the leukocytes and endothelial cells, thereby facilitating the leukocytes to reach the inflammatory site and increasing the production of other proinflammatory cytokines.   

  • IL-6 is mainly involved in stimulating fever and increasing the production of acute-phase reactants.   

  • IL-8 is a major chemoattractant for neutrophils to the site of inflammation  

  • IL-12 is mainly produced by macrophages and plays a crucial role in the defense against infections and cancers. It induces the differentiation of T-cells into Th1 cells, which then secretes cytokines (e.g. IFN-Y) that drive the immune system. IL-12 also activates natural killer cells and thereby activates cell-mediated immunity.   

Option Analysis

❌ Macrophages secrete interleukin-8, which mediates fever  :
Incorrect: Macrophages secrete IL-1, IL-6, and TNF, all of which mediate fever. It also secretes IL-8, a chemoattractant for neutrophils but not involved in inducing fever.  
❌ Macrophages secrete Interleukin-2 (IL-2) which stimulates other immune cells.  :
Incorrect: IL-2 is produced by T-cells, not macrophages.  
❌ Macrophages secrete Interleukin-4 (IL-4) which mediates the differentiation of T-helper cells into Th2 cells.   :
Incorrect: IL-4 is produced by Th2 cells, not by macrophages  
❌ Macrophages secrete IL-12 which activates natural killer cells and induce T-helper cells differentiation into Th2 cells.  :
Incorrect: IL-12 is secreted by macrophages, which activates natural killer cells. However, it induces the differentiation of T helper cells into Th1 cells, not Th2 cells.  
✅ Macrophages secrete IL-12 which activates natural killer cells and induce T-helper cells differentiation into Th1 cells.  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A researcher is studying cells produced by hematopoietic stem cells. One of the cells that is being studied is a lymphocyte that has CD3 and CD8 receptors on its surface. This type of cell originates from the bone marrow. Which of the following is the location where this cell differentiates to become a mature lymphocyte?
questions.solution:
The cell described in the question is a cytotoxic T lymphocyte. Lymphocytes are the main drivers of the adaptive immune response, and there are two types of lymphocytes, B lymphocytes (B cells) and T lymphocytes (T cells). Both lymphocytes originate from the hematopoietic stem cells in the bone marrow; however, they differentiate into mature forms in different organs.  

B cells become immature B cells from the common lymphoid progenitor cells (B cell precursors) and then mature into plasma cells in the lymph nodes and the spleen.   

On the other hand, T cell precursors in the bone marrow leave for the thymus, where they become mature T lymphocytes.  


Option Analysis

✅ Thymus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Lymph nodes  :
Incorrect: B-cells mature into plasma cells in the lymph nodes and the spleen, and T cells mature in the thymus.  
❌ Spleen:
Incorrect: B-cells mature into plasma cells in the lymph nodes and the spleen, whereas T cells mature in the thymus.  
❌ Bone marrow  :
Incorrect: T cell precursors are produced in the bone marrow from hematopoietic stem cells, which then leave the bone marrow to the thymus to mature into a T lymphocyte.  
❌ Bloodstream:
Incorrect: T cells mature in the thymus, not the bloodstream.

questions.text: A researcher investigates the pathway that activates the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system via the juxtaglomerular (JG) apparatus. Which of the following is a component of the juxtaglomerular apparatus?

choices.text: Macula densa in the distal convoluted tubule
The cotransport system (Na+/K+/2Cl−) of the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle
Principal cells of the collecting ducts
Alpha intercalated cells in the distal convoluted tubule

questions.solution:
The juxtaglomerular apparatus is a specialized structure that consists of a group of cells from the distal convoluted tubule or DCT (macula densa) and the glomerular afferent arteriole (mesangial cells and juxtaglomerular cells or JG cells, which are modified smooth muscle cells). Its primary function is to regulate blood pressure and the filtration rate of the glomerulus.
   
  • The JG cells secrete renin when the blood pressure in the arteriole falls by increased sympathetic tone (beta-1). Renin increases blood pressure via the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system.  
  • Macula densa are specialized chemoreceptor cells in the wall of the DCT which sense the delivery of sodium and chloride ions. When the blood pressure is low, it decreases renal perfusion and glomerular filtration of sodium and chloride ions, thus delivering to macula densa. These cells then secrete prostaglandins to signal JG cells to secrete renin.  
  • Lacis cells, extraglomerular mesangial cells, are flat and elongated cells near the macula densa. Their function remains unclear. 

Option Analysis

✅ Macula densa in the distal convoluted tubule:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ The cotransport system (Na+/K+/2Cl−) of the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle:
Incorrect: Thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle is not a part of the JG apparatus. The cotransport system is the site of action of loop diuretics (e.g. furosemide).  
❌ Principal cells of the collecting ducts:
Incorrect: Principal cells of the collecting ducts are not a part of the JG apparatus. When stimulated by aldosterone and antidiuretic hormone (ADH), these cells are involved in sodium and water reabsorption and potassium secretion when stimulated by aldosterone and antidiuretic hormone (ADH).  
❌ Alpha intercalated cells in the distal convoluted tubule:
Incorrect: Alpha intercalated cells in the distal convoluted tubule are not a part of the JG apparatus. These cells are involved in hydrogen (H+) ion secretion when stimulated by aldosterone by upregulating H+ ATPase activity.  
❌ Cells of proximal convoluted tubule:
Incorrect: Cells of proximal convoluted tubule are not a part of the JG apparatus.

questions.text: A 4-month-old male infant is brought to the pediatrician by his mother for follow-up. The mother asks the pediatrician about the vaccines that her child must receive. He was diagnosed with severe-combined immunodeficiency (SCID) at two months. Which of the following vaccines are contraindicated in this child?
questions.solution:
Live attenuated vaccines are a form of active immunization. Live attenuated vaccines are one type of whole-cell vaccine in which the recipient is injected with a live form of a pathogen. In live-attenuated vaccines, the pathogen is weakened but not killed; therefore, it is less pathogenic but can replicate inside the host’s body. The replicating pathogen then activates the adaptive immune system that involves both the humoral and the cellular immune systems, resulting in a strong immune response nearly as strong as a typical infection.  This is the primary advantage of live-attenuated vaccines because the immunity produced by such vaccines is the strongest and longest-lasting of all types of vaccination and can last up to several decades after a single immunization.  

However, live-attenuated vaccines have some side effects. Because the living form of the pathogen is injected, it can, in some cases, cause disease, especially in patients with low immunity (e.g., patients with AIDS and patients with severe combined immunodeficiency). Therefore, live-attenuated vaccines are contraindicated in patients with immunodeficiencies.   

Examples of live-attenuated vaccines include the Mumps-Measles-Rubella vaccine, rotavirus vaccine, intranasal influenza vaccine, chickenpox, smallpox vaccine, and yellow fever vaccine.   

Option Analysis

✅ Rotavirus vaccine  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hepatitis B vaccine  :
Incorrect: Hepatitis B is a subunit vaccine that can be administered to patients with immunodeficiencies.  
❌ Diphtheria-tetanus-acellular pertussis (DTaP) vaccine  :
Incorrect: DTaP is not contraindicated in patients with immunodeficiencies because it is not a live-attenuated vaccine.  
❌ Streptococcus pneumoniae vaccine  :
Incorrect: The Streptococcus pneumoniae vaccine is a subunit vaccine that is not contraindicated in patients with immunodeficiencies.  
❌ Intramuscular influenza vaccine  :
Incorrect: Intramuscular influenza is a killed vaccine that can be safely given to patients with immunodeficiencies.

questions.text: To understand the process of glomerular filtration, a group of researchers examine several molecules which cannot undergo filtration. One molecule that does not undergo filtration is albumin. Which of the following contributes to the glomerulus' inability to freely filter albumin?

choices.text: Negative electric charge of the basement membrane
Positive electrical charge of the basement membrane
Negative electrical charge of the endothelial cells
The size of the pores in endothelial cells
Negative electrical charge of podocyte foot processes.

questions.solution:
The glomerular filtration system barrier comprises three structures that allow blood filtration but prevent large molecules like erythrocytes and plasma proteins from being filtered.  

  1. Endothelial cells: These cells have pores that allow the passage of fluid and plasma electrolytes and proteins but prevent the passage of larger molecules like erythrocytes.   
  2. The basement membrane: The basement membrane has smaller pores that only allow the passage of certain substances (e.g., sodium, water) but are too small for plasma proteins to pass through (e.g. albumin). Additionally, the basement membrane is negatively charged, preventing negatively charged molecules (e.g. albumin) from being filtered.   
  3. The podocytes: are specialized epithelial cells that wrap around the basement membrane. These cells contain filtration slits, tiny gaps that form a barrier against the filtration of large molecules, including proteins.   


Option Analysis

✅ Negative electric charge of the basement membrane  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Positive electrical charge of the basement membrane:
Incorrect: The basement membrane is negatively charged and thus repels negatively-charged molecules, including albumin.  
❌ Negative electrical charge of the endothelial cells  :
Incorrect: The endothelial cells are not negatively charged
❌ The size of the pores in endothelial cells  :
Incorrect: The pores in the endothelial cells are large enough to filter albumin freely.  
❌ Negative electrical charge of podocyte foot processes.  :
Incorrect: Podocytes are not negatively charged.

questions.text: A group of investigators are studying the physiologic changes of urine as it passes through the distal convoluted tubule (DCT). Which of the following is true regarding the functions and transporters of DCT?

choices.text: Parathyroid hormone stimulates the Ca2+/Na exchange on the DCT
65-80% of sodium is reabsorbed in the DCT
Sodium hydrogen exchange is regulated by aldosterone
Na-K-2Cl channel is located on the apical surface of the DCT

questions.solution:
The distal convoluted tubule (DCT) is lined by tubule cells. It is divided into:

Early DCT: Channels and their functions are summarized below:
  1. Na+Cl- cotransporter (on the apical surface): Moves sodium down its concentration gradient and uses this energy to move one chloride ion. Cl- moves into the interstitium down its concentration gradient via basolateral chloride channels. 
  2. Calcium channels on the apical surface 
  3. Na-Ca2+ channels on the basolateral surface regulated by parathyroid hormone: moves sodium into the tubular cells to increase the gradient for calcium reabsorption. 
  4. Na+-K+ ATPase: pumps 3 Na+ out of the cell and lets 2 K+ ions into the cell from the interstitium, which helps to maintain low intracellular sodium levels. 
Normally, the early DCT reabsorbs about 5% of the filtered sodium, but this reabsorption is load-dependent.
 

Late DCT and collecting duct consists of principal cells and α-intercalated cells dispersed among the tubule cells.

  1.  Principal cells: 
  • ENaC that allows sodium into the cell, and
  • a potassium channel that allows potassium into the lumen
  • Na/K ATPase pump on the basolateral surface

      2.  Intercalated cells have:

  • H+/ATPase: uses ATP to pump hydrogen into the tubule against its concentration gradient
  • Hydrogen potassium ATPase: uses ATP to push 1 hydrogen into the tubule in exchange for 1 potassium, both against their concentration gradients
  • Na/K ATPase pump on the basolateral surface

The late DCT and collecting duct is hormonally regulated by aldosterone, which acts on ENaC, ATP-dependent potassium pump, and the Na-K ATPase transporter.  

Option Analysis

❌ It is impermeable to sodium:
Incorrect: The thin descending loop of Henle is impermeable to sodium. The early distal convoluted tubule is impermeable to water.  
✅ Parathyroid hormone stimulates the Ca2+/Na exchange on the DCT:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ 65-80% of sodium is reabsorbed in the DCT:
Incorrect: Around 67% of the sodium that gets filtered into the tubular fluid is reabsorbed in the PCT. Only 5-10% of filtered sodium is reabsorbed in the DCT.  
❌ Sodium hydrogen exchange is regulated by aldosterone:
Incorrect: Sodium is reabsorbed in exchange for hydrogen and potassium ions excretion in the collecting duct and is regulated by aldosterone.  
❌ Na-K-2Cl channel is located on the apical surface of the DCT:
Incorrect: Na-K-2Cl channel is located on the apical surface of the thick ascending loop of Henle.

questions.text: A 71-year-old man presents to the emergency department due to shortness of breath with exertion and difficulty sleeping. The patient has experienced progressive shortness of breath over the past several weeks to the point where he can no longer walk to the bathroom without becoming winded. He has woken up multiple times per night with shortness of breath and has been propping himself up with several pillows to sleep. Past medical history includes hypertension, hyperlipidemia, diabetes, a 25-pack-year smoking history, and heart failure (ejection fraction 14%). He is adherent to prescribed medications, including furosemide. Temperature is 36.1°C (97.0°F), pulse is 101/min, respirations are 24/min, blood pressure is 101/82 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 90% on room air. Physical examination demonstrates an additional heart sound heard just after S2, jugular venous distension, diffuse rales on auscultation of the lungs, and pitting edema of the lower extremities. Which of the following findings is most likely present in this patient?

choices.text: Decreased brain and atrial natriuretic peptide levels

questions.solution:
This patient presents with features of left ventricular dysfunction (e.g., dyspnea, orthopnea, pulmonary edema), right ventricular failure (e.g., jugular venous distention, lower extremity edema), and heart failure with reduced ejection fraction.   

In patients with decompensated heart failure, neuroendocrine mechanisms contribute to a vicious cycle in an attempt to restore hemodynamics. Diminished cardiac output fails to perfuse vital organs like the kidneys, prompting activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS). Activation of RAAS promotes increased levels of angiotensin II, a potent vasoconstrictor, and aldosterone, which increases sodium and water retention. Together, these two sequelae of the RAAS system also lead to increased afterload. Concurrently, the diminished cardiac output manifests with activation of the sympathetic nervous system, which further increases arteriolar tone and afterload.  

Over time, the compensatory mechanisms of the heart (e.g. secretion of the diuretic and vasodilatory peptides BNP/ANP) fail to compensate for this overactivation of the sympathetic nervous and RAAS systems, thus lending towards a vicious cycle of increasing afterload, strain on the left ventricle, and decompensated heart failure.

 

Option Analysis

✅ Increased levels of angiotensin II:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Increased renal perfusion:
Incorrect: Decreased, not increased, renal perfusion is observed in patients with decompensated heart failure. Decreased renal perfusion results in increased activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system, which further worsens the symptoms of heart failure.    
❌ Cor pulmonale:
Incorrect: Cor pulmonale refers to isolated right heart failure. In contrast, this patient presents with clinical findings of left ventricular dysfunction. 
❌ Increased stroke volume :
Incorrect: Stroke volume may slightly increase in early heart failure as a compensatory mechanism. However, later in the disease, stroke volume becomes profoundly diminished. 
❌ Decreased brain and atrial natriuretic peptide levels:
Incorrect: Both brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) and atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP) are protein molecules secreted by the atria and ventricles in response to stretch. These molecules serve to counteract the negative effects of heart failure by promoting diuresis and vasodilation. Both of these peptides are elevated in patients with decompensated heart failure.

questions.text: The conduction of the action potential in the mammalian heart is examined. The total time of action potential to reach from the sinoatrial (SA) node to the ventricles is estimated to be around 220 ms. However, it was noted that the action potential travels in certain areas of the heart faster than other areas. Which of the following represents the velocity of conduction of action potentials in the heart from the fastest to the slowest?

choices.text: His-Purkinje system > atria > ventricles > AV node
Atria > ventricles > His-Purkinje system > AV node
Ventricles > atria > His-Purkinje system > AV node
AV node > ventricles > atria > His-Purkinje system
AV node > atria > ventricles > His-Purkinje system

questions.solution:
Myocardial action potentials start in the pacemaker cells (most of the time in the sinoatrial [SA] node) and then propagate to the atria and the ventricles. The propagation of action potentials within the heart is rapid (around 220 ms) which allows the action potential to spread to the entire heart very fast and allows for coordinated contraction of the muscle.

The conduction of the action potential from one cell to another is due to the presence of gap junctions, which allow certain ions to flow from one depolarizing cell to the adjacent cell and cause depolarization in it.

However, the conduction velocity in the heart actually varies in different locations. After spontaneous depolarization in the SA node, the action potential spreads throughout the atria through the atrial conduction fibers at a rate of 1 ms, allowing the atria to contract together.

After that, the wave reaches the atrioventricular (AV) node in order to reach the ventricles. The AV node has the lowest conduction velocity in the entire heart at a rate of 0.1-0.5 ms. This is beneficial to allow the atria to contract and fill the ventricles before ventricular depolarization and contraction starts.

After that, the conduction travels through the His-Purkinje system, which has the highest conduction velocity of the heart (around 2-4 ms). This fast conduction allows the depolarization wave to reach both ventricles at the same time, allowing for coordinated contraction of the ventricles. Finally, within the ventricles, the conduction velocity is around 1 ms.  


Option Analysis

✅ His-Purkinje system > atria > ventricles > AV node:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Atria > ventricles > His-Purkinje system > AV node  :
Incorrect: The fastest area of conduction in the heart is the His-Purkinje system.  
❌ Ventricles > atria > His-Purkinje system > AV node:
Incorrect: The fastest area of conduction in the heart is the His-Purkinje system.  
❌ AV node > ventricles > atria > His-Purkinje system:
Incorrect: The fastest area of conduction in the heart is the His-Purkinje system, while the AV node is the slowest.  
❌ AV node > atria > ventricles > His-Purkinje system:
Incorrect: The fastest area of conduction in the heart is the His-Purkinje system, while the AV node is the slowest.

questions.text: During pregnancy, multiple hormones are released to maintain pregnancy and prepare the mammary glands for lactation. Which of the following combinations of hormonal changes occur during parturition?
questions.solution:
During pregnancy, the placenta releases human placental lactogen and progesterone, while the anterior pituitary gland releases prolactin. All three of these hormones stimulate the growth of more glandular tissue and prepare the alveolar cells to produce milk.

However, even though the breasts can make milk by mid-pregnancy, the high levels of progesterone associated with pregnancy prevent milk letdown.

Prolactin helps induce and maintain lactation and inhibits reproductive function. With delivery, there is an abrupt decline in estrogen and progesterone serum levels, which disinhibits prolactin. These changes lead to the initiation of lactation. The intensity and duration of subsequent lactation are controlled, in large part, by the repetitive stimulus of suckling and emptying of milk from the breast. Likewise, oxytocin levels also increase to assist in milk letdown and promote uterine contractions.  

Option Analysis

❌ Increase estrogen and progesterone:
Incorrect: With delivery, there is an abrupt decline in estrogen and progesterone serum levels.  
❌ Increase estrogen and prolactin:
Incorrect: With delivery, there is an abrupt decline in estrogen and progesterone serum levels, which disinhibits prolactin synthesis.  
❌ Increase progesterone and prolactin:
Incorrect: With delivery, there is an abrupt decline in estrogen and progesterone serum levels, which disinhibits prolactin synthesis.
✅ Decrease progesterone and increase prolactin  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Decrease oxytocin and prolactin:
Incorrect: With delivery, there is an abrupt decline in estrogen and progesterone serum levels, which disinhibits prolactin synthesis. Oxytocin levels also increase to assist in milk letdown and promote uterine contractions.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old man is seen by a pulmonologist for exercise-related shortness of breath. The patient states that after 10 minutes of intense workout, he has to stop for at least 40 seconds to catch his breath. The patient has not had any episodes of fever, cough, or weight changes. A pulmonary function test is ordered and partial results are shown below. What is the functional residual capacity of this patient?
 
Tidal volume   
500 mL  
Residual volume
1200 mL  
Expiratory reserve volume   
1500 mL  
Inspiratory reserve volume  
3000 mL
questions.solution:
Certain lung volumes can be measured by spirometry. These physiologic lung volumes can be combined to determine certain capacities. Functional residual capacity (FRC) is the volume of gas in the lungs that is left after normal quiet expiration. It is a sum of expiratory reserve volume (air that can still be breathed out after normal expiration) and residual volume (air in the lungs after maximal expiration). In a normal, average-sized adult, the FRC is about 2500 mL. It is usually increased in patients with obstructive lung pathology (e.g., chronic obstructive pulmonary disease) due to an increase in residual lung volume.
 

Option Analysis

❌ 5000 mL  :
Incorrect: Vital capacity is the maximum volume of gas that can be expired after a maximum inspiration. It is a sum of inspiratory reserve volume, tidal volume, and expiratory reserve volume, which, in this patient, is 5000 mL.  
✅ 2700 mL:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ 3500 mL  :
Incorrect: Inspiratory capacity is the volume of gas that can be breathed in after normal exhalation. It is a sum of inspiratory reserve volume and tidal volume, which, in this patient, is 3500 mL.  
❌ 6200 mL:
Incorrect: Total lung capacity is the volume of gas present in the lungs after a maximal inspiration. It is a sum of inspiratory reserve volume, tidal volume, expiratory reserve volume, and residual volume, which, in this patient, is 6200 mL.  
❌ 300 mL  :
Incorrect: This measured volume is the difference between expiratory reserve volume and residual volume. This does not refer to any specific capacity.

questions.text: The human body obtains vitamin D either from the diet or from sun exposure. Which of the following represents the conversion of vitamin D derived from dietary animal sources to its active form in the kidney?
questions.solution:
Vitamin D is a steroid hormone. Active vitamin D starts out as either vitamin D2 (ergocalciferol), which is derived from dietary plant sources, or vitamin D3 (cholecalciferol), which is either derived from dietary animal products but can also be made in skin cells that are exposed to sunlight.  

When vitamin D2 and D3 reach the small intestine, they get packaged along with bile salts into micelles, which get absorbed into the enterocytes. They are then incorporated into chylomicrons, which travel through the lymphatic system to enter the blood. In the blood, they bind vitamin D-binding proteins, which take them to the liver. In the hepatic endoplasmic reticulum, vitamin D2 and D3 are converted to 25-hydroxy ergocalciferol and 25-hydroxycholecalciferol, respectively, by the enzyme 25-hydroxylase. These re enter the blood and travel to the proximal tubules of the kidneys, where the enzyme 1-alpha-hydroxylase converts 25-hydroxy ergocalciferol and 25-hydroxycholecalciferol to 1,25-dihydroxy ergocalciferol and 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol, respectively, which are the active forms of vitamin D.  

In the skin, keratinocytes produce 7-dehydrocholesterol, a precursor molecule for cholecalciferol. When the skin is exposed to sunlight, 7-dehydrocholesterol absorbs ultraviolet B radiation and is converted to previtamin D3 via photolysis. Then, heat generated by cellular metabolic activities causes the previtamin D3 molecule to isomerize (change its shape) to form vitamin D3 or cholecalciferol. The vitamin D3 molecules then enter the blood, and follow the same path as dietary cholecalciferol to the liver, and then to the kidneys.  


Option Analysis

❌ Cholecalciferol → 25-hydroxycholecalciferol  :
Incorrect: The conversion of cholecalciferol to 25-hydroxycholecalciferol by 25-hydroxylase takes place in the liver.  
✅ 25-hydroxycholecalciferol → 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Ergocalciferol → 25-hydroxyergocalciferol   :
Incorrect: The conversion of ergocalciferol to 25-hydroxyergocalciferol by 25-hydroxylase takes place in the liver. Ergocalciferol is derived from dietary plant sources.  
❌ 7-dehydrocholesterol → cholecalciferol  :
Incorrect: The conversion of 7-dehydrocholesterol to cholecalciferol (vitamin D3) takes place in the skin under the influence of ultraviolet B (UVB) rays.  
❌ 25-hydroxycholecalciferol → 24,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol  :
Incorrect: The deactivation of 25-hydroxycholecalciferol to 24,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol occurs in the kidneys and is stimulated by high concentrations of 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol. 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D is the active form of vitamin D.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man requires a blood transfusion following significant bleeding after a motor vehicle accident. His blood type is found to be AB positive. This patient can receive blood from which of the following type(s) of blood donors?

choices.text: Type A and type B only
Type A, type B, and type AB
Type A, type B, type AB, and type O

questions.solution:
Every person has a unique blood group based on two classification systems: the ABO system and the Rh system.  

The immune system produces antibodies against the glycoproteins that a patient doesn’t have. The ABO system refers to the type of glycoproteins found on a person’s red blood cells. It can be either type A, type B, type A and B glycoproteins, or neither, called type O blood. People with type A blood have antibodies to type B blood, and people with type B blood have antibodies to type A blood. People with blood type AB don’t have antibodies to type A or type B blood, so they can receive blood from any blood type. Thus, people with blood type AB are universal recipients. However, since their red blood cells have both type A and type B antigens, they can’t donate blood to anyone except other AB blood type individuals.  


On the other hand, people with type O blood have antibodies to both A and B glycoproteins, so they cannot receive type A, type B, or type AB blood. But since their red blood cells don’t have type A or type B antigens, they can donate blood to anyone. That is, they’re universal donors.  

Option Analysis

❌ Type AB only  :
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. People with blood type AB don’t have antibodies to type A or type B blood so they can receive blood from any of the blood types.  
❌ Type O only  :
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. People with blood type AB don’t have antibodies to type A or type B blood so they can receive blood from any of the blood types.  
❌ Type A and type B only  :
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. People with blood type AB don’t have antibodies to type A or type B blood so they can receive blood from any of the blood types.  
❌ Type A, type B, and type AB  :
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. People with blood type AB don’t have antibodies to type A or type B so they can receive blood from any blood type.  
✅ Type A, type B, type AB, and type O  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A study is done to determine the different cells in the blood and their function. A peripheral blood smear was taken and examined, and the image is shown below. The cell identified by the arrow does which of the following functions?

choices.text: Promote class switching for antibodies produced by B-cells

questions.solution:
Eosinophils are leukocytes that are part of the innate immune system. They are granulocytes that contain many granules in their cytoplasm. These granules can help differentiate eosinophils because they stain pink with eosin stain. Eosinophils are larger than neutrophils, and they are characterized by their bilobed nucleus.   

Eosinophils have many functions in the immune system. They are phagocytes like neutrophils. These cells have specific functions in defending against helminthic infections due to their ability to recognize and phagocyte these infections. Additionally, they have the ability to phagocyte immune complexes which help clear them from the tissues. Finally, eosinophils are involved in allergic reactions, where they degranulate and release histamine and many proinflammatory cytokines when an allergen enters the body.


Option Analysis

✅ Defend against helminthic infections  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Defend against viral infections  :
Incorrect: Eosinophils are not involved in the defense against viral infections.  
❌ Promote class switching for antibodies produced by B-cells  :
Incorrect: T-helper lymphocytes are responsible for inducing class switching in the antibodies produced by B-cells. This is not a function of eosinophils.  
❌ Kill neoplastic cells   :
Incorrect: Eosinophils are not involved in detecting and killing neoplastic cells.
❌ Produce antibodies  :
Incorrect: Eosinophils do not produce antibodies.

questions.text: A study is organized on the structure of antibodies to determine the role of the different parts in it. An illustration of the structure of an antibody is shown below. Which of the following is true regarding the region marked with the letter A?

choices.text: It determines the isotype of the antibody.
It is made of both heavy chains and light chains.
It is made of light chains only.
It determines the idiotype of the antibody.
It is the antigen binding site of the antibody.

questions.solution:
Antibodies are a crucial component of the adaptive immune system that is produced and secreted by B-cells. There are 5 different isotypes of antibodies which are IgM, IgD, IgG, IgA, and IgE. Each antibody is specific for only one antigen.  

The structure of the antibody is made up of both heavy and light chains and is divided into 2 fragments: the fragment antigen binding (Fab region) and the constant fragment (Fc region).  

The Fab region is the area for antigen binding and is made of both heavy and light chains. It determines the idiotype of the antibody, where it is unique for only one antigen.  

The Fc region determines the isotype of the antibody and is made up only of heavy chains.  

Antibodies can be found attached to B-cells and also secreted in the blood. The two types of antibodies that are found on naïve B cells are IgM and IgD.  

Option Analysis

✅ It determines the isotype of the antibody.  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ It is made of both heavy chains and light chains.  :
Incorrect: The constant (Fc) region in the antibody (marked with the letter A) is only made of heavy chains.
❌ It is made of light chains only.  :
Incorrect: The constant (Fc) region in the antibody (marked with the letter A) is only made of heavy chains.  
❌ It determines the idiotype of the antibody.  :
Incorrect: The constant (Fc) region of the antibody determines the isotope of the antibody, while the fragment antigen binding region (Fab region) determines the idiotype of the antibody (marked with the letter B).  
❌ It is the antigen binding site of the antibody.  :
Incorrect: The fragment antigen binding region (Fab region) is the site for antigen binding (marked with the letter B).

questions.text: A study is performed to determine the volume of water found in different body compartments. In the study, an indicator-dilution method using labeled inulin was used. The volume calculated from the inulin-dilution method represents one of the following?
questions.solution:
The human body comprises approximately 60% water, which is distributed into different compartments: the intracellular compartment, interstitial fluid, and plasma.  

To measure the volume of different compartments, the indicator-dilution method is used. Where a measurable substance is injected into the body and distributed in the compartment of interest, the volume of that specific compartment can be measured based on the equation: Volume (V) = Amount (substance injected)/Concentration). Different substances can be used to calculate the volume of different compartments based on the features of that substance:  

  • The extracellular fluid volume: Labeled inulin or mannitol can be used to measure the extracellular fluid volume directly. These substances distribute between the plasma and the interstitial fluid but are too large to cross the cell membrane.  
  • The plasma volume: radiolabeled albumin can measure the plasma volume as it only stays in the plasma and does not cross to the interstitial fluid or the intracellular space.  
  • The interstitial fluid cannot be measured directly but can be calculated indirectly by subtracting the plasma volume from the extracellular fluid volume.  
  • Total body water (TBW): TBW can be measured using radiolabeled titrated water, which distributes in all three compartments.  
  • The intracellular fluid volume: Cannot be measured directly but indirectly by subtracting the extracellular fluid volume from the total body water.  

Option Analysis

✅ The extracellular fluid volume  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ The plasma volume  :
Incorrect: Inulin distributes between plasma and interstitial fluid; therefore, the volume calculation will account for both, not just plasma volume.  
❌ The intracellular fluid volume  :
Incorrect: Inulin is a large molecule that does not diffuse across cell membranes. It, therefore, measures the extracellular volume.  
❌ The interstitial fluid volume  :
Incorrect: Inulin distributes between plasma and interstitial fluid and measures both fluid volumes, not only the interstitial fluid volume.  
❌ Total body fluid volume  :
Incorrect: Because inulin is a large molecule, it cannot measure the intracellular volume as it does not diffuse across cell membranes. Radioactive titrated water distributes in the intracellular and extracellular compartments and can be used to measure the total body water.

questions.text: A pathologist evaluates the process of sperm production in the testes. It is noticed that cells at different levels of development are taken from the seminiferous tubules. Which of the following is true regarding spermatogenesis?

choices.text: Secondary spermatocytes undergo meiosis II to give rise to spermatids
Spermatogonia undergo meiosis I to give rise to primary spermatocyte
Primary spermatocytes have a haploid number of chromosomes (23 chromosomes)
Secondary spermatocytes have a haploid number of chromosomes (23 chromosomes) and one set of chromatids
Secondary spermatocytes undergo mitosis to give rise to spermatids

questions.solution:
Spermatogenesis is the process by which sperms are produced. It begins in puberty under the influence of the pulsatile secretions of gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), and luteinizing hormone (LH).

Spermatogenesis takes place in the seminiferous tubules and begins with spermatogonia. Each spermatogonium undergoes mitosis to give rise to two daughter cells, each having a diploid number of chromosomes (46 chromosomes). One daughter cell becomes a spermatogonium again, and the other daughter cell becomes a primary spermatocyte.

Primary spermatocytes begin moving towards the center of the seminiferous tubules and undergo meiosis one (meiosis I), giving rise to two daughter cells called secondary spermatocytes. Secondary spermatocytes have a haploid number of chromosomes (23 chromosomes) but two sets of chromatids.

Secondary spermatocytes then undergo meiosis 2 (meiosis II) to give rise to spermatids. Spermatids have a haploid number of chromosomes (23 chromosomes) but only one set of chromatids. Finally, the spermatids enter the lumen of the seminiferous tubules and undergo spermiogenesis, which involves structural changes of the spermatids (e.g., acquiring a tail and an acrosomal cap) to become sperm.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Secondary spermatocytes undergo meiosis II to give rise to spermatids:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Spermatogonia undergo meiosis I to give rise to primary spermatocyte:
Incorrect: Spermatogonia undergoes mitosis (not meiosis) and gives rise to two daughter cells, each of which has 46 chromosomes. One of the daughter cells becomes a primary spermatocyte.  
❌ Primary spermatocytes have a haploid number of chromosomes (23 chromosomes):
Incorrect: Primary spermatocytes have a diploid number of chromosomes (46 chromosomes).  
❌ Secondary spermatocytes have a haploid number of chromosomes (23 chromosomes) and one set of chromatids:
Incorrect: Secondary spermatocytes have a haploid number of chromosomes (23 chromosomes) and two sets of chromatids. They undergo meiosis II to give rise to spermatids with a haploid number of chromosomes (23 chromosomes) and one set of chromatids.  
❌ Secondary spermatocytes undergo mitosis to give rise to spermatids:
Incorrect: Secondary spermatocytes undergo meiosis II (not mitosis) to give rise to spermatids.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman comes to the office because of trouble sleeping at night. For the past 2 months, the patient has awakened completely soaked in sweat almost every night. She also reports dyspareunia and “little to no menses” for the past 8 months. She works as an accountant and finds it difficult to concentrate. Past medical history is significant for hypertension. Current medications include lisinopril and over-the-counter multivitamin medications. The patient does not use tobacco, alcohol or illicit drugs. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 140/85 mmHg. Physical examination is noncontributory. Pelvic examination reveals a small anteverted uterus and minimal vaginal rugations. Urine pregnancy test is negative. Serum TSH is 3.2 µU/mL. An elevation in which of the following laboratory values would most likely be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with amenorrhea, hot flashes, night sweats, dyspareunia and difficulty concentrating at work, in combination with physical examinations findings of minimal vaginal rugations, is consistent with menopause.

Menopause is defined as absent menses for 12 months in women over 45 years of age. It usually sets in around age 50 and is preceded by an average of 4 years of hormonal and physiologic changes termed perimenopause. During the menopausal transition, FSH levels increase due to the lack of negative feedback from estrogen and progesterone. This period is characterized by amenorrhea, anovulation, hot flashes, and vaginal dryness. Menopause is a clinical diagnosis, and an elevated FSH is not necessary to make it, though it is a reliable clinical indicator. Menopausal symptoms before the age of 40 is abnormal and is usually secondary to primary ovarian insufficiency.

There are a number of long-term effects of estrogen deficiency, including osteoporosis and cardiovascular disease.  

Option Analysis

❌ Progesterone:
Incorrect: Menopause is characterized by decreased levels of progesterone due to decreasing ovarian function.
❌ Estradiol:
Incorrect: Menopause is characterized by gradual decline in the levels of estradiol due to decreasing ovarian function. Estradiol is not a reliable indicator of menopause due to typical fluctuations.
✅ Follicle-stimulating hormone:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Testosterone :
Incorrect: Testosterone levels also decrease with menopause because less estrogen is produced by ovaries, so less is then aromatized to testosterone.
❌ Prolactin:
Incorrect: Serum prolactin levels are elevated in the case of a prolactinoma, which is characterized by additional symptoms of galactorrhea and headache, not seen in this patient. Moreover, prolactin levels are less significantly changed than FSH levels during menopause.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man presents to the emergency department due to increasing shortness of breath over the past several weeks. The patient can no longer climb a flight of stairs or walk one city block without becoming short of breath. Past medical history includes diabetes and hypertension. The patient has not seen a physician in years and is currently not on any medications. He smokes one pack of cigarettes per day. Temperature is 36.1°C (97.0°F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 22/min, blood pressure is 201/97 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 93% on room air. Physical examination demonstrates bibasilar rales and a palpable S4 heart sound. Bedside point of care ultrasound demonstrates left ventricular hypertrophy. Which of the following best describes the likely physiologic parameters regarding this patient’s left ventricular cardiac function?
questions.solution:
This patient with long-standing, untreated hypertension presents with clinical features of heart failure. Specifically, the presence of an S4 gallop and evidence of left ventricular hypertrophy on ultrasound suggest left ventricular diastolic dysfunction.  

Diastolic heart failure is most commonly due to cardiac hypertrophy from long-standing, untreated hypertension. Diastolic heart failure presents with the same clinical features as systolic heart failure. Echocardiographic findings generally demonstrate a preserved EF and a normal EDV. Patients with diastolic heart failure will also have decreased compliance (increased end diastolic pressure) due to stiff ventricular walls. Other etiologies of diastolic heart failure include infiltrative diseases, such as amyloidosis, sarcoidosis, and post-radiation fibrosis.    


In contrast, systolic heart failure is most commonly due to ischemia or myocardial infarction, which causes decreased cardiac contractility that leads to systolic dysfunction. Other causes of systolic heart failure include etiologies of dilated cardiomyopathy, such as chronic alcohol use, coxsackie B virus infection, chronic cocaine use, and Chagas disease. The inability of the heart to effectively pump blood forward through the circulation results in clinical features of left-sided heart failure, such as pulmonary edema (e.g., bibasilar crackles, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea) and an S3 heart sound (ventricular gallop). Systolic heart failure often progresses to right-sided heart failure, resulting in jugular venous distention (JVD), pitting edema, and hepatic congestion. Echocardiography in systolic heart failure typically shows an increased end diastolic volume (EDV), decreased contractility (or wall motion abnormalities), and reduced ejection fraction (EF).  

Option Analysis

✅  Ejection fraction (EF)  End diastolic volume (EDV)  Compliance  Normal  Normal  ↓ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌  Ejection fraction (EF)  End diastolic volume (EDV)  Compliance  ↓  ↑ ↑:
Incorrect: These findings are indicative of systolic heart failure, not diastolic heart failure. 
❌  Ejection fraction (EF)  End diastolic volume (EDV)  Compliance  Normal  ↑↑ :
Incorrect: These findings are indicative of a recovered ejection fraction or impending heart failure (compensatory). 
❌  Ejection fraction (EF)  End diastolic volume (EDV)  Compliance  Normal  Normal  Normal :
Incorrect: These findings describe healthy cardiac function without evidence of underlying pathology. This patient has multiple clinical features that suggest underlying diastolic heart failure. 
❌  Ejection fraction (EF)  End diastolic volume (EDV)  Compliance ↓ ↑ Normal :
Incorrect: These findings may be present in cases of neurogenic shock, wherein decreased sympathetic tone manifests with a decrease in ejection fraction and subsequent increase in EDV.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presents to his primary care provider for a follow-up visit. The patient was diagnosed with systolic heart failure several years ago. He has been experiencing significant edema in the bilateral lower extremities. An increase in which of the following factors is most likely responsible for this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient was diagnosed with systolic heart failure (now called heart failure with reduced ejection fraction). In this condition, blood cannot be pumped efficiently and back up into the capillaries. As a result, there is an increase in capillary hydrostatic pressure, which leads to peripheral edema.

The net movement of water across capillaries is described using the Starling equation. The formula is as follows:
 
 
The equation states there are two types of forces acting within, and outside, the capillaries, that determine fluid movement. The capillary hydrostatic pressure (Pc) pushes fluid out of the capillaries, whereas the interstitial hydrostatic pressure (Pi) pushes fluids into the capillaries. There are also osmotic pressures and these forces pull fluids in their direction. The capillary oncotic pressure (πc) pulls fluid into the capillaries, whereas the interstitial oncotic pressure (πi) pulls fluid into the interstitium.

The filtration coefficient (Kf) is not a force but instead determines the water permeability of the capillary walls. Lastly, there is the reflection coefficient (σ), which describes the capillary’s permeability to proteins. A coefficient of 1 means the capillary is impermeable to protein, whereas 0 means it is completely permeable.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Capillary hydrostatic pressure  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Interstitial lymphatic drainage  :
Incorrect: A decrease in interstitial lymphatic drainage results in interstitial fluid accumulation (lymphedema). Certain parasitic infections (e.g. filariasis) can block this lymphatic drainage, resulting in edema. It is not a significant cause of peripheral edema in patients with heart failure.  
❌ Capillary oncotic pressure  :
Incorrect: The Starling equation helps determine the direction of fluid flow across capillaries. An increase in capillary oncotic pressure would pull fluid from the interstitium into the capillaries, thereby reducing peripheral edema.  
❌ Interstitial oncotic pressure:
Incorrect: An increase in interstitial oncotic pressure can increase fluid outflow from the capillaries. However, given the patient’s history of systolic heart failure, he likely has poor cardiac output and backing up of blood into the capillaries. These changes would lead to an increase in capillary hydrostatic pressure, not interstitial oncotic pressure.  
❌ Capillary permeability  :
Incorrect: Inflammatory conditions (e.g., infection, vasculitis) and burns can increase capillary permeability and enable more fluid to extravasate into the interstitial space. However, capillary permeability is not typically affected in heart failure.

questions.text: An autopsy is performed to determine the cause of sudden death in a 23-year-old athlete while playing baseball. The horizontal section of the heart at the level of the ventricles reveals asymmetric ventricular septal hypertrophy. If this patient had a pre-participation sports screening, cardiac auscultation would have likely revealed a murmur that increased with the following maneuvers?
questions.solution:
The autopsy finding of this patient shows asymmetric ventricular septal hypertrophy, a finding characteristic of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM). In HCM, obstruction of the left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) is expected, which produces a harsh crescendo-decrescendo systolic ejection murmur that is best heard in the left lower sternal border (LLSB).

Instances that decrease LV blood volume worsen LVOT obstruction and increase the intensity of the HCM murmur. These include a decrease in preload (e.g., with abrupt standing, straining phase of Valsalva) or a decrease in afterload (e.g. vasodilators like hydralazine). The opposite is true, i.e. conditions that increase preload (e.g. passive leg raise, squatting) or increase afterload (e.g. vasoconstrictor like phenylephrine) would increase LV blood volume, thereby improving LVOT obstruction and decreasing the intensity of the murmur.  

Option Analysis

❌ Passive leg raising:
Incorrect: Passive leg raise increases preload, which increases left ventricular blood volume, thereby improving LVOT obstruction and decreasing the intensity of the murmur.  
✅ Straining phase of Valsalva:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Squatting:
Incorrect: Squatting increases preload and afterload, both of which increase left ventricular blood volume, thereby improving LVOT obstruction and decreasing the intensity of the murmur.  
❌ Sustained handgrip:
Incorrect: Sustained handgrip increases afterload, increasing left ventricular blood volume, thereby improving LVOT obstruction and decreasing the intensity of the murmur.  
❌ Infusion of phenylephrine:
Incorrect: Infusion of phenylephrine (an alpha-1 receptor agonist) increases afterload, increasing left ventricular blood volume, thereby improving LVOT obstruction and decreasing the intensity of the murmur.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman comes to the clinic for an evaluation of intermittent palpitations. The patient has not had any episodes of syncope, chest pain, shortness of breath, or vomiting. An electrocardiogram (ECG) is performed that shows an electrical abnormality representing the slowing of the conduction through the AV node. Which of the following is most likely to be abnormal in this patient’s ECG tracing?
questions.solution:
In a typical electrocardiogram (ECG) waveform, there is a P-wave (atrial depolarization), a QRS complex (ventricular depolarization), and a T-wave (ventricular repolarization). In addition, there are certain intervals, including the PR interval, the QRS complex, and the QT interval that help us differentiate normal from abnormal conduction.

The PR interval spans from the beginning of the p-wave to the beginning of the QRS complex. It is normally 0.12-0.20 seconds, which is three-to-five little boxes since each little box is 0.04 seconds.  Any deviation in the normal depolarization pathway from the SA node to the ventricles can change the PR interval. For example, an ectopic atrial focus is farther away from the AV node, resulting in a longer PR interval.

Another example is first degree or second degree (mobitz type I) heart block, which is when the electrical signal travels more slowly through the AV node than it normally does, causing the PR interval to lengthen beyond 0.2 seconds (as in this patient).

The QT interval is primarily a measure of ventricular repolarization. Prolongation of this interval (termed a prolonged QT) can result in lethal arrhythmias, specifically, torsades de pointes, which can degenerate into ventricular fibrillation and sudden cardiac death. Prolonged QT intervals usually result from drug therapy, hypokalemia, and/or hypomagnesemia.  

Option Analysis

❌ QT interval:
Incorrect: The QT interval spans from the beginning of the QRS complex to the end of the T-wave. It represents the ventricular systole, which is the entire span from depolarization through repolarization. It is not affected by nodal conduction abnormalities.  
✅ PR interval:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ ST segment  :
Incorrect: After the heart depolarizes, there is a brief absence of electrical activity, making an isoelectric line before repolarization, called the ST segment. On the ECG, it corresponds to the area from the end of the QRS complex to the beginning of the T wave. It is not affected by nodal conduction abnormalities.  
❌ QRS complex  :
Incorrect: The QRS complex occurs when the depolarization signal goes through the pacemaker cells of the Bundle of His and the bundle branches down into the Purkinje fibers. The apex of the heart depolarizes, followed by depolarization of the base. It is not directly affected by AV node conduction abnormalities.  
❌ T wave:
Incorrect: T-wave is a result of ventricular repolarization that appears on the ECG as a positive deflection. It is not directly affected by nodal conduction abnormalities.

questions.text: A 75-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of severe headaches, nausea, and 1 episode of vomiting. The patient has a known history of metastatic breast cancer, non-responsive to multiple chemotherapeutic regimens. On arrival, she is lethargic and oriented only to herself. Her pulse is 50/min, respirations are 8/min and shallow, and blood pressure is 150/96 mm Hg. The findings in this patient result from which of the following primary changes?
questions.solution:
Increased intracranial pressure (ICP) results in a lack of oxygen in brain tissue and a restriction of cerebral blood flow in the brain. This is most commonly caused by a head injury, bleeding in the brain (i.e., hematoma or hemorrhage), tumor, infection, stroke, excess cerebrospinal fluid, or brain swelling.

Increased ICP activates the Cushing reflex, a nervous system response resulting in Cushing’s triad. As the ICP increases, it eventually becomes more significant than the mean arterial pressure, which typically must be greater than the ICP for the brain tissue to be adequately oxygenated. This difference in pressure causes a decrease in the cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP) or the amount of blood and oxygen the brain receives, leading to the brain not receiving enough oxygen (also known as brain ischemia). To compensate for the lack of oxygen, the sympathetic nervous system is activated, causing an increase in systemic blood pressure and an initial increase in heart rate. The increased blood pressure then signals the carotid and aortic baroreceptors to start the parasympathetic nervous system, causing the heart rate to decrease. As the pressure in the brain continues to rise, the brain stem may become dysfunctional, resulting in irregular respirations followed by periods where breathing ceases completely. This progression is indicative of a worsening prognosis.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Hypovolemia:
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. Hypovolemia does not cause the Cushing reflex.  
✅ Elevated intracranial pressure:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hypoxia:
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. The primary disturbance is elevated ICP, which results in cerebral hypoxia.  
❌ Myocardial ischemia  :
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. The primary disturbance is elevated ICP, that results in cerebral ischemia.  
❌ Baroreceptor stimulation:
Incorrect: Baroreceptor stimulation is a part of the Cushing reflex that results in bradycardia.

questions.text: Normal pregnancy is characterized by adequate physiological adaptations in the mother. Which of the following best describes a normal hematologic change seen during pregnancy?

choices.text: Erythrocyte mass rise is more than blood volume

questions.solution:
Normal hematological adaptations during pregnancy are characterized by a hypercoagulable state due to an increase in blood clotting factors such as fibrinogen, factors V, VII, VIII, X, von Willebrand factor, and thrombin activation, as well as enhanced platelet aggregation–all due to the action of estrogen. At the same time, estrogen decreases the activity of antithrombin III, which normally inhibits coagulation. This hypercoagulable state decreases blood loss during the delivery of the fetus. However, this also means pregnant females have a greater risk of developing venous thromboembolism, especially in the lower legs, where there is already venous stasis.

Pregnancy also increases the risk of micronutrient deficiency (e.g iron and folate) due to increased utilization by the developing fetus.

Lastly, the blood volume increases by 30-50% during pregnancy. This allows increased blood flow to the uterus and developing placenta. Erythrocyte mass rises less significantly, leading to physiologic anemia of pregnancy.  


Option Analysis

❌ Increased activity of antithrombin III  :
Incorrect: During pregnancy, estrogen decreases the activity of antithrombin III, which normally inhibits coagulation.  
✅ Increase in plasma fibrinogen:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Development of neutropenia:
Incorrect: During pregnancy, neutrophilic leukocytosis may be seen.  
❌ Blood volume decreases by 10-20%:
Incorrect: During pregnancy, blood volume increases by 30-50%.  
❌ Erythrocyte mass rise is more than blood volume:
Incorrect: During pregnancy, the erythrocyte mass rises less significantly, leading to the physiologic anemia of pregnancy, with typical hemoglobin levels of 10-12 g/dL by term.

questions.text: A medical student is conducting an experiment where he is using an air chamber submerged in water to determine the breathing mechanics of a normal human lung. He measures the volume of air that he can maximally inhale after a normal quiet expiration. Which of the following best describes this quantity of air?
questions.solution:
Normally, lungs provide oxygen to the blood after inhaling from the environment and then exhaling after gas exchange at the level of alveoli. Certain lung volumes can be measured by a spirometer (an air chamber submerged in water being the classic example) which are as follows:
   
  • Tidal Volume (TV): During normal, quiet breathing, the volume of air moving in and out with each breath is called the tidal volume; it’s typically around 500 mL. 
  • Inspiratory reserve volume (IRV): It is the maximum volume of air that can be breathed above the tidal volume and does not include the tidal volume; it is typically around 3000 mL. 
  • Expiratory reserve volume (ERV): It is the maximum volume of air that can be exhaled after a normal quiet expiration. It is typically around 1200 mL 
  • Residual volume (RV): It is the volume of air that remains in the lungs after a maximal exhalation. It is usually around 1200 mL 
Different physiologic lung volumes can be combined to determine certain capacities. Inspiratory capacity is the volume of gas that can be breathed in after normal exhalation. It is a sum of IRV and TV.  


Option Analysis

❌ Inspiratory reserve volume:
Incorrect: Inspiratory reserve volume is the volume of air that can be breathed above the tidal volume and does not include the tidal volume.  
❌ Tidal volume:
Incorrect: During normal, quiet breathing the volume of air moving in and out with each breath is called the tidal volume; it is typically around 500 ml.  
✅ Inspiratory capacity:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Vital capacity  :
Incorrect: Vital capacity is the maximum volume of gas that can be expired after a maximum inspiration. It is a sum of inspiratory reserve volume, tidal volume, and expiratory reserve volume.  
❌ Total lung capacity:
Incorrect: Total lung capacity is the volume of gas present in the lungs after a maximal inspiration. It is a sum of inspiratory reserve volume, tidal volume, expiratory reserve volume, and residual volume

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician for evaluation of cyanotic episodes that occur when he is crying or running. The cyanosis tends to resolve when the patient squats down. Further workup is performed and the patient is diagnosed with tetralogy of Fallot. Which of the following best characterizes the changes in pulmonary physiology that occur as a result of this condition?
questions.solution:
This patient is diagnosed with tetralogy of Fallot, which manifests as a right-to-left shunt and an elevated V/Q ratio.

A shunt occurs when blood flow is redirected from an expected route. Pulmonary shunts occur when deoxygenated blood passes from the right side of the heart to the left side without participating in gas exchange within the pulmonary capillaries. Given blood is diverted from the lungs, lung perfusion decreases whereas lung ventilation is grossly unchanged. As a result, pulmonary shunts are characterized by an increase in the ventilation-to-perfusion (V/Q) ratio.

Pulmonary shunts can be divided into physiological and pathological shunts. Physiological shunts include normal blood flow through the bronchial arteries (partially empties into pulmonary veins) and coronary arteries (partially empties into the left ventricle). In contrast, pathological shunts include tetralogy of Fallot and Eisenmenger syndrome.  

Option Analysis

❌ :
Incorrect: The tetralogy of Fallot is characterized by pulmonary infundibular stenosis, right ventricular hypertrophy, overriding aorta, and ventricular septal defect. Pulmonary infundibular stenosis leads to increased right ventricular outflow resistance. As a result, blood travels from the right ventricle to the left ventricle, thus manifesting as a right-to-left shunt.   
❌ :
Incorrect: The tetralogy of Fallot is characterized by pulmonary infundibular stenosis, right ventricular hypertrophy, overriding aorta, and ventricular septal defect. Pulmonary infundibular stenosis leads to increased right ventricular outflow resistance. As a result, blood travels from the right ventricle to the left ventricle, thus manifesting as a right-to-left shunt. Moreover, since blood is diverted away from the lungs, the condition leads to decreased pulmonary blood flow and an increased V/Q ratio.   
❌ :
Incorrect: The tetralogy of Fallot is characterized by pulmonary infundibular stenosis, right ventricular hypertrophy, overriding aorta, and ventricular septal defect. Pulmonary infundibular stenosis leads to increased right ventricular outflow resistance. As a result, blood travels from the right ventricle to the left ventricle, thus manifesting as a right-to-left shunt. Moreover, since blood is diverted away from the lungs, the condition leads to decreased pulmonary blood flow and an increased V/Q ratio.   
✅ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ :
Incorrect: The tetralogy of Fallot leads to blood being diverted away from the lungs. Thus, pulmonary blood flow is decreased and there is an increase (not decrease) in the V/Q ratio.

questions.text: The auditory sensory organs are located within the membranous labyrinth. Which of the following is most appropriate regarding auditory signal transduction?

choices.text: The outer hair cells are responsible for the transduction of sound
The scala vestibuli and scala tympani are both filled with endolymph
Vibration of the round window causes a traveling wave in the basilar membrane
Low frequencies are heard at the apex near the helicotrema
Endolymph has a similar composition to other extracellular fluids

questions.solution:
