The ear contains the organ of Corti which is responsible for transforming sound waves into electrical impulses. This organ is mechanically coupled to the external environment by the tympanic membrane and the middle ear ossicles (malleus, incus, and stapes). Pressure changes in the external auditory meatus, resulting from sound waves, cause the tympanic membrane to vibrate. These vibrations are transferred to the oval window. The middle ear amplifies the force of sound waves because the oval window has a smaller surface area than that of the tympanic membrane. When the vibration of the oval window causes a traveling wave in the basilar membrane, hair cells are pushed against the tectorial membrane. Each frequency leads to vibrations at specific locations on the basilar membrane–that is, low frequencies are heard at the apex near the helicotrema (wide and flexible) and high frequencies are heard best at the base of the cochlea (thin and rigid).  


Hair cells have a tall kinocilium at one edge of the cell, which is surrounded by approximately 100 stereocilia. Deformation of the stereocilia toward the large kinocilium results in the opening of mechanically gated cation channels. The resulting entry of potassium (K+) from the K+-rich endolymph causes depolarization of the hair cell and Ca2+ entry. The release of neurotransmitters by exocytosis from the base of the cell excites the neurites of the auditory neurons. Axons of the auditory nerve synapse first in the cochlear nuclei of the medulla. Many second-order neurons pass via the lateral lemniscus directly to the inferior colliculi, whereas others synapse in the superior olivary nucleus of the pons first. Third- (or fourth-) order neurons pass from the inferior colliculus to the medial geniculate nucleus of the thalamus, where the signal is relayed via the white matter of the acoustic radiation to the auditory cortex in the temporal lobe.  

Option Analysis

❌ The outer hair cells are responsible for the transduction of sound  :
Incorrect: The inner hair cells are responsible for the transduction of sound.  
❌ The scala vestibuli and scala tympani are both filled with endolymph  :
Incorrect: The scala vestibuli and scala tympani are both filled with perilymph, which has a similar composition to other extracellular fluids. Endolymph is the fluid contained in the membranous labyrinth of the inner ear.  
❌ Vibration of the round window causes a traveling wave in the basilar membrane  :
Incorrect: Vibration of the oval window causes a traveling wave in the basilar membrane.  
✅ Low frequencies are heard at the apex near the helicotrema  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Endolymph has a similar composition to other extracellular fluids  :
Incorrect: The scala media is a blind-ended structure that contains endolymph, an unusual extracellular fluid, because it has a high [K+] of 150 mM and a low [Na+] of 1 mM. In contrast, the scala vestibuli and scala tympani are both filled with perilymph which has a similar composition to other extracellular fluids.

questions.text: A researcher is performing a histological examination of the gastrointestinal tract. Several cell types are identified and studied. The researchers isolate a group of cells called S cells, which are found in the duodenum. These cells produce a hormone that exerts the following effects?

choices.text: Increases insulin secretion from the pancreas

questions.solution:
Secretin is a peptide hormone with many physiological effects in the gastrointestinal tract. It is produced by S cells in the duodenum, and the presence of gastric acid and fatty acids in the duodenal lumen stimulates its release.  

Secretin acts on the pancreatic acinar cells to stimulate the production and release of bicarbonate (HCO3-). It also increases bicarbonate release in the bile and from the Brenner glands in the duodenum.  

These effects are crucial to neutralize the acidity of gastric fluid and elevating the pH in the lumen of the duodenum to provide an optimal environment for the digestion of fat and protect the duodenum from acidic damage. In addition, secretin stimulates the secretion of bile, which helps in the digestion of fat. Finally, secretin inhibits gastric acid release.  

Option Analysis

✅ Stimulates pancreatic HCO3- secretion  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Stimulates gallbladder contraction:
Incorrect: Cholecystokinin stimulates gallbladder contraction. It is produced by I cells in the small intestine, not S cells.  
❌ Increases insulin secretion from the pancreas  :
Incorrect: Glucose-dependent insulinotropic polypeptide (GIP) stimulates the secretion of insulin. It is produced by K cells in the mucosa of the duodenum and jejunum of the gastrointestinal tract.  
❌ Inhibits pancreatic secretions  :
Incorrect: Somatostatin inhibits pancreatic secretions and is produced by D cells in the pancreas and small intestine.  
❌ Stimulates gastric acid secretion  :
Incorrect: G cells release gastrin, which stimulates gastric acid secretion. In contrast, S cells release secretin and decrease gastric acid secretion.

questions.text: A newborn is found to have jaundice that resolved in 48 hours. The mother’s blood group is O positive, and the fetus is A positive. The previous two pregnancies were also complicated by jaundice in the newborn, requiring phototherapy. Which of the following is the most likely cause of jaundice in this newborn?

choices.text: Pre-existing anti-B and anti-A IgG antibodies in the mother
Previous pregnancy with blood group B fetus
Formation of anti-D IgG in the maternal serum from a previous pregnancy

questions.solution:
This combination of findings is associated with ABO incompatibility, resulting in hemolytic disease of the fetus and newborn (HDFN). HDFN is characterized by the destruction of fetal red blood cells and subsequent anemia. It is commonly caused by a Rhesus (Rh) or ABO incompatibility between the mother and fetus.  

ABO HDFN occurs almost exclusively in infants with blood group A or B who are born to group O mothers, given that group O mothers have naturally occurring antibodies against the A and B antigens that are of the IgG class and are thus capable of crossing the placenta and causing hemolysis in fetal and newborn RBCs. Unlike Rh, ABO HDFN may affect the first-born ABO-incompatible infant because anti-A and anti-B IgG antibodies are generally present in group O adults. Infants with ABO HDFN typically have the less severe disease than those with Rh incompatibility. Although infants affected by ABO incompatibility may require phototherapy to treat their jaundice, fewer than 0.1% require exchange transfusion. Hydrops fetalis caused by ABO alloimmune HDFN is extremely rare.  

Option Analysis

✅ Pre-existing anti-B and anti-A IgG antibodies in the mother   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Previous pregnancy with blood group B fetus  :
Incorrect: The newborn most likely has jaundice secondary to ABO incompatibility. Although the recurrence rate of ABO compatibility is high, previous ABO incompatibility is not the cause of jaundice in this patient.  
❌ Previous pregnancy with Rh-negative fetus  :
Incorrect: An Rh-negative fetus with at least one Rh-positive parent is unlikely. Moreover, it would not contribute to ABO incompatibility.
❌ Formation of anti-D IgG in the maternal serum from a previous pregnancy  :
Incorrect: Anti-D IgG is usually formed in the maternal serum in response to exposure to the Rh antigen of the fetus if the mother is Rh-negative.  
❌ Rh-positive mother  :
Incorrect: The presence of Rhesus antigen on maternal RBCs would not cause hemolytic anemia since the mother would not produce anti-D IgG antibodies.

questions.text: A patient’s immune system is exposed to a virus and subsequently forms memory B- and T cells to its antigens. One year later, the patient’s immune system is exposed to this virus again. Which of the following is true regarding the patient’s secondary immune response?

choices.text: Only B cells that do not undergo class switching can become memory B cells
The secondary immune response requires a higher pathogen burden
Memory T cells with lower levels of IL-7 receptors will live much longer
Follicular helper T cells respond to carbohydrate and lipid antigens
IgG antibodies can bind to receptors on B cells, preventing formation of IgM plasma cells

questions.solution:
A primary immune response occurs the first time the body encounters novel antigens. Naïve B- and T cells require a high level of pathogen burden so that there is plenty of antigen available for them to bind and undergo subsequent maturation. Since this antigen is new, the primary immune response can take days to weeks to occur. Some of these activated B- and T cells go on to become memory cells, which are major components of the secondary immune response. The secondary immune response occurs when the previous antigen is encountered again and requires much less pathogen burden, and occurs more quickly since there are already memory B- and T cells that “remember” the antigen.  

Memory B cells are formed after a B cell binds to a follicular dendritic cell, and then presents a peptide antigen to a follicular helper T cell. This process causes the B cell to class switch to either an IgA, IgE or IgG plasma cell. IgG antibodies have a much higher affinity than IgM antibodies. In addition, IgG antibodies can bind to the Fc gamma receptor II on newly-formed B cells, preventing them from becoming IgM-secreting plasma cells. This helps keep up a large pool of high-affinity IgG plasma cells.  

Memory T cells can either be effector memory cells or central memory cells. Effector memory cells move throughout the body looking for the antigen they “remember.” These effector cells can function as CD4+ helper T cells or CD8+ cytotoxic T cells. Effector memory T cells express lower levels of IL-7 receptors after they engage in an immune response, so they die shortly after the response. Central memory T cells stay in lymphoid tissues and maintain a high level of IL-7 receptors. Due to this, they can live up to 25 years. When they encounter an antigen, they “remember,” they will proliferate and create new T cells which can then respond to the antigen.  

Option Analysis

❌ Only B cells that do not undergo class switching can become memory B cells  :
Incorrect: Only B cells that undergo class switching (with the help of follicular dendritic cells and T cells) can become memory B cells. Class switching involves changing from an IgD- and IgM-predominant B cell to either an IgA, IgE or IgG B cell.  
❌ The secondary immune response requires a higher pathogen burden  :
Incorrect: The secondary immune response requires a much lower pathogen burden than the primary immune response since a person has already formed memory B- and T cells to that pathogen and its antigens.  
❌ Memory T cells with lower levels of IL-7 receptors will live much longer  :
Incorrect: Memory T cells that express large amounts of IL-7 receptors (e.g. central memory T cells) live much longer than those which express small amounts of IL-7 receptors (e.g. effector memory T cells).
❌ Follicular helper T cells respond to carbohydrate and lipid antigens  :
Incorrect: Follicular helper T cells only respond to peptide antigens. Thus, memory B cells can only respond to peptide antigens, since they first must undergo class switching by presenting peptide antigens to follicular helper T cells.  
✅ IgG antibodies can bind to receptors on B cells, preventing formation of IgM plasma cells  :
Correct: See Main Explanation

questions.text: A researcher is studying the pathophysiology of brain natriuretic peptides (BNP). This peptide is released from the heart's ventricles in response to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP) and brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) are two peptide molecules secreted by the atria and ventricles of the heart, respectively, in response to increased cardiac workload when the walls of the atria and ventricles are stretched (as in fluid overload states like congestive heart failure).

BNP and ANP bind to surface receptors on the vascular smooth muscle of afferent and efferent arterioles. They relax afferent arterioles via cGMP and constrict efferent arterioles increasing glomerular filtration rate (GFR). A rise in GFR causes increased sodium (Na+) filtration with no compensatory sodium reabsorption in the distal nephron. Increased sodium ion delivery to the distal convoluted tubule is sensed by the macula densa, which results in downregulation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS). The net effect is sodium loss and, by osmosis, water loss, ultimately diminished fluid overloaded states.  

Option Analysis

❌ Increased plasma aldosterone:
Incorrect: Aldosterone increases sodium and water reabsorption in volume-depleted states. It has no role in the release of BNP.  
❌ Increased plasma dopamine:
Incorrect: Dopamine, apart from acting as a neurotransmitter, acts on dopamine receptors in the heart and kidneys, where it induces vasodilation in volume-depleted states. It has no role in the release of BNP.  
✅ Diminished cardiac ejection fraction:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Decline in renal perfusion:
Incorrect: Decline in renal perfusion decreases stretch in afferent arterioles, reduces sodium delivery to macula densa, and activates the sympathetic nervous system, activating the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS). It has no role in the release of BNP.  
❌ Increased antidiuretic hormone (ADH):
Incorrect: Secretion of ADH is stimulated by angiotensin II in volume-depleted states. ADH acts on the principal cells of the collecting ducts of nephrons to reabsorb water. It has no role in the release of BNP.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man comes to the physician because of an itchy rash on his right arm. The rash began one day ago as small papules and progressed into blisters with oozing. He was weeding plants in a public yard a few days ago. His vital signs are within normal limits. A photograph of the patient's arm is shown. There is no lymphadenopathy. Which of the following best describes the underlying mechanism of this disease?

choices.text: Cytotoxic T-cell destruction of antigen-tagged cells

questions.solution:
This patient presents with an itchy, red, vesicular rash characteristic of contact dermatitis secondary to possible poison ivy exposure and a type IV (delayed-type) hypersensitivity reaction.   

Type IV hypersensitivity reaction involves damage to surrounding tissue via CD8+ T cells (also known as killer T cells or cytotoxic T cells) and CD4+ T cells, also known as helper T cells. The former targets antigens as presented on MHC class I molecules via their T-cell receptors (TCR). This results in the release of perforin and granzymes, inducing lysis of the presenting cell.  

CD4+ T cells, on the other hand, become activated when the antigen is presented to them on MHC class II molecules via an antigen-presenting cell or APC (e.g. Langerhans cells). The CD4+ T cells bind to these molecules via TCR and a CD4 co-receptor. In addition, the CD4+ T cell also expresses a surface CD28 protein which binds to the B7 protein on the surface of the APC. Ultimately, this series of interactions results in the release of interleukin 12 from the APC,  inducing differentiation of CD4+ naive T cells into type 1 helper T (TH1) cells. These cells release interleukin-2 (IL-2), which helps TH1 cells and other T cells proliferate, and interferon-gamma activates phagocytes to create more TH1 cells. Activated macrophages release proinflammatory cytokines, including tumor necrosis factor, interleukin-1, and interleukin-6, enhancing endothelial barrier permeability. These mediators allow more immune cells to enter the area of inflammation, leading to local swelling or edema, redness, and warmth and inducing systemic symptoms like fever.  

Option Analysis

❌ Complement-dependent reaction  :
Incorrect: With a complement-dependent reaction, antibody bound to antigen fixes to complement and induces direct cell lysis through the production of the membrane attack complex (MAC). Complement-dependent reactions include Goodpasture syndrome, rheumatic fever, and hyperacute transplant rejection.  
❌ Antibody-dependent cell-mediated cytotoxicity  :
Incorrect: With antibody-dependent cell-mediated cytotoxicity (cellular destruction), cell types that bear receptors for the Fc portion of IgG, such as neutrophils, eosinophils, macrophages, and natural killer (NK) cells, mediate removal of an antigen. Examples include transfusion reactions, erythroblastosis fetalis, and autoimmune hemolytic anemia.  
❌ Immune complex-mediated complement activation  :
Incorrect: Immune complex-mediated complement activation defines the mechanism of a type III hypersensitivity reaction, characterized by the deposition of IgG-antigen complexes in various tissues. Examples include polyarteritis nodosa, post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis, IgA nephropathy, and lupus nephritis. This patient presents with anaphylaxis, which is a type I hypersensitivity reaction.  
✅ Cytotoxic T-cell destruction of antigen-tagged cells  :
Correct: See Main Explanation  
❌ IgE-mediated mast cell activation  :
Incorrect: Type I hypersensitivity reactions are mediated by IgE and mast cells and are associated with hives, bronchospasm, and anaphylaxis.

questions.text: Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory agents (NSAIDs) such as ibuprofen block the action of prostaglandins on afferent arterioles in the kidney. Which of the following changes in renal function are observed with NSAID use?
questions.solution:
The kidneys produce prostaglandin E2 and prostaglandin I2 in response to sympathetic stimulation. Both molecules dilate the afferent and efferent arterioles to ensure renal blood flow doesn’t get too low during fight-or-flight situations.

Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) are commonly used medications associated with nephrotoxicity when consumed chronically or in high doses. NSAID action involves cyclooxygenase (COX) enzyme inhibition, interfering with arachidonic acid conversion into E2 prostaglandins E2, prostacyclins, and thromboxanes. In the absence of prostaglandin, unopposed vasoconstriction of the afferent arterioles occurs, leading to a decrease in glomerular filtration rate (GFR) and renal plasma flow (RPF). This change does not affect the filtration fraction, which is defined as the ratio of GFR/RPF.  

Option Analysis

❌ :
Incorrect: Constriction of the ureter can decrease GFR without affecting the RPF; however, this does not describe the effects of NSAID use on kidney function.   
✅ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ :
Incorrect: Efferent arteriole constriction (e.g. by angiotensin II) can increase the GFR and decrease renal plasma flow, leading to an increase in filtration fraction.   
❌ :
Incorrect: A decrease in serum plasma protein decreases oncotic pressure and results in more fluid being filtered via the kidney, thus increasing the GFR and thereby FF.   
❌ :
Incorrect: Dehydration decreases the RPF more than the GFR and thereby increases the FF.

questions.text: A male newborn is delivered at term to a 32-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 2. Examination of the newborn shows a swollen face and abdomen. There is palpable hepatosplenomegaly. His hemoglobin concentration is 6.9 g/dL and serum bilirubin concentration is 8.1 mg/dL. A direct antiglobulin test shows immediate agglutination of red blood cells. Her previous pregnancy was uncomplicated with the birth of a healthy boy. The mother’s blood group is AB negative, and the father's blood group is AB positive. Which of the following is the underlying cause of the newborn's current condition?

choices.text: Presence of anti-D IgG in the maternal serum
Previous pregnancy with blood group A fetus
Previous pregnancy with blood group B fetus

questions.solution:
This combination of findings is associated with Rhesus incompatibility, which can result in hemolytic disease of the fetus and newborn (HDFN). HDFN is characterized by the destruction of fetal red blood cells and subsequent anemia. It is commonly caused by a Rhesus (Rh) or ABO incompatibility between the mother and fetus.  

In Rh incompatibility with an Rh-negative mother with an Rh-positive fetus, maternal exposure to fetal blood (most often during birth) leads to maternal IgM antibodies against the Rh antigen. Over time, seroconversion to anti-Rh IgG occurs. IgG antibodies can cross the placenta. In a subsequent pregnancy with another Rh-positive child, these antibodies bind to the Rh antigen of fetal RBCs, marking them for destruction. Hydrops fetalis and severe anemia are often seen in cases of HDFN due to Rh incompatibility, but these features are usually absent in cases of HDFN due to ABO incompatibility.  

Prevention is by administering anti-D IgG to Rh-negative pregnant patients during the third trimester and early postpartum period in the first and subsequent pregnancies with an Rh-positive fetus. This prevents maternal anti-D IgG production.  

Option Analysis

❌ Mother with blood group AB   :
Incorrect: Since both mother and father’s blood group is AB, no antibodies will cross the placenta to the fetus to cause hemolysis. The fetus is unlikely to develop ABO incompatibility.  
✅ Presence of anti-D IgG in the maternal serum  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Previous pregnancy with blood group A fetus  :
Incorrect: Previous pregnancy with blood group A fetus will not result in hydrops fetalis in this newborn since the mother would not have anti-A antibodies due to her AB blood type.  
❌ Previous pregnancy with Rh-negative fetus  :
Incorrect: Previous pregnancy with an Rh-negative fetus is impossible as the father is Rh-positive. Moreover, if the previous pregnancy were with an Rh-negative fetus, no anti-D IgG would be formed in the mother, and Rh hemolytic disease of the newborn would not be seen in this pregnancy.  
❌ Previous pregnancy with blood group B fetus  :
Incorrect: Previous pregnancy with blood group B fetus will not result in hydrops fetalis in this newborn since the mother would not have anti-B antibodies due to her AB blood type.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother due to progressive chest enlargement. He first noted it 1 year ago while showering in school after physical education class. Since then, it has increased in size, and he became embarrassed after being teased by his friends. He was born at term after a normal pregnancy via vaginal delivery. His development has been uneventful, and all milestones have been reached. Medical history is significant for allergic rhinitis, for which he takes fluticasone nasal spray and oral loratadine. He has had no headaches or visual changes. He does not smoke, drink alcohol or use recreational drugs. He is at the 50th percentile for height and weight; BMI is 21. Physical examination reveals bilateral firm masses extending concentrically from the nipple. The mass is more prominent on the right side. Sexual development is Tanner stage 4. The rest of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the cause of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Medication side effects; stopping the medication will resolve the condition
Hypogonadism; hormonal treatment will resolve the condition.
Increased fat deposition; observation is indicated.

questions.solution:
This adolescent boy is presenting with isolated gynecomastia, as well as normal physical examination and development, favoring the diagnosis of physiological gynecomastia. Gynecomastia is defined as benign proliferation of the glandular breast tissue in males. It differs from the female breast development by the lack of terminal alveolar development in response to progesterone. Patients typically present with a mass or ridge of glandular tissue that is symmetrically distributed around the nipple. It may be tender or asymmetric. Gynecomastia can be physiologic or pathologic, primary (e.g. Klinefelter syndrome) or secondary (e.g. drugs). The vast majority of gynecomastia cases in children and adolescents are physiologic.  

Neonatal breast hypertrophy ー This occurs in both boys and girls during the neonatal period and is thought to be related to placental transformation of androgens to estrogens, which stimulate glandular proliferation in the fetus. Most cases resolve by one year.    

Pubertal gynecomastia ー This refers to the physiologic enlargement of the glandular breast tissue in boys during puberty. Gynecomastia peaks during mid-puberty, coinciding with peak height velocity at age 12 to 14 years, and Tanner stage 3 to 4. The pathogenesis is thought to be related to an imbalance in the androgen-to-estrogen ratio, in which a relative increase in extratesticular production of estrogen may play a role in the development of gynecomastia. While most cases of physiologic pubertal gynecomastia resolve spontaneously (typically one year of onset), management is individualized and based on the degree of psychosocial distress. Initial management often consists of reassurance and observation.  

Clinical features suspicious of pathologic gynecomastia: 
  •  Occurrence in the prepubertal stage or after puberty in boys 
  •  Rapid progression 
  •  Enlargement >4 cm (1.6 inches) in diameter 
  •  Rapid and/or precocious virilization 

Option Analysis

❌ Medication side effects; stopping the medication will resolve the condition:
Incorrect: Certain medications and drugs are associated with gynecomastia as a side effect. Examples include isoniazid, ketoconazole, ranitidine, omeprazole, etc. However, this patient is not taking any medication that is associated with gynecomastia.   
❌ Hypogonadism; hormonal treatment will resolve the condition.:
Incorrect: Klinefelter syndrome is the most common congenital cause of primary hypogonadism. It often presents during adolescence, and up to 70% of patients with Klinefelter syndrome have gynecomastia. This child has no features of Klinefelter syndrome, such as thin body habitus, long limbs, learning and behavioral difficulties, or firm and small testes.  
❌ Tumor; MRI is indicated:
Incorrect: Testicular tumors such as Leydig, Sertoli cell tumors, and germ cell tumors may cause gynecomastia due to abnormal hormone secretion. However, patients typically present with a testicular mass that does not transilluminate. A prolactinoma of the pituitary gland can also present with gynecomastia; however, patients often complain of headaches and/or visual changes.   
✅ Hormonal imbalance; reassurance is indicated.:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Increased fat deposition; observation is indicated. :
Incorrect: Increased fat deposition is termed pseudogynecomastia (lipomastia), a condition often seen in obese men. However, it differs from gynecomastia, which is glandular proliferation of the breast tissue rather than fat deposition. Also, this patient has a normal BMI.

questions.text: A graduate student is conducting an experiment to determine the effects of arterial compliance and stroke volume on pulse pressure. Which of the following best describes the effects that changes in the independent variables will have on the dependent variable?
questions.solution:
This question is asking how changes in stroke volume and arterial compliance will affect pulse pressure.

Pulse pressure is defined as the difference between systolic blood pressure (SBP) and diastolic blood pressure (DBP). Pulse pressure is directly proportional to stroke volume and inversely proportional to arterial compliance. An increase in stroke volume means more blood is ejected from the heart, which would result in an increased SBP and pulse pressure. Similarly, a decrease in vascular compliance means the ejected blood is pushing against a stiff vascular wall, which would also increase SBP and pulse pressure.

These physiological parameters can be illustrated via some clinical scenarios. One example is aortic stiffening, which can be due to natural aging or secondary to arteriosclerosis. The condition will lead to decreased arterial compliance. As a result, SBP will increase whereas DBP, which is determined by total peripheral resistance (provided chiefly by the arterioles), will remain largely unchanged.

As an aside, it is worth mentioning that in patients with significant aortic changes following chronic hypertension, stiffening of the aorta reduces the elastic reservoir capacity, and more blood runs off from each stroke volume during systole, which results in a reduced blood volume within the aorta at the onset of diastole, resulting in lower DBP.

Another example is aortic stenosis. In this condition, narrowing of the aortic valve interferes with the ejection of blood from the left ventricle into the aorta and results in decreased stroke volume. In turn, SBP and ultimately pulse pressure will decrease.  

Option Analysis

❌ :
Incorrect: Pulse pressure is directly proportional to stroke volume and inversely proportional to arterial compliance. As a result, increased vascular compliance and unchanged stroke volume will result in decreased, not increased, pulse pressure.   
❌ :
Incorrect: In this set of experimental parameters, vascular compliance is increased and stroke volume decreased. These changes would mean that less blood is pushing against the arterial walls during systole and the walls can easily expand in response to blood leaving the heart. As a result, systolic blood pressure will decrease, diastolic blood pressure will remain largely unchanged (since it is determined by the total peripheral resistance, which is provided chiefly by the arterioles), and pulse pressure will ultimately decrease.   
❌ :
Incorrect: In this set of experimental parameters, stroke volume is increased. This change means that more blood is pushing against the arterial walls during systole. As a result, systolic blood pressure will increase, diastolic blood pressure will remain largely unchanged, and pulse pressure will ultimately increase.   
❌ :
Incorrect: Pulse pressure is directly proportional to stroke volume and inversely proportional to arterial compliance. As a result, decreased vascular compliance and increased stroke volume will result in increased pulse pressure.   
✅ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 3-day-old neonate is evaluated in the newborn nursery. He was born via normal vaginal delivery to a 30-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 2, with an intrauterine pregnancy at 34 weeks gestation. He demonstrates a strong cry and moves all his extremities. Physical examination shows that the patient’s torso and upper extremities are pink, while his lower extremities have a bluish hue. Vitals are within normal limits for age. Which of the following will most likely be heard on the auscultation of the patient’s chest?

choices.text: Continuous systolic and diastolic murmur in left infraclavicular area
Holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border
Holosystolic murmur at the cardiac apex radiating to the axilla
Holosystolic murmur at the cardiac apex with a mid-diastolic rumble at the left sternal border

questions.solution:
This neonate with lower extremity “differential” cyanosis, who is born preterm (at 34 weeks gestation), most likely has patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), which is characterized by a continuous “machine-like” murmur that is best heard in the left infraclavicular area, with maximal intensity at S2.

Typically, the ductus arteriosus carries deoxygenated blood from the pulmonary artery into the descending aorta during fetal development. When the infant starts breathing at birth, the rise in oxygen concentration and decline in prostaglandin secretion (from the placenta) leads to the closure of ductus arteriosus. If it remains open after birth, declining pulmonary resistance makes it a left-to-right shunt.

Risk factors for PDA include preterm birth, congenital rubella, and hypoxia (e.g. cyanotic heart diseases). Short PDA can be asymptomatic, while others cause lower extremity (differential) cyanosis.  Uncorrected PDA can lead to Eisenmenger syndrome.  

Option Analysis

❌ Rumbling mid-to-late diastolic murmur  :
Incorrect: Mitral stenosis causes a rumbling mid-to-late diastolic murmur best heard at the cardiac apex. It is rare in newborns and is not usually associated with differential cyanosis.  
✅ Continuous systolic and diastolic murmur in left infraclavicular area:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border  :
Incorrect: Ventricular septal defect causes a holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border. It may lead to central cyanosis but is not associated with differential cyanosis in newborns.  
❌ Holosystolic murmur at the cardiac apex radiating to the axilla:
Incorrect: Mitral regurgitation causes a holosystolic murmur that radiates to the axilla at the cardiac apex. It is rare in newborns and is not usually associated with differential cyanosis.  
❌ Holosystolic murmur at the cardiac apex with a mid-diastolic rumble at the left sternal border  :
Incorrect: A complete atrioventricular canal defect can present with auscultatory findings of aortic regurgitation (holosystolic murmur, best heard at apex) and increased pulmonary venous return (mid-diastolic rumble). It is seen in patients with Down syndrome and presents with central cyanosis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman is found to have supraventricular tachycardia on an EKG. The physician starts to perform a carotid massage. Which changes will be seen in response to the carotid massage?
questions.solution:
Carotid sinus is the dilated region superior to bifurcation of carotid arteries. Distinct afferent nerve fibers in the carotid sinus join the glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX) to stimulate medullary centers directly. The baroreceptors are activated when the pressure in the carotid sinus rises. The afferent fibers in the glossopharyngeal nerve release glutamate to excite neurons in the nucleus of the tractus solitarius (NTS). Excitatory (glutamate) projections extend from the NTS to the caudal ventrolateral medulla (CVLM), where they stimulate γ-aminobutyric acid (GABA)-secreting inhibitory neurons that project to the rostral ventrolateral medulla RVLM. Excitatory projections also extend from the NTS to the cardiac vagal motor neurons in the nucleus ambiguus. Thus, increased baroreceptor discharge inhibits sympathetic nerve activity and excites vagal nerve activity to increase AV node refractory period, causing vasodilation, hypotension, and decreased cardiac output.  

Option Analysis

❌ Increased cardiac output  :
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. Carotid massage stimulates the parasympathetic nervous system, eventually decreasing cardiac output.  
✅ Decreased heart rate  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Increased blood pressure:
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. Carotid massage stimulates the parasympathetic nervous system, eventually decreasing blood pressure.  
❌ Vasoconstriction:
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. Carotid massage stimulates the parasympathetic nervous system, which would eventually cause vasodilation.  
❌ Increased preload:
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. Carotid massage stimulates the parasympathetic nervous system, which would eventually cause venodilation, peripheral blood pooling, and decreased cardiac preload.

questions.text: Pregnancy is defined by the National Institutes of Health, the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists, and the Food and Drug Administration as implantation of the blastocyst in the endometrium. Which of the following is the most common location for fertilization of the ovum?
questions.solution:
Fertilization is the union of the 2 germ cells, the ovum, and the sperm, restoring chromosome numbers and initiating the development of a new individual. It most commonly occurs in the ampulla, which is the widest section of the fallopian tubes. Fertilization typically occurs within 1 day of ovulation.  

Option Analysis

❌ Cervix:
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. Fertilization does not occur in the cervix.  
❌ Uterus:
Incorrect: It is unusual for fertilization to occur in the uterus. Instead, the blastocyst implants in the uterine wall 6 days after fertilization.  
❌ Isthmus:
Incorrect: The isthmus is the narrow section of the uterine tubes connecting the ampulla to the uterine cavity. It is an uncommon site of fertilization.  
✅ Ampulla:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Infundibulum:
Incorrect: The infundibulum is the funnel-shaped opening near the ovary to which fimbriae are attached. It is an uncommon site of fertilization.

questions.text: A researcher is conducting an experiment on pulmonary physiology. He is studying differences in blood flow and ventilation in various regions of the lung when a patient is sitting upright. A diagram of the lung is shown below. Which of the following best describes the region of the lung with the highest V/Q ratio and the corresponding physiological significance?
questions.solution:
Zone 1 represents the lung apex and has adequate ventilation but poor perfusion, which limits gas exchange. Given these physiological characteristics, Zone 1 has the highest ventilation-perfusion (V/Q) ratio.

When a patient is in the upright position, the lungs can be divided into three sections. These sections vary in blood flow, with greater blood flow in the gravity-dependent regions of the lung (e.g., lung base). In other words, at the lung apex, pulmonary arteriole pressure (Pa) and pulmonary venule pressure (Pv) are relatively low, at the lung base, Pa and Pv are relatively high, and in the middle of the lung, Pa and Pv are somewhere in between.

In Zone 1 alveolar pressure (PA) is higher than Pa and Pv. In this region, blood flow is inhibited because the arterioles are compressed by the relatively higher pressures in the nearby alveoli.

In Zone 2, PA is less than Pa but greater than Pv. However, since a pressure difference still exists between Pa and Pv, blood flow occurs. Zone 2 has a V/Q ratio less than that of Zone 1.

Finally, in Zone 3, PA is less than that of both Pa and Pv. Even though the pressure in the arterioles and venules exceeds that of the adjacent alveoli, the proteins and cells that constitute the alveolar wall are strong enough to resist collapsing. Among the different lung regions, Zone 3 has the lowest V/Q ratio.

Option Analysis

✅ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ :
Incorrect: Zone 1 corresponds to the lung apex. This region has the highest V/Q ratio given it receives adequate oxygenation but poor blood supply due to the fact that blood flow needs to act against gravity in trying to reach the superior aspects of the lung. In other words, oxygen in Zone 1 has difficulty diffusing into the bloodstream due to poor perfusion. As a result, there is wasted ventilation (not wasted perfusion).   
❌ :
Incorrect: Zone 1 corresponds to the lung apex and has the highest V/Q ratio. In contrast, Zone 2 has a V/Q ratio less than that of Zone 1 but greater than that of Zone 3.   
❌ :
Incorrect: Zone 3 corresponds to the lung base. This region receives extensive blood flow such that perfusion often exceeds ventilation. As a result, Zone 3 has the lowest V/Q ratio and wasted perfusion (not wasted ventilation).   
❌ :
Incorrect: Zone 3 corresponds to the lung base. This region receives extensive blood flow such that perfusion often exceeds ventilation. As a result, Zone 3 has the lowest V/Q ratio and wasted perfusion.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman, gravida 1 para 0, comes to the obstetrician to discuss the possibility of home birth. The patient insists on giving birth to her child at home as an approach to an “all-natural delivery.” The physician reviews her case; he states that while home delivery is possible for the patient to do, he recommends that the baby is brought in following birth to be given vitamin K to prevent fatal bleeding. Which of the following explains the need of vitamin K administration in neonates?

choices.text: Insufficient colonization of the colon by bacteria that produce vitamin K
Inability of neonates to absorb the abundant vitamin K found in breast milk
Inability to store vitamin K in neonates due to lack of fat
Neonates are unable to recycle vitamin K once used
Vitamin K requirements in neonates are much higher than in adults.

questions.solution:
Vitamin K is a fat soluble vitamin that helps in activating clotting factors involved in secondary hemostasis, and thereby contributes to coagulation. Without vitamin K, the clotting factors II, VII, IX, and X cannot be activated, and can cause massive bleeding.  

The main resources of vitamin K are from the diet. Additionally, bacteria colonizing the gut produces vitamin K and helps maintain adequate levels of vitamin K. Therefore, deficiency in vitamin K is quite rare in adults except in certain disorders (e.g. malabsorption). However, neonates are prone to vitamin K deficiency, and this is attributed to the decreased endogenous and exogenous supply of vitamin K.  

First of all, the endogenous vitamin K is through the gut bacteria. In neonates, the gut is still sterile, and therefore few bacteria that produce vitamin K are present. Insufficient colonization of bacteria in the colon that produces vitamin K in neonates plays an important role in the deficiency of vitamin K.  

Additionally, the exogenous supply of vitamin K in neonates is very low. Vitamin K is not transported across the placenta, so the neonates are born without sufficient storage. In addition, breast milk contains low amounts of vitamin K which are insufficient to meet the required levels for neonates.  

Due to these reasons, neonates must be given vitamin K soon after birth to prevent catastrophic complications which include bleeding, intracranial hemorrhage, and death.  

Option Analysis

✅ Insufficient colonization of the colon by bacteria that produce vitamin K  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Inability of neonates to absorb the abundant vitamin K found in breast milk:
Incorrect: Breast milk contains low amounts of vitamin K, which predisposes to vitamin K deficiency in neonates.  
❌ Inability to store vitamin K in neonates due to lack of fat  :
Incorrect: Vitamin K can be stored in infants, and the reason for vitamin K deficiency in neonates is deficiency in the endogenous and exogenous supply of the vitamin.  
❌ Neonates are unable to recycle vitamin K once used  :
Incorrect: The enzyme epoxide reductase is responsible for converting vitamin K to the reduced form after it is used, thereby recycling it and making it available for use again. Although the enzyme function in neonates is not at the same level as in adults, it is still functional and can recycle vitamin K to the reduced form.  
❌ Vitamin K requirements in neonates are much higher than in adults.  :
Incorrect: The reason for vitamin K supplementation in neonates is due to decreased supply, not increased demand.

questions.text: A study was done on the complement system to determine their functions in the immune response. It was found that one of the complement proteins covers the surface of bacteria and aids in phagocytosis. Which of the following is the most likely complement protein that does this function?
questions.solution:
The complement system is made of proteins that once activated, play an important role in the fight against pathogens.  

The main function of the complement occurs when C5b becomes activated, which then joins the complex from C6 to C9 and forms the membrane attack complex (MAC) which forms pores in the membranes of bacteria (specifically Gram-negative bacteria) and leads to cell lysis. The MAC is especially important in defending against Neisseria infections, and people with deficiencies in these complement proteins can develop recurrent and life-threatening infections with Neisseria species (e.g., meningococcal pneumonia).  

However, the MAC is not the only way the complement system helps in the immune response. Certain fragments of activated complement proteins also have unique functions in the immune response.  First of all, C3b also functions as an opsonin by covering the bacteria and tagging them for phagocytes. This makes the process of phagocytosis more efficient.  

Additionally, C3a and C5a act as chemotactic factors, where they help direct the neutrophils and other immune cells (e.g., macrophages, and eosinophils) to the site of inflammation. Additionally, these 2 complement proteins act as anaphylatoxins, meaning that they help in the degranulation of basophils and mast cells and the release of histamine.  

Finally, C1, C2, C3, and C4 help in clearing immune complexes. This prevents excessive inflammation and tissue damage. Patients with deficiencies of these factors may develop lupus-like syndrome due to the inability to clear immune complexes, which they deposit in various organs.  

Option Analysis

✅ C3b:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ C3a:
Incorrect: C3a functions in anaphylaxis and chemotaxis. However, it does not have opsonin ability.  
❌ C5a:
Incorrect: C5a has similar functions to C3a with anaphylaxis and chemotaxis. However, it does not have opsonin ability.  
❌ C9:
Incorrect: C9 is part of the membrane attack complex. However, it is not an opsonin.  
❌ C4b:
Incorrect: C4b joins C2b to form the C4b2b complex (C3 convertase) which converts C3 to C3a and C3b. It does not act as an opsonin.

questions.text: Two sets of preventive treatments are discussed in evaluating the management of tetanus. One approach is to give patients anti-tetanus immunoglobulins, and the other is to provide a tetanus toxoid vaccine. Which of the following is true regarding the two preventive approaches?

choices.text: The anti-tetanus immunoglobulin results in a longer-lasting immune response than the tetanus toxoid vaccine.
Both the anti-tetanus immunoglobulin and the tetanus toxoid vaccine activate the humoral and cellular response in the host body.
Anti-tetanus immunoglobulin activates the humoral immune response in the host, while the tetanus toxoid vaccine activates the humoral and cellular immunity.
The anti-tetanus immunoglobulin and the tetanus toxoid vaccine result in the formation of memory cells.
The anti-tetanus immunoglobulin results in a faster immune response than the tetanus toxoid vaccine.

questions.solution:
Two forms of immunization are currently used to prevent and treat infectious diseases: passive and active.  

Passive immunization refers to the transfer of preformed antibodies from an immunized individual to a non-immunized individual. This can occur naturally, like the transfer of IgG antibodies from the mother to the child through the placenta and the transfer of IgA antibodies through breast milk. Alternatively, it can be done artificially by taking antibodies from an immunized individual and transferring them to another individual who is not immunized.  

In passive immunization, the preformed antibodies transferred are functional as soon as they reach the host’s body and therefore serve a faster immune response than active vaccination forms.  

Passive immunization does not activate the host immune system; therefore, this immunity is short and lasts only until the antibodies transferred disappear. Also, no memory cells develop because the host's adaptive immunity is not activated.  

On the other hand, active immunity develops after exposure to an infectious agent, either naturally through infection or by vaccination. This form of immunity causes the activation of the host's adaptive immune system, resulting in the formation of immune B- and T-cells capable of defending against the infectious agent. Additionally, memory cells develop active immunity and hence can mount a fast immune response if the infectious agent is exposed to it again.  

Option Analysis

❌ The anti-tetanus immunoglobulin results in a longer-lasting immune response than the tetanus toxoid vaccine.:
Incorrect: Passive immunization (anti-tetanus immunoglobulins) results in a shorter immune response than active immunization (tetanus toxoid vaccine).
❌ Both the anti-tetanus immunoglobulin and the tetanus toxoid vaccine activate the humoral and cellular response in the host body.  :
Incorrect: An anti-tetanus immunoglobulin is a form of passive immunization which does not activate the host adaptive immune system.  
❌ Anti-tetanus immunoglobulin activates the humoral immune response in the host, while the tetanus toxoid vaccine activates the humoral and cellular immunity.  :
Incorrect: An anti-tetanus immunoglobulin is a form of passive immunization which does not activate the host adaptive immune system.  
❌ The anti-tetanus immunoglobulin and the tetanus toxoid vaccine result in the formation of memory cells.:
Incorrect: Because the anti-tetanus immunoglobulin is a passive immunity, it does not result in the formation of memory cells.  
✅ The anti-tetanus immunoglobulin results in a faster immune response than the tetanus toxoid vaccine.  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A group of scientists is evaluating the effects of estrogen on bone remodeling in an attempt to find new treatments for osteoporosis. In their study, estrogen deficiency is associated with an increased risk of osteoporosis. Which of the following is true regarding the effects of estrogen on  bone remodeling?

choices.text: Estrogen inhibits bone resorption via both direct and indirect effects on osteoclasts
The effects of estrogen on bones occur primarily in women, while testosterone has more prominent effects in men
Estrogen inhibits bone resorption but does not affect bone formation
Estrogen induces apoptosis in both osteoblasts and osteoclasts
Estrogen's effects on osteoclasts occur indirectly through osteoblasts.

questions.solution:
Estrogen is a hormone that plays a significant role in bone homeostasis in men and women and affects bone formation and resorption. Estrogen inhibits bone remodeling and resorption due to its direct and indirect effect on osteoclasts. Directly, estrogen binds to its receptor sites on osteoclasts and induces apoptosis. Estrogen also inhibits osteoclasts indirectly by decreasing the production and responsiveness to RANK-ligand.  

Additionally, estrogen stimulates bone formation by inhibiting apoptosis of osteocytes and osteoblasts. Estrogen also increases osteoblasts' production and lifespan, thus increasing bone formation. However, estrogen induces the closure of the epiphyseal growth plate, thereby limiting the linear growth of bones.  

Option Analysis

✅ Estrogen inhibits bone resorption via both direct and indirect effects on osteoclasts  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ The effects of estrogen on bones occur primarily in women, while testosterone has more prominent effects in men  :
Incorrect: In both women and men, estrogen is a significant contributor to bone remodeling  
❌ Estrogen inhibits bone resorption but does not affect bone formation  :
Incorrect: Estrogen both inhibits bone resorption and stimulates bone formation.  
❌ Estrogen induces apoptosis in both osteoblasts and osteoclasts  :
Incorrect: Estrogen inhibits apoptosis of osteoblasts and promotes apoptosis in osteoclasts.  
❌ Estrogen's effects on osteoclasts occur indirectly through osteoblasts.  :
Incorrect: Estrogen receptors are present on osteoclasts, and its effects on these cells are both direct and indirect.

questions.text: A synthetic analog of a hormone produced by the body is being studied for use in weight loss. In the study, the synthetic hormone is shown to decrease fat absorption in the gastrointestinal tract. During a 6-month evaluation after initiating treatment, it was noted that there was an increased incidence of diabetes mellitus and gallstone formation in subjects receiving the hormone. The analog used in this trial is most similar to which of the following physiological hormones?
questions.solution:
Somatostatin is a primary regulatory hormone that is produced throughout the body. In the gastrointestinal tract, somatostatin is produced by the D-cells found at several locations in the digestive system, namely the pyloric antrum, duodenum, and pancreatic islets.  

Somatostatin is an inhibitory hormone, and in the gastrointestinal tract, it inhibits various secretions, including exocrine secretions such as bile, gastric acid, pancreatic secretions, colonic fluid, cholecystokinin, and vasoactive intestinal polypeptide (VIP). Due to its inhibition of cholecystokinin, a hormone that causes gallbladder contractions, somatostatin causes bile stasis. Therefore, octreotide can increase the risk of gallstone formation. Additionally, somatostatin inhibits endocrine secretions of insulin and glucagon from the pancreas.  

The inhibitory effects of somatostatin, specifically via its analogs like octreotide, make its use beneficial in various pathological conditions, such as gastrinoma, VIPoma, and carcinoid syndrome. However, somatostatin has a very short half-life, so synthetic analogs with longer half-lives are used (e.g. octreotide).  

Option Analysis

✅ Somatostatin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Gastrin:
Incorrect: Gastrin increases gastric acid production, which may damage the villi of the intestines and decrease fat absorption. However, it is not associated with an increased risk of diabetes mellitus or gallstones.  
❌ Cholecystokinin:
Incorrect: Cholecystokinin increases fat absorption by stimulating gallbladder contraction and bile secretion into the intestines. Additionally, it decreases the risk of gallstone formation.  
❌ Secretin:
Incorrect: Secretin increases fat absorption by stimulating bile and pancreatic secretions.  
❌ Vasoactive intestinal polypeptide (VIP)  :
Incorrect: VIP does not inhibit the absorption of fat.

questions.text: A group of researchers involved in studying chemoreceptors find that patients with COPD (chronic obstructive pulmonary disease) have elevated levels of carbon dioxide in their blood without the expected physiologic compensatory changes. Which of the following best explains this phenomenon?
questions.solution:
Patients with chronic carbon dioxide elevation (e.g., COPD, obesity hypoventilation syndrome) develop central chemoreceptor tolerance. Central chemoreceptors include specialized neurons in the medulla that, when stimulated, result in an increase in blood pressure via increased sympathetic outflow. The primary factors that stimulate this response include an increase in the partial pressure of carbon dioxide, and a decrease in blood pH, with negligible effects of decreased partial pressure of oxygen.

Patients with COPD are unable to expel carbon dioxide, and over time this results in hypercapnia. The body tries to compensate for subsequent chronic respiratory acidosis in COPD patients by retaining more bicarbonate to overcome the associated acidosis. Over time, central chemoreceptors become more tolerant of elevated pCO2 levels, and respiratory drive shifts to a hypoxic drive driven by low oxygen levels rather than elevated pCO2 levels.

Option Analysis

✅ Central chemoreceptor tolerance:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Peripheral chemoreceptor tolerance:
Incorrect: Chronic hypercapnia in patients with COPD is largely mediated by central, rather than peripheral chemoreceptor tolerance.  
❌ Increased bicarbonate secretion:
Incorrect: To compensate for elevated pCO2 levels, patients with COPD will retain bicarbonate to maintain a neutral pH. Therefore, bicarbonate ion secretion will decrease, not increase.  
❌ Baroreceptor tolerance:
Incorrect: Baroreceptors in the aortic arch and carotid sinus are sensitive to blood pressure changes. Baroreceptors are not involved in maintaining homeostasis in patients with chronically elevated carbon dioxide levels.  
❌ Decreased secretion of antidiuretic hormone  :
Incorrect: The antidiuretic hormone is not involved in mediating the effects of chronic hypercapnia in patients with COPD.

questions.text: An essential step in the formation of thyroid hormones is the organification of iodine to form monoiodothyronine (MIT) and di-iodothyronine (DIT). Which of the following molecules is responsible for this reaction?
questions.solution:
Thyroid hormones are triiodothyronine (T3) and thyroxine (T4 or tetraiodothyronine). T3 and T4 are produced by the thyroid gland follicles, lined with follicular cells and separated by a small amount of connective tissue. The apical side of follicular cells surrounds a central cavity filled with colloids containing thyroglobulin.  

Thyroglobulin is a large glycoprotein synthesized by the follicular cells and then secreted into the follicle's lumen to be stored in the colloid. The basolateral membrane of follicular cells contains a sodium-iodide symporter, which pumps two sodium ions into the cell down their electrochemical gradient. Iodide is pumped into the colloid through an ion transporter called pendrin, which exchanges iodide for chloride. Iodide undergoes oxidation in the colloid with thyroperoxidase, which changes it into an iodine atom. It is then attached to tyrosine amino acid residues. This process is called iodination.  

Tyrosine residues bound by only one iodine yield monoiodotyrosine (MIT), whereas others bound by two iodine atoms yield diiodotyrosine (DIT). These molecules are then linked together by thyroperoxidase. Linking one MIT with one DIT creates T3, while linking two DIT molecules creates T4–both T3 and T4 remain bound to thyroglobulin.  


Option Analysis

❌ Thyroid deiodinase  :
Incorrect: Thyroid deiodinase is responsible for the recycling (deiodination) of MIT and DIT.  
✅ Thyroid peroxidase  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ 5'-deiodinase  :
Incorrect: 5′-deiodinase converts T4 (the major thyroid product) to T3 (the more active form of the thyroid hormone) in peripheral tissues.  
❌ Perchlorate:
Incorrect: Perchlorate is a chemical that inhibits iodine from entering follicular cells.  
❌ Propylthiouracil:
Incorrect: Propylthiouracil (PTU) inhibits thyroid peroxidase–mediated iodination of tyrosine residues in thyroglobulin. In addition, it can block the conversion of thyroxine to triiodothyronine within the thyroid and in peripheral tissues. PTU can be used in patients with hyperthyroidism.

questions.text: A researcher is studying the effects of hormones during different stages of the menstrual cycle. Which of the following is most accurate regarding the uterine cycle?

choices.text: The proliferative phase corresponds to the ovarian luteal phase
Estrogen from the corpus luteum causes lamina propria edema and endometrial thickening
The highest chance of fertilization is between day 1 and day 5 of an average 28-day cycle
During the proliferative phase, estrogen stimulates endometrial thickening and the emergence of spiral arteries
During the proliferative phase, cervical mucus thickens and becomes less hospitable to sperm

questions.solution:
The monthly menstrual cycle averages around 28 days and begins on the first day of menstruation. It has two different cycles: the ovarian cycle and the endometrial cycle. The phases of the uterine cycle include:

-Proliferative phase (corresponds to ovarian follicular phase): Following the menstrual period, high estrogen levels (produced by ovarian follicles) stimulate endometrial thickening and growth of endometrial glands. In addition, there is a slight growth of spiral arteries (due to the influence of estrogen), which help supply the growing functional endometrium. Rising estrogen levels also make the cervical mucus more hospitable to incoming sperm. The combined effects of this spike in estrogen on the uterus and cervix help to optimize the chance of fertilization, which is highest between day 11 and day 15 of an average 28-day cycle.  


-Secretory phase (corresponds to ovarian luteal phase): Under the influence of progesterone secreted by the corpus luteum, the uterus enters the secretory phase of the endometrial cycle. The spiral arteries grow significantly and become coiled, whereas the uterine glands begin to secrete more mucus. After day 15 of the cycle, the optimal window for fertilization begins to close. The cervical mucus starts to thicken and becomes less hospitable to the sperm. If the oocyte is not fertilized, the corpus luteum gradually degenerates into the nonfunctional corpus albicans, which do not produce hormones. When progesterone reaches its lowest level, the spiral arteries collapse, and the functional layer of the endometrium prepares to shed through menstruation.  


Option Analysis

❌ The proliferative phase corresponds to the ovarian luteal phase:
Incorrect: The period of rapid growth during the uterine cycle, the proliferative phase, corresponds to the ovarian follicular phase.  
❌ Estrogen from the corpus luteum causes lamina propria edema and endometrial thickening:
Incorrect: Progesterone (not estrogen) from the corpus luteum causes lamina propria edema and endometrial thickening.  
❌ The highest chance of fertilization is between day 1 and day 5 of an average 28-day cycle:
Incorrect: The highest chance of fertilization is between day 11 and day 15 of an average 28-day cycle. In contrast, day 1-5 corresponds to menstruation.  
✅ During the proliferative phase, estrogen stimulates endometrial thickening and the emergence of spiral arteries  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ During the proliferative phase, cervical mucus thickens and becomes less hospitable to sperm:
Incorrect: After day 15 of the cycle (secretory phase), the optimal window for fertilization begins to close. The cervical mucus starts to thicken and becomes less hospitable to the sperm.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the emergency room after accidentally ingesting a small plastic bead. Chest radiography reveals a radiopaque object in the right lower lobe. The bead is suspected to be causing near complete occlusion of one of the right lower lobe bronchioles. Which of the following physiological changes will most likely take place in the affected portions of the lung?

choices.text: Decreased pulmonary arteriolar smooth muscle tone

questions.solution:
This patient ingested a plastic bead that became lodged in one of the right lower lobe bronchioles. The affected portions of the lung will have decreased ventilation as well as decreased alveolar and arteriolar air pressure. These changes will ultimately lead to vasoconstriction and decreased perfusion.

Pulmonary blood flow is regulated to match alveolar ventilation and optimize oxygen exchange. Blood flow is controlled by altering arteriole resistance through adjusting arteriolar smooth muscle tone. If a region of the lung is poorly ventilated, there will be a decrease in the partial pressure of oxygen within the arterioles (PAO2) adjacent to that region. These changes in turn lead to hypoxic vasoconstriction and divert blood away from poorly ventilated regions of the lung.

In certain conditions, such as emphysema or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, there is chronic hypoxia and vasoconstriction. As a result, the right heart must generate increased pressures to pump blood through pulmonary circulation. Over time, these changes lead to pulmonary hypertension.

Option Analysis

✅ Decreased perfusion:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Increased perfusion:
Incorrect: The bead is causing significant occlusion of the affected bronchiole, leading to decreased ventilation. As a result, there will be a decrease in the partial pressure of oxygen within the alveoli (PAO2) and in the arteriole adjacent to the alveoli (PaO2). A decrease in PaO2 will cause hypoxic vasoconstriction and decreased perfusion, not increased perfusion.  
❌ Elevated V/Q ratio:
Incorrect: The obstructing bead will cause decreased ventilation (V) to the affected portions of the lung. As a result, the affected portions will have a decreased V/Q ratio.  
❌ Decreased pulmonary arteriolar smooth muscle tone:
Incorrect: The bead is causing significant occlusion of the affected bronchiole, leading to decreased ventilation. As a result, there will be a decrease in the partial pressure of oxygen within the alveoli (PAO2) and in the arteriole adjacent to the alveoli (PaO2). A decrease in PaO2 will cause hypoxic vasoconstriction and increased vascular smooth muscle tone.  
❌ Right ventricular hypertrophy:
Incorrect: Conditions such as emphysema can lead to chronic hypoxia. In turn, there will be persistent vasoconstriction. As a result, the right heart must generate increased pressures to pump blood through pulmonary circulation. Over time, these changes can lead to right ventricular hypertrophy.

questions.text: A researcher is studying the structure and function of hemoglobin. He discovers that certain conditions favor the unloading of oxygen to tissues, as demonstrated in the graph below. Which of the following conditions favors this effect?

choices.text: Decreasing the partial pressure of CO2

questions.solution:
The oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve reflects the saturation of hemoglobin at different partial pressures of oxygen. Several conditions may result in either a left or right curve shift. A rightward shift indicates increasing oxygen unloading to tissues, where certain conditions decrease hemoglobin’s affinity for oxygen. In contrast, a leftward shift means decreasing oxygen unloading to tissues and a relative increase in affinity for oxygen. Conditions associated with either shift are reflected in the tables above.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Increasing temperature:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Decreasing temperature:
Incorrect: The decreasing temperature will result in a left shift of the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve, not a rightward shift.  
❌ Increasing the pH:
Incorrect: Increasing the pH will result in a left shift of the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve, not a rightward shift.  
❌ Decreasing the partial pressure of CO2:
Incorrect:  Decreasing the partial pressure of CO2 will result in a left shift of the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve, not a rightward shift.  
❌ Presence of carbon monoxide:
Incorrect:  The presence of carbon monoxide will result in a left shift of the oxygen-hemoglobin curve due to its higher affinity for hemoglobin when compared to oxygen.

questions.text: The total amount of calcium circulating in the serum is either protein-bound, anion-bound, or ionized calcium. Which of the following changes will be seen in a patient with a serum pH of 7.55?
questions.solution:
Plasma calcium concentration is about 5 to 10 mEq/L and it can be found in three forms:  
  • 50% is ionized and is physiologically active  
  • ~40% of plasma calcium is bound to proteins and is physiologically inactive  
  • 10% is bound to anions like phosphate or citrate   

Hypoproteinemia (e.g., nephrotic syndrome, liver cirrhosis, severe malnutrition, malabsorption) results in a total decrease in Ca2+ level, but ionized Ca2+ levels are unaffected. On the other hand, pH influences the binding of calcium to serum proteins.  
- ↑ pH → ↓ H+ in serum binding to proteins → ↑ Ca2+ binding to proteins → ↓ ionized Ca2+ concentration compensatory ↑ PTH  
- ↓ pH → ↑ H+ in serum binding to proteins → ↓ Ca2+ binding to proteins → ↑ ionized Ca2+ concentration compensatory ↓ PTH  

Option Analysis

❌ ↑ ionized Ca2+  :
Incorrect: An increase in pH (more basic) decreases the amount of H+ in serum that binds to proteins, thereby increasing Ca2+ binding to proteins. This leads to a decrease in ionized calcium.  
✅ ↓ ionized Ca2+  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ ↓ PTH  :
Incorrect: An increase in pH (more basic) decreases the amount of H+ in serum that binds to proteins, thereby increasing Ca2+ binding to proteins. This leads to a decrease in ionized calcium, which stimulates the release of parathyroid hormone (PTH).  
❌ ↓ 1-alpha hydroxylase activity  :
Incorrect: An increase in pH (more basic) decreases the amount of H+ in serum that binds to proteins, thereby increasing Ca2+ binding to proteins. This leads to a decrease in ionized calcium, which stimulates the release of parathyroid hormone (PTH). PTH enhances the activity of 1-alpha hydroxylase in the proximal convoluted tubule and increases calcium reabsorption.  
❌ ↑ calcitonin  :
Incorrect: An increase in pH (more basic) decreases the amount of H+ in serum that binds to proteins, thereby increasing Ca2+ binding to proteins. This leads to a decrease in ionized calcium. Calcitonin is released in response to high serum ionized calcium (not low).

questions.text: A group of investigators discovered special cells in the enteric nervous system that generate slow wave potentials in the intestinal tract. These cells are most appropriately described as which of the following?
questions.solution:
Interstitial cells of Cajal, located in the myenteric plexus, act like pacemaker cells in the heart. Cajal cells generate rhythmic depolarization and repolarization of the cell membrane, called slow-wave potentials, without any external stimulation from the neural or endocrine system.  

The depolarization of the Cajal cells is caused by the opening of slow sodium channels in the cell membrane which cause an influx of sodium ions, while repolarization is caused by the opening of potassium channels which allow for an efflux of potassium. Cajal cells are connected to smooth muscle cells via gap junctions which allow the slow wave potential to travel through the smooth muscles triggering voltage-gated ca2+ (calcium) channels to open, sparking depolarization of the smooth muscle cells.   

Option Analysis

❌ Keratinocytes:
Incorrect: Keratinocytes are the predominant cells in the epidermis, which are constantly generated in the basal lamina and go through maturation, differentiation, and migration to the surface. These are not found in the enteric nervous system.  
❌ Neuroglia:
Incorrect: Neuroglia is a diverse class of cells that provide developmental, physiological, and metabolic support for neurons. They are responsible for maintaining homeostatic control and immune surveillance in the nervous system. These are not found in the enteric nervous system.  
❌ Enterochromaffin (EC) cells  :
Incorrect: Enterochromaffin-like (ECL) cells in the intestinal mucosa sense a food bolus, and in response, secrete serotonin (5-HT) which binds to primary afferent neuron receptors to activate the peristalsis reflex. It is, however, not a part of the enteric nervous system and does not generate slow wave potentials.  
✅ Interstitial cells of Cajal  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Parietal cells  :
Incorrect: Parietal cells are found in the stomach where they secrete hydrochloric acid.  It is, however, not a part of the enteric nervous system and does not generate slow wave potential.

questions.text: A peripheral smear is taken from a patient and is examined under the microscope. One type of cell was identified and is shown in the picture below (marked with a black arrow). Which of the following is true about this cell?

choices.text: It is part of the adaptive immune response.
It helps in killing cancerous cells.
It presents foreign antigens to lymphocytes.

questions.solution:
Neutrophils are polymorphonuclear leukocytes (PMNs) with a multilobed nucleus (2-5 lobes). They are the most abundant granulocytes in the blood and they contain many granules (azurophilic and specific granules).  

Neutrophils are the main cells responsible for acute inflammation. They help defend against bacterial infections by phagocytosis. Once the bacteria is phagocytosed, it is destroyed via lysosomes or by oxidative bursts.  

Option Analysis

❌ It is part of the adaptive immune response.  :
Incorrect: Neutrophils are part of the innate immune system, not the adaptive immune system.  
❌ It helps in killing cancerous cells.  :
Incorrect: Neutrophils do not kill cancerous cells. Natural killer cells and T-cells are responsible for fighting against cancerous cells.  
❌ It defends against helminthic infections.  :
Incorrect: Eosinophils, not neutrophils, defend against helminthic infections.  
❌ It presents foreign antigens to lymphocytes.  :
Incorrect: Neutrophils are not antigen presenting cells. They are incapable of presenting antigens to lymphocytes.  
✅ It defends against bacterial infections.  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A group of immunologists are evaluating the human body’s defense mechanisms against pathogens. In their studies, they focused on the differences between the adaptive immune system and the innate immune system. Which of the following statements is true regarding these immune systems?

choices.text: The complement system is part of the innate immune system
The adaptive immune system cells have receptors that recognize surface structures shared between different pathogens but not found on the surface of their own body cells
All the cells of the lymphoid lineage are part of the adaptive immune system
The innate immune system is able to mount a stronger immune response when encountering a pathogen for the second time.
Secreted proteins are only seen in the innate immune system

questions.solution:
The immune system helps defend the body against infections and foreign molecules. It is made up of 2 parts: the innate and the adaptive immune responses.   

The innate immune system is the first-line defense against pathogens invading the body. The innate immune system is made of immune cells, which are macrophages, neutrophils, dendritic cells, and natural killer cells. In addition, it also includes other non-immune parts like the physical barrier of the skin and the secretions and enzymes in the body (e.g. gastric acid). The innate immune system is non-specific, which means that it responds in the same way to different pathogens. One of the features of this system is that it is fast and the immune cells can destroy the foreign body or pathogen within hours of entering the body. However, one of the drawbacks of the innate immune system is the lack of memory, and therefore will not be able to recognize an antigen or a foreign body if encountered again and will respond exactly the same as the first encounter of such antigen.  

Innate immunity against pathogens relies on the pattern recognition receptors (PRR) which recognizes and detects a wide range of pathogens that share common structures called pathogen-associated molecular patterns (PAMPs). Once they recognize PAMPs, the innate immune cells are able to destroy the pathogens immediately. Examples of PAMPs include lipopolysaccharide (LPS) on the surface of gram-negative bacteria as well as flagellin on the surface of bacteria. These PAMPs are found on the cell surface of the pathogen and therefore surface PRR will be able to recognize them. Additionally, intracellular PRR are able to recognize intracellular PAMPs like viral DNA or RNA.  

On the other hand, the adaptive immune response is made of lymphocytes and antibodies. It is specific against every single pathogen and this leads to a slower reaction than that of innate immunity. However, adaptive immune cells (lymphocytes) are able to form memory cells, and once a pathogen is encountered again, a much stronger and faster response occurs. The adaptive immune cells are capable of secreting immunoglobulins (i.e. antibodies) and cytokines that help modulate the immune response.  

Option Analysis

✅ The complement system is part of the innate immune system  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ The adaptive immune system cells have receptors that recognize surface structures shared between different pathogens but not found on the surface of their own body cells  :
Incorrect: Unlike the innate immune system, the adaptive immune system is specific and recognizes each different pathogen by its specific antigens.  
❌ All the cells of the lymphoid lineage are part of the adaptive immune system  :
Incorrect: Natural killer cells originate from the lymphoid lineage, but they are part of the innate immune system.  
❌ The innate immune system is able to mount a stronger immune response when encountering a pathogen for the second time.  :
Incorrect: Unlike the adaptive immune system, the innate immune system does not have memory cells. Therefore, when encountering a pathogen for the second time, the innate immune system will respond the same way it responds to the first encounter.  
❌ Secreted proteins are only seen in the innate immune system  :
Incorrect: Both systems secrete proteins that help in mounting the immune response.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is evaluated for a 6-hour history of fever, itchy rash, and generalized body aches. Ten days ago, he received a snake bite treatment in the emergency department. Physical examination is significant for fever, an urticarial rash, myalgia, and polyarthritis. Urine dipsticks show 2+ protein. Serum complement levels are reduced. Which is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Cytotoxic T-cell destruction of antigen-tagged cells

questions.solution:
This patient most likely has serum sickness after receiving anti-snake venom. This condition is a type III hypersensitivity reaction.   

Serum sickness refers to a systemic inflammatory response to the presence of immune complexes. It typically occurs when a patient receives foreign serum and elicits an antibody response against the foreign antigens in the serum. A classic example includes snakebites treated with antivenom serum. In response to this initial episode, the body generates antibodies against the anti-venom antibodies. So if the patient is bitten by a snake again with subsequent administration of serum, antibodies from the initial exposure bind and form immune complexes with the anti-venom antibodies. These immune complexes can deposit and cause vasculitis as well as tissue necrosis.  

Typical serum sickness results in fever, urticaria, arthralgia, lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, and eosinophilia a few days to two weeks following injection of the foreign serum or drug. Symptoms improve as the immune system removes the antigen and subsides completely when the antigen is eliminated.  

Option Analysis

❌ Arthus reaction  :
Incorrect: Arthus reaction refers to localized inflammation, in contrast to systemic inflammation. Intradermal injection of antigen into a pre-sensitized (has circulating IgG) individual leads to the immune complex formation in the skin (e.g., enhanced local reaction to a booster vaccination).  
✅ Serum sickness  :
Correct: See Main Explanation  
❌ IgE-mediated mast cell activation  :
Incorrect: Type I hypersensitivity reactions are mediated by IgE and mast cells and can be associated with hives, bronchospasm, and anaphylaxis. It occurs within minutes following the exposure to antigen.  
❌ Cytotoxic T-cell destruction of antigen-tagged cells  :
Incorrect: T cell-mediated destruction of antigen-tagged cells is characteristic of type IV hypersensitivity reactions, such as allergic contact dermatitis and exanthematous drug reactions.  
❌ Type II hypersensitivity reaction  :
Incorrect: Type II hypersensitivity reactions occur when antibodies bind to cell-surface antigens resulting in cellular destruction, inflammation, and dysfunction. Serum sickness is a type III hypersensitivity reaction.

questions.text: During states of reduced renal blood flow, angiotensin II is produced. Which of the following best describes the effect of angiotensin II on the kidney?
questions.solution:
