questions.text: An investigation is done on hemostasis to determine the steps involved in preventing blood loss after injury. During the experiment, the team determines that hemostasis typically has two stages: primary and secondary hemostasis. Which of the following is true regarding primary hemostasis?

choices.text: ADP released from activated platelets binds to P2Y12 receptors on adjacent platelets, causing increased expression of Gp2B/3A.
After an endothelial injury, vasodilation mediated by neural reflex occurs immediately
Adhesion of platelets to the site of injury is mediated by binding to von Willebrand factor (vWF) via GpIIB/IIIA receptors
Calcium released from platelets binds to P2Y12 receptors on adjacent platelets, causing increased expression of Gp2b/3A.
Fibrinogen mediates platelets aggregation via GpIB receptors

questions.solution:
After an injury to a blood vessel, hemostasis occurs to prevent blood loss. Hemostasis is divided into two stages, primary and secondary hemostasis. Primary hemostasis occurs first and results in a platelet plug formation at the site of endothelial injury.  

Primary hemostasis starts immediately after an endothelial injury and is divided into five main stages: endothelial injury, exposure, adhesion, activation, and aggregation.   

Endothelial injury: Primary hemostasis starts when a blood vessel's endothelium is injured. The first thing that happens is vasoconstriction to prevent further blood loss, which is mediated by both neural reflex and endothelin released from damaged endothelial cells.  



Exposure: The injured endothelial cells allow for the exposure of subendothelial collagen,  which binds to the von Willebrand factor (vWF) released from damaged endothelial cells.  

Adhesion: Platelets then bind to the vWF (which is bound to the subendothelial collagen at the site of injury) via GpIB receptors on the platelets, which results in the activation of platelets.  



Activation: Once the platelets bind to VWF and get activated, they undergo a conformational change and release calcium, ADP, and thromboxane A2. Calcium is involved in the secondary hemostasis. ADP binds to the P2Y12 receptors on adjacent platelets and induces the expression of GpIIB/IIIA receptors on the platelets, which mediates the final step of primary hemostasis.  



Aggregation: Finally, after GpIIB/IIIA are expressed on the platelets, fibrinogen binds these receptors and helps aggregate platelets together, forming a platelet plug and marking an end for the primary hemostasis.  



Option Analysis

✅ ADP released from activated platelets binds to P2Y12 receptors on adjacent platelets, causing increased expression of Gp2B/3A.   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ After an endothelial injury, vasodilation mediated by neural reflex occurs immediately  :
Incorrect: Immediately after endothelial injury, vasoconstriction is mediated by neural reflex and endothelin. This is the first step in primary hemostasis.  
❌ Adhesion of platelets to the site of injury is mediated by binding to von Willebrand factor (vWF) via GpIIB/IIIA receptors  :
Incorrect: vWF binds to the subendothelial collagen exposed after endothelial injury. Then platelets bind to the VWF using GpIB receptors. This is called adhesion.  
❌ Calcium released from platelets binds to P2Y12 receptors on adjacent platelets, causing increased expression of Gp2b/3A.  :
Incorrect: Calcium released from activated platelets aids in secondary hemostasis. In contrast, ADP binds to the P2Y12 receptors on adjacent platelets, resulting in increased expression of Gp2b/3A.  
❌ Fibrinogen mediates platelets aggregation via GpIB receptors  :
Incorrect: Fibrinogen mediates platelet aggregation via GpIIB/3A receptors.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents for evaluation of right calf swelling. An ultrasound is performed and the patient is found to have a blood clot occluding half the luminal diameter of the right popliteal vein. At baseline, the patient’s right popliteal vein has a resistance of R. The pressure gradient across the vessel is P and the rate of blood flow is Q. Assuming the pressure gradient is unchanged, which of the following best characterizes the new vascular resistance and flow rate?
questions.solution:
This question is asking how changes in blood vessel diameter will affect vascular resistance and blood flow. To answer this question, it is essential to understand the factors affecting vascular resistance as well as the relationship between vascular resistance, pressure, and flow.

Vascular resistance describes the impediment to blood flow through a vessel and can be calculated via the following equation:
 
 
According to the equation, resistance is proportional to the vessel’s length, and blood viscosity (how thick a fluid is). In other words, an increase in blood viscosity (e.g. polycythemia) or vessel length will lead to an increase in resistance. In contrast, resistance is inversely proportional to the fourth power of the vessel’s radius. Thus, if the vessel radius were halved, as in this vignette, then resistance would increase 16-fold.

The relation between flow rate, pressure gradient, and vascular resistance is demonstrated via the following equation:
 

Therefore, an increase in resistance will lead to a decrease in blood flow, assuming the pressure gradient remains unchanged. In this vignette, since the vascular resistance increased from R to 16R, the flow will decline from Q to Q/16.  

Option Analysis

✅ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ :
Incorrect: Resistance is inversely proportional to the fourth power of the vessel radius. Occlusion of half the vessel lumen will cause the radius to half and resistance to increase 16-fold (16R). The increase in resistance will in turn cause the flow rate to decrease.   
❌ :
Incorrect: Resistance is inversely proportional to the fourth power of the vessel radius. Occlusion of half the vessel lumen will cause the radius to half and resistance to increase 16-fold (16R). The increase in resistance will in turn cause the flow rate to decrease.   
❌ :
Incorrect: Resistance is inversely proportional to the fourth power of the vessel radius. As a result, a decrease in vessel radius by one-half will lead to a 16-fold increase in resistance (16R). Furthermore, blood flow is inversely proportional to resistance. This means the 16-fold increase in resistance will cause the flow rate to be 1/16th of the original (Q/16).   
❌ :
Incorrect: Resistance is inversely proportional to the fourth power of the vessel radius. As a result, a decrease in vessel radius by one-half will lead to a 16-fold increase in resistance (16R). Furthermore, blood flow is inversely proportional to resistance, which means an increase in resistance will result in decreased blood flow.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the clinic to establish care. The patient does not have any complaints. She does not have chest pain, dizziness, palpitations, or shortness of breath. Cardiac auscultation in the left 5th intercostal space reveals an early diastolic high-frequency sound followed by a mid-to-late diastolic murmur. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Heart murmurs can be characterized by the location where they are best heard, their timing within the cardiac cycle, and associated findings. Diastolic murmurs are heard after the second heart sound (S2). The auscultatory findings of a mid-to-late diastolic murmur with associated opening snap (early diastolic high-frequency sound) make the diagnosis of mitral stenosis (MS) most likely. An abrupt halt causes the opening snap in leaflet motion after rapid opening due to fusion at the tips of the leaflets.

Other commonly encountered causes of diastolic murmurs include:
 
  •  Tricuspid stenosis, which causes the same murmur like that of mitral stenosis best heard at the left lower sternal border. The inspiratory accentuation aids in differentiation from the murmur of mitral stenosis. 
  •  Aortic regurgitation causes a high-pitched, blowing, early diastolic decrescendo murmur. It can be best heard at the base (in aortic root dilation) or left sternal border (in valvular disease). 
  •  Pulmonic regurgitation also causes the same murmur as aortic regurgitation and radiates to the left sternal border, making differentiation difficult. When it occurs as an isolated defect, its murmur may increase with inspiration. It is usually seen in patients with pulmonary hypertension. 

Option Analysis

❌ Aortic stenosis:
Incorrect: Aortic stenosis causes a crescendo-decrescendo systolic ejection murmur that is best heard in the right second intercostal space. It radiates to the carotids in the neck.  
✅ Mitral stenosis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Aortic regurgitation:
Incorrect: Aortic regurgitation causes a high-pitched, blowing, early diastolic decrescendo murmur that is best heard at the base (in aortic root dilation) or left sternal border (in valvular disease).  
❌ Ventricular septal defect  :
Incorrect: Ventricular septal defect causes a holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border (LLSB).  
❌ Mitral valve prolapse  :
Incorrect: Mitral valve prolapse causes a late systolic crescendo murmur with a midsystolic click best heard over the apex.

questions.text: During an evaluation of the action potential of the heart, some cells were identified to be responsible for the rate of the heart. These cells are located in the right atrium near the opening of the superior vena cava. The action potential of these cells is recorded and shown below. It was found that the slope of phase 4 (marked with the blue dot) determines the rate at which the heart contracts. Which of the following events occur during this phase?

choices.text: Influx of sodium ions into the cell
Influx of calcium ions into the cell
Efflux of potassium ions outside the cell
Efflux of chloride ions outside the cell
Influx of potassium ions into the cell

questions.solution:
Pacemaker cells are where the action potential of the heart starts; therefore, they are responsible for setting the rhythm and the rate of the heart. These cells continuously generate action potentials that are then conducted to the rest of the heart. The most important pacemaker cells are the sinoatrial (SA) nodes located in the right atrium near the opening of the superior vena cava. Additionally, the atrioventricular (AV) node is a small structure in the heart, near the coronary sinus on the interatrial septum, which also contains pacemaker cells. Other pacemaker cells are also found in the internodal tract, the Bundle of His, and the Purkinje fibers.

The action potential in the pacemaker cells is different from the rest of the heart, and is divided into 3 main phases: phase 4, phase 0, and phase 3.

Phase 4, also known as the pacemaker phase, is unique to the pacemaker cells. In this phase, there is a gradual depolarization due to the slow influx of sodium ions into the cells through the  hyperpolarization-activated cyclic nucleotide-gated channel (HCN channel); these may sometimes be referred to as the “funny” current (If). This slow influx of sodium brings the membrane potential from -65 mV to the threshold of the pacemaker cells -40 mV. The slope of this phase determines the heart rate.
 

Phase 0, is the depolarization phase. Once the action potential of the pacemaker reaches the threshold of -40 mV, voltage-gated calcium channels open and the influx of calcium ions into the cells causes depolarization and brings the membrane potential up to +10 mV. Note that the depolarization of the pacemaker cells is due to the influx of calcium ions, and not sodium ions unlike the myocardial cells.
 
 
Phase 3, is the repolarization phase. Finally, once depolarization is complete, the voltage-gated calcium channels close and the potassium channels open. This results in a rapid efflux of potassium ions outside the cells bringing the membrane potential back to -65 mV or even lower. During this phase, both the HCN channels bringing sodium ions in and the potassium channels bringing potassium ions out of the cell are open; however, because much more potassium ions leave than sodium enters the cell, the membrane potential drops. After phase 3 is done, the action potential is complete, and the cell enters phase 4 again to start a new action potential.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Influx of sodium ions into the cell  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Influx of calcium ions into the cell  :
Incorrect: Depolarization of the pacemaker cells (phase 0) is due to the influx of calcium ions into the cells. However, in phase 4, only sodium ions are open, and calcium channels are closed.  
❌ Efflux of potassium ions outside the cell:
Incorrect: Efflux of potassium ions outside the cell is responsible for phase 3 (repolarization phase) of the action potential in pacemaker cells. Phase 4 is due to an influx of sodium ions.  
❌ Efflux of chloride ions outside the cell  :
Incorrect: Phase 4 of the action potential in the pacemaker is due to the influx of sodium ions into the cell, not the efflux of chloride ions outside the cell.  
❌ Influx of potassium ions into the cell  :
Incorrect: Phase 4 of the action potential in the pacemaker is due to the influx of sodium ions into the cell, not the influx of potassium ions into the cells.

questions.text: Glucagon, a hormone produced during a period of fasting, is made by pancreatic α-cells, which are adjacent to the insulin-producing β-cells. Which of the following best describes the action of glucagon?

choices.text: Inhibits the activity of glycogen phosphorylase

questions.solution:
Glucagon, a hormone produced during a period of fasting, is made by pancreatic α-cells, which are adjacent to the insulin-producing β-cells. Glucagon signals via Gs-protein coupled receptors and the secondary messenger molecule cyclic AMP. It primarily acts on the liver and adipose tissue in humans. It stimulates processes that promote the release of glucose into the system, such as glycogenolysis, gluconeogenesis, and fatty acid oxidation. Glucagon levels increase two to threefold in response to hypoglycemia, and the liver begins production of glucose from glycogen. During times of high blood glucose, glucagon is reduced to half of its normal level. Glucagon also stimulates the release of insulin, thereby allowing insulin-sensitive cells to take up the released glucose. Glucagon secretion is also inhibited by insulin, amylin, and somatostatin.   

Option Analysis

❌ Stimulates glycogen synthesis  :
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. Glucagon inhibits glycogen synthesis by the enzyme glycogen synthase.  
❌ Increases the rate of glycolysis  :
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. Glucagon decreases glycolysis.  
❌ Inhibits gluconeogenesis  :
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. Glucagon stimulates gluconeogenesis.  
❌ Inhibits the activity of glycogen phosphorylase  :
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. Glucagon promotes glycogenolysis by stimulating glycogen phosphorylase.  
✅ Stimulates fatty acid oxidation  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman, gravida 1 para 0, comes to the physician for her first prenatal visit at ten weeks gestation. The patient has no active complaints at this time. Vitals are within normal limits. Serum studies in this patient are most likely to show the following sets of laboratory values?
questions.solution:
Thyroglobulin (Tg) plays a vital role in synthesizing and storing thyroid hormones. Under normal circumstances, TBG binds noncovalently to nearly all of the T4 and T3 in plasma, and it binds T4 with greater affinity than T3.  

The hyperestrogenic state during pregnancy stimulates the synthesis of thyroid-binding globulin (TBG) and increases TBG's glycosylation. This process slows the clearance of TBG, increasing its serum level. As more free T3 and T4 bind to TBG, the level of free thyroid hormones decreases. Consequently, the pituitary gland secretes more TSH, enhancing the production and secretion of thyroid hormones. This achieves a new equilibrium in which the total T3 and T4 levels (i.e., bound and unbound T3 and T4) are increased while the free T3 and T4 levels are normal. On the other hand, in states of hypoproteinemia (e.g., nephrotic syndrome, chronic liver disease), TBG synthesis decreases, leading to an increase in free T3/T4 in serum. This reduces thyroid hormone synthesis.   

Option Analysis

✅  Thyroid-binding globulin  Free T3  Free T4  Total T3 + T4  ↑  Normal  Normal  ↑ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌  Thyroid-binding globulin  Free T3  Free T4  Total T3 + T4 ↓ Normal  Normal  ↓ :
Incorrect: This set of thyroid function tests is typically seen in conditions that cause thyroid-binding globulin deficiency (e.g., nephrotic syndrome, cirrhosis), which leads to a higher level of free T3 and T4. Consequently, TSH secretion is suppressed, and the new equilibrium shows decreased total T3 and T4 levels with normal free T3 and T4 levels.   
❌  Thyroid-binding globulin  Free T3  Free T4  Total T3 + T4  Normal   Normal  Normal  Normal  :
Incorrect: This set of thyroid function tests is typically seen in a healthy nonpregnant individual. However, the hyperestrogenic state in pregnancy results in physiological changes that would alter this patient's thyroid function test.   
❌  Thyroid-binding globulin  Free T3  Free T4  Total T3 + T4  Normal   ↑ ↑ ↑ :
Incorrect: A thyroid function test that shows an increase in the free and total T3 and T4 levels is typically seen in hyperthyroidism. Although hCG, which increases significantly during pregnancy, has a thyrotropic activity, this patient is clinically euthyroid (i.e., normal heart rate and blood pressure and no symptoms of hyperthyroidism).   
❌  Thyroid-binding globulin  Free T3  Free T4  Total T3 + T4  ↓ ↓ Normal  ↓:
Incorrect: A normal free T4 level in decreased thyroid-binding globulin, free T3, and total T3 and T4 levels can be seen in sick euthyroid syndrome. Sick euthyroid syndrome is seen in severely ill patients and is therefore unlikely in this healthy pregnant patient.

questions.text: A researcher is studying respiratory physiology. Which of the following conditions will most likely lead to an increase in lung compliance?
questions.solution:
Lung compliance describes the distensibility of the respiratory system. It measures the change in lung volume for a given change in pressure. The value is inversely released to lung stiffness or elastance (amount of elastic tissue present), with a stiffer lung or lung having more elastic tissue possessing lower compliance.

In general, conditions that decrease the amount of pulmonary elastic tissue (e.g., emphysema, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease) will increase compliance. In contrast, conditions that increase pulmonary elastic tissue (e.g., pulmonary fibrosis, scarring), increase alveolar filling (e.g., pneumonia, acute respiratory distress syndrome), or decrease pulmonary surfactant production (e.g., neonatal respiratory distress syndrome) will cause a decrease in compliance.  

Option Analysis

✅ Emphysema:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis:
Incorrect: Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis will lead to increased lung stiffness and decreased compliance.  
❌ Guillain-Barre syndrome:
Incorrect: Guillain-Barre syndrome is an immune-mediated condition that can lead to respiratory muscle weakness. As a result, the condition will lead to decreased chest wall compliance. However, it would not affect lung compliance.  
❌ Acute respiratory distress syndrome:
Incorrect: Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) is characterized by alveolar injury and accumulation of exudative fluid within the airspaces. These changes will lead to increased lung stiffness and decreased lung compliance.  
❌ Lobar pneumonia:
Incorrect: Lobar pneumonia is characterized by the accumulation of exudative fluid within the alveoli. These changes will lead to increased lung stiffness and decreased lung compliance.

questions.text: A researcher is currently studying pulmonary circulation in both healthy adults and those with chronic lung disease. Which of the following is an example of perfusion-limited gas exchange?
questions.solution:
Normal gas exchange in the lung depends on diffusion and perfusion limitations. Diffusion-limited gas exchange is limited by the diffusion rate of the gas across the alveolar membrane. Examples include carbon monoxide or structural lung diseases such as COPD.

In contrast, perfusion-limited gas exchange results in partial pressures that equilibrate before blood leaves the alveolar capillaries, and gas exchange is dependent on the rate of blood flow through the capillary. A classic example is the administration of nitrous oxide, as this gas displays a rapid diffusion rate across the alveolar membrane and is not bound by hemoglobin. This results in a rapid rise of nitrous oxide within blood with only a minimal amount of the gas within an alveolus.

Option Analysis

✅ Administration of nitrous oxide:
Correct: See Main Explanation,  
❌ Emphysema:
Incorrect: In diffusion-limited gas exchange, the partial pressures between the alveolus and capillary do not equilibrate by the time blood reaches the end of the capillary. Diffusion-limited gas exchange is limited by the diffusion rate of the gas across the alveolar membrane. Examples include carbon monoxide or structural lung diseases such as COPD.  
❌ Pulmonary fibrosis:
Incorrect: In diffusion-limited gas exchange, the partial pressures between the alveolus and capillary do not equilibrate by the time blood reaches the end of the capillary. Diffusion-limited gas exchange is limited by the diffusion rate of the gas across the alveolar membrane. Examples include carbon monoxide or structural lung diseases such as COPD.  
❌ Administration of carbon monoxide:
Incorrect: In diffusion-limited gas exchange, the partial pressures between the alveolus and capillary do not equilibrate by the time blood reaches the end of the capillary. Diffusion-limited gas exchange is limited by the diffusion rate of the gas across the alveolar membrane. Examples include carbon monoxide or structural lung diseases such as COPD.  
❌ Strenuous exercise:
Incorrect: Strenuous exercise is an example of diffusion-limited gas exchange, not perfusion-limited gas exchange.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to the physician to evaluate episodic right upper quadrant pain. The pain comes a few hours after eating a meal, especially fatty meals, and lasts for 3-4 hours. The pain is colicky. Ultrasound reveals a stone in the cystic duct. The pain is triggered mainly due to the secretion of which of the following hormones?
questions.solution:
This patient has gallstones, and the colicky pain is due to the contraction of the gallbladder against an obstruction. Gallbladder contraction is mediated by cholecystokinin (CCK).

CCK is a peptide hormone produced by the I cells in the small intestine, specifically, the duodenum and jejunum. The presence of fatty acids and amino acids in the lumen of the small intestines stimulates the secretion of CCK.  

CCK stimulates gallbladder contraction to release bile into the intestine. It also stimulates pancreatic secretions, which help in the digestion of fat while mediating the relaxation of the sphincter of Oddi to allow these juices to reach the intestine. Finally, CCK decreases gastric emptying.   

Option Analysis

❌ Secretin:
Incorrect: Secretin stimulates the secretions of pancreatic fluid and bile. However, it does not mediate gallbladder contraction.  
✅ Cholecystokinin  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Somatostatin:
Incorrect: Somatostatin inhibits the secretion of various hormones in the gastrointestinal tract, including cholecystokinin. Therefore, using somatostatin analogs octreotide) can predispose to the formation of gallstones. However, biliary colic is due to the contraction of the gallbladder against an obstruction, which is mediated by cholecystokinin.  
❌ Gastrin:
Incorrect: Gastrin is not related to gallbladder contraction.  
❌ Vasoactive intestinal polypeptide (VIP)   :
Incorrect: VIP is not related to gallbladder contraction.

questions.text: A group of researchers are conducting a study on vitamin K. In the study, they find that vitamin K, once absorbed, enters the liver and participates in a series of reactions that lead to the activation of several clotting factors. Which of the following is true regarding vitamin K?

choices.text: y-glutamyl carboxylase uses the reduced form of vitamin K to activate clotting factors.
The reduced form of vitamin K is converted to the oxidized form using epoxide reductase enzyme.
Vitamin K helps activate the clotting factors of the extrinsic pathway only.
Vitamin K helps activate the clotting factors of the intrinsic pathway only.
Epoxide reductase uses the reduced form of vitamin K to activate clotting factors.

questions.solution:
Vitamin K is a fat soluble vitamin that is obtained from the diet or from bacteria in the gut. Once absorbed, vitamin K enters the liver where it is activated and used in the activation of clotting factors.  

The active form of vitamin K is the reduced form. Once in the reduced form, vitamin K acts as a cofactor to the enzyme y-glutamyl carboxylase in activating the clotting factors II, VII, IX, X, and protein C and S. After this reaction, vitamin K is converted into the oxidized form which is inactive.  

In order to recycle and reuse vitamin K, it must be converted back to the reduced form (active form), which is done by the enzyme epoxide reductase. Epoxide reductase converts the oxidized form of vitamin K to the reduced form, which can be then used again by y-glutamyl carboxylase in the activation of clotting factors. Notably, warfarin is an anticoagulant that inhibits vitamin K epoxide reductase, thereby inhibiting this recycling process.  


Option Analysis

✅ y-glutamyl carboxylase uses the reduced form of vitamin K to activate clotting factors.  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ The reduced form of vitamin K is converted to the oxidized form using epoxide reductase enzyme.  :
 Incorrect: The active form of vitamin K is the reduced form, and epoxide reductase converts the oxidized form to the reduced form and, therefore, activates vitamin K.
❌ Vitamin K helps activate the clotting factors of the extrinsic pathway only.  :
Incorrect: Vitamin K helps in activating factors II, VII, IX, X, as well as protein C and S.  
❌ Vitamin K helps activate the clotting factors of the intrinsic pathway only.  :
Incorrect: Vitamin K helps in activating factors II, VII, IX, X, as well as protein C and S.  
❌ Epoxide reductase uses the reduced form of vitamin K to activate clotting factors.  :
Incorrect: The function of epoxide reductase is to convert the oxidized form of vitamin K to the reduced form, where it can be used by the enzyme y-glutamyl carboxylase to activate clotting factors.

questions.text: During an evaluation of the inflammatory response against certain bacterial pathogens, an interaction between lymphocytes and macrophages was observed to mediate an immune response. In this interaction, macrophages are exposed to the pathogen and then secreted interleukin-12, which activates a specific lymphocyte to secrete interferon-gamma. Which of the following is the correct match of the source and function of interferon-gamma?

choices.text: Source  Function   Th1 cells   Stimulates the differentiation of Th2 cells

questions.solution:
Cytokines play an important role in the immune response by acting on specific receptors. Hundreds of cytokines are produced by immune cells (e.g., macrophages, lymphocytes) and non-immune cells.  

Some cytokines are produced by T-cells, especially CD4+ cells, which can help the immune system. Interleukin-2 (IL-2) is one of these cytokines that is produced by CD4+ T-helper cells. IL-2 stimulates the growth of lymphocytes, including helper and cytotoxic lymphocytes, and natural killer cells to help perform an immune response. Interleukin-3 (IL-3) is also produced by helper T-cells and acts on the bone marrow to stimulate the production of more immune cells.  

IL-2 and IL-3 are produced by all helper T cells. However, some cytokines are produced specifically by Th1 cells, while others are produced by Th2 cells only.  

The main cytokine produced by Th1 cells is interferon-gamma (IFN-γ). IFN-γ is released from Th1 cells after they are activated by pathogens or by interleukin-12 (IL-12) released from macrophages. IFN-γ then activates the macrophages to make them more efficient in engulfing and killing the pathogens and, in some cases, activates the macrophages to induce the formation of a granuloma. It also activates natural killer cells to kill virally-infected cells while increasing the expression of MHC. Furthermore, IFN-γ can mediate class switching in B-cells to IgG; finally, it inhibits the differentiation of Th2 cells.  

On the other hand, the cytokines released from Th2 cells are mainly geared towards fighting parasitic infections but are also involved in allergic responses (e.g. asthma). These cytokines are IL-4, IL-5,IL-10, and IL-13.  

  • IL-4: Induces the growth and differentiation of Th2 cells. It also stimulates the class switching in B-cells to IgE and IgG. IL-4 also mediates the degranulation of mast cells.  
  • IL-5: Stimulates the B-cells and causes class switching to IgA. It also stimulates the production and growth of eosinophils.  
  • IL-10: An anti-inflammatory cytokine that attenuates the immune system. It targets macrophages and inhibits IL-12 production and thus inhibits the Th1 development; it also targets Th1 cells and inhibits the production of IL-2 and IFN-γ. It also decreases the expression of antigens on MHC II.  
  • IL-13: Stimulates the growth of B-cells and class switching to IgE. It acts with IL-4 in mediating immune responses against parasitic infections as well as in mediating allergic reactions.    

Option Analysis

✅  Source  Function   Th1 cells   Stimulate natural killer cells :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌  Source  Function   Th1 cells   Stimulates the differentiation of Th2 cells:
Incorrect: Interferon-gamma inhibits the differentiation of Th2 cells.   
❌  Source  Function   Th2 cells   Decrease MHC expression :
Incorrect: IL-10 produced by Th2 cells attenuates the immune response and decreases MHC expression. However, IFN-γ increases the expression of MHC and is produced by Th1 cells.   
❌  Source  Function   Th2 cells   Enhance class switching to IgA :
Incorrect: This is the function of IL-5 produced by Th2 cells.
❌  Source  Function   Th1 cells   Activates eosinophils :
Incorrect: IL-5 produced by Th2 cells, not Th1 cells, stimulates the production and growth of eosinophils.

questions.text: A maturing T cell undergoes VDJ rearrangement. A strand of DNA containing a V and D gene is looped on itself, and a piece of DNA between these two genes is cut out. These two pieces of DNA are subsequently reattached. Which of the following enzymes is responsible for adding random nucleotides to promote further diversity at this stage of T cell formation?
questions.solution:
B cells and T cells both undergo V(D)J rearrangement during the cell maturation process to promote diversity among antigen-binding at the variable regions of the B cell and T cell receptors. Within the variable regions of the B cell receptor (BCR) and T cell receptor (TCR), the hypervariable region is created when the two chains of the receptor bind together to form the final antigen-binding site. Within these hypervariable regions, V(D)J rearrangement occurs extensively. This process starts with beta-chains in T cells and heavy chains in B cells, where random V, D, and J regions are combined with random nucleotides between them. These resultant cells with incomplete receptors are then tested with multiple other chains (alpha-chains for T cells and light chains for B cells) to ensure they are functional and not self-reactive. Alpha-chains (T cells) and light chains (B cells) only contain V and J regions, so they undergo a similar process but without any D genes. This eventually leads to a pool of immune cells with one chain containing a wide variety of VDJ combinations, which is paired with a wide variety of other chains containing a wide variety of VJ combinations.  

The actual process of V(D)J rearrangement is accomplished via several important enzymes, including recombination-activating gene 1 (RAG1), RAG2, Artemis, Ku DNA-protein-kinase, terminal deoxynucleotide transferase (TdT), and others. Recombination signal sequences flank the V, D, and J regions, and signal the DNA to be looped around that area. RAG1 and RAG2 bind to this area and cut out the non-coding circular DNA. Artemis and Ku DNA-protein-kinase then begin reattaching and recombining the V, D, and J segments without this non-coding DNA. During recombination, TdT inserts random nucleotides between the V, D, and J genes, creating a unique strand of DNA and thus protein, even if the V, D, and J genes are the exact same.   

Option Analysis

❌ Artemis enzyme  :
Incorrect: This repair protein, along with Ku DNA-protein-kinase, recombines DNA sequences that have been cut by RAG1 and RAG2.  
✅ Terminal deoxynucleotide transferase (TdT)  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Recombination-activating gene 1 (RAG1)  :
Incorrect: RAG1 and RAG2 cut VDJ genes at the recombination signal sequences, allowing for subsequent reattachment of DNA strands without these signal sequences and wasting a circular piece of non-coding DNA.  
❌ Recombination-activating gene 2 (RAG2)  :
Incorrect: RAG1 and RAG2 cut VDJ genes at the recombination signal sequences, allowing for subsequent reattachment of DNA strands without these signal sequences and wasting a circular piece of non-coding DNA.
❌ Ku DNA-protein-kinase  :
Incorrect: This repair protein, along with Artemis, recombines DNA sequences that have been cut by RAG1 and RAG2.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman is diagnosed with post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis following a history of skin infection. Which of the following best describes the underlying mechanism of this disease?

choices.text: Cytotoxic T-cell destruction of antigen-tagged cells

questions.solution:
Hypersensitivity reactions occur when the normally protective immune system responds abnormally, potentially harming the body. In type III hypersensitivity reactions, IgG binds to the antigen (e.g., the drug molecules in circulation) to form an immune complex (antigen-antibody complex). These complexes are usually removed by cells of the monocyte-macrophage system but, in excess, circulate and deposit in blood vessels, the kidneys, and joints. In autoimmune disorders, “self” antigens often elicit antibodies that bind to organ antigens or deposit in organs and tissues. When deposited, the immune complexes initiate a complement cascade that attracts neutrophils resulting in neutrophil lysis or phagocytosis. Finally, environmental antigens such as fungal spores and certain medications induce immune complex formation.  

Acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis is a well-known immune complex disease that occurs several weeks following a group A β-hemolytic streptococcal infection, particularly of the skin. Lumpy deposits of immunoglobulin and complement components, C3, are observed along the glomerular basement membrane. Complement levels are typically low, suggesting an antigen-antibody reaction with corresponding consumption.  

Additional examples of type III hypersensitivity include rheumatoid arthritis, reactive arthritis, and systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).   

Option Analysis

❌ Complement-dependent reaction  :
Incorrect: With a complement-dependent reaction, antibody bound to antigen fixes to complement and induces direct cell lysis through the production of the membrane attack complex (MAC). Examples include Goodpasture syndrome, rheumatic fever, and hyperacute transplant rejection.  
❌ Antibody-dependent cell-mediated cytotoxicity  :
Incorrect: With antibody-dependent cell-mediated cytotoxicity (cellular destruction), cell types that bear receptors for the Fc portion of IgG, such as neutrophils, eosinophils, macrophages, and natural killer (NK) cells, mediate removal of an antigen. Examples include transfusion reactions, erythroblastosis fetalis, and autoimmune hemolytic anemia.  
✅ Immune complex-mediated complement activation  :
Correct: See Main Explanation  
❌ Cytotoxic T-cell destruction of antigen-tagged cells  :
Incorrect: T cell-mediated destruction of antigen-tagged cells is characteristic of type IV hypersensitivity reactions, such as allergic contact dermatitis and exanthematous drug reactions.  
❌ IgE-mediated mast cell activation  :
Incorrect: Type I hypersensitivity reactions are mediated by IgE and mast cells and are associated with hives, bronchospasm, and anaphylaxis.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man who previously lived at sea level moves to a new city in the mountains. Which of the following changes are expected to be seen after 6 months of living at a higher elevation?
questions.solution:
Erythropoietin (EPO) is a glycoprotein that stimulates red blood cell synthesis in the bone marrow. It is mainly produced in the peritubular cells of the renal cortex, although a tiny fraction is produced by other organs (mainly the liver).

EPO synthesis and release are directly controlled by tissue hypoxia. Under normal conditions, a small amount is produced to maintain normal red blood cell (RBC) production. However, when PaO2 drops, the synthesis of EPO increases significantly to stimulate additional RBC production.

When the kidney tubular cells receive normal amounts of oxygen, oxygen hydroxylates the alpha-portion of a factor called hypoxia-induced factor (HIF). This change tags the HIF for ubiquitination and destruction. However, when oxygen supply decreases, the alpha segment of HIF is not hydroxylated or destroyed. Therefore, HIF remains in the cell and diffuses to the nucleus, increasing the synthesis of EPO mRNA and eventually leading to increased EPO production.

Option Analysis

✅ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ :
Incorrect: Hypoxia (e.g. living in high altitudes) causes increased erythropoietin production and increased red blood cell (RBC) synthesis. However, the RBC lifespan does not change.   
❌ :
Incorrect: Increased red blood cell count in patients exposed to hypoxic conditions for prolonged periods is secondary to increased erythropoietin production.   
❌ :
Incorrect: These changes may be present in the setting of a primary bone marrow malignancy (e.g. polycythemia vera), resulting in increased red blood cell (RBC) synthesis independent of erythropoietin levels. However, this patient recently moved to a city located at high elevation and is expected to have increased erythropoietin levels and increased RBC count.   
❌ :
Incorrect: Reduced oxygen content at high altitudes leads to increased erythropoietin and red blood cell count.

questions.text:
A 5-day-old male is brought to the pediatrician for evaluation for jaundice. He was born at 40 weeks gestation via an uncomplicated vaginal delivery. The patient’s blood is B, Rh D-negative. His mother’s blood is AB, Rh D-positive. The patient has been exclusively breastfed, produces 6-7 wet diapers per day, and has passed meconium. He is at the 70th percentile for weight and height. Physical examination shows scleral icterus as well as yellowing of the skin of the head and chest. The remainder of the exam is noncontributory. Laboratory testing reveals the following findings:  
 
Laboratory value  Result
 Total bilirubin  9.0 mg/dL 
 Conjugated bilirubin  0.3 mg/dL 
 Hemoglobin  17.1 g/dL 
 Leukocyte count  6,500/mm3 
Which of the following best describes the pathophysiology of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Destruction of neonatal erythrocytes by maternal antibodies
Breakdown of blood accumulated under the scalp
Fibro-obliterative destruction of the biliary tracts

questions.solution:
This patient has physiologic jaundice of the newborn, a common condition that manifests within 2-7 days after birth. The condition is often seen in preterm infants and Asian newborns.  

Physiologic jaundice of the newborn is caused by three factors. First, fetal erythrocytes have shorter lifespans. As a result, more unconjugated bilirubin gets produced. Second, newborn livers have immature UDP-glucuronyl transferase that is inefficient in conjugating bilirubin. Third, there is increased enterohepatic circulation of bilirubin. This phenomenon is because there is a lower concentration of bacteria in neonatal digestive tracts, and therefore there is less intestinal bacterial conversion of conjugated bilirubin to urobilin, which is excreted via urine. As a result, more conjugated bilirubin is broken down into unconjugated bilirubin by beta-glucuronidase (an intestinal enzyme) and reabsorbed.  

Physiologic jaundice of the newborn is usually a benign condition that resolves in 1-2 weeks. Most cases do not require treatment. In severe cases, treatment with non-UV phototherapy is used to isomerize unconjugated bilirubin into a water-soluble form that can be excreted via urine. This therapy prevents kernicterus, which occurs when large amounts of unconjugated bilirubin deposit in the brain and cause neurological damage.  

Option Analysis

❌ Destruction of neonatal erythrocytes by maternal antibodies:
Incorrect: This describes ABO and Rh-incompatibility. Both of these conditions occur when maternal antibodies cross the placenta and attack fetal red blood cells, resulting in their lysis. However, this patient’s mother is unlikely to produce anti-D antibodies (given she is Rh D-positive) or anti-B antibodies (given she is AB positive).
❌ Insufficient breast milk intake:
Incorrect: This describes breastfeeding failure jaundice, which occurs secondary to poor breast milk intake. As a result, these babies have inadequate stooling and decreased elimination of bilirubin by stool. This leads to increased enterohepatic circulation of bilirubin and an unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. However, this patient is producing 6-7 wet diapers per day, which indicates that he is well-hydrated and successfully breastfeeding. A helpful tip in determining the minimum number of wet diapers in the first week of life is that it is usually equivalent to the number of days since birth (e.g. a 5-day-old infant should produce 5 wet diapers/day). 
❌ Breakdown of blood accumulated under the scalp :
Incorrect: Breakdown of blood in a cephalohematoma can cause unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. The condition is often caused by shearing forces during vacuum or forceps delivery. In contrast, this patient had an uncomplicated vaginal delivery. Moreover, no scalp swelling was found on physical exam.
✅ Reduced hepatic conjugation of bilirubin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Fibro-obliterative destruction of the biliary tracts:
Incorrect: This describes biliary atresia, a condition wherein fibrosis results in destruction of the extrahepatic biliary tree. Individuals will have jaundice, dark urine, and pale stools. However, biliary atresia would cause conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, whereas this patient has unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with severe midsternal chest pain. The patient reports 2 episodes of non-bloody emesis and diaphoresis since the start of the chest pain half an hour ago. Blood pressure is 110/75 and pulse is 89/min. Physical examination is unremarkable. An electrocardiogram (ECG) is performed based on which a provisional diagnosis of inferior wall myocardial infarction is made. Which of the following patterns of ECG changes are most likely seen in this patient?

choices.text: ST-elevation in leads I, V5, and aVL
ST-elevation in leads V1 and V2
ST-elevation in leads V3 and V4
ST-elevation in leads II, III, and aVF
ST-depression in leads I and V5

questions.solution:
The electrocardiogram (ECG) records the flow of electrical impulses throughout the heart. Depolarization current flowing towards a positive electrode causes an upward deflection in the reading. A total of 12 leads are used in a standard ECG reading which is as follows:
 
  •  Six precordial electrodes (V1-V6): These electrodes are lined in the horizontal plane of the heart, collectively known as the chest leads. 
  •  Three augmented vector leads (aVR, aVL, and aVF): These electrodes are lined in the coronal plane. 
  •  Three bipolar limb leads (lead I, II, and III): Lined in the coronal plane, these leads use two electrodes instead of one. Lead 1 uses the right arm as the negative pole and the left arm as the positive, forming a vector that goes to the right. Lead 2 uses aVR as negative and aVF as the positive poles, forming a vector that goes to the +60 degree mark. Finally, lead 3 uses aVL as negative and aVF as the positive pole, forming a vector that goes to the +120 degree mark 
In inferior wall myocardial infarction (MI), the inferior portion of the heart (that is usually supplied by the right coronary artery) is affected, which causes ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVF.
 

Option Analysis

❌ ST-elevation in leads I, V5, and aVL  :
Incorrect: Leads I, V5, and aVL correspond to the lateral wall of the heart that is supplied by the left circumflex artery.  
❌ ST-elevation in leads V1 and V2:
Incorrect: ST-elevation in leads V1 and V2 would be seen in MI involving the septal wall of the heart that is usually supplied by the left anterior descending artery.  
❌ ST-elevation in leads V3 and V4  :
Incorrect: ST-elevation in leads V3 and V4 would be seen in MI involving the anterior wall of the heart that is usually supplied by the left anterior descending artery.  
✅ ST-elevation in leads II, III, and aVF:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ ST-depression in leads I and V5:
Incorrect: Leads I, and V5 correspond to the lateral wall of the heart that is supplied by the left circumflex artery.

questions.text: Substantial evidence supports the advantages of breastfeeding over breast milk substitutes (e.g. formula) or early addition of foods. Which of the following statements is most appropriate regarding the recommendations and benefits of breastfeeding?

choices.text: For premature babies, breastfeeding increases the incidence of necrotizing enterocolitis
The benefits of exclusive breastfeeding for the first six months of life are powerful
Colostrum coats the baby’s gastrointestinal tract and has a constipation effect
The amount of vitamin D in breast milk is typically sufficient for the bone health of the infant
Maternal infections like HIV are not a contraindication to breastfeeding

questions.solution:
Substantial evidence supports the advantages of breastfeeding over breast milk substitutes (e.g. formula) or early addition of foods. The benefits of exclusive breastfeeding are powerful for the first six months of life. Breast milk contains secretory IgA, which supplements the baby’s gastrointestinal and immune systems. Breast milk reduces the baby’s risk of developing infections and conditions such as allergies, asthma, and obesity. Moreover, breastfeeding facilitates maternal-child bonding and decreases the risk of maternal breast and ovarian cancer.

However, it should be noted that the amount of vitamin D in breast milk is typically insufficient for bone health. Exclusively breastfed infants may require vitamin D supplementation.

Contraindications to breastfeeding include maternal use of illicit substances (e.g., cocaine, heroin, cannabis). Other harmful substances, such as alcohol and tobacco, can also pass from mother to child via breast milk. Finally, maternal infections (e.g. HIV) are a contraindication to breastfeeding in high-income settings but may be appropriate in low-income settings where the cost of formula and access to clean water are serious challenges.  


Option Analysis

❌ For premature babies, breastfeeding increases the incidence of necrotizing enterocolitis:
Incorrect: For premature babies, breastfeeding reduces the incidence of necrotizing enterocolitis and may enhance their neurocognitive development. 
✅ The benefits of exclusive breastfeeding for the first six months of life are powerful :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Colostrum coats the baby’s gastrointestinal tract and has a constipation effect:
Incorrect: Colostrum coats the baby’s gastrointestinal tract and has a laxative effect.
❌ The amount of vitamin D in breast milk is typically sufficient for the bone health of the infant:
Incorrect: The amount of vitamin D in breast milk is typically insufficient for bone health. Moreover, the primarily indoor lifestyle of modern newborns further prevents vitamin D synthesis. As a result, supplemental vitamin D is often needed. 
❌ Maternal infections like HIV are not a contraindication to breastfeeding:
Incorrect: Maternal infections like HIV are a contraindication to breastfeeding in high-income settings. In contrast, breastfeeding may be appropriate in low-income settings when other factors, such as the cost of formula and access to clean water, are serious challenges.

questions.text: A group of scientists are investigating the role of macrophages in different tissues. They noted that macrophages in different tissues all have the same origins from the bone marrow and monocytes. Which of the following is the correct match of the macrophage and the tissue it resides in?
questions.solution:
Macrophages are one of the most important cells in regulating inflammation and tissue homeostasis. They are produced in the bone marrow as monocytes which are secreted into the blood. Once monocytes leave the blood, they are called macrophages. Macrophages are found in different tissues around the body and there are some resident macrophages in different tissues. These macrophages may have different roles, but they all originate from the bone marrow and the monocytes in the blood. These macrophages have different names according to the tissue they are found in:  

  • Kupffer cells: liver  
  • Osteoclasts: bone  
  • Langerhans cells: skin  
  • Histiocytes: connective tissue  
  • Microglial cells: Central nervous system  

Option Analysis

✅  Macrophage  Tissue of residence  Kupffer cells   Liver :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌  Macrophage  Tissue of residence  Kupffer cells   Connective tissue :
Incorrect: Histiocytes are macrophages residing in connective tissue, while Kupffer cells are macrophages residing in the liver   
❌  Macrophage  Tissue of residence  Monocytes   Peripheral tissues :
Incorrect: Monocytes are only found in the blood, and once they leave tissues they are called macrophages.   
❌  Macrophage  Tissue of residence  Langerhans cells   Bone:
Incorrect: Osteoclasts are macrophages residing in the bones, while Langerhans cells are found in the skin.   
❌  Macrophage  Tissue of residence  Langerhans cells   Connective tissue :
Incorrect: Macrophages in connective tissue are called histiocytes, and in the skin are called Langerhans cells.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to the physician to evaluate episodic right upper quadrant pain. The pain comes a few hours after eating a meal, especially fatty meals, and lasts for 3-4 hours. The pain is colicky. Ultrasound reveals a stone in the cystic duct. The pain is triggered mainly due to the secretion of which of the following hormones?
questions.solution:
This patient has gallstones, and the colicky pain is due to the contraction of the gallbladder against an obstruction. Gallbladder contraction is mediated by cholecystokinin (CCK).

CCK is a peptide hormone produced by the I cells in the small intestine, specifically, the duodenum and jejunum. The presence of fatty acids and amino acids in the lumen of the small intestines stimulates the secretion of CCK.  

CCK stimulates gallbladder contraction to release bile into the intestine. It also stimulates pancreatic secretions, which help in the digestion of fat while mediating the relaxation of the sphincter of Oddi to allow these juices to reach the intestine. Finally, CCK decreases gastric emptying.  

Option Analysis

❌ Secretin:
Incorrect: Secretin stimulates the secretions of pancreatic fluid and bile. However, it does not mediate gallbladder contraction.  
✅ Cholecystokinin  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Somatostatin:
Incorrect: Somatostatin inhibits the secretion of various hormones in the gastrointestinal tract, including cholecystokinin. Therefore, using somatostatin analogs octreotide) can predispose to the formation of gallstones. However, biliary colic is due to the contraction of the gallbladder against an obstruction, which is mediated by cholecystokinin.  
❌ Gastrin:
Incorrect: Gastrin is not related to gallbladder contraction.  
❌ Vasoactive intestinal polypeptide (VIP)  :
Incorrect: VIP is not related to gallbladder contraction.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents to his outpatient provider due to periorbital edema and lower extremity swelling. He has also experienced weight gain despite making no changes to his diet or exercise routine. Laboratory testing demonstrates proteinuria. An additional workup is performed and the patient is diagnosed with nephrotic syndrome. A change in which of the following factors is primarily responsible for this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient was diagnosed with nephrotic syndrome. In this condition, damage to the glomerular filtration barrier leads to massive proteinuria and loss of albumin (a major plasma protein). As a result, there is decreased capillary oncotic pressure and subsequent fluid extravasation into the interstitial space.

The net movement of water across capillaries is described using the Starling equation. The formula is as follows:

The equation states there are two types of forces acting within, and outside, the capillaries, that determine fluid movement. The capillary hydrostatic pressure (Pc) pushes fluid out of the capillaries, whereas the interstitial hydrostatic pressure (Pi) pushes fluid into the capillaries. There are also osmotic pressures and these forces pull fluids in their direction. The capillary oncotic pressure (πc) pulls fluid into the capillaries, whereas the interstitial oncotic pressure (πi) pulls fluid into the interstitium.

The filtration coefficient (Kf) is not a force but instead determines the water permeability of the capillary walls. Lastly, there is the reflection coefficient (σ), which describes the capillary’s permeability to proteins. A coefficient of 1 means the capillary is impermeable to protein, whereas 0 means it is completely permeable.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Capillary hydrostatic pressure  :
Incorrect: This patient has nephrotic syndrome. The condition is characterized by the loss of albumin and other proteins via urine. These changes would result in a decreased capillary oncotic pressure, which in turn causes fluid extravasation from the capillaries into the interstitial space.  
❌ Interstitial hydrostatic pressure  :
Incorrect: This patient has nephrotic syndrome. The condition is characterized by the loss of albumin and other proteins via urine. These changes would result in a decreased capillary oncotic pressure, which in turn causes fluid extravasation from the capillaries into the interstitial space.  
✅ Capillary oncotic pressure  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Interstitial oncotic pressure  :
Incorrect: The interstitial oncotic pressure is determined by the protein concentration of the interstitial fluid and is usually quite low. Nephrotic syndrome primarily leads to the loss of albumin (a major plasma protein) via the urine, which leads to decreased capillary oncotic pressure.  
❌ Capillary permeability  :
Incorrect: Inflammatory conditions (e.g., infection, vasculitis) and burns can increase capillary permeability and enable more fluid to extravasate into the interstitial space. While some causes of nephrotic syndrome (e.g. membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis) are associated with inflammation, the primary cause of edema is nonetheless the proteinuria and subsequent decrease in capillary oncotic pressure.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the clinic to establish care. She has not seen a doctor in many years. She has no active complaints. Physical examination is unremarkable. Cardiac auscultation reveals a midsystolic click followed by a short late-systolic murmur at the cardiac apex. When the patient is asked to bear down against a closed glottis, it makes the click occur earlier in systole. Which of the following is the most likely cause of change in the timing of systolic click with this maneuver?

choices.text: Increased blood flow through an abnormal valve
Decrease in transaortic valve pressure gradient
Increased right ventricular filling and ejection time

questions.solution:
The auscultatory findings of midsystolic click followed by a short late-systolic murmur in this patient are typical for mitral valve prolapse. The murmur results from regurgitation of blood due to malaligned valve margins secondary to prolapse. The click is caused by the sudden tensing of the chordae tendineae as they are pulled tight by the ballooning valve leaflets.

In patients with MVP, there is a set left ventricular (LV) size during systole at which prolapse occurs. Therefore, maneuvers that change the LV end-diastolic volume affect the timing of the click and the murmur. Decreases in LV volume (e.g. secondary to decreased preload during the straining phase of Valsalva) reduce the tension and increase the slack in the mitral valve apparatus. Because the ventricular walls are closer, they reach the critical LV size earlier, leading to an earlier systolic click. The opposite is also true, i.e. increases in LV volume (e.g. secondary to increased preload during squatting) increase the distance between ventricular walls, thereby taking more time to reach the critical LV size, as a result of which prolapse occurs later in systole or not at all.  

Option Analysis

✅ Decrease in left ventricular volume:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Increased blood flow through an abnormal valve:
Incorrect: Murmurs that increase in intensity due to increased blood flow include murmurs produced due to stenotic and regurgitant valves (e.g. mitral regurgitation). The straining phase of Valsalva decreases preload, which reduces the flow through the valves.  
❌ Increased preload:
Incorrect: Murmurs that increase in intensity due to increased preload include murmurs produced due to stenotic and regurgitant valves (e.g. mitral regurgitation). The straining phase of Valsalva decreases preload.  
❌ Decrease in transaortic valve pressure gradient:
Incorrect: Decrease in transaortic valve pressure gradient due to maneuvers that increase afterload (e.g. handgrip) decreases the intensity of aortic stenosis murmur.  
❌ Increased right ventricular filling and ejection time:
Incorrect: Increased right ventricular filling and ejection time (as observed in conditions that increase preload like deep inspiration) leads to delay in closure of the pulmonic valve, which causes physiologic splitting of the second heart sound (S2). It decreases the intensity of the MVP murmur.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man comes to the emergency department for evaluation of intermittent palpitations. He denies any episodes of syncope, chest pain, shortness of breath, or vomiting. Past medical history is significant for hypertension. An electrocardiogram (ECG) is performed which is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of observed findings in this patient’s ECG?  
 

Reproduced from: Osmosis notes

choices.text: Slowing of conduction at the AV node

questions.solution:
This patient with palpitations and electrocardiogram (ECG) findings of irregularly irregular rhythm and absence of distinct P waves, most likely has new-onset atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response.

Atrial fibrillation (AF) is one of the most common cardiac arrhythmias. It is more prevalent in men and with increasing age. Risk factors include hypertensive heart disease, coronary artery disease, and rheumatic heart disease. AF has the following electrocardiographic characteristics:
  
  •  The RR intervals follow no repetitive pattern (irregularly irregular).  
  •  Absence of distinct P waves. Thus, even when an atrial cycle length (the interval between two atrial activations or the P-P interval) can be defined, it is not regular. 
Usually, it occurs when there are multiple ectopic foci in the atria that start firing all at once, the atrial rate can increase to 350-450 beats per minute. These foci fire too quickly for the atria to be fully depolarized by any one of them, so with AF, there aren’t any P-waves on an ECG; but, rather small waves that reflect waves of atrial depolarization that couldn’t make it through the AV node. The ventricular rate is much lower than the atrial rate, but still can be over 120 beats per minute.  


Option Analysis

✅ Ectopic foci in the atria:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Slowing of conduction at the AV node  :
Incorrect: Slowing of conduction at the AV node usually results in a first-degree or Mobitz type I second-degree heart block in which the PR segment is prolonged. In contrast, no distinct P waves can be appreciated in this patient’s ECG.  
❌ Conduction block below AV node  :
Incorrect: A conduction block below the AV node usually leads to Mobitz Type II second-degree heart block which appears on the ECG as an abnormal PR segment with a beat drop. In contrast, no distinct P-waves can be appreciated in this patient’s ECG.  
❌ Conduction through an accessory pathway:
Incorrect: Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome usually occurs as a result of an accessory conduction pathway (bundle of Kent) that results in pre-excitation and tachycardia. The classic ECG findings of WPW include a short PR interval and delta wave (slurred upstroke in the QRS complex) with or without nonspecific ST-T wave changes.  
❌ Defective myocardial sodium channels  :
Incorrect: Defective myocardial sodium channels are seen in patients with Brugada syndrome. The common ECG pattern seen in such patients includes ST elevation in leads V1 and V2 and predisposes to ventricular (not atrial) arrhythmias.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man comes to the clinic for evaluation of chronic exercise intolerance. He has to stop and catch his breath after walking two blocks or climbing 2 flights of stairs. The patient has a 55-pack-year smoking history. He undergoes pulmonary function testing and the results are shown below. Which of the following best represents the total volume of gas in this patient’s airways that does not participate in gas exchange?  

Calculated tidal volume (VT)  
500 mL
Upper airway volume  
80 mL
Conducting airway volume  
100 mL  
Inspired CO2 pressure (PICO2)  
1 mmHg  
Arterial CO2 pressure (PACO2)  
50 mmHg  
Expired CO2 pressure (PT)  
20 mmHg
questions.solution:
The total volume of gas in the airways that does not participate in gas exchange is referred to as physiologic dead space (VD). This patient with an extensive smoking history and exercise intolerance most likely has increased VD, which is calculated by Bohr’s equation as follows:

VD = VT (PACO2 - PT)/PACO2
VD = 500 (50 - 20/50)
VD = 500 (30/50)
VD = 500 (0.6)
VD = 300 mL

Physiologic dead space is the combination of anatomic dead space and alveolar dead space. Physiologic dead space is the volume of gas in the non-exchanging parts of the airway (e.g., upper airway, trachea, bronchi, bronchioles) whereas alveolar dead space is the volume of gas in the alveoli that does not exchange due to disruptions in alveolar anatomy, diffusion barrier, or blood vessels perfusing the alveoli (ventilation-perfusion, or V/Q mismatch).  

Option Analysis

❌ 180 mL:
Incorrect: This answer choice represents the anatomic dead space (upper airway + conducting airway) but does not account for all non-exchanging lung volume.  
✅ 300 mL:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ 500 mL:
Incorrect: This value represents the tidal volume of the patient, which can be calculated from pulmonary function testing by subtracting total lung capacity (vital capacity + residual volume) from residual volumes (functional reserve capacity + inspiratory reserve volume).  
❌ 600 mL:
Incorrect: This answer choice does not represent the physiologic dead space.  
❌ 700 mL:
Incorrect: This answer choice does not represent the physiologic dead space.

questions.text: A researcher is studying oxygen content within blood among different disease processes. Which of the following diseases will result in increased oxygen content?
questions.solution:
Oxygen content refers to the amount of oxygen bound to hemoglobin plus the amount of oxygen dissolved in arterial blood. It is calculated via the equation below, where Hb = hemoglobin concentration, Sao2 = arterial O2 saturation, and PaO2 = partial pressure of O2 in arterial blood.

                       O2 content = (1.34 × Hb × Sao2) + (0.003 × PaO2)

Several conditions can result in either increased or decreased oxygen content dependent on how they affect the parameters of this equation. For example, anemia results in a decreased overall oxygen content due to decreases in hemoglobin content, whereas carbon monoxide poisoning results in decreased arterial oxygen saturation. Other conditions may result in increased total oxygen content, such as polycythemia, which increases the content of hemoglobin.  

Option Analysis

✅ Polycythemia:
Correct: See Main Explanation  
❌ Iron deficiency anemia:
Incorrect: Iron deficiency anemia results in a decreased amount of hemoglobin in red blood cells, a decreased oxygen-carrying capacity, and therefore a decreased amount of oxygen content.  
❌ Carbon monoxide poisoning:
Incorrect: Carbon monoxide poisoning results in decreased total oxygen content. This occurs secondary to the fact that CO has a much higher binding affinity for hemoglobin when compared to oxygen.  
❌ Hemorrhagic shock:
Incorrect: Like other forms of anemia, hemorrhagic shock results in a decreased oxygen-carrying capacity, and therefore a decreased amount of oxygen content.  
❌ Methemoglobinemia:
Incorrect:  Methemoglobinemia results in a decreased oxygen content due to its limited ability to both bind and offload oxygen to tissues.

questions.text: A group of researchers are studying cells involved in both innate and adaptive immune responses. They identify a specific cell of the innate immune system that uses perforin and granzymes to induce apoptosis of virally infected cells and tumor cells. Which of the following cell types is most likely mediating the response described above?
questions.solution:
Natural killer cells (NK) serve as an important component of the innate immune system and cell-mediated immunity. NK cells use both perforin and granzymes to induce apoptosis of virally infected cells and tumor cells. These cells are induced to kill when exposed to a nonspecific activation signal on a target cell. NK cells also kill via antibody-dependent cell-mediated cytotoxicity, where CD16 binds the Fc region of bound IgG.  

Similarly, CD8+ T cells directly kill virus-infected and tumor cells via perforin and granzymes. While also being a component of cell-mediated immunity like NK cells,  these cells are part of the adaptive, rather than innate immune response. Cytotoxic T cells require priming and will only engage with specific antigens to kill viruses, intracellular bacteria, and tumor cells. Thus, cytotoxic T cells do this in an antigen-specific manner, looking for their specific antigen expressed on the MHC I molecule of the target cell.  

Option Analysis

✅ Natural killer cells  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ B-cells  :
Incorrect: B-cells are responsible for antibody production. These cells differentiate into plasma cells to secrete specific immunoglobulins.  
❌ CD4+ T cells  :
Incorrect: CD4+ T cells help B cells make antibodies and produce cytokines to recruit phagocytes and activate other leukocytes.  
❌ Hematopoietic stem cells  :
Incorrect: Hematopoietic stem cells are precursor cells and are not involved in cell-mediated cytotoxicity.  
❌ Regulatory T cells  :
Incorrect: Regulatory T cells help maintain specific immune tolerance by suppressing CD4+ and CD8+ T-cell effector functions.

questions.text: A group of researchers is currently studying the process of bone remodeling. Two primary cells, osteoblasts and osteoclasts, play an essential role in the remodeling process. Which of the following is true regarding these cells?

choices.text: Osteoblasts induce the differentiation of osteoclasts from precursor cells via secretion of RANK ligand.
Osteoclasts resorb bone by creating an alkaline environment via alkaline phosphatase
Osteoblasts activate osteoclasts via secretion of osteoprotegerin
Osteoblasts and osteoclasts originate from mesenchymal stem cells of the periosteum
Osteoclasts activate osteoblasts via secretion of RANK-L

questions.solution:
Bone remodeling is a complex process that involves a constant interplay of the breakdown of old bone and the formation of newer bone. The two major cell types involved in this process are osteoblasts and osteoclasts.  

Osteoclasts are phagocytosing cells that originate from the fusion of monocytes. RANK-ligand produced by osteoblasts induces the differentiation and activation of osteoclasts by binding  RANK receptors. Once activated, osteoclasts secrete collagenase, breaking down bony collagen and hydrochloric acid, dissolving hydroxyapatite into circulation.   Osteoblasts are bone-forming cells that originate from mesenchymal stem cells of the periosteum. They secrete RANK-ligand, which activates osteoclasts by binding RANK receptors. Osteoblasts also produce osteoprotegerin, which binds RANK-L and prevents RANK-RANKL interactions, thus limiting osteoclast activation. In addition, osteoblasts secrete collagen to catalyze the mineralization of bones by trapping calcium ions and phosphate into hydroxyapatite. This mineralization process is mediated mainly by the enzyme alkaline phosphatase, which creates an alkaline environment.  

Option Analysis

✅ Osteoblasts induce the differentiation of osteoclasts from precursor cells via secretion of RANK ligand.   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Osteoclasts resorb bone by creating an alkaline environment via alkaline phosphatase  :
Incorrect: Osteoblasts contribute to bone formation by trapping calcium and phosphate in the bone (hydroxyapatite) using alkaline phosphatase. On the other hand, osteoclasts resorb bone and free hydroxyapatite and create an acidic environment.  
❌ Osteoblasts activate osteoclasts via secretion of osteoprotegerin  :
Incorrect: Osteoblasts secrete RANK ligand (RANK-L), which binds the RANK receptors on osteoclasts and activates them. Osteoblasts secrete osteoprotegerin, which inhibits the binding of RANKL-RANK.  
❌ Osteoblasts and osteoclasts originate from mesenchymal stem cells of the periosteum  :
Incorrect: Osteoblasts originate from mesenchymal stem cells of the periosteum, while osteoclasts differentiate from monocytes.  
❌ Osteoclasts activate osteoblasts via secretion of RANK-L  :
Incorrect: Osteoblasts activate osteoclasts via secretion of RANK-L.

questions.text: A study is performed to understand the fluid compartments of the body. Researchers divide body fluid compartments into two main categories: intracellular and extracellular. Extracellular gets further subdivided into interstitial fluid and plasma. Which of the following statements is correct?

choices.text: Potassium ion concentration is higher in extracellular fluid than in intracellular fluid
Sodium ion concentration is higher in the intracellular compartment than in the extracellular compartment
The highest amount of water in all compartments is found in the intestinal compartment
The highest amount of water in all compartments is found in the plasma compartment
The interstitial fluid has a slightly higher concentration of chloride ions than plasma

questions.solution:
The human body primarily comprises water, accounting for approximately 60% of total body weight. Body fluid compartments are divided into both intracellular and extracellular compartments, with the extracellular compartment further subdivided into the interstitium and the plasma.   

The majority of total body water is found in the intracellular compartment, accounting for approximately ⅔ of the total body water (or 40% of the total body weight). In comparison, the extracellular compartment accounts for ⅓ of the total body water (or 20% of the total body weight). Of the fluid in the extracellular compartment, 75% is found in the interstitial fluid, and the remaining 25% is found in plasma.  

In addition, ion concentration differs between the extracellular and intracellular compartments and the plasma and interstitium. Higher concentrations of potassium and magnesium ions are found in the intracellular compartment, while the concentrations of sodium and chloride ions are higher in the extracellular compartment. In the interstitium, a higher concentration of small anions (e.g. Chloride) occurs, while in plasma, there is a slightly higher concentration of cations (e.g. Sodium). This difference exists due to negatively charged proteins, which cannot leave the plasma.  

Option Analysis

❌ Potassium ion concentration is higher in extracellular fluid than in intracellular fluid  :
Incorrect: Potassium ions concentration is higher in the intracellular compartments than in the extracellular compartments.  
❌ Sodium ion concentration is higher in the intracellular compartment than in the extracellular compartment:
Incorrect: Sodium ion concentration in the extracellular compartment is higher than the intracellular concentration.
❌ The highest amount of water in all compartments is found in the intestinal compartment  :
Incorrect: The highest amount of water is found in the intracellular compartment, accounting for two-thirds of total body water.
❌ The highest amount of water in all compartments is found in the plasma compartment  :
Incorrect: The highest amount of water is found in the intracellular compartment, accounting for two-thirds of total body water.  
✅ The interstitial fluid has a slightly higher concentration of chloride ions than plasma  :
Correct: See Main Explanation

questions.text: A 26-year-old man is brought to the emergency department to evaluate his altered mental status after being found down while working outdoors on a hot sunny day. He had two episodes of non-bloody, nonbilious emesis before arrival. His temperature is 40°C (104°F), pulse is 130/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 70/50 mmHg. Mucous membranes are dry. Which of the following changes will likely be observed in the glomerular function of this patient?
questions.solution:
During states of severe dehydration, a significant drop in blood pressure reduces renal plasma flow (RPF) and glomerular filtration rate (GFR) despite renal autoregulatory mechanisms (these mechanisms begin failing with sustained systolic blood pressures below 80 mmHg).

In response, renin is released from granular cells and causes a cascade of reactions that result in the production of angiotensin II and subsequent vasoconstriction of the efferent arteriole. This effect increases glomerular hydrostatic pressure and slightly improves GFR, but not to normal levels. In addition, vasoconstriction of the efferent arteriole reduces the RPF even further. The overall effect is an increase in filtration fraction (FF), which is the ratio of GFR/RPF.  

Option Analysis

❌ :
Incorrect: Constriction of the ureter can decrease GFR without affecting the RPF, resulting in decreased FF.   
❌ :
Incorrect: In the absence of prostaglandin, unopposed vasoconstriction of the afferent arterioles occurs, leading to a decrease in glomerular filtration rate (GFR) and renal plasma flow (RPF). This change does not affect the filtration fraction, which is defined as the ratio of GFR/RPF.   
❌ :
Incorrect: Angiotensin II evokes vasoconstriction of the efferent arteriole, resulting in an elevated glomerular filtration rate (GFR), reduced renal plasma flow (RPF), and an increase in filtration fraction (FF).   
❌ :
Incorrect: A decrease in serum plasma protein decreases oncotic pressure and results in more fluid being filtered via the kidney, thus increasing the GFR and thereby FF.   
✅ :
Correct: See Main Explanation

questions.text: A group of investigators is studying the function of the thyroid gland. They discovered that the thyroid hormone acts on nearly every cell in the body. Which of the following is most appropriate regarding thyroid hormone?

choices.text: It inhibits ovulation in females by inhibiting GnRH synthesis and release
It has cardiac inotropic and chronotropic effects
It stimulates linear growth and muscle mass through IGF-1
It regulates renal free water reabsorption and serum osmolality
It increases Ca2+ reabsorption from the distal collecting tubule

questions.solution:
Thyroid hormones act on nearly every cell in the body. It is essential for normal growth and development. It controls the rate of metabolism and, therefore, the function of practically every organ in the body. Thyroid hormones help activate the sympathetic nervous system, which is responsible for the fight or flight response. The following are some examples of the specific effects of thyroid hormone.  

  • It has cardiac inotropic and chronotropic effects, increases cardiac output and blood volume, and decreases systemic vascular resistance.  
  • It induces white adipose tissue differentiation, lipogenic enzymes, and intracellular lipid accumulation; stimulates adipocyte cell proliferation; stimulates uncoupling proteins; and uncouples oxidative phosphorylation.  
  • It regulates triglyceride and cholesterol metabolism, as well as lipoprotein homeostasis.
  • It regulates the synthesis of pituitary hormones, stimulates growth hormone production, and inhibits TSH  
  • It is necessary for axonal growth and development  

Option Analysis

❌ It inhibits ovulation in females by inhibiting GnRH synthesis and release  :
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. Prolactin inhibits ovulation in females by inhibiting GnRH synthesis and release.
✅ It has cardiac inotropic and chronotropic effects  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ It stimulates linear growth and muscle mass through IGF-1  :
Incorrect: Thyroid hormone is essential for bone growth and development by activating osteoclast and osteoblast activities. It acts synergistically with growth hormone but does not act through IGF-I (the mechanism of growth hormone).  
❌ It regulates renal free water reabsorption and serum osmolality  :
Incorrect: Vasopressin regulates renal free water reabsorption and serum osmolality.  
❌ It increases Ca2+ reabsorption from the distal collecting tubule  :
Incorrect: Parathyroid hormone increases Ca2+ reabsorption from the distal collecting tubule.

questions.text: A 25-year-old gravida 1, para 0, is at a gestational age of 20 weeks. Which of the following is the best estimation of the embryonic age of the fetus?
questions.solution:
Embryonic age is the actual age of the growing baby, starting at the time of conception. The age of the fetus is two weeks shorter than the gestational age. Ovulation occurs two weeks after the last menstrual period and fertilization occurs close to ovulation. Therefore, the date of conception lies at the date of ovulation.
