It is a less accurate measurement due to the difficulty of calculating the date. The length of pregnancy should be 38 weeks according to the embryonic age.  

On the other hand, gestational age is the age of the pregnancy taken from the beginning of the last menstrual period (LMP). It includes an additional two weeks of time when the woman is not pregnant, while fetal age is calculated after conception. It is more accurate than embryonic age. The length of the pregnancy should be 40 weeks according to the gestational age.

Option Analysis

✅ 18 weeks:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ 20 weeks:
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. Embryonic age of the fetus is two weeks shorter than the gestational age as ovulation occurs two weeks after the last menstrual period and fertilization occurs close to ovulation. Therefore, the date of conception lies at the date of ovulation.
❌ 22 weeks:
Incorrect:This answer choice is incorrect. Embryonic age of the fetus is two weeks shorter than the gestational age as ovulation occurs two weeks after the last menstrual period and fertilization occurs close to ovulation. Therefore, the date of conception lies at the date of ovulation.
❌ 24 weeks:
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. Embryonic age of the fetus is two weeks shorter than the gestational age as ovulation occurs two weeks after the last menstrual period and fertilization occurs close to ovulation. Therefore, the date of conception lies at the date of ovulation.
❌ 26 weeks:
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. Embryonic age of the fetus is two weeks shorter than the gestational age as ovulation occurs two weeks after the last menstrual period and fertilization occurs close to ovulation. Therefore, the date of conception lies at the date of ovulation.

questions.text: Parathyroid hormone is released from the parathyroid gland in response to hypocalcemia. Which of the following electrolyte changes will be seen in this patient?

choices.text: Increased phosphate reabsorption from the proximal convoluted tubule
Increased calcium reabsorption from the distal convoluted tubule
Increased calcium reabsorption from the proximal convoluted tubule
Increased phosphate reabsorption from the distal convoluted tubule

questions.solution:
A slight decrease in the free ionized Ca2+ level is sensed through the Ca2+ sensor in parathyroid chief cells, resulting in an increased release of parathyroid hormone (PTH). PTH binds to receptors in osteoblasts leading to the recruitment of pre-osteoclasts and their maturation to active osteoclasts, which are responsible for increased bone resorption and release of Ca2+ and inorganic phosphate (Pi) into the circulation.  

In the kidney, PTH promotes Ca2+ reabsorption from the distal convoluted tubule and Pi excretion in the urine. In addition, PTH stimulates the hydroxylation of 25-hydroxyvitamin D at the 1-position, leading to the formation of the active form of vitamin D (calcitriol). Vitamin D increases intestinal absorption of dietary Ca2+ and renal reabsorption of filtered Ca2+. In the bone, vitamin D increases the number of osteoclasts and stimulates bone resorption, with a resulting increase in the release of Ca2+ into the circulation. An increase in free ionized Ca2+ levels decreases the release of PTH from the parathyroid gland, decreases the activation of vitamin D in the kidney, and stimulates parafollicular cells of the thyroid gland to release the hormone calcitonin.  

Option Analysis

❌ Decreased calcium resorption from bone  :
Incorrect: PTH increases calcium resorption from the bone to increase serum calcium levels.  
❌ Increased phosphate reabsorption from the proximal convoluted tubule  :
Incorrect: PTH decreases phosphate reabsorption from the proximal convoluted tubule.  
✅ Increased calcium reabsorption from the distal convoluted tubule  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Increased calcium reabsorption from the proximal convoluted tubule   :
Incorrect: PTH does not affect calcium reabsorption in the proximal tubule.  
❌ Increased phosphate reabsorption from the distal convoluted tubule  :
Incorrect: PTH reduces the reabsorption of phosphate from the proximal tubule of the kidney, which means more phosphate is excreted through the urine (mnemonic: PTH can be remembered as the “phosphate-trashing hormone”)

questions.text: In order to prevent hypercoagulability as well as excessive bleeding, activation of the coagulation cascade and the processes that inhibit it occur simultaneously in the circulatory system. Which of the following best describes the function of the activated protein C complex?

choices.text: Catalyzes the conversion of plasminogen to plasmin
Inhibition of factors Va and VIIIa
Degradation of thrombin and factors IXa and Xa
Activation of factor XI and factor VIII

questions.solution:
Anticoagulation prevents clots from growing too large and forming emboli. Thrombin (factor II) activates a number of coagulation factors including fibrinogen, factor V, factor VIII, and XIII. It is the main target of two proteins that help with anticoagulation–protein C and antithrombin III.  

Protein C is a circulating plasma protein produced in the liver along with a cofactor called protein S. Both interact with thrombomodulin on the surface of intact endothelial cells. When there is a lot of thrombin around a damaged blood vessel, excess thrombin binds to thrombomodulin and it can no longer participate in the coagulation cascade. Furthermore, the thrombin-thrombomodulin complex binds to and activates proteins C and S. This forms a complex that includes protein C, protein S, and thrombin-thrombomodulin. This protein complex proteolytically cleaves and inactivates active factors V and VIII and inhibits both the intrinsic and common coagulation pathways.  

Another anticoagulant is antithrombin III, which binds both thrombin and factor X, both of which are in the common pathway. Excess thrombin can bind to antithrombin–similar to how it binds to thrombomodulin–and becomes unavailable. It also binds to excess active factor X and inhibits factors VII, IX, XI, and XII, although with much less affinity. Antithrombin is also the target of an effective medication called heparin. Heparin binds to antithrombin and increases its affinity for its target proteins, thus increasing its anticoagulant effects.  




Option Analysis

❌ Inhibition of tissue factor  :
Incorrect: Tissue factor (TF) pathway inhibitor (TFPI) is an anticoagulant protein that inhibits the early phases of the procoagulant response.  
❌ Catalyzes the conversion of plasminogen to plasmin  :
Incorrect: Tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) is a serine protease found on endothelial cells involved in the breakdown of blood clots (fibrinolysis). tPA catalyzes the conversion of plasminogen to plasmin.  
✅ Inhibition of factors Va and VIIIa  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Degradation of thrombin and factors IXa and Xa  :
Incorrect: Antithrombin III is involved in the degradation of thrombin and factors IXa and Xa.  
❌ Activation of factor XI and factor VIII  :
Incorrect: Thrombin activates factor XI and factor VIII.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man comes to the physician to take the influenza vaccine. He tells the physician that he read about two types of vaccines available against influenza. The physician agrees with the patient and tells him about the two forms of influenza vaccine: the intranasal and intramuscular forms. The patient was given the intramuscular influenza vaccine. Which of the following statements is correct regarding the intramuscular influenza vaccine?

choices.text: It induces an immune response that is mainly humoral.
It has no differences from the intranasal influenza vaccine.
It is contraindicated in patients with immunodeficiencies.
It induces a strong humoral and cellular immune response.

questions.solution:
Inactivated vaccines are whole-cell vaccines where the pathogen is killed or inactivated using heat or chemicals (e.g. formalin) and then injected into the body. The inactivation does not alter the antigen structure; therefore, once injected, the vaccine will stimulate the adaptive immune system to produce an immune response. This vaccine is safe and has fewer side effects than live attenuated vaccines. Additionally, it can be given to pregnant women and patients with immunodeficiencies.  

However, inactivated or killed vaccines result in an immune response that is mainly humoral, with little to no involvement of the cellular immune system (i.e. T-cells). This response is weaker than live-attenuated vaccines and lasts for a shorter period. Therefore, booster doses are usually required as the immunity wanes.  

Examples of inactivated or killed vaccines include intramuscular influenza, polio vaccine, rabies vaccine, and hepatitis A vaccine.    

Option Analysis

✅ It induces an immune response that is mainly humoral.  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ It is a live-attenuated vaccine.  :
Incorrect: The intramuscular influenza vaccine is inactivated, while the intranasal influenza vaccine is live attenuated.  
❌ It has no differences from the intranasal influenza vaccine.  :
Incorrect: The intramuscular influenza vaccine is inactivated, while the intranasal influenza vaccine is live attenuated.  
❌ It is contraindicated in patients with immunodeficiencies.  :
Incorrect: The intramuscular influenza vaccine is inactivated and not contraindicated in patients with immunodeficiencies. In contrast, the intranasal influenza vaccine is live-attenuated and is contraindicated in patients with immunodeficiencies.  
❌ It induces a strong humoral and cellular immune response.  :
Incorrect: Intramuscular influenza vaccine is an inactivated vaccine. This type of vaccine mainly induces a humoral immune response with little or no cellular response. On the other hand, live attenuated vaccines cause strong humoral and cellular immune responses.

questions.text: There are many factors that influence sodium reabsorption and excretion in the kidneys. Which of the following causes increased excretion of sodium into the urine?
questions.solution:
Sodium is a major component of the extracellular fluid and accounts for a major part of blood osmolality. Sodium homeostasis is the process of regulating the amount of sodium in the extracellular fluid and is mainly achieved by the kidneys.

The two major factors that affect sodium homeostasis are blood volume and pressure.

In the setting of a drop in blood volume and pressure (e.g. hemorrhage), mechanisms are activated to increase sodium and water reabsorption from the kidneys to restore blood volume and pressure. One such system is the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone-system (RAAS). Renin converts angiotensinogen to angiotensin, and angiotensin II increases sodium reabsorption in the proximal convoluted tubules. Additionally, angiotensin II stimulates the release of aldosterone, which acts on the collecting ducts and tubules to increase sodium reabsorption. Moreover, sympathetic activation increases the reabsorption of sodium both indirectly (through stimulation of renin release) and directly by acting on the proximal convoluted tubules to increase sodium reabsorption. Finally, antidiuretic hormone (ADH) released from the posterior pituitary in response to low blood volume increases sodium reabsorption in the thick limb of the loop of Henle.

In contrast, increased blood pressure and volume stimulates sodium excretion (and eventually water) in the kidneys. This effect is achieved not only through the aforementioned mechanisms but also by certain hormones such as atrial natriuretic peptide, which is secreted by the atria in response to increased blood volume.

Other factors that also influence sodium homeostasis include serum osmolarity, wherein increased osmolarity of blood causes increased sodium excretion and vice versa.   

Option Analysis

✅ Increased circulating blood volume:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Sympathetic activation:
Incorrect: Sympathetic activation decreases the excretion of sodium into the urine and increases sodium reabsorption. These effects are achieved indirectly (through increasing renin release) and directly through increasing sodium reabsorption in the proximal convoluted tubules.  
❌ Decreased blood pressure:
Incorrect: Decreased blood pressure causes activation of the sympathetic system and renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system, both of which increase sodium reabsorption.  
❌ Decreased serum osmolarity:
Incorrect: Decreased serum osmolarity causes increased reabsorption of sodium in the kidneys.  
❌ Decreased parathyroid hormone levels:
Incorrect: Parathyroid hormone inhibits the sodium-phosphate transporter in the proximal convoluted tubules, thus increasing the amount of sodium excreted in the urine. Therefore, decreased parathyroid hormone levels cause decreased excretion of sodium into the urine.

questions.text: A group of researchers are studying the physiology of the loop of Henle. They discover that the loop of Henle plays an important role in concentrating urine by generating a hypertonic medullary interstitium in a process called countercurrent multiplication. Which of the following is true regarding the loop of Henle?

choices.text: The thick ascending loop of Henle is impermeable to sodium
The Na-K-2Cl channel is located on the apical surface of the thick ascending loop of Henle
The thin descending loop makes urine less concentrated as it descends
The Na+/Ca2+ exchanger on the thin limb increases the calcium reabsorption
65-80% of filtered sodium is reabsorbed in the loop of Henle

questions.solution:
The loop of Henle consists of three major segments based on cellular morphology and anatomic location.
 
  • Descending thin limb: Lined by squamous epithelial cells containing aquaporin proteins on the apical and basolateral surfaces and very few channels for solutes. The osmolarity in the medullary interstitium increases from 300 mOsm/L to 1200 mOsm/L at the end of descending limb, mostly due to the sodium gradient. 
  • Ascending thin limb: Sodium and chloride channels lie on the apical and basolateral surfaces. The interstitial fluid osmolarity decreases to around 600 mOsm/L at the top of the thin ascending loop. 
  • Ascending thick limb: Lined by cuboidal cells, which do not have aquaporin proteins and are impermeable to water. The apical surfaces have Na+K+2Cl- cotransporters that shuttle one sodium into the cell down its concentration gradient, which powers the movement of one potassium and two chlorides into the cell. On the basolateral surface, a Na/K ATPase uses ATP, which indirectly induces paracellular reabsorption of magnesium and calcium. 
Further up the thick ascending loop, the tubular fluid starts decreasing in osmolarity due to solute removal, reaching around 325 mOsm/L at the top of the thick ascending loop. The process of creating this gradient is called countercurrent multiplication. During this process, ATP is used to augment the concentration gradient and in return reabsorb water.    


Option Analysis

❌ The thick ascending loop of Henle is impermeable to sodium:
Incorrect: The thick ascending loop of Henle is impermeable to water. The thin descending loop of Henle is impermeable to sodium.  
✅ The Na-K-2Cl channel is located on the apical surface of the thick ascending loop of Henle:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ The thin descending loop makes urine less concentrated as it descends:
Incorrect: The thick ascending loop makes urine less concentrated as it ascends, as it causes reabsorption of solutes down the concentration gradient and is impermeable to water.  
❌ The Na+/Ca2+ exchanger on the thin limb increases the calcium reabsorption:
Incorrect: The Na/Ca exchanger is located on the distal convoluted tubule. Calcium reabsorbs paracellularly in the thick ascending limb.  
❌ 65-80% of filtered sodium is reabsorbed in the loop of Henle:
Incorrect: Only 10-20% of the filtered sodium is reabsorbed in the thick ascending limb.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the physician for evaluation. During evaluation of sexual development of the boy, his genitalia and pubic hair are at Tanner stage 2 of sexual development. Which of the following characteristics are expected to be seen at this stage of sexual development?

choices.text: The penis enlarges in size and length
Coarse pubic hair appears but does not extend to the thighs
Coarse pubic hair appears and extends to the inner thighs

questions.solution:
Tanner scale is a scale used to evaluate the development of primary and secondary sexual characteristics in both males and females, and it represents a set of steps that males and females go through at puberty. The tanner scale assesses three independent criteria: the genitalia, pubic hair, and breast development in females. There are five stages in the tanner scale which are:

  • Stage 1: the prepubertal stage; no pubic hair is present in either males or females; males have a small penis and testis; females have a flat chest.  
  • Stage 2: soft pubic hair starts to appear in males and females; the testes start to enlarge in males; breast buds appear in females.  
  • Stage 3: pubic hair begins coarsening; the penis starts to enlarge in both size and length; in females, the breast mounds form and the breasts enlarge.  
  • Stage 4: pubic hair covers the pubic area; the penis widens; the breasts continue to enlarge and form a mound on mound contour.  
  • Stage 5: pubic hair extends to the inner thighs; the penis and testes reach adult size; the breasts reach adult contour. 
 


Option Analysis

✅ Testicular enlargement:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ The penis enlarges in size and length:
Incorrect: Enlargement of penile size and length happens during Tanner stage 3 of development.  
❌ The penis enlarges in width:
Incorrect: The penis enlarges in width at Tanner stage 4 of development.  
❌ Coarse pubic hair appears but does not extend to the thighs:
Incorrect: Coarsening of the pubic hair begins in Tanner stage 3 and continues in Tanner stage 4 to cover the pubic area but without extending to the inner thighs. In Tanner stage 2, soft pubic hair starts to appear.  
❌ Coarse pubic hair appears and extends to the inner thighs:
Incorrect: In Tanner stage 5 pubic hair extends into the inner thighs.

questions.text: A researcher is conducting a study on cardiac physiology. The test subject has a heart rate of H and an ejection fraction of F. The subject’s pressure-volume loop is shown below. Which of the following best approximates the cardiac work (also termed stroke work) performed by this patient’s heart?
questions.solution:
Cardiac work (also called stroke) is the work the heart performs during each beat. It can be calculated by multiplying the stroke volume by the mean aortic pressure. Cardiac work can also be approximated as the area within the pressure-volume loop. Therefore, the bigger the loop and the greater its area, the more work the heart does.  

In this vignette, the pressure-volume loop is roughly the shape of a rectangle. The area is the product of the width and height, mathematically represented as (V3-V1)*(P3-P1). The rectangle’s width corresponds to the difference between V3 and V1, whereas its height corresponds to the difference between P3 and P1.  

A related concept is cardiac minute work, which is how much work the heart performs over a minute. It can be calculated by multiplying the cardiac work by the number of beats per minute. In this vignette, the cardiac minute work is mathematically represented as (V3-V1)*(P3-P1)*H.  

Option Analysis

✅ (V3-V1)*(P3-P1):
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ (V3-V1)*(P3-P1)*H:
Incorrect: Cardiac work is the work the heart performs during each beat. It can be approximated as the area of the pressure-volume loop. Multiplying the cardiac work by the heart rate (as in this answer choice) will yield minute work, the amount of work the heart performs in a minute.  
❌ (V3-V1)*(P3-P2):
Incorrect: Cardiac work is the work the heart performs during each beat. It can be approximated as the area of the pressure-volume loop, which can be mathematically represented as the product of the loop’s height (P3-P1) and width (V3-V1).  
❌ (V3-V1)*(P3-P2)*H:
Incorrect: Cardiac work is the work the heart performs during each beat. It can be approximated as the area of the pressure-volume loop, which can be mathematically represented as the product of the loop’s height (P3-P1) and width (V3-V1).  
❌ (V3*F)*(P3-P1)*H  :
Incorrect: Cardiac work is the work the heart performs during each beat. The loop’s height is the difference between P3 and P1, whereas the loop’s width corresponds to the stroke volume, equal to the end-diastolic volume (V3) multiplied by the ejection fraction. However, multiplying the cardiac work by the heart rate will yield minute work.

questions.text: A patient's current pressure-volume loop is shown below in red. His pressure-volume loop from five years ago is shown below in dark blue as a reference. Which clinical scenarios would best account for the changes between the two pressure-volume loops?
questions.solution:
This patient’s most recent pressure-volume loop demonstrates increased stroke volume and decreased end-diastolic volume. Among the answer choices, only dobutamine (an inotropic medication) administration would account for these changes.  

Pressure-volume loops characterize changes in left ventricular pressure and volume throughout the cardiac cycle. Changes in contractility, preload, and afterload can all affect the shape of the pressure-volume loop.    

Increased contractility (e.g., catecholamine release, dobutamine use) will cause the heart to contract more forcefully and increase ventricular pressure during systole. As a result, more blood is ejected from the left ventricle during systole, meaning stroke volume will increase, and end-systolic volume will decrease.    

An increase in afterload (e.g., aortic stenosis, system hypertension) will lead to impaired ventricular emptying. In turn, ventricular pressure will have to rise higher than usual during systole to push blood out of the heart. Likewise, the heart can pump less blood out due to the increase in afterload. Therefore, stroke volume will decrease, and end-systolic volume will increase.    

Finally, an increase in preload (e.g. increased blood volume) means more blood enters the left ventricle during diastole, which translates into a greater end-diastolic volume. There is also a greater stroke volume given the Frank-Starling relation, which states that the greater the end-diastolic volume, the greater the stroke volume ejected during systole.  



Option Analysis

❌ Aortic stenosis:
Incorrect: Aortic stenosis will lead to an increase in cardiac afterload and aortic resistance. As a result, ventricular pressure during systole must rise higher than usual to push blood out of the left ventricle. Moreover, due to the increase in afterload, the heart can pump less blood out of the heart. Therefore, aortic stenosis would lead to an increased end-systolic volume and decreased stroke volume, as seen in the graph below.  

❌ Systolic heart failure:
Incorrect: Systolic heart failure is characterized by a loss of inotropy, which prevents blood from being squeezed out from the heart and results in an increased end-systolic volume. There may also be an increase in end-diastolic volume since the condition causes blood to pool in the pulmonary and venous circulation, thereby increasing preload. A pressure-volume loop of this can be seen below. This patient’s most recent pressure-volume loop does not reflect these changes.  
 

❌ Recent blood transfusion:
Incorrect: A blood transfusion would increase the circulating blood volume and preload. As a result, there would be greater ventricular filling during diastole and a higher end-diastolic volume, as seen in the pressure-volume loop below. In contrast, the end-diastolic volume remains unchanged between this patient’s two pressure-volume loops.


❌ Recent diltiazem administration:
Incorrect: Diltiazem is a nondihydropyridine calcium channel blocker that will lead to decreased cardiac contractility. As a result, diltiazem administration will decrease (as opposed to increasing) stroke volume.
✅ Dobutamine administration:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman comes to the clinic for a routine checkup. She does not have any active complaints. Past medical history is significant for hypertension, and type 2 diabetes mellitus diagnosed 40 years ago. She takes amlodipine, metformin, and insulin. Cardiac auscultation reveals a low-frequency heart sound at the end of diastole that is best heard at the cardiac apex. This patient most likely has which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The auscultatory findings in this patient demonstrate a low-frequency extra heart sound at the end of diastole, known as the fourth heart sound (S4). It is often heard in older adults due to an age-related decline in left ventricular compliance and is a benign finding in such cases. However, it can be pathological in patients with restrictive cardiomyopathy or left ventricular hypertrophy following prolonged hypertension (as in this case). It is thought to occur from a surge of blood striking a stiff left ventricle due to right atrial contraction. It may also be heard in patients during the early stages of an acute myocardial infarction–this sound occurs when the blood hits the noncompliant and infarcted cardiac tissue.  

Notably, ventricular gallops (S3 and S4) are best heard with the stethoscope bell over the cardiac apex. At the same time, the patient is in the left lateral decubitus position (brings the heart closer to the chest wall) at end-expiration (decreases lung volume).

Option Analysis

❌ Aortic root dilation:
Incorrect: Aortic root dilation can be associated with aortic insufficiency, which causes a high-pitched early diastolic decrescendo murmur instead of an extra heart sound.
❌ Atrial septal defect:
Incorrect: An atrial septal defect produces a fixed splitting of the second heart sound at the start of diastole.
❌ Mitral valve prolapse:
Incorrect: Mitral valve prolapse is classically associated with a mid-systolic click followed by a mid-to-late systolic murmur. It does not produce a diastolic sound or murmur.
❌ Patent ductus arteriosus  :
Incorrect: Patent ductus arteriosus causes a continuous machine-like murmur best heard in the left infraclavicular area.
✅ Left ventricular hypertrophy   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A scientist is studying different types of glucose transporters (GLUT) found in human tissues. Which GLUT proteins depend on insulin for its expression and upregulation on the cell surface?
questions.solution:
Glucose is one of the main energy sources in human tissues. There are seven important types of glucose transporters in the human body, which include glucose transporters 1 through 5 (GLUT 1-5) and sodium-glucose cotransporters (SGLT) 1 and 2 (found in the small intestines and kidneys, respectively).  

For the most part, the expression of these transporters is independent of insulin. However, expression, upregulation, and exocytosis of GLUT4 require insulin. Insulin is an anabolic hormone that increases glycogen, triglyceride, adenosine triphosphate (ATP), and protein synthesis while down-regulating lipolysis and glucagon release.  

GLUT4, an insulin-dependent glucose transporter, is mainly found in adipose tissues and striated muscles. Exercise and insulin increase their expression, which leads to increased intracellular glucose and resultant ATP generation from glucose metabolism.  



Option Analysis

❌ GLUT1:
Incorrect: GLUT1 is found in red blood cells, the brain, the cornea, and placental tissues. It is not dependent on insulin for its expression and upregulation.
❌ GLUT2:
Incorrect: GLUT2 is found in beta islet cells of the pancreas, liver, kidneys, and gastrointestinal tract. This protein is not dependent on insulin for expression and upregulation.
❌ GLUT3:
Incorrect: GLUT3, like GLUT1, is found in the brain and placental tissues. It is not dependent on insulin for its expression and upregulation.
✅ GLUT4:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ GLUT5:
Incorrect: GLUT5 is found in spermatocytes and gastrointestinal tract tissue. It is not dependent on insulin for its expression and upregulation.

questions.text: A group of investigators discover that both bile salts and bilirubin can be recycled via enterohepatic circulation. Which of the following is the primary site of bile salt reabsorption in the gastrointestinal tract?
questions.solution:
Bile acids are efficiently conserved under normal conditions. Because bile acids are ionized, they cannot cross the intestine wall passively. The uptake of the conjugated bile acids is coupled to that of sodium by the activity of the Na+/K+-ATPase in the distal ileum. The transporter that mediates this uptake is the apical sodium-dependent bile salt transporter (ASBT). The reabsorbed bile acids enter the portal bloodstream and are taken up rapidly by hepatocytes, reconjugated, and resecreted into bile (enterohepatic circulation). Typically, the bile acid pool circulates ~5–10 times daily. Intestinal reabsorption of the pool is about 95% efficient; therefore, fecal loss of bile acids is in the range of 0.2–0.4 g/d. In the steady-state, this fecal loss is compensated by an equal daily synthesis of bile acids by the liver; thus, the size of the bile acid pool is maintained.  

Malabsorptive conditions like Crohn's disease can decrease enteric bile salts' reabsorption at the distal ileum. This prevents normal fat absorption and may cause bile acid diarrhea.


Option Analysis

❌ Ampulla of duodenum:
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. The bile is not secreted in the first part of the duodenum and, therefore, cannot be reabsorbed here.  
❌ Jejunum:
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. The jejunum is not the primary site of bile acid reabsorption.  
✅ Distal ileum:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Ascending colon:
Incorrect: Only a minor portion of the bile acid pool spills into the colon in healthy individuals. In the colon, bile is deconjugated and can be absorbed passively. The colon is not the primary site of bile acid reabsorption.  
❌ Descending colon:
Incorrect: Only a minor portion of the bile acid pool spills into the colon in healthy individuals. The colon is not the primary site of bile acid reabsorption. In the colon, it is deconjugated and can be absorbed passively.

questions.text: Cerebral blood flow can remain fairly constant over a wide range of cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP). Which of the following changes will result in a reduced CPP?
questions.solution:
Cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP) is the difference between mean arterial pressure (MAP) and intracranial pressure (ICP) (or central venous pressure [CVP]) if it is more significant than ICP. CPP is dependent on MAP. MAP is normally 80 to 100 mm Hg. A reduction in blood pressure or elevation of ICP can reduce CPP.

Moderate to severe increases in ICP (>30 mm Hg) can compromise CPP and CBF, even in the presence of a normal MAP. Sustained perfusion pressures less than 25 mm Hg may result in irreversible brain damage.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Increase in intracranial pressure (ICP):
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Increase in PaCO2:
Incorrect: CPP is directly proportional to PaCO2 until PaCO2> 90 mm Hg. An increase in PaCO2 will increase the CPP.  
❌ Decrease in PaO2:
Incorrect: Hypoxemia increases CPP only when PO2 < 50 mm Hg. It does not reduce the CPP.  
❌ Increase in systemic blood pressure:
Incorrect: An increase in blood pressure will increase the mean arterial pressure (MAP), which increases the gradient between MAP and ICP, leading to an increase in CPP.  
❌ Decrease in central venous pressure:
Incorrect: Central venous pressure [CVP] affects the CPP only when it is more significant than ICP. Moreover, a reduced CVP will increase the CPP.

questions.text: Therapeutic hyperventilation may treat acute cerebral edema unresponsive to other interventions. Which changes during hyperventilation enhance cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP)?
questions.solution:
Cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP) is determined by the pressure of the blood reaching the brain (mean arterial pressure [MAP]) and the ICP acting against this blood pressure:

CPP = MAP — ICP

Therefore, if ICP rises at a constant MAP, cerebral perfusion pressure will fall, leading to decreased cerebral perfusion.

Increases in the respiratory minute volume mediated by increases in tidal volume and respiratory rate result in alveolar hyperventilation that decreases the PaCO2 causing cerebral vasoconstriction, reduced CBF, decreased cerebral blood volume, and decreased ICP. Therefore, therapeutic hyperventilation may be used to treat acute cerebral edema (e.g., 2° to stroke) unresponsive to other interventions.  

Option Analysis

❌ Increase in PO2:
Incorrect: During hyperventilation, which lowers arterial PCO2 and increases the blood pH, the average PO2 decreases in proportion to the decline in arterial PCO2.  
❌ Decrease in central venous pressure:
Incorrect: Central venous pressure [CVP] affects the CPP only when it is greater than ICP. Moreover, it is not affected by therapeutic hyperventilation.  
❌ Increase in intracranial pressure:
Incorrect: Increases in the respiratory minute volume mediated by increases in tidal volume and respiratory rate result in alveolar hyperventilation that decreases the PaCO2 causing cerebral vasoconstriction, reduced CBF, decreased cerebral blood volume, and decreased ICP.  
✅ Decrease in PCO2:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Decrease in systemic blood pressure:
Incorrect: Hyperventilation causes vasoconstriction and an increase in systemic blood pressure.

questions.text: Polysomnographic profiles define two basic states of sleep: (1) rapid eye movement (REM) sleep and (2) non–rapid eye movement (NREM) sleep. Which of the following stages and waveforms corresponds to the stage of sleep during which bruxism occurs?

choices.text: Awake with eyes closed and beta waveform
Stage N2 with sleep spindles and K complexes

questions.solution:
Polysomnographic profiles define two basic states of sleep: (1) rapid eye movement (REM) sleep and (2) non–rapid eye movement (NREM) sleep. NREM sleep is further subdivided into three stages: N1, N2, and N3 characterized by increasing arousal threshold and slowing the cortical EEG. REM sleep is characterized by a low-amplitude, mixed-frequency EEG similar to that of NREM stage N1 sleep, and the EOG shows REMs, which tend to occur in flurries or bursts. EMG activity is absent in nearly all skeletal muscles except those involved in respiration, reflecting the brainstem-mediated muscle paralysis characteristic of REM sleep.

Stage 2 of non-REM sleep is marked by the appearance of sinusoidal waves called sleep spindles (7–15 Hz), and occasional high voltage biphasic waves called K complexes. Bruxism also occurs during this stage of sleep. A summary of sleep stages is described below.
   

Option Analysis

❌ Awake with eyes closed and beta waveform:
Incorrect: In adult humans who are awake but at rest and with eyes closed, the most prominent component of the EEG is a fairly regular pattern of waves at a frequency of 8–13 Hz and amplitude of 50–100 µV.  This pattern is the alpha rhythm.  
❌ Stage N1 with alpha waveform:
Incorrect: Stage 1 non-REM sleep is the transition from wakefulness to sleep, and EEG shows a low-voltage, mixed frequency pattern. A theta rhythm (4–7 Hz) can be seen at this stage of sleep.  
✅ Stage N2 with sleep spindles and K complexes:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Stage N3 with beta waveform:
Incorrect: Stage 3 of non-REM sleep is characterized by the appearance of a high-amplitude delta rhythm (0.5–4 Hz) on EEG, reflecting a further reduction in arousal, and a further reduction in muscle tone.  
❌ REM sleep with theta waveform:
Incorrect: During REM sleep, characteristic rapid, roving eye movements occur during this stage of sleep and are recorded as an electrooculogram (EOG). Except for eye movement, there is almost a complete loss of skeletal muscle tone in REM sleep. The threshold for arousal from sleep by sensory stimuli is elevated during this time. A beta rhythm (highest frequency, lowest amplitude) can be seen at this stage.

questions.text: A researcher uses an electron microscope to visualize muscle fibers and captures the image below. Which of the following zones of the sarcomere will shorten during muscle contraction?
questions.solution:
The sarcomere is the smallest functional unit of striated muscle. Shortening of some areas of the sarcomere helps facilitate muscle contraction. The different structures and zones that compose a sarcomere are shown in the image above.  

During muscle contraction, the section of the sarcomere that contains only actin (termed I band) and the section that contains only myosin (termed H band) shorten in length. In addition, the overall length of the sarcomere shortens.  

In contrast, the length of the myosin fibers (termed A band) remains unchanged during muscle contraction. Furthermore, the thickness of the Z-lines, which mark the boundaries of each sarcomere, and M-line, which serve as the attachment site for myosin, remain unchanged during contraction.



Option Analysis

❌ Zone 1 only:
Incorrect: Zone 1 refers to the distance from one Z-line to another. While this distance is reduced as the muscle contracts, so is the section of the sarcomere that contains only actin (Zone 4) and the section that contains only myosin (Zone 5).  
❌ Zone 2 only:
Incorrect: Zone 2 refers to the length of the myosin filaments. The myosin filaments are of fixed length and do not shorten during muscle contraction.  
❌ Zone 3 only:
Incorrect: Zone 3 refers to the width of the Z-line, which forms the border of each sarcomere. The width of the Z-line remains unchanged during muscle contraction.   
❌ Zone 4 only:
Incorrect: Zone 4 is the section of the sarcomere that contains only actin. While this distance is reduced as the muscle contracts, so is the overall length of the sarcomere (Zone 1) and the length of the section that contains only myosin (Zone 5).  
❌ Zone 5 only:
Incorrect: Zone 5 is the section of the sarcomere that contains only myosin. While this distance is reduced as the muscle contracts, so is the overall length of the sarcomere (Zone 1) and the length of the section that contains only actin (Zone 4).  
❌ Zones 4 and 5 :
Incorrect: The three zones that shorten during muscle contraction are Zone 1 (overall length of the sarcomere), Zone 4 (section of the sarcomere that contains only myosin), and Zone 5 (section of the sarcomere that contains only actin).  
✅ Zones 1, 4, and 5 :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A researcher is studying the effects of exercise on a healthy human subject. The study participant is instructed to run on a treadmill, and various physiologic parameters will be studied. Which of the following physiologic parameters is most likely to be decreased in this subject several minutes after initiating exercise?
questions.solution:
During exercise, cardiac output, and pulmonary blood flow increases due to increased oxygen demand by the tissues while pulmonary vascular resistance decreases. In response to increased cardiac output, perfusion increases in the apex of each lung, increasing the available surface area for gas exchange; this increases the amount of the lung that is perfused, thereby These changes increase oxygen delivery to exercising tissues. As a result, there is increased lactic acid, and CO2 production, as well as increased temperature, which decreases the hemoglobin’s affinity for oxygen, thereby increasing its delivery to the tissues in need.



Option Analysis

❌ Ventilation rate:
Incorrect: Ventilation rate increases during exercise due to a number of factors: initially, psychological stimuli (anticipation of exercise) drives the increase in ventilatory rate, followed by the increased delivery of CO2 to the lungs following sustained exercise.  
❌ Pulmonary blood flow:
Incorrect: During exercise, cardiac output and pulmonary blood flow increases while pulmonary vascular resistance decreases. 
❌ CO2 production :
Incorrect: During exercise, CO2 production increases due to increased cellular respiration by the muscle tissues. 
✅ Physiologic dead space:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Cardiac output:
Incorrect: During exercise, cardiac output and pulmonary blood flow increases due to increased oxygen demand while pulmonary vascular resistance decreases.

questions.text: A team of researchers is investigating different mechanisms for transmitting sensory information via neurons. They isolate free nerve endings from skin tissue that transmit pain via type C nerve fibers. Which of the following describes a characteristic of these nerve fibers?

choices.text: They are found in the lens of the eye

questions.solution:
Type C nerve fibers are tiny, unmyelinated fibers used by free nerve endings to transmit pain and temperature from the skin and viscera. Since these fibers are unmyelinated, they transmit the sensory information slowly compared to their myelinated counterparts.  

Option Analysis

❌ They are found in the lens of the eye:
Incorrect: Type C nerve fibers are only present in the skin and viscera.  
❌ Small, myelinated fibers:
Incorrect: Small myelinated fibers are responsible for transmitting temperature sensation in type A-delta nerve fibers.  
✅ Small, unmyelinated fibers:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Large, myelinated fibers:
Incorrect: Examples of large, myelinated fibers include Pacinian and Meissner corpuscles located in the deep skin layers and Glabrous (hairless) skin. These fibers function to sense fine touch, vibration, and pressure.  
❌ Large, unmyelinated fibers:
Incorrect: Large unmyelinated fibers can be seen with nerve endings that transmit instinctive pain and temperature in the skin and viscera via type B fibers.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 18 weeks of gestation, comes to the clinic for a routine visit. She does not have any active complaints at this time. Their medical history is noncontributory, and she only takes multivitamins. Cardiac auscultation shows a low-frequency diastolic heart sound that is heard shortly after the second heart sound when the patient lies in the left lateral decubitus. Which of the following labeled phases of the cardiac cycle does this heart sound correspond to?
questions.solution:
The graph below depicts various pressure and volume changes that correspond to the electromechanical activity of the heart with each heartbeat, called the cardiac cycle.  

A normal adult human heart makes two heart sounds during a typical cardiac cycle called the first (S1) and second, (S2) heart sounds. S1  is auscultated at the start of systole due to the closure of atrioventricular valves. At the same time, S2 is heard at the beginning of diastole due to the closure of the semilunar valves (aortic and pulmonic valves).  

In high output states (e.g., pregnancy, anemia) or patients with systolic heart failure, a third (S3) heart sound can also be heard. It is a low-frequency sound that occurs shortly after S2 during diastole. It is caused by the sudden limitation of ventricular movement during rapid passive ventricular filling. The fourth (S4) heart sound is an extra low-frequency heart sound that coincides with atrial contraction and is produced by the resultant surge of blood striking a stiff left ventricle. It can be heard in older adults secondary to an age-related decrease in ventricular compliance. Other pathologic causes included concentric hypertrophy and restrictive cardiomyopathy.  



Option Analysis

❌ A:
Incorrect: This phase of the cardiac cycle corresponds to atrial depolarization. It causes atrial contraction that increases the atrial pressure and pumps blood into the ventricle. In patients with diastolic dysfunction, an abnormal gallop sound can be heard in this phase as blood is forced into the stiff ventricle, called S4.  
❌ B:
Incorrect: This corresponds to the isovolumetric ventricular contraction phase in which a rise in ventricular pressure leads to closure of atrioventricular valves, making the first heart sound (S1). In this instance, the ventricles contract against closed valves leading to an abrupt rise in ventricular pressure. Once it exceeds the aortic pressure, the aortic valve opens.
❌ C:
Incorrect: This corresponds to the ventricular ejection phase of the cardiac cycle. It marks the opening of the aortic valve, which leads to the decline in the ventricular volume and pressure until it is lower than the aortic pressure, at which point the aortic valve closes back. No heart sounds are heard in this phase.  
❌ D:
Incorrect: This corresponds to the isovolumetric ventricular relaxation phase that occurs during diastole and starts when the aortic valve closes due to declining ventricular pressure, producing a second heart sound (S2). The aortic valve closes before the pulmonic valve.  
✅ E:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: You are teaching the medical students how to measure jugular venous pressure at the bedside. A normal jugular venous pressure tracing is shown. Which of the following labels corresponds to the right atrial passive emptying phase?
questions.solution:
The jugular venous pressure (JVP) is the pressure over the internal jugular vein that can be visualized during physical examination. It gives an indirect estimate of right atrial pressure since it follows about the same pressure changes as those in the right atrium. During a normal cardiac cycle, the changes in the JVP can be noted, as shown in the image below.  

When the right atrium actively empties the residual blood, it can be seen on the JVP tracing as a wave. It is followed by a closure of the tricuspid valve and right ventricular contraction that causes bulging of the valve in the right atrium, which is projected as the c wave. Shortly after that, the pulmonic valve opens, causing rapid ejection of the blood from the right ventricle. This decreases right atrial pressure, which is noted as the x descent. At this point, the right atrium starts filling up again for the next cardiac cycle. This corresponds to the v wave, indicating rising atrial pressure. Finally, after ventricular emptying, the tricuspid valve opens again, causing ejection of blood into the right ventricle and rapid fall in right atrial pressure noted as the y descent. It is prominent in constrictive pericarditis and absent in cardiac tamponade.  



Option Analysis

❌ Label A:
Incorrect: This corresponds to the right atrial contraction after the right passive emptying phase. It empties the residual blood in the right atrium into the right ventricle. It is absent in atrial  fibrillation.  
❌ Label C:
Incorrect: This label corresponds to the abrupt rise in right atrial pressure secondary to right ventricular contraction against the closed tricuspid valve during the isovolumetric contraction phase.  
❌ Label X  :
Incorrect: This corresponds to atrial relaxation and downward displacement of the closed tricuspid valve during the rapid ventricular ejection phase. Since the tricuspid valve is closed, right atrial emptying does not occur in this phase. This phase can be reduced or even absent in patients with tricuspid regurgitation or right heart failure due to loss of pressure gradient.  
❌ Label V:
Incorrect: This corresponds to the rise in right atrial pressure due to increasing right atrial volume against the closed tricuspid valve. Right atrial emptying does not occur in this phase.  
✅ Label Y  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: An investigator is studying weight regulation using experimental mouse models. Knockout mice are created with a homozygous mutation in ghrelin receptors, preventing the receptors from binding to ghrelin and initiating its normal signaling cascade. Which of the following best describes the normal role of ghrelin?

choices.text: Stimulates smooth muscle contraction in the upper gastrointestinal tract
Acts on hypothalamus to decrease appetite
Stimulates appetite and promotes weight gain

questions.solution:
Ghrelin is produced primarily in the stomach in response to fasting. It stimulates appetite and promotes weight gain. Sleep deprivation, fasting, or Prader-Willi syndrome lead to increased ghrelin levels. It acts on the lateral area of the hypothalamus (hunger center) to stimulate appetite.  

On the other hand, leptin, which is primarily produced in adipocytes and large fat cells, decreases food intake in the following ways: 
  •  It decreases the production of neuropeptide Y, a potent appetite stimulant, in the arcuate nucleus of the hypothalamus. 
  •  It stimulates the production of proopiomelanocortin (POMC) in the arcuate nucleus. Alpha-melanocyte-stimulating hormone is produced by cleavage of POMC and inhibits food intake.  
Mutation of the leptin gene can cause severe obesity. Sleep deprivation or starvation decreases leptin production. Leptin typically acts on the ventromedial area of the hypothalamus (satiety center) to suppress appetite.  



Option Analysis

❌ Stimulation of gallbladder contraction:
Incorrect: Cholecystokinin stimulates gallbladder contraction and release of pancreatic enzymes and bicarbonate secretion.
❌ Stimulates parietal cell acid production:
Incorrect: Gastrin stimulates parietal cell acid production by G cells in the gastric antrum in response to vagal activity and gastric distention.  
❌ Stimulates smooth muscle contraction in the upper gastrointestinal tract:
Incorrect: Motilin stimulates smooth muscle contraction in the upper gastrointestinal tract and generally increases gastric motility.  
❌ Acts on hypothalamus to decrease appetite  :
Incorrect: Leptin is produced by fat cells in response to short-term food intake and long-term adequacy of fat stores. It acts on the hypothalamus to decrease appetite. During fasting states, leptin levels fall.  
✅ Stimulates appetite and promotes weight gain:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A group of investigators are studying the hypothalamic-pituitary axis involved in the release of prolactin. Which of the following is true regarding the regulation of prolactin release?

choices.text: Prolactin secretion from the posterior pituitary is constantly inhibited by dopamine
Metoclopramide inhibits the release of prolactin
Thyrotropin-releasing hormone can stimulate prolactin release
Prolactin release from the anterior pituitary stimulates GnRH
Prolactin stimulates its own release by increasing dopamine synthesis

questions.solution:
Prolactin is secreted by the lactotroph cells in the anterior pituitary gland. In women that are not pregnant or breastfeeding, and in men, prolactin levels are usually kept in check by the hypothalamus in two ways. First, its secretion is tonically inhibited by dopamine from the tuberoinfundibular pathway of the hypothalamus. Additionally, increased prolactin in turn inhibits its own secretion by increasing dopamine synthesis and secretion from the hypothalamus. It is important to note that thyrotropin-releasing hormone (TRH) increases prolactin secretion, and therefore, the elevation of TRH (such as in 1° or 2° hypothyroidism) can result in hyperprolactinemia.  

During pregnancy, high circulating concentrations of estrogen and progesterone increase prolactin levels by 10- to 20-fold. Estrogen and progesterone inhibit the stimulatory effects of prolactin on milk production. The abrupt drop in estrogen and progesterone levels following delivery allows prolactin—which temporarily remains high—to induce lactation. Other prolactin-releasing stimuli include the nursing stimulus, as well as stress.  



Option Analysis

❌ Prolactin secretion from the posterior pituitary is constantly inhibited by dopamine:
Incorrect: Prolactin is secreted by lactotrophs located in the anterior pituitary and is tonically inhibited by dopamine from the tuberoinfundibular pathway of the hypothalamus.
❌ Metoclopramide inhibits the release of prolactin:
Incorrect: Metoclopramide is a dopamine antagonist and it stimulates the release of prolactin.  
✅ Thyrotropin-releasing hormone can stimulate prolactin release  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Prolactin release from the anterior pituitary stimulates GnRH:
Incorrect: Prolactin release from the anterior pituitary inhibits GnRH synthesis and release. The GnRH inhibition results in decreased luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) levels from the anterior pituitary.  
❌ Prolactin stimulates its own release by increasing dopamine synthesis  :
Incorrect: Increased prolactin inhibits its own secretion by increasing dopamine synthesis and secretion from the hypothalamus.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man comes to the clinic to establish care. He currently has no active complaints. His past medical history is unremarkable, and he takes no medications. Vitals are within normal limits. Cardiac auscultation reveals two heart sounds, one at the start of systole and corresponding to the pulse. The heart sound described in this patient occurs as a result of the following?

choices.text: Blood striking a stiff left ventricle

questions.solution:
A normal adult human heart makes two heart sounds during a typical cardiac cycle called the first (S1), and second, (S2) heart says. S1 is auscultated at the start of systole due to the closure of atrioventricular valves (mitral and tricuspid valves). At the same time, S2 is heard at the beginning of the diastole of the semilunar valves (aortic and pulmonic valves). S1 radiates to all cardiac listening posts but is loudest at the apex. S2 can be divided into A2 (aortic valve) and P2 (pulmonic valve). A2 is loudest at the right upper sternal border, while P2 is at the left upper sternal border.  

Option Analysis

❌ Blood striking a stiff left ventricle:
Incorrect: S4 is a low-frequency extra heart sound at the end-diastole that occurs from a surge of blood striking a stiff left ventricle during right-atrial contraction. Causes include an age-related decline in ventricular compliance, restrictive cardiomyopathy, and left ventricular hypertrophy.
❌ Rapid passive filling of ventricles  :
Incorrect: Third heart sound (S3) is caused by a sudden limitation of ventricular movement during the rapid passive ventricular filling phase. Its presence in patients aged >40 suggests ventricular volume overload that can be secondary to aortic/mitral regurgitation or systolic heart failure.  
✅ Closure of mitral valve:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Closure of aortic valve  :
Incorrect: Closure of the aortic valve produces a second heart (S2) sound that occurs during diastole when the aortic valve closes due to declining ventricular pressure in the isovolumetric ventricular relaxation phase.  
❌ Aortic root dilation  :
Incorrect: Aortic root dilation can be associated with aortic insufficiency, which produces a high-pitched early diastolic decrescendo murmur instead of an extra heart sound.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the emergency department with shortness of breath. He uses 3-pillows at night to help relieve his dyspnea. Past medical history is significant for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and inferior wall myocardial infarction treated medically a year ago. Cardiac auscultation reveals a low-frequency diastolic sound that is heard at the cardiac apex shortly after the sound of closure of the aortic valve. An echocardiogram shows a left ventricular ejection fraction of 30-35%. Which of the following is the most likely heart sound described in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient with dyspnea and orthopnea, together with echocardiographic finding of ejection fraction of 30-35%, most likely has acute decompensation of systolic heart failure (now referred to as heart failure with reduced ejection fraction [HFrEF]). Cardiac examination reveals a low-frequency sound heard shortly after S2 during diastole, the third heart sound (S3).  

A third heart sound (S3) is caused by a sudden limitation of ventricular movement during the cardiac cycle's rapid passive ventricular filling phase. It can be a normal finding in healthy children, young adults, and pregnant women. However, patients aged >40 suggest ventricular volume overload that can be secondary to aortic/mitral regurgitation or systolic heart failure.  

Of note, ventricular gallops (S3 and S4) are best heard with the bell of the stethoscope over the cardiac apex. At the same time, the patient is in the left lateral decubitus position (brings the heart closer to the chest wall) at end-expiration (decreases lung volume).

Option Analysis

❌ S1:
Incorrect: The first heart sound (S1) occurs due to the closure of the atrioventricular valves (mitral and tricuspid valves) due to rising ventricular pressure in the isovolumetric ventricular contraction phase of the cardiac cycle.
❌ S2:
Incorrect: The second heart sound (S2) occurs due to the closure of the semilunar valves (aortic and pulmonic valves) due to declining ventricular in the isovolumetric ventricular relaxation phase of the cardiac cycle.
✅ S3:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ S4:
Incorrect: The fourth heart sound (S4) is an abnormal gallop sound that is heard in patients with diastolic dysfunction during the phase of atrial contraction. It occurs as a result of blood striking a stiff ventricle.
❌ A murmur of aortic stenosis:
Incorrect: Aortic stenosis usually causes a crescendo-decrescendo systolic ejection murmur that is best heard in the right second intercostal space (aortic area).

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the clinic because of a recent weight loss of 4.5-kg (9.9-lb) and recurrent fatty stools over the past several months. The patient has a history of diabetes mellitus and gallstones. Laboratory studies show decreased concentrations of pepsinogen, amylase, lipase, insulin, and glucagon. A CT scan shows a mass in the pancreas. Based on this patient's symptoms, which of the following substances might be secreted by this pancreatic tumor?
questions.solution:
Somatostatin is an inhibitory hormone that is normally produced by the D-cells of the pancreas. It inhibits gastric acid, pepsinogen, insulin, glucagon, pancreatic and small intestine fluid release, and also inhibits gallbladder contraction. Somatostatin secretion is induced by amino acids, free fatty acids, glucose, glucagon, and cholinergic and β-adrenergic neurotransmitters. It is inhibited by α-adrenergic neurotransmitters and insulin.

Option Analysis

❌ Cholecystokinin:
Incorrect: Cholecystokinin  is a hormone produced in the duodenum that stimulates pancreatic and gallbladder secretion of enzymes and bile, respectively, to aid in the digestion of fat and protein.  
❌ Gastrin:
Incorrect: Gastrin is produced by the G-cells in the gastric mucosa and stimulates the release of gastric acid from parietal cells.
❌ Intrinsic factor  :
Incorrect: Intrinsic factor is secreted by parietal cells in the stomach. It binds to vitamin B12 to facilitate absorption in the terminal ileum.
❌ Secretin:
Incorrect: Secretin is released by duodenal S-cells. It helps to maintain pH and the digestive environment in the duodenum. It stimulates secretion in the stomach, liver, and pancreas.
✅ Somatostatin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 35-year-old scientist with a medical history of type II diabetes mellitus and obesity carries out an experiment in which she injects herself with glucose intravenously in the form of 5% dextrose solution. Afterward, she takes a blood sample to measure serum insulin levels. The next day, she orally administers the same amount of glucose and retakes the blood sample. The serum insulin levels were higher this time than in the previous sample. Which of the following is the most likely cause for this discrepancy?

choices.text: History of type II diabetes mellitus
Glucose uptake by other organs when given intravenously

questions.solution:
Glucose is the major regulator of insulin release. However, insulin release is enhanced by incretins, gut hormones secreted from enteroendocrine cells into the blood in response to an oral glucose load. They increase insulin release mainly by augmenting beta (β) cell sensitivity to glucose. The phenomenon is referred to as “the incretin effect”. In the vignette, this effect accounts for the higher insulin levels in response to oral glucose than intravenous glucose.  

There are two types of incretin: glucagon-like peptide 1 (GLP-1) and glucose-dependent insulinotropic polypeptide (GIP), also known as a gastric inhibitory peptide. GLP-1 is secreted from enteroendocrine L-cells of the small intestine, while GIP is secreted from K-cells of the small intestine. Eventually, GLP-1 is broken down into inactive metabolites by an enzyme called dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP4).  

Based on this phenomenon, two medications have been developed to enhance insulin secretion, lowering blood glucose levels in patients with type II diabetes mellitus. The first is an incretin mimetic (e.g. exenatide, which is an agonist of the GLP-1 receptor), and the other is an incretin enhancer (e.g. sitagliptin, which is a DPP4 inhibitor).  

Option Analysis

❌ History of type II diabetes mellitus  :
Incorrect: Type II diabetes mellitus is associated with insulin resistance. However, the condition does not affect the insulinotropic effects of glucagon-like peptide 1 (GLP-1), which is the cause of higher serum insulin levels in response to oral glucose load in this subject.
❌ Glucose uptake by other organs when given intravenously  :
Incorrect: Glucose uptake is facilitated by glucose transporters (GLUT). Although each GLUT has a different affinity for glucose uptake, it cannot be the reason for the discrepancy in serum insulin levels between oral versus intravenous glucose administration.  
❌ Age-related changes:
Incorrect: Age is not shown to be associated with the degree of insulin release in response to oral versus intravenous glucose load. The incretin effect is a more likely explanation.
❌ Obesity:
Incorrect: Obesity is associated with insulin resistance. However, obesity is not associated with the degree of insulin release in response to oral versus intravenous glucose administration. The incretin effect is a more likely explanation.  
✅ Incretin effect  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A bacterial antigen is presented to a CD4+ T-cell via the MHC II protein. Which additional signals must be present on the antigen-presenting cell for T-cell activation to occur?
questions.solution:
T-cell activation requires two signals. The first is the interaction between a T-cell receptor (TCR) and a major histocompatibility protein (MHC). The second is the interaction between the ligand B7 and receptor CD28.    

Antigens are presented to T-cells via MHCs found on the surface of antigen-presenting cells. MHC I typically presents endogenous antigens (e.g. viral or tumor proteins), whereas MHC II typically presents exogenous antigens (e.g. bacterial proteins).      

The first signal is transmitted when MHC I binds to the T-cell receptor (TCR) and CD8 co-receptor on CD8+ T-cells or when MHC II binds to the TCR and CD4 co-receptor on CD4+ T-cells. Of note, the antigen presented by the MHC molecule must be of the right size and shape to bind strongly with a TCR and trigger signal transmission. The second signal occurs when CD28 on the T-cell surface binds with B7 (CD80/86) on the antigen-presenting cell.      

In contrast, if a T-cell interacts with an MHC-antigen complex but does not receive the second signal, it will become anergic. This extra layer of security helps maintain self-tolerance when the body’s immune system will not attack antigens expressed by its organs.    

Once a T-cell has received both signals, it will begin synthesizing inflammatory cytokines. In particular, IL-2 is released and binds to T-cell receptors in a process termed autocrine (self) stimulation, leading to T-cell proliferation and differentiation.  


Option Analysis

❌ CD40:
Incorrect: CD40 is a receptor found on B-cells. The binding of CD40L, which is present on T-cells, with CD40 leads to B-cell activation and increased immunoglobulin production. In contrast, CD40 is not required for T-cell activation.  
❌ IL-2:
Incorrect: Interleukin 2 (IL-2) is a cytokine produced primarily by activated CD4+ and CD8+ T-cells. IL-2 plays an important role in promoting T-cells proliferation and differentiation. However, IL-2 is neither necessary for the initial activation of T-cells nor found on antigen-presenting cells.  
✅ B7:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ MHC I:
Incorrect: Major histocompatibility complex class I (MHC I) proteins typically present endogenous antigens to CD8+ T-cells. The complex formed by the antigen and MHC I molecule is one of the signals necessary for CD8+ T-cell activation. In contrast, MHC I is not typically involved in CD4+ T-cell activation.   
❌ Tumor necrosis factor-alpha:
Incorrect: Tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-α) is a cytokine produced by monocytes during acute inflammation. TNF-α is involved in regulating the immune response, recruiting leukocytes, and helping maintain granulomas. However, TNF-α is not a signal that must be present with the MHC-antigen complex to induce T-cell activation.

questions.text: A 47-year-old man presents to a rural clinic for evaluation of fevers and abdominal pain, which have been ongoing for the past month. Laboratory testing demonstrates an elevated eosinophil count and elevated IgE level. ELISA testing confirms the presence of Toxocara cana antigens. Which of the following is released by the type of T-cell involved in mediating these laboratory changes and helping the body fight this infection?
questions.solution:
Type 2 helper (Th2) T-cells play a major role in fighting parasitic infections. They stimulate mast cells, basophils, and eosinophils and release IL-4, promoting B-cell class switching to IgE.  

The various types of T-cells release different cytokines. A comparison of the cytokines released by each cell type can be found below.



Option Analysis

❌ Interferon-gamma:
Incorrect: Interferon-gamma (IFNγ) stimulates macrophages to kill phagocytosed organisms. It can also activate natural killer cells and cause them to eliminate virally-infected cells. However, IFNγ is not typically produced by type 2 helper (Th2) T-cells, which are the type of T-cells primarily involved in fighting parasitic infections.  
❌ Interleukin 17:
Incorrect: Interleukin 17 (IL-17) is produced by type 17 helper (Th17) T-cells. Th17 cells regulate tissue inflammation, activate neutrophils, and fight extracellular infections. However, IL-17 is not typically released by type 2 helper (Th2) T-cells, which recruit mast cells, basophils, and eosinophils and induce immunoglobulin class switching to IgE. These changes ultimately enable Th2 cells to fight parasitic infections.  
✅ Interleukin 4:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Complement 3b  :
Incorrect: Complement 3b (C3b) is part of the innate immune system. It can opsonize invading pathogens and mark them for clearance by the immune system. However, complement proteins are not released by T-cells.  
❌ Interleukin 35:
Incorrect: Interleukin 35 (IL-35) is an anti-inflammatory cytokine that plays a role in immune suppression. However, it is not released by type 2 helper (Th2) T-cells, which are the type of T-cells primarily involved in fighting parasitic infections.

questions.text: A researcher studies lung compliance and pressure-volume curves for the lung and chest wall in healthy adult patients. He discovers that lung inflation follows a different pressure-volume curve than lung deflation. Which of the following terms best describes this phenomenon?
questions.solution:
Hysteresis refers to the phenomenon that lung inflation follows a different pressure-volume curve than lung deflation due to the effects of overcoming surface tension during inspiration. This results in a more considerable change in pleural pressure when compared to lung volume change, as depicted in the graph above. Hysteresis develops due to surfactant's effects on the lung's surface tension.  

Option Analysis

✅ Hysteresis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Elastic recoil  :
Incorrect: Elastic recoil refers to the tendency for the lungs to collapse inward and the chest wall to spring outward.  
❌ Compliance:
Incorrect: Compliance refers to a change in lung volume for a given change in pressure.  Hysteresis, specifically, is the difference between expiratory and inspiratory compliance.  
❌ Minute ventilation  :
Incorrect: Minute ventilation refers to the total volume of gas entering the lungs per minute.  
❌ Alveolar ventilation:
Incorrect: Alveolar ventilation refers to the total volume of gas entering the alveoli each minute.

questions.text: A researcher is studying skeletal muscle physiology. Baseline characteristics of a muscle sample obtained from a mouse are recorded. Which combination of changes to the number of muscle fibers recruited, frequency of muscle stimulation and velocity of muscle contraction will enable this muscle sample to generate the greatest force?
questions.solution:
There are five main factors that determine the force produced during a muscle contraction. These factors are described in the following table:
 

Option Analysis

❌ :
Incorrect: Increasing the frequency of muscle stimulation and number of muscle fibers recruited will increase the force of contraction. Increasing the velocity of contraction decreases the number of actin-myosin cross-bridges that can form, thereby decreasing the force of contraction.   
✅ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ :
Incorrect: Increasing the number of muscle fibers recruited and decreasing the velocity of contraction will increase the force of contraction. Decreasing the stimulation frequency will reduce the number of calcium ions released into the sarcoplasm, thereby decreasing the force of contraction.   
❌ :
Incorrect: Decreasing the number of muscle fibers recruited will decrease the force of muscle contraction.   
❌ :
Incorrect: Decreasing the velocity of contraction will increase the force exerted during muscle contraction. Decreasing the number of fibers recruited and the frequency of stimulation will decrease the force of contraction. As a result, this combination of changes will not help the muscle sample produce the greatest force.

questions.text: The blood-brain barrier is absent in several specialized regions collectively called circumventricular organs. Which of the following structures is considered the vomiting center of the brain?
questions.solution:
The blood-brain barrier (BBB) is absent in several specialized regions of the brain collectively called circumventricular organs. These areas are: (1) the posterior pituitary (neurohypophysis) and the adjacent ventral part of the median eminence of the hypothalamus, (2) the area postrema, (3) the organum vasculosum of the lamina terminalis (OVLT, supraoptic crest), and (4) the subfornical organ (SFO).

The area postrema is concerned with cardiovascular control, where circulating angiotensin II produces a neurally mediated increase in blood pressure. The circumventricular organs have fenestrated capillaries and are said to be “outside the blood-brain barrier.” These organs function as chemoreceptor zones for many peptides and substances.  

Option Analysis

❌ Posterior pituitary:
Incorrect: Posterior pituitary is one of the circumventricular organs but is not the vomiting center.  
❌ Organum vasculosum lamina terminalis:
Incorrect: Organum vasculosum lamina terminalis (OVLT) is the site of the osmoreceptor controlling vasopressin secretion. Evidence suggests that circulating interleukin-1 (IL-1) produces fever by acting in the organum vasculosum lamina terminalis.  
✅ Area postrema:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Subfornical organ:
Incorrect: Angiotensin II acts on the subfornical organ (SFO) to increase water intake. It is not the vomiting center of the brain.  
❌ Median eminence of the hypothalamus:
Incorrect: Ventral part of the median eminence of the hypothalamus is one of the circumventricular organs, but it is not the brain's vomiting center.

questions.text: A group of researchers is examining the relative concentrations of several substances along the proximal convoluted tubule. They discover one substance that can be used to approximate renal plasma flow. This substance is denoted by which of the following lines detailed in the graph below?
questions.solution:
The substance in question is reflective of para-aminohippuric acid (PAH), which can be used to approximate renal plasma flow (RPF). This molecule is wholly removed from the blood that passes through the kidneys. It undergoes glomerular filtration and tubular secretion due to unique transport molecules on the basolateral membrane of the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT). The only case in which this does not occur is when these transport molecules are fully saturated, leaving some PAH in the bloodstream. In the former case, when PAH filtration falls below its maximum transport, all the PAH making it to the kidneys is removed from the blood that passes through them. Thus, RPF can be calculated using PAH as a surrogate marker by taking the concentration of PAH in the urine (UPAH) times the urine flow rate (V), all divided by the concentration of PAH in the renal artery (PPAH).  

 


This is in contrast to inulin (depicted by line B), which is neither secreted nor reabsorbed in the proximal tubule resulting in a lower relative concentration than PAH. It increases in concentration along the proximal convoluted tubule due to water reabsorption.  

Option Analysis

✅ A:
Correct: See Main Explanation   
❌ B:
Incorrect: This line depicts inulin concentration along the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT). Its clearance rate approximates the glomerular filtration rate (GFR).   
❌ C:
Incorrect: This line depicts glucose concentration along the PCT. It falls as glucose is reabsorbed more quickly than water, making its tubular fluid/plasma (TF/Px) concentration <1.   
❌ D:
Incorrect: This line depicts sodium concentration along the PCT, which reflects a TF/Px concentration of approximately 1, showing that sodium and water are reabsorbed at almost the same rate.   
❌ E:
Incorrect: This line depicts chloride. Reabsorption of this molecule occurs slower than water in early proximal convoluted tubules and then matches the rate of water reabsorption more distally.

questions.text: Estrogen and progesterone are the female sex hormones and are produced mainly by the ovaries. Which of the following enzymes are involved in the conversion of testosterone to estradiol?
questions.solution:
Estrogen is one of the female sex hormones and is produced mainly by the ovaries. The female body can synthesize three types of estrogens: estradiol, estrone, and estriol.    

Estrogen is a steroid hormone and its production starts with cholesterol. Cholesterol reaches the theca cells, where the enzyme cholesterol desmolase converts cholesterol to pregnenolone. Another enzyme in theca cells called 3ꞵ-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase converts some of the pregnenolone to progesterone.  

However, most of the pregnenolone is converted to 17-hydroxypregnenolone, and then into dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA). 3ꞵ-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase also acts on DHEA and converts it into androstenedione (a testosterone precursor).  

Androstenedione diffuses to nearby granulosa cells, which have two enzymes of their own. The first is 17ꞵ-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase, which converts androstenedione to testosterone, and the second is aromatase, which converts testosterone into 17ꞵ-estradiol - the most biologically active type of estrogen.  



Option Analysis

❌ Cholesterol desmolase:
Incorrect: Cholesterol desmolase converts cholesterol to pregnenolone.  
❌ 3ꞵ-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase:
Incorrect: 3ꞵ-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase converts pregnenolone to progesterone and dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA) to androstenedione.  
❌ 17ꞵ-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase:
Incorrect: 17ꞵ-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase converts androstenedione to testosterone.  
✅ Aromatase:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ 5α-reductase:
Incorrect: 5α-reductase converts testosterone to dihydrotestosterone.

questions.text: Hypersensitivity reactions occur when the normally protective immune system responds abnormally, potentially harming the body. Which of the following is an example of a type II hypersensitivity reaction?
questions.solution:
Hypersensitivity reactions occur when the immune system overreacts to a foreign stimulus, resulting in tissue damage. All hypersensitivity shares the common motif of pre-sensitization or pre-exposure to an antigen with a prior immune response.  

There are three specific mechanisms by which type II hypersensitivity reactions occur.  

  • Complement-dependent reactions (inflammation): Antibody bound to antigen can fix complement and induce direct lysis of the cell through the production of the membrane attack complex (MAC), or the complement can coat cells with C3b (an opsonin) and promote phagocytosis of the antigen. Example: Goodpasture syndrome, Rheumatic fever, and hyperacute transplant rejection. 
 
  • Antibody-dependent cell-mediated cytotoxicity (cellular destruction): Cell types that bear receptors for the Fc portion of IgG, such as neutrophils, eosinophils, macrophages, and natural killer (NK) cells, mediate the removal of antigen. Examples: Transfusion reactions, erythroblastosis fetalis, and autoimmune hemolytic anemia. 
 
  • Antibody-mediated cellular dysfunction: Antibodies themselves affect the function of the antigen. Examples: Graves disease is due to an antibody that activates the thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) receptor, resulting in hyperthyroidism. Myasthenia gravis is due to antibodies against the acetylcholine (ACh) receptor, impairing neuromuscular depolarization. 

Option Analysis

❌ Allergic asthma:
Incorrect: Allergic asthma is an example of type I hypersensitivity reaction.
❌ Rheumatoid arthritis:
Incorrect: Rheumatoid arthritis is an example of a type III hypersensitivity reaction.
❌ Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis:
Incorrect: Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis is an example of a type III hypersensitivity reaction.  
❌ Contact dermatitis  :
Incorrect: Contact dermatitis is an example of a type IV hypersensitivity reaction.  
✅ Hemolytic disease of the newborn:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man comes to a clinic in Denver, Colorado. He arrived in the city two days ago via plane. The patient came to visit his daughter. The patient has been experiencing headaches and nausea “ever since landing.” Which of the following acid-base imbalances is most likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Altitude sickness describes the pathological effect of high altitude on humans. The condition is caused by acute exposure to low partial pressure of oxygen at high altitudes and typically occurs above 2,400 meters (8,000 feet). It presents with a collection of nonspecific symptoms characterized by shortness of breath, fatigue, headaches, and nausea.

Being exposed to low atmospheric oxygen results in hyperventilation and respiratory alkalosis. The body compensates metabolically by increasing the amount of erythropoietin, resulting in increased hematocrit and hemoglobin.
