Moreover, the body increases bicarbonate excretion via the kidneys to produce metabolic acidosis and compensate for respiratory alkalosis.

Acetazolamide is a medication that can help alleviate altitude sickness. Acetazolamide decreases renal bicarbonate reabsorption and decreases blood pH. In turn, the body increases its respiratory rate, which increases the amount of oxygen available.  

Option Analysis

❌ Respiratory acidosis:
Incorrect: Respiratory acidosis is seen in patients with failure of ventilation and accumulation of carbon dioxide. Respiratory acidosis is commonly seen in patients who have overdosed on opioids, are obese, and are approaching respiratory failure secondary to asthma or COPD exacerbation.  
✅ Respiratory alkalosis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis:
Incorrect: This patient is most likely experiencing symptoms of altitude sickness. The presence of low atmospheric oxygen causes the body to hyperventilate, which leads to respiratory alkalosis (not acidosis). Overtime, the body compensates for respiratory alkalosis by increasing renal bicarbonate excretion, thereby leading to metabolic acidosis.  
❌ Metabolic alkalosis:
Incorrect: The causes of metabolic alkalosis can be classified into several mechanisms: intracellular shift of hydrogen ions (e.g. hypokalemia), gastrointestinal loss of hydrogen ions (e.g. vomiting), excessive renal hydrogen ion loss (e.g. hyperaldosteronism), retention or addition of bicarbonate ions (e.g. acetazolamide use), or volume contraction (e.g. diuretic use). In contrast, this patient likely has altitude sickness, which is associated with hyperventilation, respiratory alkalosis, and compensatory metabolic acidosis.

questions.text: A researcher is studying the electromechanical activity of the heart throughout a normal cardiac cycle. Which of the following labels corresponds to the isovolumetric ventricular relaxation phase of the cardiac cycle?
questions.solution:
The graph below depicts the pressure changes that correspond to the electromechanical activity of the heart with each heartbeat, called the cardiac cycle. The changes in the curves allow one to identify the cycle phases and the time of opening and closing of the cardiac valves.  

Isovolumetric ventricular relaxation is a phase that occurs during diastole and starts when the aortic valve closes due to declining ventricular pressure. During this phase, mitral and aortic valves are closed, causing an abrupt decline in ventricular pressure. When it becomes lower than the atrial pressure, the mitral valve opens, and the rapid ventricular filling phase starts.  



Option Analysis

❌ A:
Incorrect: This corresponds to the isovolumetric ventricular contraction phase, in which a rise in ventricular pressure leads to the closure of atrioventricular valves. In this instance, the ventricles contract against closed valves leading to an abrupt increase in ventricular pressure. Once it exceeds the aortic pressure, the aortic valve opens.  
❌ B:
Incorrect: This corresponds to the ventricular ejection phase of the cardiac cycle. It marks the opening of the aortic valve, leading to the ventricular volume and pressure decline until it is lower than the aortic pressure. At this point, the aortic valve closes back.
✅ C:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ D:
Incorrect: This corresponds to the rapid ventricular filling phase. It occurs when the atrial pressure exceeds the ventricular pressure, the two atrioventricular valves open, and the two ventricles start to fill rapidly with blood from the atria. This leads to a rapid fall in atrial pressure.  
❌ E  :
Incorrect: This is the first phase of the cardiac cycle as it corresponds to the atrial depolarization seen on an electrocardiogram as a P wave. It causes atrial contraction that increases the atrial pressure and pumps blood into the ventricle. As a result, the ventricular pressure slightly increases.

questions.text: A researcher is conducting a study on cardiac physiology. The study data is used to generate the left ventricular pressure-volume loop shown below. Which of the following best describes the cardiac cycle phase of each side of the loop?
questions.solution:
Pressure-volume loops characterize changes in left ventricular pressure (y-axis) and volume (x-axis) during the cardiac cycle. The loop can be divided into four phases: isovolumetric contraction, systolic ejection, isovolumetric relaxation, and ventricular filling.    

The right lower corner of the loop corresponds to the end-diastolic point. The mitral valve then closes, and the heart begins contracting, marking the beginning of systole. As the ventricle contracts, intraventricular pressure increases. However, since the mitral and aortic valves are closed, the blood has nowhere to go, and ventricular volume is unchanged. As a result, this phase (phase 1) is termed isovolumetric contraction.    

Eventually, intraventricular pressure exceeds the aortic pressure, forcing the aortic valve to open. Blood can now leave the left ventricle, and ventricular volume decreases. These physiological changes are represented by the loop's upper margin (phase 2) and systolic ejection.    

Eventually, aortic pressure exceeds left ventricular pressure, and the aortic valve closes, marking the end of systole. The ventricle begins relaxing, and intraventricular pressure decreases. Since the aortic valve is closed and the mitral valve has not yet opened, blood volume within the ventricle is unchanged. Hence, this phase (phase 3) is termed isovolumetric relaxation.    

Finally, the pressure within the left ventricle drops below the left atrium, enabling the mitral valve to open. Blood flows from the atrium into the ventricle, and its volume increases. This phase (phase 4) is termed ventricular filling. Once there is no more pressure gradient between the two chambers and the mitral valve closes, the cardiac cycle starts again.



Option Analysis

✅ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ :
Incorrect: Phase 1 is characterized by an increase in ventricular pressure but no change in ventricular volume, which corresponds to isovolumetric contraction. Phase 2 is characterized by a decrease in ventricular volume and represents systolic ejection. Phase 3 is characterized by decreased ventricular pressure and means isovolumetric relaxation. Finally, phase 4 is characterized by increased ventricular volume and corresponds to ventricular filling.   
❌ :
Incorrect: Phases 1 and 2 correspond to isovolumetric contraction and systolic ejection. However, phase 3 represents isovolumetric relaxation. Ventricular filling, characterized by a progressive increase in ventricular volume, does not occur until phase 4.
❌ :
Incorrect: Phase 1 is characterized by an increase in ventricular pressure but no change in ventricular volume, corresponding to isovolumetric contraction. Phase 2 is characterized by a decrease in ventricular volume and represents systolic ejection. Phase 3 is characterized by decreased ventricular pressure and means isovolumetric relaxation. Finally, phase 4 is characterized by increased ventricular volume and corresponds to ventricular filling.
❌ :
Incorrect: During the ejection phase, blood leaves the right ventricle, and as a result, ventricular volume decreases. Phase 1 is characterized by an increase in ventricular pressure but no change in volume. Therefore, it cannot represent the ejection phase. In contrast, the ejection phase (both rapid and reduced ejection) occurs during phase 2.

questions.text: A physiologist is conducting a study on a human subject. The left ventricular pressure-volume loop below is generated using data obtained from the subject. The subject has a heart rate of H and ejection fraction of F. Which of the following best approximates the subject’s stroke volume?
questions.solution:
Pressure-volume loops characterize left ventricular pressure and volume changes during the cardiac cycle. Stroke volume can be calculated by finding the difference between the end-diastolic and end-systolic volumes.    

The right lower corner of the loop corresponds to the end-diastolic point. The blood volume in the ventricle is termed the end-diastolic volume (V3). The mitral valve then closes, and the heart begins contracting, marking the beginning of systole. As the ventricle contracts, intraventricular pressure increases.    

Eventually, intraventricular pressure exceeds the aortic pressure, forcing the aortic valve to open. Blood then leaves the left ventricle, causing ventricular volume and pressure to decrease progressively. When the aortic pressure exceeds the left ventricular pressure, the aortic valve closes, and the volume of blood remaining in the ventricle is termed the end-systolic volume (V1).
   
Stroke volume is the amount of blood ejected by the left ventricle during each systolic contraction. Therefore, it can be calculated by either finding the difference between the end-diastolic and end-systolic volumes (V3-V1), which is the loop’s width or by multiplying the end-diastolic volume by the ejection fraction (V3*F).  



Option Analysis

❌ (V3-V1)*(P4-P1)  :
Incorrect: Stroke work is the work the heart performs during each beat. It can be approximated as the area of the pressure-volume loop. If the loop is estimated to be a rectangle, the area is its width (V3-V1) multiplied by its height (P4-P1). However, this question asks for the stroke volume, not cardiac work.
❌ (V3-V1)*(P3-P1)*H  :
Incorrect: Minute work is the heart's amount of work in a minute. It can be calculated by multiplying stroke work ((V3-V1)*(P4-P1)), which can be approximated as the area of the pressure-volume loop, by the heart rate (H). However, this question asks for the stroke volume, not cardiac work.  
❌ (V3-V1)*F  :
Incorrect: Stroke volume is the amount of blood pumped out of the left ventricle during each heartbeat. It can be calculated by finding the difference between the end-diastolic volume (V3) and end-systolic volume (V1). Alternatively, it can be calculated by multiplying the end-diastolic volume by the ejection fraction. However, multiplying the stroke volume by the ejection fraction, as in this answer choice, will not yield a clinically-relevant value.  
❌ (P4-P3):
Incorrect: In the above diagram, P4 corresponds to the systolic blood pressure, whereas P3 corresponds to the diastolic blood pressure. The difference between P4 and P3 represents the pulse pressure, not the stroke volume.  
✅ (V3-V1)  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man comes to the emergency department for the evaluation of syncope. Physical examination shows weak and slow rising arterial pulse. Cardiac auscultation reveals a harsh midsystolic murmur best heard at the right second intercostal space. Splitting of the second heart sound (S2) is also appreciated. Which of the following maneuvers will most likely eliminate the splitting of the second heart sound?
questions.solution:
This patient with pulsus parvus et tardus (weak and slow rising pulse) and auscultation finding of a harsh midsystolic murmur in the aortic area most likely has aortic stenosis (AS). AS can cause paradoxical splitting of the second heart sound (S2) that can be eliminated by deep inspiration.  

Physiologically, the second heart sound (S2) produced by the closure of aortic and pulmonic valves can be separated into A2 and P2. This is because the aortic valve usually closes before the pulmonic valve. This phenomenon can be augmented by inspiration, thereby increasing the venous return, leading to delayed closure of the pulmonic valve. Widening of this splitting can be in conditions that delay RV emptying.  

Paradoxical splitting is heard in conditions that delay aortic valve closure (e.g. aortic stenosis), due to which P2 occurs before A2. On inspiration, P2 closes later and moves closer to A2, “paradoxically” eliminating the split.  


Option Analysis

✅ Deep inspiration:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Amyl nitrate inhalation  :
Incorrect: Amyl nitrate causes vasodilation, resulting in a transient decrease in venous return. This would result in decreased right ventricular filling time and early closure of the pulmonic valve, potentiating the paradoxical splitting.
❌ Having the patient stand up:
Incorrect: Abrupt standing results in a transient decrease in venous return. This would decrease right ventricular filling time and lead to the earlier closure of the pulmonic valve, thereby potentiating the paradoxical splitting.
❌ Phase 2 of the Valsalva maneuver:
Incorrect: Phase 2 of the Valsalva maneuver (bearing down against a closed glottis) would decrease the venous return, potentiating the paradoxical splitting.

questions.text: Insulin glargine is added to the medication regimen of a patient with a hemoglobin A1c of 11.2%. Which changes will most likely occur in response to this new medication?
questions.solution:
Insulin is an anabolic peptide hormone that binds to a tyrosine kinase receptor on target tissues (e.g., liver, skeletal muscle, adipose tissue) to regulate the metabolism of carbohydrates, proteins, and fats. Insulin stimulates glucose uptake by increasing the expression of GLUT4 in skeletal muscle and adipose tissue and glucokinase activity in the liver.  

Insulin decreases protein kinase A activity, which leads to increased fructose-2,6-bisphosphate (F-2,6-BP) concentration. Increased F-2,6-BP concentration increases the activity of the glycolytic enzyme phosphofructokinase-1 and decreases the activity of the gluconeogenic enzyme fructose-1,6-bisphosphatase.  

Moreover, insulin increases glycogenesis by activating glycogen synthase.  

Insulin decreases lipolysis in adipose tissue by decreasing the expression of adipocyte triglyceride lipase and increases lipogenesis by increasing the activity of acetyl CoA carboxylase, HMG CoA reductase, and endothelial lipoprotein lipase.  

Finally, insulin promotes amino acid uptake and protein synthesis and decreases ketogenesis.

Option Analysis

❌ :
Incorrect: Insulin administration would increase glycogenesis and glycolysis. Moreover, insulin would decrease gluconeogenesis and lipolysis.
✅ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ :
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the effects of glucagon, which would result in decreased hepatic glycolysis and glycogenesis and increased lipolysis and hepatic gluconeogenesis. Insulin has a different set of effects.
❌ :
Incorrect: Insulin administration would increase glycogenesis and inhibit lipolysis. However, it would lead to an increase, not a decrease, in glycolysis. Moreover, insulin administration would decrease gluconeogenesis and hepatic glucose production.
❌ :
Incorrect: Epinephrine causes an increase in lipolysis, muscle glycolysis, hepatic gluconeogenesis, and a decrease in glycogenesis. Insulin has a different set of effects.

questions.text: A scientist is studying the mechanism of insulin release from pancreatic beta (β) cells. Which of the following is the main trigger for insulin release in the human body?
questions.solution:
Glucose is the major regulator of insulin release. When glucose is absorbed into the bloodstream and reaches the beta islet cells of the pancreas, it is sensed by glucose transporters 2 (GLUT2) on the cell surface. Glucose enters β cells, where it generates ATP via cellular respiration. An increase in ATP closes potassium (K+) channels and depolarizes the cell membrane. Depolarization leads to voltage-gated calcium (Ca2+) channels opening, leading to Ca2+ influx and stimulation of insulin release via exocytosis.  



Option Analysis

✅ Glucose:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Fructose:
Incorrect: Fructose is not the main trigger for insulin release in the human body.  
❌ Glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1):
Incorrect: Glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) is an incretin released from enteroendocrine L-cells in the small intestine in response to an oral glucose load. It increases insulin release mainly by augmenting beta (β) cell sensitivity to glucose. However, GLP-1 is not a direct trigger for insulin release.  
❌ Gastric inhibitory peptide (GIP):
Incorrect: Gastric inhibitory peptide (GIP) is an incretin released from enteroendocrine K-cells in the small intestine in response to an oral glucose load. It increases insulin release mainly by augmenting beta (β) cell sensitivity to glucose and is not a direct trigger for insulin release. 
❌ Sympathetic neural activity   :
Incorrect: Studies have shown that insulin secretion stimulates feeding-induced parasympathetic neural activity in the pancreas. In contrast, stress-induced sympathetic neural activity in the pancreas inhibits insulin secretion.

questions.text: A segment of the thyroid gland is examined under microscopy. In the examination, 2 types of cells are identified: one that is responsible for the production of thyroid hormones, and another type of cell that is responsible for secreting a different type of hormone. The second type of cell is shown in the image below (black arrow). The hormone produced by these cells does which of the following functions?

choices.text: Decreases reabsorption of phosphorus in the distal convoluted tubules.
Decreases absorption of calcium from the intestines
Decreases reabsorption of phosphorus in the proximal convoluted tubules.
Increases absorption of calcium in the distal convoluted tubules

questions.solution:
Calcitonin is a peptide hormone that is produced by the parafollicular cells (C-cells) in the thyroid gland, which make up a tiny minority of the gland. Parafollicular cells are pale-staining cells that are typically situated basally in the epithelium, without direct contact with the follicular lumen. These cells are found between the follicles of the thyroid gland as shown in the image.  

Calcitonin is a hormone that plays a role in the regulation of calcium levels in the blood. When free ionized calcium levels rise in the blood, they stimulate the release of calcitonin from the parafollicular cells. Calcitonin then helps lower the calcium levels (remembered as calcitonin “tones down” calcium) by its actions on the bones (primarily) and the kidneys.


In the bones, calcitonin binds to calcitonin receptors on the osteoclasts, and inhibits bone resorption; this lowers the release of calcium and phosphorus in the blood, and thereby lowers serum calcium levels. The bones are the main site of action of calcitonin.


However, minor actions of calcitonin are on the kidneys, which also helps to lower serum calcium levels. Calcitonin activates its receptors in the distal convoluted tubules, and once activated, they inhibit the principal cells in the tubules from reabsorbing calcium and phosphorus, leading to decreased calcium and phosphorus levels in the blood, and increased excretion of both ions in the urine causing calciuria and phosphaturia.  



Option Analysis

✅ Decreases reabsorption of phosphorus in the distal convoluted tubules.  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Decreases absorption of calcium from the intestines  :
Incorrect: Calcitonin has no effect on calcium absorption from the intestines.
❌ Increases bone resorption  :
Incorrect: Calcitonin decreases bone resorption.  
❌ Decreases reabsorption of phosphorus in the proximal convoluted tubules.:
Incorrect: Calcitonin has no effects on the proximal convoluted tubule as there are no receptors located in that segment of the nephron for it. It decreases the reabsorption of phosphorus and calcium in the distal convoluted tubules.
❌ Increases absorption of calcium in the distal convoluted tubules:
Incorrect: Calcitonin decreases the reabsorption of calcium in the distal convoluted tubules.

questions.text: A researcher isolates an immune cell from a blood sample. This cell initially produces IgM but, after being stimulated by a T-cell, can go on to produce other classes of antibodies. Which of the following surface proteins is most likely expressed by this cell?
questions.solution:
This researcher most likely identified a B-cell, which expresses the CD40 surface protein. After being activated, a B-cell initially produces IgM. However, once it interacts with a helper T-cell, the B-cell can undergo class switching and produce additional antibodies, including IgG, IgA, and IgE.  

The different cells of the immune system can be distinguished based on their surface proteins. A comparison of the proteins expressed by each cell type can be found below.  



Option Analysis

✅ CD40:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Glycoprotein IIb/IIIa:
Incorrect: Glycoprotein IIb/IIIa (GpIIb/IIIa) is an integrin complex found on the surface of platelets and plays an important role in promoting platelet aggregation. It is targeted by medications including abciximab, eptifibatide, and tirofiban. However, GpIIb/IIIa is not found on B-cells, which are responsible for producing IgM and other antibody classes (e.g., IgG, IgE, IgA) after undergoing class switching.  
❌ FOXP3:
Incorrect: FOXP3 is a marker found on regulatory T-cells (Treg). These cells are responsible for ensuring self-tolerance and, in turn, help reduce the risk of autoimmune diseases. In contrast, this researcher most likely isolated a B-cell, which would not express FOXP3.  
❌ CD8:
Incorrect: This researcher most likely identified a B-cell. After being activated, B-cells produce IgM but can subsequently undergo class switching to produce other antibody classes (e.g., IgG, IgE, IgA). In contrast, CD8 is expressed on T-cells but not on B-cells.  
❌ CD28:
Incorrect: CD28 is a surface protein found on T-cells. It interacts with B7 on antigen-presenting cells and contributes to T-cell activation. In contrast, this researcher most likely isolated a B-cell, which would not express CD28.

questions.text: A patient with a past medical history of Crohn disease has recurrent nephrolithiasis episodes; urinalysis recurrently shows envelope-shaped crystals. Which of the following is this patient's most likely underlying cause of recurrent nephrolithiasis?

choices.text: Urease-positive bacteria in the renal pelvis
The inability of intercalated cells to secrete H+

questions.solution:
Malabsorptive conditions can decrease enteric bile salts' reabsorption at the distal ileum. Calcium, which normally chelates free oxalate, binds free lipids. More free oxalate is absorbed, which promotes the formation of renal calcium oxalate stones. This prevents fat absorption leading to fatty stool/bile acid diarrhea.  



Credit: Wikimedia Commons

Option Analysis

✅ Decreased absorption of bile salts:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Impaired intestinal ornithine reabsorption:
Incorrect: Autosomal recessive cystinuria is a hereditary defect of the proximal convoluted tubule in nephrons and small intestine (amino acid transport proteins). These defects prevent proper reabsorption of ornithine, cysteine, lysine, and arginine in the small intestine and the kidneys. This leads to the precipitation of hexagonal-shaped cystine stones in the urine, not envelope-shaped crystals.  
❌ Urease-positive bacteria in the renal pelvis:
Incorrect: Urease-producing bacteria are a group of pathogens that can cause urinary tract infection and are responsible for forming ammonium magnesium phosphate stones, also called struvite stones. It is not envelope-shaped and is less likely than calcium oxalate stones (envelope-shaped crystals) in a patient with Crohn disease.  
❌ Increased urine homocysteine levels:
Incorrect: Homocystinuria is caused by enzyme deficiencies that increase blood and urine homocysteine levels. The condition is not associated with kidney stone formation.  
❌ The inability of intercalated cells to secrete H+:
Incorrect: The inability of intercalated cells to secrete H+ can be seen in distal renal tubular acidosis. Patients with this condition are at increased risk for renal calcium phosphate stones, which are wedge-shaped, not enveloped-shaped crystals.

questions.text: It is known that bilirubin gives bile its color. Which of the following is most appropriate regarding the formation and secretion of bilirubin?

choices.text: The bilirubin released in the blood from macrophages is water-soluble.
Uridine glucuronyl transferase conjugates the bilirubin in the liver
Bilirubin is formed via glycosylation of erythrocytes in macrophages
Bilirubin is conjugated in the hepatocytes via the addition of two glycine molecules
The majority of bilirubin in bile is unconjugated bilirubin

questions.solution:
Bilirubin is the pigment that gives bile its color and is a byproduct of hemoglobin metabolism. The red blood cells are destroyed near the end of their lifespan by immune cells. Macrophages break down hemoglobin into heme and iron. Next, an enzyme called heme oxidase converts heme to biliverdin, which is green in color. Then, the enzyme biliverdin reductase converts biliverdin into bilirubin, which is yellow, and the bilirubin enters the blood. The bilirubin in the blood is not water-soluble and is referred to as unconjugated bilirubin. Albumin in the blood binds to the unconjugated bilirubin and transports it to the hepatocytes. Within the hepatocytes, the enzyme uridine glucuronyl transferase attaches the unconjugated bilirubin to glucuronic acid, turning it into conjugated bilirubin. The conjugation of bilirubin allows the bilirubin to become more water-soluble. As a result, conjugated bilirubin can be secreted into bile, whereas unconjugated bilirubin is typically not found in bile.  

Option Analysis

❌ The bilirubin released in the blood from macrophages is water-soluble.:
Incorrect: The bilirubin in the blood is not water-soluble and is referred to as unconjugated bilirubin. Albumin in the blood binds to the unconjugated bilirubin and transports it to the hepatocytes.   
✅ Uridine glucuronyl transferase conjugates the bilirubin in the liver:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Bilirubin is formed via glycosylation of erythrocytes in macrophages:
Incorrect: Bilirubin is formed via oxidation of heme by heme oxygenase in the macrophages  
❌ Bilirubin is conjugated in the hepatocytes via the addition of two glycine molecules:
Incorrect: The enzyme uridine glucuronyl transferase attaches the unconjugated bilirubin to glucuronic acid, turning it into conjugated bilirubin.   
❌ The majority of bilirubin in bile is unconjugated bilirubin:
Incorrect: Only conjugated bilirubin can be secreted into bile, whereas unconjugated bilirubin is typically not found in bile.

questions.text: A T-cell is activated after its surface receptors bind to the MHC I molecule and B7 signal found on an antigen-presenting cell. This T-cell subsequently undergoes differentiation. Which of the following best characterizes the function of the cell type that will most likely arise from this T-cell?

choices.text: Destruction of infected cells via induction of apoptosis
Stimulation of antibody production by B-cells

questions.solution:
T-cells can differentiate into many cellular subtypes after being activated.  

CD8+ T-cells require two signals from an antigen-presenting cell to be activated. These signals are the 1) MHC I-antigen complex and 2) B7 ligand. Once activated, CD8+ T-cells can differentiate into cytotoxic T-cells, which release perforins and granzymes to trigger apoptosis in tumor cells and cells infected by intracellular pathogens (e.g. viruses).  

The MHC II-antigen complex and B7 activate CD4+ T-cells. Afterward, they can differentiate into multiple cellular subtypes, including Th1, Th2, Th17, T follicular helper (TFH), and regulatory T-cells.    

Th1 cells help the body fight intracellular pathogens by producing interferon-gamma, which stimulates macrophages to kill ingested pathogens and producing IL-2, which stimulates cytotoxic T-cells and natural killer cells.    

Th2 T-cells stimulate mast cells, basophils, and eosinophils and induce immunoglobulin class switching to IgE. Th2 cells are important in fighting parasitic infections.   

Th17 T-cells help regulate tissue inflammation, activate neutrophils, and fight extracellular infections.    

T follicular helper (TFH) cells assist in B-cell maturation and differentiation. They also promote the formation of memory B-cells.    

Finally, regulatory T-cells (Treg) are responsible for ensuring self-tolerance and, in turn, help reduce the risk of autoimmune diseases.  

Option Analysis

✅ Destruction of infected cells via induction of apoptosis:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Stimulation of antibody production by B-cells:
Incorrect: CD4+ T-cells can give rise to several subtypes of T-cells, including Th1, Th2, and T follicular helper cells. These cellular types, in turn, promote immunoglobulin class switching and antibody production by B-cells. However, CD4+ T-cells are stimulated by MHC II molecules (as opposed to MHC I molecules) on antigen-presenting cells. The T-cell described in this question stem is likely a CD8+ T-cell since it interacts with the MHC I molecule.  
❌ Maintenance of self-tolerance  :
Incorrect: Regulatory T-cells are responsible for maintaining self-tolerance when the body’s immune system does not attack antigens expressed by its organs. Regulatory T-cells are a subtype of CD4+ T-cells. In contrast, the T-cell described in this question stem is most likely a CD8+ T-cell since it interacts with the MHC I molecule.  
❌ Activation of neutrophils:
Incorrect: Th17 T-cells regulate the inflammatory response, fight extracellular pathogens, and activate neutrophils. Th17 T-cells arise from CD4+ T-cells, which would interact with MHC II (not MHC I) molecules.  
❌ Upregulation of IgE production:
Incorrect: Th2 T-cells induce immunoglobulin class switching to IgE. They also stimulate mast cells and eosinophils. However, Th2 cells arise from CD4+ T-cells, which would interact with MHC II (not MHC I) molecules. The T-cell described in this question stem is likely a CD8+ T-cell since it interacts with the MHC I molecule.

questions.text: A researcher isolates an immune cell from a blood sample. This cell stimulates eosinophils and mast cells. It also promotes B-cell class switching so that they produce IgE. Which of the following surface proteins is most likely expressed by this cell?
questions.solution:
The researcher most likely identified a Th2 T-cell. This cell type helps fight parasitic infections by stimulating mast cells and eosinophils and promoting B-cell class switching, so they produce IgE. Th2 cells (and all T-cells, for that matter) express the CD28 surface protein.   

Different immune cells can be distinguished based on their surface proteins. A comparison of the proteins expressed by each cell type can be found below.  



Option Analysis

❌ Major histocompatibility complex type I :
Incorrect: Major histocompatibility complex class I (MHC I) proteins help present fragments of exogenous antigens to CD8+ T-cells. MHC I molecules are found on antigen-presenting cells. While antigen-presenting cells play an important role in activating the immune response, they are not directly involved in either class switching to IgE or stimulation of mast cells and eosinophils.  
❌ B7:
Incorrect: B7 is a ligand found on the surface of antigen-presenting cells. Interaction between B7 and CD28 (found on T-cells) is one of the signals required for T-cell activation. However, antigen-presenting cells are not directly involved in either class switching to IgE or stimulation of mast cells and eosinophils.  
❌ CD19 :
Incorrect: CD19 is found primarily on B-cells. This surface protein plays an important role in B-cell survival and maturation. In contrast, this researcher most likely isolated a Th2 T-cell, which promotes B-cell class switching to IgE and stimulates mast cells and eosinophils.  
❌ CD8:
Incorrect: This researcher most likely identified a Th2 T-cell, which is derived from CD4+ T-cells. As a result, Th2 cells would not express the CD8 surface protein.  
✅ CD28:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A biologist isolates an immune cell from a blood sample. This cell’s primary function is to fight intracellular pathogens. It contains CD3, CD4, and CD40 surface proteins and stimulates macrophages and cytotoxic T-cells. Which of the following cells was most likely isolated?
questions.solution:
This biologist most likely isolated a subtype of T helper cell called the type 1 helper (Th1) T-cell.  

T helper cells interact with and stimulate other immune cells. In addition to Th1 cells, different types of T helper cells include type 2 helper (Th2), type 17 helper (Th17), and T follicular helper (TFH) cells. There is another group of T-cells called T regulatory (Treg) cells. However, they are not considered helper T-cells since they are primarily involved in the contraction and regulation of the immune response.  

Th1 cells help the body fight intracellular pathogens by producing interferon-gamma, which stimulates macrophages to kill ingested pathogens and producing IL-2, which stimulates cytotoxic T-cells and natural killer cells.  

Th2 T-cells stimulate mast cells, basophils, and eosinophils and induce immunoglobulin class switching to IgE. Th2 cells are essential in fighting parasitic infections.  

Th17 T-cells help regulate tissue inflammation, activate neutrophils, and fight extracellular infections.  

T follicular helper (TFH) cells assist in B-cell maturation and differentiation. They also promote the formation of memory B-cells.  

Finally, regulatory T-cells (Treg) are responsible for ensuring self-tolerance and help reduce the risk of autoimmune diseases.  



Option Analysis

✅ Type 1 helper T-cell:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Type 2 helper T-cell  :
Incorrect: Type 2 helper (Th2) T-cells stimulate mast cells, basophils, and eosinophils. They also induce immunoglobulin class switching to IgE. Th2 cells are essential in fighting parasitic infections. In contrast, Th2 cells do not typically play a significant role in stimulating macrophages and cytotoxic T-cells or fighting intracellular pathogens.  
❌ Regulatory T-cell  :
Incorrect: Regulatory T-cells (Treg) are responsible for ensuring self-tolerance and, in turn, help reduce the risk of autoimmune diseases. In contrast, Treg cells are not typically involved in fighting intracellular pathogens.  
❌ T follicular helper cell  :
Incorrect: T follicular helper (TFH) cells assist in B-cell maturation and differentiation. They also promote the formation of memory B-cells. However, they do not play a significant role in stimulating macrophages and cytotoxic T-cells or fighting intracellular pathogens.  
❌ Natural killer cells  :
Incorrect: Natural killer cells are part of the innate immune system. They can release perforins and granzymes to induce apoptosis in tumor or virally infected cells. However, since they are not derived from CD4+ T-cells, natural killer cells would not express the CD4+ surface protein.

questions.text: A researcher studies the development of the male genitalia in utero. Which of the following hormones is directly responsible for the differentiation of the epididymis during the intrauterine period?
questions.solution:
Testosterone is the primary male hormone and is an androgen. The effects of testosterone are first seen in the fetus. During the first six weeks of development, the reproductive tissues of males and females are identical. Still, in week seven, genes in the sex-determining region of the Y chromosome (called the SRY gene) initiate the development of testicles.  

Once they form, the fetal testicles secrete testosterone which guides the development of the male urogenital tract and external genitalia, as well as testicular descent through the inguinal canal, which happens in the last two months of fetal development. The functions of testosterone are summarized in the table below.  

Testosterone is converted to dihydrotestosterone (DHT) by 5α-reductase. DHT is responsible for the early differentiation of the penis, scrotum, and prostate. It is also involved in the late phase of prostate growth, balding, and sebaceous gland activity.  



Option Analysis

❌ Androstenedione:
Incorrect: Androstenedione is released from the adrenal glands. It is the least potent androgen and does not directly affect the differentiation of the epididymis.  
✅ Testosterone:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Dihydrotestosterone:
Incorrect: Dihydrotestosterone (DHT) is responsible for the early differentiation of the penis, scrotum, and prostate. It is also involved in the late phase of prostate growth, balding, and sebaceous gland activity.  
❌ Gonadotropin-releasing hormone  :
Incorrect: Gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) stimulates the release of luteinizing hormone and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) in the pituitary which in turn stimulates the release of testosterone.  
❌ Luteinizing hormone:
Incorrect: Gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) stimulates the release of luteinizing hormone and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) in the pituitary, which in turn stimulates the release of testosterone.

questions.text: The production of estrogen involves coordinated enzymatic activities between the theca and granulosa cells of the ovarian follicle. Which of the following most appropriately describes the function of estrogen?

choices.text: Prepares uterus for implantation during luteal phase
Facilitates development of internal and external genitalia

questions.solution:
Estrogen is a female sex hormone produced mainly by the ovaries. The estrogen receptors are members of the superfamily of steroid hormone receptors found primarily in the nucleus.  

Pulsatile release of gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) from the hypothalamus stimulates the pulsatile pituitary release of luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH). Both FSH and LH stimulate ovarian production of estradiol and progesterone. The variations in pulsatile release of the gonadotropins result in a cyclic response of ovarian function. Each cycle lasts 28 days and can be divided into two phases of 14 days each. During the follicular phase of the menstrual cycle, estrogen makes the superficial layer of the uterus (endometrium) thicken up and sprout progesterone receptors. It also acts as a negative feedback signal, making the pituitary secrete less FSH as estrogen levels rise.  

Right before ovulation, the markedly high estrogen levels make the pituitary much more sensitive to the actions of hypothalamic GnRH. These changes result in a positive feedback signal, leading to a massive surge of FSH and LH that leads to ovulation.  

During the luteal phase, progesterone binds to receptors in the endometrium and stimulates the endometrial glands to produce more secretions, which prepare the uterus for a potential pregnancy. Progesterone acts as a negative feedback signal during the luteal phase - making the pituitary secrete less LH. In turn, the levels of progesterone decrease as well, and menstruation follows.  

Estrogen promotes the development of internal/external genitalia, endometrial proliferation, and increases watery cervical mucus production. In the ovaries, it exerts potent mitotic effects on granulosa cells. In the breast, estrogen stimulates growth and differentiation of the ductal epithelium, induces mitotic activity of ductal cylindrical cells, and stimulates the growth of connective tissue. Other estrogen functions are summarized below:  



Option Analysis

❌ Prepares uterus for implantation during luteal phase:
Incorrect: During the luteal phase, progesterone prepares the uterus for implantation of a fertilized egg by stimulating endometrial glandular secretions and spiral artery development.  
❌ Prevents endometrial hyperplasia:
Incorrect: Estrogen enhances endometrial proliferation, whereas progesterone prevents endometrial hyperplasia.  
✅ Facilitates development of internal and external genitalia  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Decreases myometrial excitability in pregnancy:
Incorrect: Progesterone decreases myometrial excitability during pregnancy by reducing contraction frequency and intensity. Estrogen, on the other hand, increased myometrial excitability.
❌ Produces thick cervical mucus:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the function of progesterone. Progesterone induces the production of thick cervical mucus that inhibits sperm entry into the uterus.

questions.text: A pathologist is reviewing skin biopsy slides under a microscope. She identifies a neural crest cell derivative that produces pigment to shield the body from ultraviolet radiation. Within which layer of the skin is this cell type located?
questions.solution:
Melanocytes are found within hair follicles and the stratum basale of the epidermis. These cells produce a protein pigment called melanin, which ranges in color from black to reddish yellow and provides skin and hair with pigmentation. It also protects the skin and eyes against ultraviolet radiation and photodamage.  

Melanocytes are derived from neural crest cells, stem cells originating from the embryonic ectoderm germ layer. During embryonic development, melanoblasts (precursor cells to melanocytes) travel peripherally along nerve branches to reach the dermis and the epidermis. While traveling to their final destination, melanoblasts multiply in number and sequentially express additional genes that result in their maturation into melanocytes. Due to this migratory process, melanocytes may be present in the dermis during fetal development but not after birth.  



Option Analysis

❌ Stratum lucidum:
Incorrect: Melanocytes are derived from neural crest cells and produce melanin, a pigment that protects the body from ultraviolet radiation. Melanocytes are located within the stratum basale and hair follicles. The stratum lucidum contains dead keratinocytes.  
❌ Stratum granulosum:
Incorrect: Melanocytes are derived from neural crest cells and produce melanin, a pigment that protects the body from ultraviolet radiation. Melanocytes are located within the stratum basale and hair follicles. In contrast, the stratum granulosum is composed of keratinocytes.  
✅ Stratum basale:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Papillary dermis  :
Incorrect: Melanocytes are derived from neural crest cells and produce melanin, a pigment that protects the body from ultraviolet radiation. Although dermal melanocytes can be seen during fetal development, they are not present after birth. Melanocytes pass through the dermis during fetal development to reach the epidermis.
❌ Hypodermis:
Incorrect: Melanocytes are derived from neural crest cells and produce melanin, a pigment that protects the body against ultraviolet radiation. Although dermal melanocytes can be seen during fetal development, they are not typically present after birth. Melanocytes pass through the dermis during fetal development to reach the epidermis.

questions.text: Primordial germ cells are an essential part of ovarian development. After the primordial cells reach the gonad, they continue to multiply through successive mitotic divisions. Which of the following statements is most appropriate regarding oogenesis?

choices.text: The primary oocyte is arrested in metaphase I until puberty
Pituitary FSH makes the granulosa cells produce more androstenedione
The maximal number of oogonia is achieved at the 20th week of gestation
Meiosis I is completed in the oocyte destined for ovulation in response to the FSH surge
Meiosis II is completed after ovulation regardless of fertilization

questions.solution:
In the fetal period, once the primordial germ cells arrive in the gonad, they differentiate into oogonia. All oogonia either develop into primary oocytes or become atretic (degenerate). The maximal number of oogonia is achieved at the 20th week of gestation, at which time 6 to 7 million oogonia are present in the ovary. Approximately 1 to 2 million oogonia are present at birth. Fewer than 400,000 are present at the initiation of puberty, of which fewer than 500 are destined to ovulate.    

Mitotic division of oogonia increases the population. Many oogonia further differentiate into primary oocytes, which begin meiosis. However, the process arrests after only prophase I is completed. In childhood, primary oocytes remain suspended in prophase I. A primary oocyte with its surrounding epithelial cells is called a primordial follicle. Beginning in puberty and extending through the reproductive years, several primordial follicles mature each month into primary follicles. A few of these continue development to secondary follicles. One or two secondary follicles progress to a tertiary or Graafian follicle stage. The first meiotic division completes this stage to produce a haploid secondary oocyte and a polar body. During this process, cytoplasm is conserved by the secondary oocyte. Consequently, the polar body is disproportionately small. The secondary oocyte halts meiosis at prophase II. One of the secondary oocytes is then released at ovulation. If the oocyte is fertilized by sperm, completion of the second meiotic division follows. If fertilization fails to occur, the oocyte degenerates before the second meiotic division is completed.  



Option Analysis

❌ The primary oocyte is arrested in metaphase I until puberty:
Incorrect: The primary oocyte is arrested in prophase I until puberty.  
❌ Pituitary FSH makes the granulosa cells produce more androstenedione:
Incorrect: Pituitary FSH makes the granulosa cells produce more estrogen. LH release stimulates the formation of androstenedione.  
✅ The maximal number of oogonia is achieved at the 20th week of gestation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Meiosis I is completed in the oocyte destined for ovulation in response to the FSH surge:
Incorrect: Meiosis I is completed in the oocyte destined for ovulation in response to the LH surge.
❌ Meiosis II is completed after ovulation regardless of fertilization:
Incorrect: Meiosis II is completed only if the ovum is fertilized.

questions.text: An electrophysiologist is teaching medical students different aspects of a normal electrocardiogram with the cardiac cycle. Considering the following image to be a reading from limb lead II of an ECG, which of the following letters in the labeled image represents ventricular repolarization?
questions.solution:
In a healthy heart, the depolarization wave starts at the sinoatrial (SA) node in the right atrium from where it travels to the cardiac apex, which aligns with the lead II vector. It quickly travels through the intranodal tracts to the left atrium, causing a positive deflection on the electrocardiogram (ECG), called the P-wave. The wave is then carried to the AV node, where it gets delayed for a bit to allow the atria enough time to get fully emptied. It appears as a flat line on the ECG called the PR interval. From there, the signal goes through the pacemaker cells of the Bundle of His, and the bundle branches down into the Purkinje fibers. The apex of the heart depolarizes, followed by depolarization of the base, creating a QRS complex on the ECG.  

After tissue depolarizes, there is a brief absence of electrical activity, making an isoelectric line called the ST segment. After that, the ventricles repolarize, the wave of which travels in an overall upward direction. This appears on the ECG as a positive deflection called the T-wave, because it is a repolarization wave traveling towards a negative electrode.  

Option Analysis

❌ P:
Incorrect: This represents the P wave, which is a result of the beginning of the atrial depolarization wave that starts at the sinoatrial (SA) node in the right atrium and quickly travels to the left atrium through intranodal tracts. The direction is the same as that of the lead II vector, making the deflection positive.   
❌ Q:
Incorrect: From the AV node, the signal goes through the pacemaker cells of the Bundle of His and bundle branches. In addition to moving through the fast pacemaker cells, the signal also goes through the slow myocytes in the interventricular septum, in a direction that’s slightly away from the lead II vector, creating a tiny negative deflection on the ECG–a Q wave.  
❌ R:
Incorrect: When the depolarization wave flows down into the Purkinje fibers, the largest vectors are the ones in the left ventricle, in the direction of lead II, creating a large positive deflection on the ECG–an R wave.  
❌ S:
Incorrect: When the depolarization wave reaches the left ventricle, the apex of the heart depolarizes first. Then the wave moves back up to depolarize the top of the ventricles, which is in a direction away from lead II, causing a slight negative deflection on the ECG - an S wave.  
✅ T:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to the emergency department after developing dyspnea, hives, and audible wheezing. The patient accidentally ingested peanuts an hour ago,  to which she has a known allergy. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Cytotoxic T-cell destruction of antigen-tagged cells
Direct tissue damage by irradiated antibiotic agent

questions.solution:
Hypersensitivity reactions occur when the immune system responds abnormally to a stimulus, resulting in potential harm to the body. Type I hypersensitivity reactions are mediated by IgE and mast cells and can be associated with hives, bronchospasm, and anaphylaxis.  

Pathophysiology of type I hypersensitivity reactions involves binding IgE to the surface of mast cells and basophils via high-affinity receptors. This eventually results in cross-linking of IgE by antigens, leading to cellular activation and release of preformed and newly synthesized mediators, including histamine, tryptase, and leukotrienes. These mediators cause vasodilation, increased vasopermeability, and smooth-muscle contraction. The effects of these molecules are termed “early phase reactions'', as they happen within minutes of the second exposure.  

There are also “late-phase reactions,” which happen 8-12 hours after exposure, where TH2 cells, eosinophils, and basophils are recruited to the site of allergen exposure. These include interleukin-4, interleukin-5, and interleukin-10, and leukotrienes. These mediators perform various cellular activities, including smooth muscle contraction, further release of histamine, and chemotaxis of neutrophils, mast cells, and additional eosinophils.  

Examples of type I hypersensitivity reactions include ingested allergens like foods, dander, bee stings, mold, drugs/medications, and pollen. Common allergens include latex, lotions, soaps, and penicillin. Some allergic diseases include atopic eczema, allergic urticaria, allergic rhinitis (Hay fever), allergic asthma, and anaphylaxis.  

Option Analysis

✅ IgE-mediated mast cell activation  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Immune complex-mediated complement activation:
Incorrect: Immune complex-mediated complement activation defines the mechanism of a type III hypersensitivity reaction, characterized by the deposition of IgG-antigen complexes in various tissues. Examples include polyarteritis nodosa, post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis, IgA nephropathy, and lupus nephritis. This patient presents with anaphylaxis, which is a type I hypersensitivity reaction.
❌ Cytotoxic T-cell destruction of antigen-tagged cells:
Incorrect: T cell-mediated destruction of antigen-tagged cells is characteristic of type IV hypersensitivity reaction. Although drug reactions caused by cephalosporins like ceftriaxone often result in skin lesions, they are typically maculopapular or morbilliform in appearance and manifest 12–48 hours following exposure. Examples include allergic contact dermatitis and exanthematous drug reactions.  
❌ Perivascular cutaneous polymorphonuclear infiltration:
Incorrect: Perivascular cutaneous polymorphonuclear infiltration is typical of cutaneous small-vessel vasculitis. Although these conditions can cause urticarial lesions following exposure, they more commonly manifest with painful, palpable purpura, ulceration, and petechiae. Moreover, these symptoms are antibody-mediated and usually occur weeks after exposure.  
❌ Direct tissue damage by irradiated antibiotic agent:
Incorrect: Direct skin tissue damage through irradiation of an antibiotic agent (a drug-induced photosensitivity reaction) causes an intense sunburn of exposed skin within hours of sun exposure. Cephalosporins do not induce photosensitivity.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man is diagnosed with myasthenia gravis, a chronic autoimmune condition characterized as a type II hypersensitivity reaction. Which of the following best describes the underlying mechanism of this disease?

choices.text: Cytotoxic T-cell destruction of antigen-tagged cells

questions.solution:
Hypersensitivity reactions occur when the immune system overreacts to a foreign stimulus, resulting in tissue damage. All hypersensitivity shares the common motif of pre-sensitization or pre-exposure to an antigen with a prior immune response.    

There are three specific mechanisms by which type II hypersensitivity reactions occur.  
 
  • Complement-dependent reactions (inflammation): Antibody bound to antigen can fix complement and induce direct lysis of the cell through the production of the membrane attack complex (MAC), or the complement can coat cells with C3b (an opsonin) and promote phagocytosis of the antigen. Example: Goodpasture syndrome, Rheumatic fever, and hyperacute transplant rejection. 
 
  • Antibody-dependent cell-mediated cytotoxicity (cellular destruction): Cell types that bear receptors for the Fc portion of IgG, such as neutrophils, eosinophils, macrophages, and natural killer (NK) cells, mediate the removal of antigen. Examples: Transfusion reactions, erythroblastosis fetalis, and autoimmune hemolytic anemia. 
 
  • Antibody-mediated cellular dysfunction: Antibodies themselves affect the function of the antigen. Examples: Graves disease is due to an antibody that activates the thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) receptor, resulting in hyperthyroidism. Myasthenia gravis is due to antibodies against the acetylcholine (ACh) receptor, impairing neuromuscular depolarization. 

Option Analysis

❌ Complement-dependent reaction:
Incorrect: With complement-dependent reaction, antibody bound to antigen can fix complement and induce direct lysis of the cell through the production of the membrane attack complex (MAC), or the complement can coat cells with C3b (an opsonin) and promote phagocytosis of the antigen. Examples include Goodpasture syndrome, Rheumatic fever, and hyperacute transplant rejection.  
❌ Antibody-dependent cell-mediated cytotoxicity:
Incorrect: With antibody-dependent cell-mediated cytotoxicity (cellular destruction), cells that bear receptors for the Fc portion of IgG, such as neutrophils, eosinophils, macrophages, and natural killer (NK) cells, mediate removal of antigen. Examples include transfusion reactions, erythroblastosis fetalis, and autoimmune hemolytic anemia.
✅ Antibody-mediated cellular dysfunction:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Immune complex-mediated complement activation  :
Incorrect: Immune complex-mediated complement activation defines a type III hypersensitivity reaction, characterized by tissue deposition of IgG-antigen complexes. Examples of type III hypersensitivity reactions include polyarteritis nodosa, post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis, IgA nephropathy, and lupus nephritis.  
❌ Cytotoxic T-cell destruction of antigen-tagged cells:
Incorrect: T cell-mediated destruction of antigen-tagged cells is characteristic of type IV hypersensitivity reactions, such as allergic contact dermatitis and exanthematous drug reactions.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man presents to the cardiologist for evaluation of dyspnea and intermittent chest pain. An echocardiogram is performed as part of the workup and reveals aortic stenosis secondary to a bicuspid aortic valve. Which of the following best illustrates this patient’s left ventricular pressure-volume loop (red line) compared to that of a healthy individual of the same age (dark blue line)?
questions.solution:
This patient was diagnosed with aortic stenosis. The condition will increase cardiac afterload and manifest with changes to the pressure-volume loop, including an increase in systolic blood pressure and a decrease in stroke volume.  

Pressure-volume loops characterize changes in left ventricular pressure and volume throughout the cardiac cycle. The loop can be divided into four phases: isovolumetric contraction, systolic ejection, isovolumetric relaxation, and ventricular filling. The loop’s width corresponds to the stroke volume, which is the difference between the end-diastolic and end-systolic volumes.    

An increase in afterload (e.g., aortic stenosis, system hypertension) will lead to impaired ventricular emptying. In aortic stenosis, aortic resistance increases, and the ventricular pressure during systole has to rise higher than usual for blood to be pushed out into the aorta. Hence, the height of the pressure-volume loop will increase. Furthermore, an increase in afterload means less blood can be pumped out of the heart during each beat. As a result, the end-systolic volume will be higher than that of a healthy individual, and stroke volume will decrease, which manifests as a narrowing of the pressure-volume loop.  

Option Analysis

❌ :
Incorrect: These changes may occur in individuals with systolic heart failure. The condition is characterized by a loss of inotropy, which prevents blood from being squeezed out of the heart and results in an increased end-systolic volume. There may also be an increase in end-diastolic volume since the condition causes blood to pool within the pulmonary and venous circulation, thereby increasing preload.
✅ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ :
Incorrect: Increased cardiac contractility (e.g., sympathetic stimulation, digoxin administration) would result in this pressure-volume loop. Increased cardiac contractility means the heart beats more forcefully, and more blood is ejected from the left ventricle during systole. As a result, stroke volume will increase, and end-systolic volume will decrease.
❌ :
Incorrect: An increase in preload would result in greater ventricular filling and a greater end-diastolic volume. In contrast, aortic stenosis would lead to an increase in afterload.
❌ :
Incorrect: Mitral stenosis would result in this pressure-volume loop. Mitral stenosis impairs ventricular filling and leads to a decrease in end-diastolic volume. As a result, there is a decrease in stroke volume by the Frank-Starling relationship and a fall in cardiac output and aortic pressure. This reduction in afterload enables the end-systolic volume to decrease slightly (but not enough to overcome the decrease in end-diastolic volume).

questions.text: A 43-year-old man with a history of schizophrenia, currently controlled with haloperidol, is concerned about abnormal discharge from both nipples over the past 3 months. The patient describes the fluid as white. On further review of systems, he endorses a diminished sexual drive. It is determined that this patient’s symptoms are secondary to the increased release of a hormone. This hormone is secreted into the circulation at which of the following sites?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of this patient is consistent with hyperprolactinemia, leading to bilateral galactorrhea and decreased libido.  

Prolactin is secreted mainly by lactotroph cells in the anterior pituitary gland. It stimulates milk production in the breast and also inhibits ovulation in females and spermatogenesis in males by inhibiting GnRH synthesis and release. The GnRH inhibition results in decreased luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) levels from the anterior pituitary. FSH and LH normally induce the development of ovarian follicles and ovulation; this explains why women typically do not ovulate or have menstrual periods while breastfeeding. Excessive amounts of prolactin are associated with decreased libido. The secretion of prolactin is tonically inhibited by dopamine from the tuberoinfundibular pathway of the hypothalamus; this pathway was most likely interrupted by this patient’s medication for schizophrenia, which was likely an antipsychotic, most of which are dopamine antagonists.  

Oxytocin, on the other hand, is synthesized within the neurons in the paraventricular and supraoptic nuclei and is released into the circulation from the axon terminal in the posterior pituitary. Oxytocin acts mainly on mammary ducts to facilitate milk letdown during nursing. It also may help initiate or facilitate labor by stimulating the contraction of the uterine smooth muscle.  

Outside of pregnancy, oxytocin levels are low, but production increases just a bit during an orgasm.  

Option Analysis

✅ A:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ B:
Incorrect: This is the vestigial intermediate lobe of the pituitary gland, which is derived from Rathke's pouch during embryonic development. Although it is not a significant source of secretory products in humans, it can secrete a small amount of melanocyte-stimulating hormone.  
❌ C:
Incorrect: Vasopressin (also known as ADH) and oxytocin are synthesized within the neurons in the paraventricular and supraoptic nuclei and are released into the circulation from the axon terminal in the posterior pituitary. Oxytocin acts mainly on mammary ducts to facilitate milk letdown during nursing. It also may help initiate or facilitate labor by stimulating the contraction of uterine smooth muscle.  
❌ D:
Incorrect: The posterior hypothalamus is involved in the control of sympathetic responses including temperature regulation.  
❌ E:
Incorrect: The mammillary bodies are important for memory recall. This region does not directly secrete hormones.

questions.text:
A 37-year-old woman presents for evaluation of fatigue and dyspnea. These symptoms are exacerbated by exertion. She immigrated from Cambodia 15 years ago. Past medical history is notable for seasonal allergies and an episode of severe pharyngitis as a child. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 127/81 mmHg, and pulse is 72/min. On physical examination, an opening snap is heard after the S2 heart sound. This murmur is best heard over the 5th intercostal space at the midclavicular line. Pulmonary and abdominal examinations are unremarkable. This patient will most likely have which of the following pressure-volume loops?  

*The dark blue loop represents that of a healthy individual and is meant to serve as a reference.
questions.solution:
This patient has a remote history of pharyngitis and currently presents with a cardiac murmur best heard over the 5th intercostal space at the midclavicular line. These findings are suggestive of mitral stenosis. The pressure-volume changes associated with mitral stenosis, along with other valvular disorders, can be found in the below table:  



Option Analysis

❌ :
Incorrect: This patient has a history of pharyngitis as a child and currently presents with a cardiac murmur best heard over the 5th intercostal space at the midclavicular line. These findings are suggestive of mitral stenosis. The condition will impair ventricular filling and lead to a decrease in the end-diastolic volume. In contrast, this pressure-volume loop demonstrates an increased end-diastolic volume and a decreased end-systolic volume, which is more consistent with the presentation of mitral regurgitation.
❌ :
Incorrect: This patient has a history of pharyngitis as a child and currently presents with a cardiac murmur best heard over the 5th intercostal space at the midclavicular line. These findings are suggestive of mitral stenosis. The condition will impair ventricular filling and lead to a decrease in the end-diastolic volume.
❌ :
Incorrect: Increased cardiac contractility (e.g., sympathetic stimulation, digoxin administration) will result in this pressure-volume loop. Increased cardiac contractility means the heart beats more forcefully, and more blood is ejected from the left ventricle during systole. As a result, stroke volume will increase, and end-systolic volume will decrease. However, this patient’s history and heart murmur are more concerning for mitral stenosis.
❌ :
Incorrect: This loop is characterized by an increase in the end-diastolic volume. In contrast, this patient likely has mitral stenosis. The condition impairs blood flow from the left atrium into the left ventricle and would result in decreased (not increased) end-diastolic volume.
✅ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: Growth hormone (GH) is a peptide hormone that stimulates growth, cell reproduction, and cell regeneration in humans and other animals. Which of the following is true regarding growth hormone?

choices.text: Its secretion is pulsatile, with highest peak levels occurring at early in the morning
Lactotrophs in the anterior pituitary stimulates the release of growth hormone
It stimulates linear bone growth and muscle growth through IGF-1
It is released constantly in response to growth hormone–releasing hormone
It increases insulin sensitivity by enhancing glucose tolerance

questions.solution:
Growth hormone (GH), also called somatotropin, is secreted by the anterior pituitary gland. It induces protein synthesis and nitrogen retention and also impairs glucose tolerance by antagonizing insulin action. GH also stimulates lipolysis, leading to increased circulating fatty acid levels, reduced omental fat mass, and enhanced lean body mass. GH promotes sodium, potassium, and water retention and elevates serum levels of inorganic phosphate. Linear bone growth occurs as a result of complex hormonal and growth factor actions, including those of IGF-I. GH stimulates epiphyseal prechondrocyte differentiation. These precursor cells produce IGF-I locally, and their proliferation is also responsive to growth factors. It is released in pulses in response to growth hormone–releasing hormone (GHRH), with the highest peak levels occurring at night, generally correlating with sleep onset.  

Option Analysis

❌ Its secretion is pulsatile, with highest peak levels occurring at early in the morning:
Incorrect: GH secretion is pulsatile, with the highest peak levels occurring at night, generally correlating with sleep onset.
❌ Lactotrophs in the anterior pituitary stimulates the release of growth hormone:
Incorrect: Somatotrophs in the anterior pituitary stimulate the release of growth hormones. Lactotrophs are the cells in the anterior pituitary that produce and release the hormone prolactin.  
✅ It stimulates linear bone growth and muscle growth through IGF-1  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ It is released constantly in response to growth hormone–releasing hormone:
Incorrect: Growth hormone is released in pulses in response to growth-hormone–releasing hormone.
❌ It increases insulin sensitivity by enhancing glucose tolerance  :
Incorrect: Growth hormone decreases insulin sensitivity by impairing glucose tolerance.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man is brought to the ED by his partner after the patient became disoriented, diaphoretic, and tachycardic. The patient is found to have a blood glucose of 40 mg/dL. Which of the following hormonal changes will be seen in this patient?

choices.text: ↑ GHRH → ↑ GH → ↑  IGF-I → decreased glucose uptake and increased lipolysis
↑ GHRH → ↑ GH → ↓ IGF-I  →  decreased glucose uptake and increased lipolysis
↑  IGF-I  → ↑ GH → ↑ GHRH → increased glucose uptake and decreased lipolysis
↑ Somatostatin → ↑ GH →  ↑ IGF-I  → decreased glucose uptake and increased lipolysis
↑ Somatomedin → ↑ GH →  ↑ IGF-I  → decreased glucose uptake and increased lipolysis

questions.solution:
Growth hormone (GH) acts on a number of target tissues and organs, including bones and muscles, adipose tissue, and the liver. Stimulation of GH production and secretion occurs through hypothalamic neurosecretory nuclei production of growth hormone-releasing hormone (GHRH) in response to stress, hypoglycemia, deep sleep, or during exercise. Positive feedback for GH secretion is also known to occur from a hormone produced in the stomach, called ghrelin, which induces additional food intake. GH acts by binding to specific receptors, located mostly in the liver, and induces intracellular signaling by a phosphorylation cascade involving the JAK/STAT (signal-transducing activators of transcription) pathway. Its predominant action is to stimulate hepatic synthesis and secretion of insulin-like growth factor 1; IGF-1 mediates most of the peripheral actions of GH.  

IGF-1, which is produced by the liver, provides negative feedback to the pituitary and hypothalamus to limit GH and GHRH secretion, respectively. Other sources of negative feedback and GH suppression occur through somatostatin, also called growth hormone-inhibiting hormone (GHIH), which is produced by both the pancreas and the hypothalamus. Somatostatin also directly suppresses GH release by producing somatotropin release-inhibitory factor (SRIF).  



Option Analysis

✅ ↑ GHRH → ↑ GH → ↑  IGF-I → decreased glucose uptake and increased lipolysis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ ↑ GHRH → ↑ GH → ↓ IGF-I  →  decreased glucose uptake and increased lipolysis:
Incorrect: Increased growth hormone stimulates the release of insulin-like growth factor, which decreases glucose uptake in tissue and increases lipolysis.  
❌ ↑  IGF-I  → ↑ GH → ↑ GHRH → increased glucose uptake and decreased lipolysis  :
Incorrect: Hypoglycemia stimulates the release of GHRH from the hypothalamus, which in turn releases the GH from the anterior pituitary. Insulin-like growth factor inhibits the release of GHRH and GH via negative feedback.  
❌ ↑ Somatostatin → ↑ GH →  ↑ IGF-I  → decreased glucose uptake and increased lipolysis  :
Incorrect: Somatostatin is a GHRH inhibitor and is released in states of hyperglycemia to help maintain blood glucose levels. Hypoglycemia would not stimulate its secretion.
❌ ↑ Somatomedin → ↑ GH →  ↑ IGF-I  → decreased glucose uptake and increased lipolysis:
Incorrect: Somatomedin is a regulatory molecule secreted by the liver in response to GH acting on target tissues.  Hypoglycemia would not stimulate its secretion.

questions.text: A group of researchers is studying the synthesis and secretion of insulin and C-peptide. Which of the following statements is true regarding insulin synthesis?

choices.text: Insulin is synthesized in the smooth endoplasmic reticulum of pancreatic beta cells
C-peptide is packaged with insulin in secretory vesicles
C-peptide is further cleaved into insulin
Insulin is secreted directly from the cytoplasm via endolysosomes
Exogenous insulin use increases insulin and C-peptide levels

questions.solution:
Insulin is synthesized in pancreatic beta cells as preproinsulin, which is guided by a signal peptide into the rough endoplasmic reticulum during translation. The signal peptide is removed, converting preproinsulin to proinsulin. Protein folding and disulfide bond formation occur as proinsulin traverses the rough endoplasmic reticulum. Proinsulin is then transported to the Golgi apparatus, packaged with proteolytic enzymes into insulin secretory granules, and cleaved into mature insulin and C-peptide. C-peptide and insulin are then co-secreted from the pancreatic beta cells in equimolar amounts.  

C-peptide (connecting peptide) connects the alpha and beta chains of proinsulin. It plays a vital role in the correct folding of insulin and the formation of disulfide bridges.  



Option Analysis

❌ Insulin is synthesized in the smooth endoplasmic reticulum of pancreatic beta cells:
Incorrect: Insulin is synthesized in the rough endoplasmic reticulum of pancreatic beta cells.
✅ C-peptide is packaged with insulin in secretory vesicles:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ C-peptide is further cleaved into insulin:
Incorrect: Proinsulin is secreted from the beta cells located within the islets of Langerhans of the endocrine pancreas. Afterward, proinsulin is cleaved into insulin and C-peptide.  
❌ Insulin is secreted directly from the cytoplasm via endolysosomes  :
Incorrect: Insulin is packaged into vesicles by the rough endoplasmic reticulum and then secreted from the beta cells via exocytosis. In contrast, some other proteins, such as interleukin-1, lack a signaling sequence and are hypothesized to be secreted directly from the cytoplasm via endolysosomes.
❌ Exogenous insulin use increases insulin and C-peptide levels:
Incorrect: Insulin and C-peptide are increased during increased endogenous insulin production, such as insulinomas and sulfonylurea use. In contrast, exogenous insulin lacks C-peptide.

questions.text: A scientist is studying different types of glucose transporters found in human tissues. He observes that some transporters have a higher affinity for glucose than others. Which transporters have the highest affinity for glucose uptake?
questions.solution:
Glucose is one of the human tissues' main sources of cellular respiration, which is used to make energy. There are seven important types of glucose transporters in the human body, which include glucose transporters 1 through 5 (GLUT 1-5) and sodium-glucose cotransporters (SGLT) 1 and 2 (found in the small intestines and kidneys, respectively).  

Each transporter is found in different body tissues and has a different affinity for glucose based on its Michaelis-Menten constant (Km), which can be defined most simply as the amount of substrate necessary to allow an enzyme or peptide to function at half its maximal velocity.  

Glucose transporter 3 (GLUT3) is found in the brain, neurons, and placenta. It is known to have the lowest Km (resulting in the highest affinity) for glucose among all the GLUTs. This characteristic is important since the brain and placenta are vital and need to have glucose available at all times, even in insufficient quantities (e.g., starvation, critical illness), to ensure adequate amounts are present for metabolism and ATP formation.   

Option Analysis

❌ Glucose transporter 2 (GLUT2):
Incorrect: GLUT2 is found in beta islet cells of the pancreas, liver, kidneys, and gastrointestinal (GI) tract tissues. Though it is not dependent on insulin for its expression and upregulation, it has a low affinity for glucose. It only uptakes glucose at higher serum levels (for storage and glucose-mediated insulin release).  
✅ Glucose transporter 3 (GLUT3):
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Glucose transporter 4 (GLUT4)  :
Incorrect: GLUT4, also known as an insulin-dependent glucose transporter, is mainly found in adipose tissues and striated muscles. Exercise and insulin increase their expression, increasing intracellular glucose and ATP generation from glucose metabolism. It has a moderate affinity for glucose.  
❌ Glucose transporter 5 (GLUT5)  :
Incorrect: GLUT5 is found in spermatocytes and gastrointestinal (GI) tract tissues. Though it is not dependent on insulin for its expression and upregulation, it is mainly a fructose transporter.
❌ Sodium-glucose co-transporter (SGLT1)  :
Incorrect: SGLT1 is an ATP and sodium-dependent transporter found on the luminal surface of enterocytes of the intestinal epithelium. It helps in glucose absorption and does not have the highest affinity for glucose.

questions.text: A B-cell is activated after an antigen causes its surface receptors to crosslink. This B-cell subsequently uses its MHC molecule to present a fragment of the antigen to a nearby helper T-cell. The MHC-antigen complex and CD40 protein on the B-cell’s surface successfully interact with the T-cell receptor and CD40L. Which of the following changes will most likely occur to this B-cell?
questions.solution:
The B-cell in this vignette has been activated by an antigen and later stimulated by a T-cell. As a result, the B-cell will likely undergo class switching and produce non-IgM antibodies.  

B-cells are produced and mature in the bone marrow, where they undergo VDJ recombination to produce different types of B-cell receptors (BCRs). Afterward, B-cells leave and travel to secondary lymphoid organs (e.g., spleen, lymph nodes).  

B-cells are exposed to antigens in these lymphoid organs and can be activated in one of two ways. First, the B-cell can be activated if an antigen binds and causes crosslinking BCRs. Alternatively, if the complement C3d has attached to the antigen, it can activate a B-cell by binding to the BCR and CD21 protein (which binds with C3d).  

An activated B-cell then differentiates into a plasma cell that secretes only IgM. If an activated CD4+ T-cell is present, it can help the B-cell undergo class switching. Since B-cells are a type of antigen-presenting cell, they will present the antigen on an MHC class II molecule to the nearby CD4+ T-cell. Once the T-cell is activated, it will express CD40L, which binds to CD40 on the B-cell. These changes prompt the B-cell to express cytokine receptors and T-cell to secrete cytokines (e.g., IL-4, IL-5), thereby enabling class switching and production of non-IgM antibodies (e.g., IgG, IgE, IgA).



Option Analysis

❌ Increased production of pentameric antibodies  :
Incorrect: IgM antibodies have a pentameric structure. B-cells initially produce IgM after being activated by an antigen. However, B-cells will undergo class switching after being stimulated by a T-cell and stop producing IgM.
✅ Initiation of IgG production:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Release of perforins  :
Incorrect: Perforins are proteins released by cytotoxic T-cells and natural killer cells. The perforins bind to the target cell and cause the formation of pores in the cellular membrane. Granzymes can pass through these pores and induce apoptosis of the target cell. In contrast, perforins are not released by B-cells.  
❌ Increased release of IL-10  :
Incorrect: Interleukin 10 (IL-10) is released by T-cells and causes downregulation of the immune response. In contrast, IL-10 is not typically produced by B-cells.  
❌ Upregulation of interferon-gamma production   :
Incorrect: Interferon-gamma (IFNγ) can be produced by T-cells and natural killer cells. Its effects are multifold and include stimulating macrophages to kill phagocytosed organisms, promoting granuloma formation, and increasing cellular expression of MHC molecules. In contrast, IFNγ is not routinely released by B-cells after being activated by T-cells.

questions.text: A group of investigators is studying the effects of a novel drug, Drug X, on bile acid synthesis in patients with cholelithiasis. Drug X specifically targets the rate-limiting enzyme involved in bile acid synthesis. Which of the following enzymes does this drug most likely target?
questions.solution:
Bile is a greenish liquid made by the liver and stored in the gallbladder. Major solute components of bile include bile salts (bile acids conjugated to glycine or taurine, making them water-soluble) and phospholipids, with cholesterol and bile pigments (e.g. bilirubin) making up only a tiny percentage.  

Bile is first manufactured in the liver by cells called hepatocytes. Hepatocytes use an enzyme called 7-alpha-hydroxylase to convert cholesterol into two primary bile acids, cholic acid, and chenodeoxycholic acid. Some of these primary bile acids get dehydroxylated in the intestines, giving rise to secondary bile acids–specifically, deoxycholic acid and lithocholic acid. The liver can conjugate or attach the amino acids glycine or taurine to all four of these bile acids, which ultimately gives rise to 8 different forms of bile salts. These bile salts are the main component of bile. Therefore, bile is made in the liver and flows into the intestines.
