 Bile helps with digestion and absorption of lipids and fat-soluble vitamins (e.g., vitamins A, D, E, and K) as well as bilirubin and cholesterol excretion and has antimicrobial activity (via membrane disruption). It is important to note that bile production is the primary mechanism by which the body can excrete cholesterol and bilirubin.  

Option Analysis

❌ Acetyl-CoA carboxylase:
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. Acetyl-CoA carboxylase is the rate-limiting enzyme in fatty acid synthesis.
❌ Carnitine acyltransferase I:
Incorrect:  This answer choice is incorrect. Carnitine acyltransferase I is the rate-limiting enzyme in fatty acid oxidation.
❌ HMG-CoA synthase:
Incorrect:  This answer choice is incorrect. HMG-CoA synthase is the rate-limiting enzyme in ketogenesis.  
❌ HMG-CoA reductase:
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. HMG-CoA reductase is the rate-limiting enzyme in cholesterol synthesis.
✅ Cholesterol 7α-hydroxylase:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: An investigator studies the fate of conjugated bilirubin once it is released into the intestine. Which of the following is most appropriate regarding the excretion of conjugated bilirubin?

choices.text: Conjugated bilirubin is metabolized further during its passage along the biliary tree
Most of the bilirubin is unconjugated by the enteric bacteria in the small intestine
90% of the conjugated bilirubin circulates enterohepatically via the intestinal lumen
The majority of urobilinogen is lost in the urine
Bilirubin is extensively metabolized in the colon, producing urobilinogen and stercobilinogen

questions.solution:
The bile containing the conjugated bilirubin flows into the intestines. In the intestines, certain bacteria hydrolyze and reduce conjugated bilirubin into a colorless compound called urobilinogen, which can enter various pathways. When it's in the intestines, most of the urobilinogen, also called stercobilinogen, becomes oxidized by gut bacteria to form stercobilin. Stercobilin is what makes feces brown in color.   

There’s a system by which bilirubin and bile acids are recycled, called the enterohepatic circulation. A small amount of urobilinogen not excreted in the feces gets reabsorbed from the gut into the bloodstream. Some of that urobilinogen (~10%) travels through the blood to the kidneys, where it is converted to urobilin, which is very water-soluble and therefore excreted into the urine, giving urine its yellow color. The remainder goes back to the liver to be sent out into the intestines.  



Option Analysis

❌ Conjugated bilirubin is metabolized further during its passage along the biliary tree:
Incorrect: Conjugated bilirubin is neither further metabolized nor absorbed during its passage along the biliary tree.  
❌ Most of the bilirubin is unconjugated by the enteric bacteria in the small intestine :
Incorrect: In the small intestine, there appears to be little deconjugation or additional bilirubin metabolism in the healthy gut.  
❌ 90% of the conjugated bilirubin circulates enterohepatically via the intestinal lumen:
Incorrect: Bilirubin does not circulate enterohepatically to any significant degree, likely because it cannot be taken up from the intestinal lumen in its conjugated form, and once unconjugated in the colon it is rapidly metabolized to other products.  
❌ The majority of urobilinogen is lost in the urine:
Incorrect: Only about 10% of urobilinogen travels through the blood to the kidneys, where it is converted to urobilin, which is very water-soluble and therefore excreted into the urine, giving urine its yellow color.  
✅ Bilirubin is extensively metabolized in the colon, producing urobilinogen and stercobilinogen:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A group of researchers is examining the relative concentrations of several substances along the proximal convoluted tubule. They discover one substance that is ideal for estimating the glomerular filtration rate. This substance is denoted by which of the following lines detailed in the graph below?
questions.solution:
The substance in question is most likely inulin, which can be used to approximate the glomerular filtration rate (GFR). Inulin is a naturally occurring polysaccharide molecule that is biologically inert, unbound by plasma proteins, freely filtered at the glomerulus, and is neither reabsorbed, nor secreted by the kidneys. It increases in concentration along the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT) due to water reabsorption.  

In contrast, Para-aminohippuric acid (PAH) (Line A) can be used to approximate renal plasma flow (RPF). It is both filtered and secreted in the PCT and is not reabsorbed. As a result, it is wholly removed from the blood that passes through the kidneys. It undergoes glomerular filtration and tubular secretion due to unique transport molecules on the basolateral membrane of the PCT.  

Option Analysis

❌ A:
Incorrect: Line A reflects para-aminohippuric acid (PAH), which can be used to approximate renal plasma flow (RPF), not the glomerular filtration rate.  
✅ B:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ C:
Incorrect: This line depicts glucose concentration along the PCT. It falls as glucose is reabsorbed more quickly than water, making its tubular fluid/plasma (TF/Px) concentration <1.  
❌ D  :
Incorrect: This line depicts sodium concentration along the PCT, which reflects a TF/Px concentration of approximately 1, showing that sodium and water are reabsorbed at almost the same rate.  
❌ E:
Incorrect: This line depicts chloride. Reabsorption of this molecule occurs slower than water in early proximal convoluted tubules and then matches the rate of water reabsorption more distally.

questions.text: Autoregulation of cerebral blood flow refers to the ability of the brain to maintain a relatively constant blood flow despite changes in perfusion pressure. Which of the following is the primary regulator of cerebral perfusion?
questions.solution:
Autoregulation of cerebral blood flow (CBF) refers to the ability of the brain to maintain constant blood flow despite changes in perfusion pressure. The most important extrinsic influences on CBF are respiratory gas tensions—particularly PaCO2 levels. CBF is directly proportional to PaCO2 between 20 and 80 mm Hg. Blood flow changes approximately 1 to 2 mL/100 g/min per millimeter of mercury change in PaCO2.

Whereas hyperoxia may be associated with only minimal decreases (–10%) in CBF, severe hypoxemia (PaO2 <50 mm Hg) significantly increases CBF. This effect is almost immediate and is thought to be secondary to changes in the pH of CSF and cerebral tissue. Because ions do not readily cross the blood-brain barrier, but CO2 does, acute changes in PaCO2 but not HCO3– affect CBF. Only marked changes in PaO2 alter CBF.

Cerebral perfusion autoregulation also relies on a gradient between mean arterial pressure (MAP) and intracranial pressure (ICP). Decreasing blood pressure or ICP reduces cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP).
 

Option Analysis

❌ PaO2:
Incorrect:  Cerebral perfusion autoregulation is driven by PCO2. PO2 modulates perfusion in  severe hypoxia and hypoxemia increase cerebral perfusion pressure only if PO2< 50 mm Hg.  
✅ PaCO2:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Blood-brain barrier:
Incorrect: The blood-brain barrier (BBB) prevents circulating substances (e.g., bacteria, drugs, medications) from reaching the central nervous system. It does not play any role in the autoregulation of cerebral perfusion as oxygen and carbon dioxide freely enter the brain.  
❌ Chemoreceptor trigger zone:
Incorrect: The chemoreceptor trigger zone (CTZ), located within area postrema, is the site of action of multiple antiemetic drugs. It does not play any role in the autoregulation of cerebral perfusion.  
❌ Intracranial pressure:
Incorrect: Cerebral perfusion autoregulation relies on a pressure gradient between mean arterial pressure (MAP) and intracranial pressure (ICP), but not the intracranial pressure alone.

questions.text: The blood-brain barrier (BBB) strives to maintain the constancy of the environment of the neurons in the CNS. Which of the following is the most appropriate statement about the BBB?

choices.text: Lipid-soluble substances cannot cross the BBB freely
Circumventricular organs have an intact BBB
It is formed by fenestrated capillary endothelial cells
Glucose crosses the BBB by carrier-mediated transport mechanisms
The area postrema has an intact BBB

questions.solution:
The blood-brain barrier (BBB) strives to maintain the constancy of the environment of the central nervous system. Functions of the blood-brain barrier include protection of the brain from toxins, autoimmune regulation, and prevention of neurotransmitter escape into general circulation.

Four structures form the BBB:
 
  •  Tight junctions between non-fenestrated capillary endothelial cells 
  •  Basement membrane 
  •  Astrocyte foot processes 
  •  Pericytes 
The BBB allows for the passage of lipid-soluble substances but restricts the movement of those that are ionized or have large molecular weights. Thus, the movement of a given substance across the blood-brain barrier is governed simultaneously by its size, charge, lipid solubility, and degree of protein binding in the blood. Therefore, carbon dioxide, oxygen, and lipid-soluble molecules (such as most anesthetics) freely enter the brain, whereas most ions, proteins, and large substances (such as mannitol) penetrate poorly.
   

Option Analysis

❌ Lipid-soluble substances cannot cross the BBB freely:
Incorrect: Nonpolar/lipid-soluble substances cross the BBB rapidly via diffusion.  
❌ Circumventricular organs have an intact BBB:
Incorrect: Circumventricular organs have fenestrated capillaries and are said to be “outside the blood-brain barrier.”  
❌ It is formed by fenestrated capillary endothelial cells:
Incorrect: The BBB is formed by tight junctions between non-fenestrated capillary endothelial cells.  
✅ Glucose crosses the BBB by carrier-mediated transport mechanisms:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ The area postrema has an intact BBB:
Incorrect: The area postrema is a circumventricular organ with fenestrated capillaries and no blood-brain barrier.

questions.text: Sleep cycle is regulated by circadian rhythm via a complex interplay of hormones and deep brain structures. Which of the following structures in the brain drives circadian rhythm?
questions.solution:
Sleep is a naturally recurring state characterized by altered consciousness, inhibited sensory activity, inhibition of voluntary muscles, and reduced environmental interaction. Specifically, sleep is distinguished from wakefulness by a decreased ability to react to stimuli but is more easily reversed than the state of hibernation or being comatose.

The circadian rhythm regulates the sleep cycle, which is driven by the hypothalamus's suprachiasmatic nucleus (SCN). The circadian rhythm controls the nocturnal release of ACTH, prolactin, melatonin, and norepinephrine, which in concert determine the duration and quality of sleep.  Ultimately, circadian rhythm is entrained to light/dark cycles as stimulated by neurons in the retina. Light signals are relayed via the retinohypothalamic (RHT) fibers to the SCN, which then stimulates the release of norepinephrine and stimulates the pineal gland to secrete melatonin and induce sleep.

Option Analysis

❌ Preoptic nucleus:
Incorrect: The preoptic nucleus of the hypothalamus is involved in thermoregulation and sexual behaviors. It releases GnRH and has no significant effect on circadian rhythm.  
❌ Ventral posterolateral nucleus:
Incorrect: The ventral posterolateral nucleus of the thalamus relays senses of vibration, pain, pressure, proprioception (conscious), light touch, and temperature to the primary somatosensory cortex.  
❌ Lateral nucleus:
Incorrect: The lateral nucleus of the hypothalamus is referred to as “the hunger center”. It is stimulated by ghrelin and inhibited by leptin.  
✅ Suprachiasmatic nucleus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Supraoptic nucleus:
Incorrect: The supraoptic nucleus of the hypothalamus synthesizes antidiuretic hormone, which does not affect circadian rhythm.

questions.text: A researcher is studying skeletal muscle physiology. She identifies a protein that hydrolyzes adenosine triphosphate and uses the released energy to return the protein’s head to a cocked position. Which of the following structures does this protein most likely interact with during muscle contraction?
questions.solution:
The protein this researcher identified is myosin. During muscle contraction, myosin binds with actin to cause muscle shortening.  

Muscle contraction begins when an action potential reaches the neuromuscular endplate and triggers muscle cell depolarization. The depolarization wave propagates along transverse tubules to reach dihydropyridine receptors, which, when activated, cause ryanodine receptors to open and release calcium into the cytoplasm. Calcium binds to troponin and leads to a conformational change, moving tropomyosin away from the myosin-binding sites on actin.  

Before myosin can bind to actin, it first needs to power up. Part of the myosin head is an ATPase, an enzyme that cleaves ATP into ADP and a phosphate ion to release energy. The energy cocks the myosin head back into its high-energy position. The myosin head then binds to the actin filament at designated sites, resulting in cross-bridge formation. The myosin head pulls on the actin filament in a movement called the power stroke, which leads to muscle shortening.    

Once the power stroke completes, the ADP and phosphate ion detach from the myosin head. A new ATP molecule binds, causing the myosin head to detach from actin. The new ATP is cleaved, and the energy is used to re-cock the myosin head into a high-energy position for the next power stroke.  



Option Analysis

❌ Tropomyosin:
Incorrect: Myosin contains an ATPase that breaks down adenosine triphosphate (ATP) to release energy. The energy causes the myosin head to return to a high-energy cocked position. During muscle contraction, myosin binds to and pulls on actin filaments leading to muscle shortening.   
❌ Sarcoplasmic reticulum:
Incorrect: The protein this researcher identified is most likely myosin. While the release of calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum is necessary for muscle contraction, myosin does not interact directly with this structure.  
✅ Actin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Transverse tubules:
Incorrect: The transverse tubules are infoldings of the cellular membrane that penetrate the center of skeletal and cardiac muscle. They are responsible for synchronizing action potential conduction and muscle contraction. Transverse tubules do not interact directly with myosin, the protein identified by this researcher.  
❌ Dihydropyridine receptor:
Incorrect: Dihydropyridine receptor activation causes ryanodine receptors, a type of calcium channel found on the sarcoplasmic receptor, to open. In turn, calcium is released into the cytoplasm and promotes muscle contraction. However, dihydropyridine receptors do not interact directly with myosin, the protein identified by this researcher.

questions.text: A biologist is studying smooth muscle physiology and identifies a protein that phosphorylates the light chain of myosin and increases myosin ATPase activity. Which of the following is most directly involved in regulating the activity of this protein?
questions.solution:
The protein this biologist identified is most likely myosin light-chain kinase, and its activity is regulated by calmodulin.    

Smooth muscle contraction occurs when a stimulus causes L-type voltage-gated calcium channels to open. The influx of extracellular calcium triggers the release of more calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum in a phenomenon termed calcium-induced calcium release. The calcium binds to the protein calmodulin, which activates myosin light-chain kinase (MLCK). MLCK phosphorylates the myosin light chain and increases myosin ATPase activity, leading to cross-bridge formation and muscle contraction.  

On the other hand, smooth muscle relaxation occurs when a combination of external signals (e.g. binding of acetylcholine or bradykinin receptors) and increased intracellular calcium induces nitric oxide synthase activity in endothelial cells surrounding the smooth muscle. This enzyme produces nitric oxide, which diffuses into the nearby muscle cells to increase cGMP production and activate myosin light-chain phosphatase (MLCP). MLCP then dephosphorylates myosin, thereby preventing myosin from binding with actin and terminating smooth muscle contraction.  

Option Analysis

✅ Calmodulin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Transverse tubules:
Incorrect: The transverse tubules are infoldings of the cellular membrane that penetrate the center of skeletal and cardiac muscles. They are responsible for helping synchronize action potential conduction and muscle contraction. In contrast, this researcher is studying a smooth muscle sample.   
❌ Myosin-light chain phosphatase:
Incorrect: Myosin-light chain phosphatase is an enzyme found within smooth muscle cells. It is responsible for the dephosphorylation of myosin light chains and subsequent smooth muscle relaxation. However, myosin-light chain phosphatase is not responsible for regulating the activity of myosin light-chain kinase, which is the protein identified by this researcher.  
❌ Tropomyosin:
Incorrect: Tropomyosin covers the myosin-binding sites on actin filaments in skeletal and cardiac muscle. In contrast, tropomyosin is not typically involved in smooth muscle contraction or relaxation. Tropomyosin needs to be removed before actin and myosin can bind and cause muscle contraction.  
❌ Actin:
Incorrect: This biologist most likely identified the protein myosin light-chain kinase. Actin is not directly involved in regulating the activity of this protein.

questions.text: Progesterone is a steroid hormone and its production starts with cholesterol. It is responsible for the luteal changes in the endometrium and the cyclical changes in the cervix and vagina. Which of the following is the most appropriate statement regarding the functions of progesterone?

choices.text: Decreases the action of prolactin on breast tissue
Stimulates endometrial glandular secretions during menses
Development of internal and external genitalia
Increases maternal IGF-1 concentrations during pregnancy

questions.solution:
Progesterone is a steroid hormone and its production starts with cholesterol. It is secreted by the corpus luteum, placenta, and follicles (in small amounts).  

Progesterone released by corpus luteum acts as a negative feedback signal on the pituitary, decreasing the release of FSH and LH. It also secretes inhibin, which prevents FSH and LH release.These effects result in a decline in estrogen levels and a rise in progesterone levels. If the oocyte is fertilized, the corpus luteum keeps secreting progesterone. If the oocyte is not fertilized, the corpus luteum gradually degenerates into the nonfunctional corpus albicans that do not synthesize progesterone.  

The principal target organs of progesterone are the uterus, breasts, and brain. During the luteal phase, progesterone stimulates endometrial glandular secretions and spiral artery development to prepare the uterus for implantation of a fertilized egg. It also induces the production of thick cervical mucus that inhibits sperm entry into the uterus. Progesterone decreases the number of estrogen receptors in the endometrium and increases the rate of conversion of 17β-estradiol to less active estrogens. Moreover, progesterone is thermogenic and probably is responsible for the rise in basal body temperature at the time of ovulation.    

During pregnancy, progesterone decreases myometrial excitability due to its antiestrogenic effect, hence maintaining the pregnancy. In the breast, progesterone stimulates the development of lobules and alveoli. It induces the differentiation of estrogen-prepared ductal tissue. However, it inhibits the action of prolactin on the breast until after delivery, when the levels of progesterone and estrogen fall and lactation begins.   

Option Analysis

❌ Increases myometrial excitability in pregnancy:
Incorrect: Progesterone decreases myometrial excitability during pregnancy by reducing contraction frequency and intensity.  
✅ Decreases the action of prolactin on breast tissue:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Stimulates endometrial glandular secretions during menses:
Incorrect: Progesterone stimulates endometrial glandular secretions and spiral artery development during the luteal phase to prepare the uterus for implantation of the fertilized egg.  
❌ Development of internal and external genitalia:
Incorrect: Estrogen is involved in the development of internal and external genitalia, breasts, and female fat distribution.
❌ Increases maternal IGF-1 concentrations during pregnancy:
Incorrect: The placenta makes human placental lactogen (hPL) which is thought to be responsible for the marked rise in maternal plasma insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1) concentrations as the pregnancy approaches term.
